DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FUTURE BELONGS TO ITS PEOPLE: FILMMAKER(REPEAT)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's future belongs to its people, and the people of Taiwan have the right to find "their real selves, " Taiwanese-American filmmaker Will Tiao said in an interview with CNA Thursday.

"Taiwanese have the right to find themselves... because they have never had the chance to develop and articulate their own selves, " Tiao said on the last day of a two-week promotion tour of a film titled Formosa Betrayed.

The movie, which Tiao plans to shoot next year and release in 2008, is about the story of the 1982 murder of a Taiwanese professor who was killed for speaking out for an independent and democratic Taiwan.
Many people in Taiwan have shown enormous support for a movie they think is long overdue, said Tiao, who was born in Kansas and comes from a family with strong pro-Taiwanese independence views.

While stressing his position as a foreigner and trying to stay away from political analysis during his visit, Tiao said he still believes Taiwan's future should belong to its people and that Taiwan is "a democracy that is coming into its own."

"Taiwan is slowly starting to realize that it does have to deal with the past if it wants to move toward becoming a normal country, " he said, adding that people of this generation are probably not as aware of history as they should be.

For a long time, Taiwanese have been told by others about who they are -- first the Japanese and then the Chinese. But Taiwanese have the right to define themselves and explore what Taiwan identity is, Tiao said.

People of Taiwan have to know and reconcile the past before moving forward. Only by doing so can they learn to deconstruct those arguments of "conventional wisdom" and look at the world in a new perspective, according to Tiao, who spent 10 years in Washington working for the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, a pro-independence lobby group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BEATS SOUTH KOREA IN ASIAN GAMES BASEBALL(REPEAT)
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Li Chien-chung and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: Hsieh Chia-hsian and Chen Yung-chi hit a total of three solo home runs as Taiwan defeated defending champion South Korea 4-2 to snatch its first victory at the 15th Asian Games baseball round in Doha, Qatar Thursday.
The two teams tied 0-0 in the first three innings. Chen broke the deadlock in the top of the fourth by hitting a solo homer.
Soon after, Chen Chin-feng followed with a double deep into left field and he came home for Taiwan's second run off a hit by Lin Chih-sheng.
Hsieh added a solo shot in the fifth while Chen blasted another one in the eighth to end the game.
Taiwan coach Yeh Chih-shien said every player played well, which contributed to the team's win.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD FEDERATION OF TAIWANESE ASSOCIATIONS TO MEET IN TAIPEI(REPEAT)

TEXT.P: The World Federation of Taiwanese Associations (WFTA) is scheduled to hold its 2006 annual congress in Taipei Saturday, with normalization of Taiwan's statehood as its main theme, organizers said Thursday.

The conference will bring together hundreds of representatives of major Taiwanese associations from around the world as well as domestic political leaders and academics for brainstorming sessions on promoting Taiwan's progress in democratic reform, rule of law and national stability.

Vice President Annette Lu will deliver a keynote speech at the opening session at Grand Hotel. Other speakers will include Presidential Office Secretary-General Tan Sun Chen, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Chang Siao-yueh, Representative to Japan Ko Se-kai and ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun. President Chen Shui-bian will attend a dinner party.
Many scholars and political analysts will also attend the meeting which will close at Sunday noon. The WFTA was founded in 2000 to promote Taiwanese identity and eventual formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 1, or the eleventh day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1640: Portugal becomes independent again after the Portuguese under the leadership of John IV drive out the Spaniards.
1887: Portugal secures the secession of Macau from China's Ching court.
1918: The Danish parliament passes an act giving independence to Iceland.
1921: With the United States and Britain as mediators, representatives of China and Japan hold negotiations on the issue of the Shantung dispute on the sidelines of a meeting in Washington.
1922: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Manchu dynasty, and Wan Yung, daughter of Yung Yuan, a former minister in the Ching court, hold their wedding ceremony in Beijing's Forbidden City.
1927: The Republic of China's Chiang Kai-shek and Soong Mayling hold a wedding ceremony witnessed by Tsai Yuan-pei in Shanghai.
1932: The government of the Republic of China, which was moved to Loyang on Jan. 30 due to the Japanese invasion, moves back to Nanjing.
1935: Chiang Kai-shek is elected chairman of the Kuomintang, the ruling party of China.
1936: Chinese Communist Party leaders, including Mao Tse-tung, Chu Teh, and Chou En-lai, send a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek asking him to allow the CCP to join the war against Japan to save the country.
1951: Communist Chinese troops enter Lhasa, Tibet.
1956: Chiang Kai-shek finishes his book titled "Soviet Russia in China."
1959: Twelve members of the United Nations, including the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, Japan, and France, sign a treaty in Washington stipulating that the South Pole region will be used for peaceful purposes such as scientific exploration and that no military bases will be allowed.
1961: The first nuclear reactor in the Republic of China, installed by scientists from the National Tsinghua University campus in Hsinchu, is put into operation.
1962: India rejects mainland Chinese proposals for a cease-fire and negotiations over disputed territory.
1969: The ROC government sets up the Armed Forces University, with Yu Po-chuen serving as commandant and Chiang Wei-kuo as vice commandant.
1971: A total of 43 miners of the Keelung Coalmine Company are killed in an accident at the Chisingkeng mine in northern Taiwan.
1972: The ROC and Ivory Coast sign a trade agreement.
1973: A total of 14 seamen go missing when the Tatung, a freighter plying the route between the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung and Makung, in the Penghu archipelago, sinks.
1973: The Kuomintang selects 45 candidates for the Taipei City Council election. Sixty-three candidates fight for 49 seats.
1976: A metalworking trade mission representing leading U.S. companies arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: Jurisdiction of the Central Bank of China is moved from the Presidential Office to the Executive Yuan.
1987: Eight people are killed in a fire blamed on arson at a job-training center on the ROC-controlled Green Island.
1987: The Ministry of Education announces that National Chungcheng University will be established in Minhsiung Village, Chiayi County and will begin admitting students in the 1989 academic year.
1988: Benazir Bhutto is nominated to be prime minister of Pakistan, becoming the first woman elected to govern a Muslim nation.
1988: The Executive Yuan announces guidelines governing unofficial participation in international academic conferences and cultural and athletic activities held in mainland China, as well as regulations governing visits to Taiwan by overseas mainland Chinese scholars and students.
1989: Mikhail Gorbachev becomes the first Soviet leader to visit the Vatican and meet the Pope, ending 70 years of mutual hostility between the USSR and the Vatican.
1999: The first batch of the two-in-one lottery tickets issued by the Central Bank of China go on sale, causing a buying spree around the island.
2001: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) loses its position as the largest party in the legislature at the legislative election, winning only 68 seats as compared with the 87 seats won by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Motse's lesson of the day: "There are many rulers in the world but few are magnanimous. For everybody to imitate the ruler is to imitate the unmagnanimous. Imitating the unmagnanimous cannot be taken as following the right standard."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AIMING FOR 15 GOLDS AT ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Lee Chien-chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan aims to win 15 gold medals at the 15th Asian Games which opened in Doha, Qatar Friday, according to a sports official accompanied Taiwan's national team to the games.
A total of 391 athletes are representing Chinese Taipei in 34 different sports at the games, which will run through Dec. 15.
More than 13,000 athletes from 45 countries are expected to compete in the 39 sports and 423 events at the Asian Games -- all figures which represent record highs for the games.
Among the 39 sports, chess and the triathlon have been included for the first time at the games.

This is also the first time that the Asian Games are being held in West Asia. The host Qatar government has reportedly spent some US$1 billion for the high-profile sports event -- building gyms, sports arenas and facilities in the country, half of whose territory is located in the desert.
By sponsoring the 15th Asian Games, the Qatar government has vowed to transform Qatar into the "mecca of sports" in the Middle East to boost athletic and sports development in that part of the world.

Chinese Taipei is confident that it can win gold medals in about 10 sports, namely taekwondo, archery, shooting, karate, tennis, soft tennis, table tennis, rhythmic gymnastics, bowling and golf. It is also hoping to pick up gold in the equestrian event.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE GOALS SET FOR DEVELOPING PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRY: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: The government has envisioned three major goals for the development of the country's pharmaceutical industry over the next 10 years, including turning the island into a biomedicine research, development and manufacturing stronghold, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday.

The other two goals are making Taiwan into a medical and pharmaceutical research and development center on major diseases in Asia, as well as a gene pharmacology research and development center in Asia, the vice premier said.
She made the remarks while attending the annual conference of the International Research-based Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association in Taipei.

To achieve the goals, the government should step up multinational cooperation in the bio-tech industry, assist local manufacturers, learn from the systems used in the industrialized nations to carry out a comprehensive review on statutes regarding the promotion of the industry as well as company law and regulations governing the listing of companies so as to attract investment by local and foreign manufacturing companies by creating a sound investment environment.

Tsai said the government has listed the bio-tech sector as one of the priority industries and has included it in the list of emerging strategic industries that are provided with government incentives.

She said that the government has invested around NT$55 billion (US$1.66 billion) in the bio-tech industry over the past four years, adding that the bio-tech industry currently generates NT$160 billion in revenue. She estimated total revenues will hit NT$320 billion in 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROWTH IN NUMBER OF HIV-POSITIVE INMATES SLOWING DOWN: MOJ

TEXT.P: The rise in the number of HIV-positive inmates or detainees has slowed down since the first quarter of this year thanks to the Center for Disease Control's (CDC's) active AIDS prevention and awareness campaign, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Friday.

Quoting MOJ tallies, Cheng An-hsiung, director of the ministry's Department of Corrections, said the number of HIV-positive inmates and detainees stood at 1,700 at the end of last year, marking a four-fold increase from 419 recorded in 2004.

As of the end of September this year, the number of HIV-positive inmates/detainees rose to 2,600, with those serving prison terms accounting for 92 percent of the total. The monthly figures so far this year show that the growth in the number of HIV-positive inmates has been slackening, Cheng said.

To mark the anniversary of a "Clean Syringe Exchange Program" to prevent the spread of HIV infection among drug addicts, the CDC issued a press release at the end of October, saying that the percentage of new HIV infections had declined from 14.4 out of every 100,000 people a year ago to 13 for the first nine months of this year.

According to the CDC statistics, a total of 2,316 new HIV-carriers were recorded in the January-September period, down from 3,400 recorded for the same period last year. The CDC forecast this year's total number of new HIV carriers at 3,100.
"All these figures point to encouraging signs of a slowdown in expansion of HIV infection," Cheng said.

In addition to the "Clean Syringe Exchange Program" launched by the CDC to provide clean syringes for drug addicts, Chen said, the slowdown in HIV infection can also be attributed to the CDC's intensified HIV/AIDS awareness campaign over the past year.

According to Cheng, 95 percent of the HIV-positive inmates are serving time for drug-related crimes, with the ratio reaching 99 percent among HIV-positive female inmates. More worrisome is the fact that female HIV-positive inmates are getting younger, he added.

Against this backdrop, Cheng said, the MOJ has directed correctional institutions to step up education of imprisoned drug addicts in cooperation with local health units to help them understand the risks and hazards of sharing syringes with other drug abusers.

An MOJ study showed that HIV-positive inmates are most worried about their job prospects in their post-incarceration life. Cheng said the MOJ has begun to cooperate with private social groups and corporations to offer job opportunities, psychological counseling and medical assistance to released HIV-positive convicts.

DOC.HEADLINE: WVT APPEALS FOR HELP FOR AIDS ORPHANS

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan (WVT), a Christian charity dedicated to helping disadvantaged people and carrying out emergency humanitarian relief missions, called on the public Friday to extend a helping hand to millions of children around the world who have lost one or both parents to AIDS.

The WVT, which has taken part in various global AIDS prevention and aid programs for more than 13 years, made the appeal in conjunction with the commemoration of Dec. 1 World AIDS Day -- a day of action on HIV and AIDS.

Noting that World AIDS Day is a time to remember those who have lost their lives to the disease, admire the bravery of those living with HIV, and raise awareness and money to help the victims, the WVT urged local people to donate funds for AIDS orphans in Taiwan and in other countries around the world.
Prospective donors are welcome to sign up via the Internet at http: //www.worldvision.org.tw/edm/20061127aidschild/ or deposit funds in the WVT's postal account at 15752467.

Quoting U.N. tallies, the WVT said the world now has 15 million AIDS orphans. As most HIV carriers are middle-aged people, the number of AIDS orphans is expected to increase further in the next few years.
Since the first AIDS case was detected in 1981, the WVT said HIV infection has spread so rapidly and extensively that it has become not just a health problem but also a grave social issue.

Of the 8.3 million HIV carriers in Asia, two-thirds are in India, the WVT said, adding that the number of HIV-positive people in China has also been rising quickly to stand at about 650,000 at present. Given the geographic proximity to China, it said, Taiwan cannot afford to remain lax in precaution and prevention efforts.

In order to create a more friendly environment for HIV carriers and full-blown AIDS patients, the WVT said more efforts should be devoted to reducing discrimination and stigmatization of all HIV victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MRT'S TOTAL PASSENGER TRAFFIC TO TOP 2.5 BILLION

TEXT.P: The total passenger traffic of Taipei's mass rapid transit (MRT) system is expected to top 2.5 billion early this month, the Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. (TRTC) announced Friday.
The figure will represent a 25-fold increase since the system's passenger traffic reached 100 million on Dec. 22, 1998, TRCT officials said.
With a population of 23 million in Taiwan, the figure is equivalent to 109 rides per person, they said.

Meanwhile, for the second consecutive year, Taipei's MRT system was rated by University of London's Railway Technology Strategy Center as the most reliable system among the world's 25 major metro systems in 2005, they noted.
According to Deputy Taipei Mayor Chen Yu-chang, while the section of the MRT system that is currently in operation totals 76 km, another 76 km are under construction and 250 km are under planning.
After all these projects are completed, the density of the MRT network will be similar to that of other major metro systems in the world, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO NOBEL LAUREATES TO SUPPORT RESEARCH AT NCKU INNOVATION CENTER

TEXT.P: Two Nobel laureates will render their support to research work to be conducted at the soon-to-be-inaugurated Institute of Innovations and Advanced Studies (IIAS) located at National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) in Tainan City, southern Taiwan, school officials said Friday.

Alan G. MacDiarmid, a New Zealand-born American chemist who, with two other chemists, won the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2000, and Aaron Ciechanover from the Israel Institute of Technology, who shared the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2004 with two other scientists, have been confirmed to be joining research to be carried out by the IIAS teams to help pursue innovation and excellence in research, the NCKU officials said.

In addition to the two Nobel laureates, seven other world-class scientists, including Paul C.W. Chu, a U.S. Presidential Science laureate and president of Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, and Harold Weinstock, a fellow of the U.S. Air Force Office of Scientific Research, are also expected to render their support to the IIAS scientific and technological research.

The mission of the IIAS is for the institute to become a platform to initiate, facilitate, and accelerate collaborative research at the highest possible levels for Taiwan scientists with their global counterparts, according to Tzeng Yon-hua, a member of the IEEE Nanotechnology Council and one of the chief organizers of the IIAS.

The IIAS is being established to pursue vigorously the integration and sharing of expertise and facilities with other global centers of excellence; jointly organize workshops to brainstorm on and about frontier and critical research areas; and encourage and facilitate co-directing of graduate students and postdoctoral research fellows, Tzeng added.
Members of the IIAS will thus include distinguished scholars not only from NCKU but also from other institutions in Taiwan and around the world.

It is anticipated that the creation of such a collaborative platform for scholars in Taiwan and abroad will allow Taiwan scientists to be more visible globally and involved in research with greater global impact, he noted.

On the sidelines of the IIAS's inauguration ceremony, the NCKU is also sponsoring an international academic workshop slated for Dec. 12-15. Programs of the workshop will feature discussions on alternative/renewable energy, frontier biomedicine, enabling materials, and micro-nano science and technology.

MacDiarmid received the Nobel Prize in chemistry in 2000 for his co-discovery of conductive polymers. Prior to his discovery, polymers, or more commonly known as plastics, were accepted to be electrical insulators with limited high-tech applications.

His contributions made possible the use of electrically conductive plastics in many aspects of daily life, ranging from anti-static sheets for electronic devices and flexible flat panel displays to plastic solar cells.

Facing an enormous and critical global energy crisis, MacDiarmid has in recent years been globe trotting, urging scientific communities from all corners of the globe to develop effective means of producing biofuels.
At the workshop, MacDiarmid will deliver two lectures, one on the amazing electrically conductive plastics and the other on agricultural energy.

Aaron Ciechanover was awarded the 2004 Nobel Prize in chemistry for his co-discovery of one of the most important cyclical processes in biochemistry, namely the regulated degradation of proteins that build up in all plants, animals and human beings.

Ciechanover and the other co-winners of the 2004 Nobel Prize worked "stubbornly" and carefully for decades on the non-mainstream subject of cell degradation and discovered that a molecule called ubiquitin labeled proteins that were destined to be destroyed leaving only unlabeled and desirable proteins to be continuously built up.

Known for his electrifying lectures, Ciechanover is expected to give a lecture at the workshop on "Proteins Dynamics: The Three Decades Journey From a Basic Biological Idea Into Human Diseases and Drug Development."

The seven other distinguished scholars -- also including nanomaterials and nanodevices experts Donhee Ham of Harvard University, Supriyo Bandyopadhyah of Virginia Commonwealth University and Bin Yu of the NASA Ames Research Center -- who have agreed to support the IIAS research endeavor, will also join the workshop, according to Tzeng.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR ATTENTION TO ROC NATIONALS WITH AIDS

TEXT.P: A lawmaker of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) called Friday for attention to be paid to the plight of Republic of China nationals residing overseas who cannot return to Taiwan because they have AIDS.

DPP Legislator Sue Huang pointed out that these ROC nationals, mostly born overseas to ROC-citizen parents, have not registered their households in Taiwan and that if they want to return to the island for settlement, they first need to pass a health checkup, she said.
Under the current law, if they have AIDS, tuberculosis, intestinal parasites or leprosy, they cannot return even if they are ROC passport holders, Huang said.
As there is no cure for AIDS, the patients are unable to return and enjoy the rights of a citizen, she said, adding that even if they are in Taiwan, they will be repatriated.
In comparison, those who have registered their households can return to Taiwan and get medical care even if they test positive for HIV after being infected overseas.
Lin Yi-hui, secretary-general of an association to promote the rights of AIDS patients, also said that although there are only a "few" such individual cases, the matter still has to be addressed.
An Immigration Office official said that the office has acted according to the law and followed the regulations established by the Department of the Health (DOH) in handling these cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL TO OPEN CARGO FLIGHTS TO STOCKHOLM

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) is scheduled to begin operating cargo flights from Taipei to Stockholm, Sweden from Dec. 6, the first a Taiwanese carrier has entered the Scandinavian market, CAL officials said Friday.
CAL will operate a Boeing 747-400F twice weekly to Stockholm's Arlanda International Airport, flying in from Luxembourg and proceeding from Stockholm via Abu Dhabi to Taipei, CAL officials said.
It will be CAL's seventh all-cargo route in Europe.
The new route will help reduce costs and time that would otherwise be required for shipments delivery of Taiwan-originating cargo to Scandinavia, the officials said.

With the economies of the newly developed countries in Asia flourishing, imports of telecommunications equipment, electronics and vehicles have increased noticeably, they said, adding that Scandinavian countries are prominent suppliers and exporters of these products, making air cargo transport from Scandinavia to Asia more critical than ever.
Stockholm is the gateway to the other Scandinavian countries -- Finland, Norway and Denmark -- the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC WARNS OF PUNISHMENT FOR `GHOST VOTERS'

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) warned so-called "ghost voters" in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities Friday that they will risk punishment if their false abodes are detected.

According to CEC Deputy Secretary-General Teng Tian-you, voter numbers in the two special municipalities have "abnormally" increased over the past few months prior to the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections, as well as the Dec. 30 borough chief elections.

Warning the public that they will be breaking the law if they vote in a housing registration neighborhood where they do not really live, Teng said the CEC has already asked the Ministry of the Interior to step up checks of falsely registered voters in the two cities as the elections approach.
"Ghost voters" can affect election results and those people who register a false abode in order to cast their ballots in a certain district will be fined or otherwise punished, Teng said.
Although numbers of residents in Taipei and Kaohsiung have both declined over the past three years in a row, the two cities' voter numbers have actually increased, he pointed out.
In Taipei, the number of eligible voters had grown by 9,916 as of the end of August compared to a year ago, while the figure for Kaohsiung rose by 7,994, he went on.
Teng voiced his doubts about the "abnormal" voter population growth in the two special municipalities and warned the public against "irregularities."

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMAND CENTER FOR RETURN OF KMT'S 'ILL-GOTTEN' ASSETS INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A national command center for the campaign to demand that the opposition Kuomingtang (KMT) return its "ill-gotten" assets to the national coffers was formally opened Friday in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

Ruling Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Yu Shyi-kun presided over the inauguration ceremony along with the initiators of the "National League For The Return of Ill-Gotten Assets, " Cheng Cheng-yu and Wu Nan-ho.
In his address, Yu expressed the hope that the civil group will be able to collect the 1 million signatures required for the issue to be put to a national referendum.

Mentioning that on this date in 1945 the Japanese emperor declared defeat and surrendered to end World War Two, Yu said the emperor then promised that Japan, which had ruled Taiwan as a colony for 50 years, would return every piece of land and all buildings and other assets to the people of Taiwan.
However, the KMT government which took over the reigns of power in Taiwan "indulged its corrupt officials to turn them into property of "one person and one party," Yu claimed.

He also noted that his party has proposed at the Legislative Yuan a bill regulating ways to manage "ill-gotten" assets. However, the bill has been blocked by the KMT and its ally the People First Party, which together hold a slim majority in the Legislative Yuan.

"Fortunately, the ruling party can still force the opposition to return its ill-gotten assets to the Taiwan people via the existing Referendum Law," Yu said, urging people to sign the petition for the holding of a national referendum on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 45.85 points to close at 7,613.57.
The bourse opened at 7,587.51 and fluctuated between 7,621.81 and 7,557.62 during trading. A total of 6.26 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$133.03 billion (US$4.11 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.84 percent, followed by foodstuff issues at 1.78 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.56 percent, textile stocks at 1.26 percent, cement stocks at 1.24 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.14 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.51 percent, and machinery and electronics at 0.38 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 715 to 497, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIOXIN CONTENT IN FOOD BELOW ALARM LEVELS: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: The dioxin levels in food in Taiwan are below the alarm levels set by the Department of Health, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Consumers' Foundation.

The survey collected 20 food samples from traditional markets near garbage incinerators in the Peitou, Neihu, Mucha, Hsintien and Shulin areas of Taipei City and Taipei County and from traditional markets in areas where dioxin contamination has been reported, including Taipei County's Pali township, Changhua County's Hsienhsi township and the neighborhood of a plant belonging to China Petrochemical Development Corp. in Tainan City.

The samples covered five pieces of duck, four pieces of free-range chicken, four duck eggs and one piece each of beef, pork, goose, oyster, fish, shrimp and crab. Tests on the samples were conducted by National Cheng Kung University's Research Center for Environmental Trace Toxic Substances.

According to Cheng Jen-hung, chairman of the foundation, the results indicate that the cases of dioxin contamintation reported in the country so far remain isolated incidents, but added that the government needs to continue to monitor the situation.

Wu Chia-cheng, deputy secretary-general of the foundation and a professor of chemistry, noted that dioxins can be emitted from natural phenomena such as volcanic eruptions and forest fires, or can be a byproduct of chemical processing.
Dioxins are also produced when organic material is burned in the presence of chlorine, Wu added.
He said dioxins can enter the body through the nose, skin or mouth, with the ingestion of food accounting for as many as 95 percent of dioxin contaminations in humans.
Dioxins generally accumulate in the fat and it takes a very long time for the toxin to be released from the body, he said.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Council Backs Mayor's Veto in Race Bias Case. The career of Los Angeles Fire Chief William Bamattre dangled in the balance Wednesday as the City Council backed away from a settlement offered to a black firefighter who accused the department of racial discrimination.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP LAWMAKER TO RETURN TO TAIWAN TO 'REGAIN PARTY'S GLORY'
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 30 (CNA) (By Timothy Hwang and S.C. Chang)

TEXT.P: A former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker and Cabinet minister said in New York Thursday that he will return to Taiwan soon in a bid to help rebuild the party's "glorious and beautiful image."

Lo Wen-chia, who had just concluded a visiting scholar program at Harvard University, said he will "engage in direct dialogue with voters" in Taiwan, hoping to "reignite supporters' passion" for the DPP.
But he denied that he will run for DPP chairman in anticipation of an election failure Dec. 9, when voters in Taiwan's two largest cities will elect their mayors and city council members.
Neither will he contest a legislative seat in an election that is scheduled for late next year, Lo told the CNA.

The former protege of President Chen Sui-bian said recent remarks he made that drew attacks from some DPP stalwarts were aimed at "protecting the DPP and absolutely not at attacking the president or distancing myself from the president."

In a speech at Boston University Nov. 28, Lo said he had read the prosecution's indictment against first lady Wu Shun-jean and others on charges of embezzlement, forgery and perjury and he felt badly that the president had given contradictory and false testimony.
He also said he did not believe the president would embezzle public funds, although the prosecutors named the first couple as "joint perpetrators" in the corruption case.
"If you listen to my Boston speech carefully, you will find it was moderate and full of plain facts and not aimed at criticizing the president at all," Lo said.
He deplored that the DPP's "reformist and integrity images" have been surpassed by the Kuomintang (KMT) within a short span of time, while people's identity with the DPP has rapidly dropped.
"I have a strong emotional attachment to the DPP, a party that has achieved a great deal and a party I will never leave. I believe many people think like me," he added.
He claimed that the DPP could become Taiwan's ruling party in 2000 because it understands Taiwan's social trends and can lead mainstream public opinion.
Leading public opinion through a good grasp of the pulse of society is the "DPP's core value" -- a core value that Lo said his proposed "New DPP Campaign" was aiming at.
Although Taiwan has been losing its advantages by focusing too much on politics while ignoring much other "serious business, " Lo said he was still confident that Taiwan will survive and thrive.

The National Disaster Coordinating Council (NDCC) reported widespread power blackout and communication systems failure in many provinces of the Bicol region and some areas in Southern Tagalog as super-typhoon "Reming" (international codename: "Durian") with center winds of 190 kilometers per hour, made landfall in Catanduanes yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Supertyphoon batters Bicol
TROPICAL STORM "REMING" (international code name: Durian) whipped the Bicol region earlier Thursday, crippling transportation, stranding thousands of passengers, downing power lines, and forcing 166 families to evacuation centers.
The Philippine Star: 'Reming' spares Metro
Super typhoon "Reming" (international code name Durian) changed course yesterday and spared Metro Manila.
The Manila Times: Abalos moves to automate '07 polls
Chairman Benjamin Abalos Sr. of the Commission on Elections will convene an emergency meeting of the Comelec's advisory committee on Monday to decide on the automation of the May 2007 polls in pilot regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post: Iraq Panel to Urge Pullout Of Combat Troops by '08;. The bipartisan Iraq Study Group plans to recommend withdrawing nearly all U.S. combat units from Iraq by early 2008 while leaving behind troops to train, advise and support the Iraqis, setting the first goal for a major drawdown of U.S. forces, sources familiar with the proposal said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD CALLS FOR NO TALKS ABOUT PARTY REFORM AHEAD OF ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Faced with a call for a "New DPP Movement," ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Yu Shyi-kun expressed hope Friday that the issue can be shelved until after the Dec. 9 Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.

"The DPP listens to criticism, " Yu said, referring to criticism of President Chen Shui-bian by former Legislator Lo Wen-chia -- a former protege of Chen -- during a speech at Boston University in late November.

However, with the approach of the special municipal elections, Yu said he hopes party members will focus their attention on the election campaign and refrain from criticizing the party ahead of the vote.

Yu made the remarks in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, where he was on a visit to stump for party candidates running for the mayorship and city council, in response to media inquiries on the New DPP Movement initiated by Lo, who previously headed the Cabinet-level Council of Hakka Affairs.

Lo said in a speech in the United States that he had read the prosecution's indictment of first lady Wu Shu-jen in an embezzlement case and felt badly that the president gave contradictory and false testimony.
Lo said he did not believe the president would embezzle public funds, even though the indictment named the first couple as "joint perpetrators" in the case.
Asked about the DPP Central Review Committee's decision to suspend first lady's membership rights for 18 months after she was indicted, Yu said he respects the committee's ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Japan Times: Murakami enters plea of not guilty in NBS case Yoshiaki Murakami, founder of Japan's best-known investment fund, pleaded not guilty Thursday to charges of insider trading involving shares of Nippon Broadcasting System Inc. (by Mike Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 70 points to close at 7,612, with 37,466 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January increased 65 points to finish at 7,610, with 463 contracts traded, while March futures gained 33 points to end at 7,582, with 515 contract transactions. June futures moved up 59 points to close at 7,599, with five contract transactions, while September futures increased 79 points to close at 7,415, with eight contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,542 for December, 7,545 for January, 7,549 for March, 7,540 for June and 7,336 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures gained 1.75 points to close at 322.15, with 4,360 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 1.5 points to finish at 321.45, with 59 contract transactions. March TE futures increased 0.15 points to close at 319.8, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
December TF futures gained 7.6 points to close at 1,045.6, with 2,375 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 7.6 points to close at 1,043.6, with 34 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE MARRIED WOMEN WORKING: DGBAS

TEXT.P: The 2006 annual labor force participation rate among Taiwan's married women stood at a record high of 48.38 percent for May, indicating that more Taiwan housewives are working than ever, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Friday.
More and more married women are willing to work or seek employment in a bid to share the household financial burden or to satisfy their career pride, according to DGBAS officials.
The labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population in the labor force.
The DGBAS chooses May as the base month for the labor force participation rate survey each year, as May is the least fluctuating month in terms of employment and unemployment.

This year's survey found that the labor force participation rate among married women has risen to 48.38 percent, marking a 20-year high. By comparison, males had a labor force participation rate of 67.36 percent, while the rate for single women stood at 55.96 percent.

Labor force participation rates differed considerably by age, the survey found. While only about 34 percent of married women aged over 45 remain in the labor force, 64.54 percent of married women aged between 25 and 44 are in the workforce and 46.69 percent of married women aged between 15 and 24 are in the workforce.

By education background, the survey found that 66.58 percent of the married women who have college or higher education backgrounds are career women, followed by their counterparts with junior high school education or lower at 33.4 percent.

The survey also found that married women without children have a participation rate as high as 71.31 percent, which declines to 58.14 percent if they have children under the age of six and drops further to 44.67 percent if they have children over six.
Using a timeline of 20 years, the DGBAS found that the labor force participation rate married women has risen modestly but gradually, from 41.82 percent in 1986 to 48.38 percent by May this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MEDICAL TEAM PROVIDES FREE SERVICES IN HONDURAS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese medical team is on a visit to Honduras -- one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America -- to give local poor people free medical treatment services.
The two-week free medical mission will take the group to the country's inland regions, including San Lorenzo, Juticalpa, and El Progreso.

The Mobile Medical Team, headed by Taipei Medical University Hospital President Wu Chih-hsiung, was organized by the government-operated International Cooperation and Development Fund as part of efforts to help the people of Taiwan's allies in the region who are suffering from poverty and illness.

The group visited Honduran first lady Xiomara Castro de Zelaya Thursday accompanied by Republic of China Ambassador Lai Chien-chung. During the meeting, Castro de Zelaya expressed gratitude to the ROC government for its aid and donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, losing NT$0.062 to close at NT$32.370.
A total of US$1.26 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.432 and hit a low of NT$32.250.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 900,000 WORKERS HAVE THOUGHT OF CHANGING JOBS THIS YEAR: POLL

TEXT.P: A total of 895,000 workers in Taiwan have thought of finding new jobs this year, accounting for 8.89 percent of the total employed population, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The number marks the lowest level over the last five years since the number of workers thinking about finding new jobs peaked at 1.02 million in 2001, DGBAS officials said.
Among the workers who have thought about changing jobs this year, 514,000 are men and 381,000 are women, the officials said.
The annual survey is based on labor force statistics compiled in May.
As of May, workers had remained in their present jobs for eight years and seven months on average, which was one month longer than last year's survey.
By gender, the average length that the workers had spent on their present jobs was nine years and six months among male workers and seven years and five months among female workers.
On the reasons why workers would think about finding new jobs, 68.26 percent said they wanted a change in their work environment, while others said they wanted to increase their income.

Of the 895,000 workers who have had the idea, 250,000, or 27.92 percent, have actually looked for new jobs. The ratio represents a rise of 0.09 percentage points from last year and a soar of 8.74 percentage points over the past 10 years, according to the survey.
By age, 15.21 percent of the workers thinking about changing jobs are in the 15-24 age group, 6.36 percent are in the 45-64 age group and 1.3 percent are 65 or above.

While senior high school graduates account for the highest ratio among all potential job changers, at 10.12 percent, college graduates and those with higher education account for the lowest ratio, at 6.97 percent.
By industry, the largest percentage of potential job changers are from the hotel and restaurant industry, at 12.61 percent, followed by those from the mining industry, at 11.82 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-GRAFT LEADER DEMANDS RELEASE OF DETAINED MILITARY INSTRUCTOR

TEXT.P: The leader of the ongoing "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign demanded Friday that the high school drillmaster detained by military prosecutors three days earlier on charges of inciting a riot because of his support for the campaign be released immediately.

Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who launched the anti-graft campaign in early September, warned in a statement that if the Ministry of National Defense (MND) ignores this demand, the red-clad followers of the campaign will take "drastic action."

Army Maj. Tung Hua-cheng, a drillmaster at the Taibei High School in Shilin, showed up at the site of the anti-graft rally Sept. 20 in support of its demand for President Chen Shui-bian's ouster. He was wearing his military uniform but was apparently trying to hide his identity with a face mask and a pair of sunglasses.
Tung displayed a letter he wrote to Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, saying that in the event of a war, the rank and file soldiers will "turn their guns inward."

The military instructor could face seven years in prison for "inciting active duty servicemen to riot" in violation of Article 16 of the Criminal Law of the Armed Forces, according to Military High Court prosecutors.

Shih is currently in Thailand attending an anti-corruption forum. His statement, faxed to the anti-graft campaign headquarters in Taipei, was read at a press conference on his behalf by Lin Cheng-chieh, a deputy commander of the campaign.
The statement noted that as a democratic country ruled by law, Taiwan has come a long way from the martial law period through the sacrifices and dedication of many people, which put the DPP in power.
"The pluralism, tolerance and freedom of expression found in Taiwan today represent a spirit that the people of Taiwan cherish and pride themselves on most," it said.

"These achievements did not come easily, yet I am afraid it will take only overnight [for the government] to discard such treasured values and let the people feel the 'green chilling effect,'" it added.
Green is the color chosen by the DPP for its party flag. The DPP and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union, are frequently addressed as the "pan-green camp."

Shih urged the leaders of all opposition parties to stand up on the people's side for the detained military instructor. He also called on government authorities to "rein in your horse at the edge of a cliff."

The anti-graft campaign's threat to take drastic action came a day after opposition lawmakers vowed to freeze the MND's budget and have every military leader's special fund expenditures re-examined if Tung is not released.

They contended that the prosecution of Tung on charges of inciting a riot is a human rights violation, and that the military officer did not do anything wrong by exercising his right to freedom of expression.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Poison trail leads back to Moscow
The Kremlin was at the centre of another poison mystery last night after the family of a Russian former Prime Minister claimed that he had been struck down by unknown toxins.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICEY FISH CATCH FROM CHINA NABBED IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: Coastal patrol officers seized late Thursday over 30 metric tons of expensive fish smuggled in from China at the Nanliao fishing port in northern Hsinchu county, a spokesman for the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said Friday.

Acting on a tipoff that a fishing vessel from Hsinchu was attempting to smuggle in fish from China, prosecutors and CGA agents seized some 33 metric tons in seven categories of fish, including striped mullet and pomfret, aboard a local fishing boat.

The contraband catch had a market value of more than NT$20 million (US$615,000) , CGA agents estimated. They pointed out that their information showed that the catch was not caught by the fishing vessels, which left Hsinchu Nov. 27 to bring the contraband produce from China.
The three-member crew, including the captain, surnamed Lin, were turned over to the Hsinchu Prosecutor's Office earlier Friday for investigation on charges of smuggling, according to the spokesman.
The bust was part of a four-month operation begun in November by the CGA following orders from the Executive Yuan to stamp out smuggling, the spokesman said.
He also called on the public never to purchase agricultural and fishery products smuggled in from China because they usually contain too many preservatives and illegal substances to keep them fresh.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONLINE VOTING FOR `10 CLASSIC VILLAGES' KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) urged the public Friday to take part in an online selection of Taiwan's top 10 classic fishing and farming villages for the chance to win big prizes.

The selection will run until Feb. 28 on the Internet and the public are welcome to visit the 20 qualified villages on the COA's website following a primary screening of 50 villages, a COA spokesman said.

The COA will inspect the 20 villages and the results will be combined with the online voting for a final ranking that is slated to be announced next March, the spokesman said, adding that those who take part in the voting could win prizes ranging from a tour to digital cameras and MP3 players.

In line with the online voting, the COA is also sponsoring a photo contest through March 5 with the aim of soliciting 150 photos that record the unique landscapes of Taiwan's fishing and farming villages.
Photographers could win a cash prize of NT$2,000 for each work selected in the contest.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Dec.01 [CNA] The Moscow Times: 4 Airplanes Checked for Radiation
British authorities said Thursday that they suspected at least four aircraft of being contaminated with radiation, including planes that made trips between Moscow and London, in the latest twist in the death of former spy Alexander Litvinenko. [ By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: The Only Consensus on Iraq: Nobody's Leaving Right Now
In the cacophony of competing plans about how to deal with Iraq, one reality now appears clear: despite the Democrats' victory this month in an election viewed as a referendum on the war, the idea of a rapid American troop withdrawal is fast receding as a viable option. On Thursday in Amman, Jordan, President Bush declared that Iraqis need not fear that he is looking for "some kind of graceful exit out of Iraq." But a graceful exit -- or even an awkward one -- appears to be just what the Iraq Study Group, led by James A. Baker III and Lee H. Hamilton, tried to design in the compromise reached by Republicans and Democrats on the panel on Wednesday. The question now is whether Bush can be persuaded to shift course.
Wall STreet Journal: Rural Renewal, Energy Boom Lifts Small-Town Hope On Northern Plains
A new energy boom is reviving hopes across North Dakota. Little towns see a golden opportunity to stem the population decline that has long bedeviled all of North Dakota. Over the past two years, renewable energy projects that will cost more than US$1 billion have been announced in the state, including five ethanol plants, three biodiesel plants and five wind farms. Oil taxes have helped to generate a US$500 million state budget surplus. North Dakota's population peaked at nearly 681,000 during the Great Depression, then gradually declined as the state bounced through the ups and downs of agriculture and oil, and young people left the state for better jobs and warmer weather. Today, with just 637,000 people, the state is so sparsely populated that it still has a single area code.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLANATION OF FUNDS NOT INTENDED TO SWAY CASES: DGBAS

TEXT.P: An explanation of discretionary expense funds for President Chen Shui-bian, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and other senior officials is aimed at clarifying misgivings about their use and is not intended to sway any individual cases being probed, the country's chief budget agency said Friday.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan issued the remarks in a press release in response to public debate after it explained the "state affairs fund" for Chen and the "special expense fund" for Ma and other senior officials around the island during a Cabinet meeting Wednesday.

DGBAS Minister Hsu Chang-yao said at the time that Chen's fund should not fall under the same reimbursement rules as other general expenses funds because it is of "a special nature, " as it combines a "special expense fund and a secret fund."

Hsu noted that the fund has been appropriated to the Presidential Office since 1949 and has been mainly used for inspection tours at home or abroad, giving bonuses, subsidies, hosting guests and giving presents in a wide range of fields.

Hsu's remarks were considered by some as an Executive Yuan attempt to get Chen and Ma, as well as other officials, off the hook, as more and more officials are being probed over the use of the discretionary funds.

The DGBAS also said in its press release that the agency has normal exchanges with the Ministry of Audit (MOA) under the Control Yuan and that the MOA made a regular check of accounts in mid-November.

The DGBAS was responding to reports carried by the China Times newspaper that the MOA and the DGBAS are at loggerheads over the use of the "state affairs fund" and that the MOA made a surprise raid on the DGBAS to demand that Minister Hsu present all receipts claiming reimbursement from his "special expense fund." Hsu was also forced to turn over his "guest list" for verification.
The DGBAS said the visit was arranged in late September and was not a surprise raid.
The MOA also denied that the two agencies disagree on the fund use.

At issue is the MOA's views on the "state affairs fund, " which amounts to around NT$5 million (US$50,500) a year. The MOA has maintained that every expense should be accompanied with invoices or receipts for reimbursement, while the DGBAS said the fund combines a "special expenses fund" for senior officials, only half of which requires receipts.

Prosecutors probing the alleged misuse of the "state affairs fund" indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen Nov. 3 on embezzlement and forgery charges after it was found that she used invoices collected from family members and others to claim NT$14.8 million reimbursement from the state affairs fund between July 2002 and March 2006.

Prosecutors also said that had probed the possible flow of the half of the special "state affairs fund" that the president can claim reimbursement from without providing any proof of spending. But he added that no hard evidence was found to show that the president had pocketed money from this part of the fund.

Chen was named along with Wu as a "joint perpetrator" but has prosecution immunity while in office. He has denied any wrongdoing, claiming that the use of invoices belonging to other people was to cover expenses incurred in "secret diplomatic programs."

Ma, who doubles as main opposition Kuomintang chairman, has also been questioned by prosecutors twice over his mishandling of his own "special expenses fund, " when a staff member of the Taipei city government was caught using larger-amount invoices claiming reimbursement in lieu of hundreds of smaller-amount invoices to claim reimbursement from half of the fund, NT$170,000 per month, that requires receipts.
Prosecutors are also investigating if half of the "proof-free" fund deposited directly into Ma's personal account might not have been used for official duties but to line his pocket.

Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin also said in Wednesday's Cabinet meeting that the "special expense funds" for senior officials were "de facto special allowances" for the officials and can be kept if they are not used up by the end of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN HEALTH OFFICIALS CALL ATTENTION TO BETELNUT CHEWING RISKS

TEXT.P: Hualien health officials called for the public Friday not to chew betelnut, saying that it is closely related to oral cancer.
The health officials said that according to a survey on betelnut chewing people over the age of 15 last year, Hualien County topped the nation with 37.2 percent.
They noted that nearly 90 percent of oral cancer patients chew betelnut and that if they also smoke and drink, the ratio of developing oral cancer can increase many-fold.

Statistics compiled by the Hualien county government last year show that the overall death rate among oral cancer patients in Hualien was 14.07 per 100,000 people, or the fifth-most common cause of death.
Among men alone, the rate for oral cancer mortality was 24.68 per 100,000, or the third-most common cause of death.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S UNIVERSITY TUITION TO BE RAISED BETWEEN 2.4%, 10%

TEXT.P: Tuition fees for public universities around the country will be raised from 2.4 percent to 10 percent next year to meet rising costs and upgrade facilities, National Taiwan University (NTU) President Lee Si-chen revealed Friday.

Lee said the tuition adjustment plan was proposed at an earlier board meeting of the Association of National Universities of Taiwan (ANUT) , with participants all agreeing a tuition hike would help efforts to maintain teaching quality at the institutions.
Lee, who is also chairman of the association, explained that the island's consumer price index has seen an average yearly growth of 2.4 percent to 2.5 percent.
"The planned hike would only help schools offset the annual inflation," he said.

A university has to continue investing in upgrading software and hardware to boost its competitiveness, Lee said, noting that in this regard, a tuition hike has to surpass the annual growth rate in cost levels.
Therefore, NTU intends to raise its tuition fees by 2 percent-3 percent next year, Lee added.

The general tuition hike plan will be submitted to the 2007 conference of Taiwan's university presidents for discussion. It is expected the hike will take effect at the start of the 2007 academic year in September, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROOM FOR IMPROVEMENT IN TAIWAN'S CREATIVE INDUSTRY: III

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to step up efforts to develop its creative industry as its output in the field pales in comparison with leading countries, a representative of the Institute for Information Industry (III) said Friday.

Taiwan's 2004 output in the creative industry was US$17 billion, only slightly more than one-tenth of the U.K.'s output of US$160 billion. The numbers indicate Taiwan has a long way to go in developing the industry, said Ho Wen-hsiung, director of III's Industry Support Division.
China's creative industry output is US$220 billion annually, while Japan checks in at US$130 billion, only slightly less than its well-known auto industry, Ho added.
With its reputation in creative industries throughout Asia, Taiwan should do better than that, he said.
Taiwan is capable of turning the tide in the sector of the digital creative industry, given its advantage in information and communication technology and rich cultural assets, Ho said.

It's never too late to start developing the creative industry, which makes up an integral part of a knowledge-based economy. And it is a route that Taiwan has to take because its output in the computer hardware industry went from US$20 billion in 2001 to US$10 billion in 2004, Ho noted.
"In fact, the creative industry is not a new industry. It is just a new integration of value chains," Ho pointed out.

III was established in 1979 as a non-profit organization, jointly sponsored by Taiwan's government and dozens of prominent private enterprises, for the purpose of growing and strengthening Taiwan's information industry development.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT DOES NOT BUILD SUCCESS ON OTHERS' FAILURE: KMT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his party will not "compete for worst record" with other political parties and neither will it build its own success on other parties' failures.
Pepping up KMT nominees for the Dec. 30 ward chief elections, Ma urged the party's mayors, councilors and ward chiefs to "be clean and diligent, and love the people."

He said the KMT won the three-in-one local elections late last year because the party had high morale, while the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was embroiled in a string of corruption charges.

This year, the DPP has been bogged down by even more corruption scandals and has been "abandoned" by the people of Taiwan, Ma claimed, urging the KMT members not to "relish a rival that is corrupted by power."
"We must not make the same mistakes or walk on the same path as the DPP," he said. "Instead, we should learn lessons from its failure and map out a strategy for our party's development," he added.
The DPP motto is "be clean and diligent, and love the homeland" -- just one word different from Ma's proposed maxim for KMT politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU PROSECUTORS DONATE BOOKS TO REMOTE SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Prosecutor's Office donated 825 books Friday to 68 remote primary and junior schools throughout the county, with Magistrate Cheng Yung-chin presiding over the donation ceremony at the Hsinchu County Government.

Cheng accepted the books on behalf of school authorities from Prosecutor General Hung Wei-hua, who promised in future to continue periodically helping schoolchildren foster reading habits and sharpen their competitive edge, particularly those from aboriginal tribes living in remote mountainous areas.
According to Hung, the Hsinchu Prosecutor's Office purchased the books with money from a charity fund set up to handle the office's deferred prosecution fines.

Since a legal amendment passed in 2002, prosecutors are entitled to ask that defendants charged with minor offenses pay a certain amount of their deferred prosecution fines to the national coffers or charitable or public interest groups if they don't wish to carry out mandatory community service, Hung said.

Hung said the defendants must be very happy to know their fines are being used to help schoolchildren, adding that monetary donations may also be made for emergency assistance, drug rehabilitation or paying national health insurance fees for children from underprivileged families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES AID TO PANAMANIAN FLOOD VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan has donated US$10,000 worth of relief supplies to victims of floods in Panama that have killed 11 people in past weeks and caused 4,500 people great hardship.
ROC Ambassador to Pamana Hou Ping-fu presented the donation to the Panamanian government Thursday. Hou said the relief represents Taiwan people's care and friendship for the Panamanian people.
Several Taiwanese expatriate groups and Taiwan-funded companies in Panama also donated US$5,000 worth of relief goods to help Panamanian flood victims.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1,000 PAPER CRANES FOLDED FOR EARLY RECOVERY OF TAICHUNG MAYOR'S WIFE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan Dec. 1 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Students at Feng Chia University presented 1,000 paper cranes to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu through his deputy Friday, hoping good wishes brought by the origami birds will help the mayor's wife recover from injuries suffered in a recent car accident.

Taichung's Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi accepted the paper cranes from representatives of the university's Student Association at the Taichung City Council, promising to relay the good wishes to the mayor, who has stayed at Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan County since Nov. 18 to be with his seriously injured wife, Shao Hsiao-ling.

The mayor's wife is still in the hospital's intensive care unit. She has been in a coma since the accident, although doctors have said she is not in critical condition. A medical team performed two separate surgical operations, amputating her left forearm and a ruptured spleen.

Feng Chia students were especially shocked by the bad news because on Nov. 15 -- only three days before the car accident -- they met with the mayor on campus and accepted his congratulations for the university's 45th anniversary.

Leading members of the student association said they were stunned by the Nov. 18 accident, because only a day earlier they had been accorded warm hospitality when they paid a visit to the mayor and the Taichung City Council.
The Student Association launched a drive last month, asking Feng Chia students to fold 1,000 paper cranes and to pray for the early recovery of the mayor's wife.

The crane is a symbol of longevity in China, Japan and other Asian countries. The legend holds that by folding 1,000 paper cranes, people can move the gods to grant their wish and make a sick loved one healthy again.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD TO ANNOUNCE FREE-TRADE ZONE POLICY AT YEAR'S-END

TEXT.P: The government is expected to announce details of its five-point policy guidelines for the country's five free-trade zones at the end of this year after holding three seminars this month, officials said Friday.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has set up free-trade zones in four sea ports in Keelung, Taipei (Bali) , Taichung and Kaohsiung, and at Taoyuan International Airport.

The project, launched in 2003, aims to make Taiwan an international business operation center that offers infrastructure and services facilitating the flow of capital, people, commodities and information.

To achieve that end, the CEPD has drafted five policy guidelines: introduce a global operation mechanism for commodity flow; improve the operating environment for international commodity flow; provide services to builders of the commodity flow infrastructure; strengthen the functions of free-trade zones; and revitalize market functions.

CEPD officials said Taiwan is a key transshipment center for East Asia and North America. Besides its geographical advantage, Taiwan -- as the world's 16th largest trading nation with annual trade worth US$381 billion (2005) -- also enjoys a competitive edge in serving as a dispatch base for countries buying products from China and Southeast Asia, they said.
In the light of these advantages, they said Taiwan should seize the opportunity to transform itself into a transshipment center, as well as a provider of services to business operators.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ISSUES TRAVEL ADVISORY AGAINST FIJI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued an "orange-level" travel advisory against Fiji Friday, urging locals to refrain for the time being from visiting the South Pacific island country out of safety concerns.
On the ministry's travel advisory scale, an orange-level alert is the second most serious warning.

Noting that Fiji's political situation has become volatile after its embattled prime minister and other senior officials went into hiding earlier in the day amid the threat of a military coup, MOFA officials said locals should suspend business or sightseeing trips to that country at this time.

Those already there should avoid public demonstrations or assembly venues for the sake of their own safety, the officials said. If necessary, they can contact the country's representative office in Fiji via its round-the-clock emergency hotline: 679-992-6661.

Meanwhile, the officials said locals had better avoid visiting the Yiksan region in South Korea's North Cholla Province at this time because of a recent outbreak of the H5N1 strain of avian influenza there. The South Korean government has taken steps to prevent further spread of the outbreak. Visitors to South Korea should shun the affected region and avoid coming into contact with poultry and wild birds, and avoid eating raw poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q4 PRIVATE CONSUMER SPENDING TO RISE 2.21%: DGBAS

TEXT.P: Private consumer spending in the fourth quarter will increase 2.21 percent, the highest quarterly growth this year, the Cbinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) forecast Friday.
The agency also predicted that private consumer spending for the entire year will grow 1.5 percent.

The third quarter saw a mere 0.4 percent increase in private consumer spending due to credit card problems, DGBAS officials said, adding that private consumer spending in the fourth quarter is expected to regain momentum and register a 2.21 percent rise.

Business revenues generated by wholesalers, retailers, and restaurants, which form the bulk of private consumption, totaled NT$952.1 billion in September, representing a 5.8 percent increase compared to the same period last year, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR URGED TO MAINTAIN ADMINISTRATIVE NEUTRALITY

TEXT.P: The campaign office of the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, Huang Chun-ying, urged acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan Friday to maintain administrative neutrality in the lead-up to the Dec. 9 mayoral election.

Huang's spokesman pointed out at a press conference that Yeh and some 20 department chiefs in the Kaohsiung city government have taken leave Dec. 1-8 to canvass for Chen Chu, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate, in an attempt to boost her chances of an election victory.
"It is unprecedented that a Kaohsiung mayor and so many department chiefs take an eight-day leave collectively," said Chen Shei-saint, a former KMT legislator.
"Doesn't the city government have anything else to do in the next week except help Chen Chu with her election campaign?" he asked.

"There are urgent matters the acting mayor should attend to, such as the spread of dengue fever," he said, adding, "We have already seen three deaths from dengue hemorrhagic fever last month, and the city government should attach more importance to the lives of Kaohsiung residents than to the election campaign."

The acting mayor is serving as the head of Chen Chu's election campaign and is apparently doing her utmost in the final dash to help the DPP candidate get elected on Dec. 9, so she can smoothly hand over the reins to Chen Chu on Dec. 25.
Chen Chu, former chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, is still lagging in opinion polls behind Huang.

Results of a Nov. 27 DPP survey show her still trailing 3 percent behind Huang in voter approval ratings, but another poll conducted by the United Daily News a day earlier placed Chen Chu at 29 percent, and Huang at 38 percent.
The DPP customarily gets strong backing in Kaohsiung and has defeated the KMT in the two previous mayoral elections.

Analysts believe Chen Chu's poor performance is due mainly to negative publicity about the first family's alleged involvement in an embezzlement case that has led public prosecutors to indict first lady Wu Shu-jen and to name the first couple as "joint perpetrators."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T TO ISSUE WHITE PAPER ON RIGHTS PROTECTION FOR THE DISABLED

TEXT.P: The government will come up with a white paper on protecting and promoting the rights of people with mental or physical disabilities in the next six months, Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Wan-yi said Friday.
According to Lin, Premier Su Tseng-chang gave the instructions regarding the drafting of such a policy framework during a meeting of the Cabinet-level Social Welfare Promotion Commission.

Su directed the Ministry of the Interior to invite other relevant government agencies to review current policy deficiencies and enforcement flaws with regard to protecting disabled people's rights and benefits, including the creation of a safe, convenient and barrier-free living environment for them, Lin said.

"The premier also demanded that relevant government agencies draw up a comprehensive plan for providing services to the disabled, in terms of their different needs at different stages of life, " Lin said, adding that the policy paper will be ready for release in six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY

TEXT.P: Today is Saturday, Dec. 2, or the 12th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial-level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six-and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.

Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA ISSUES TRAVEL ADVISORY AGAINST FIJI(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) issued an "orange-level" travel advisory against Fiji Friday, urging locals to refrain for the time being from visiting the South Pacific island country out of safety concerns.
On the ministry's travel advisory scale, an orange-level alert is the second most serious warning.

Noting that Fiji's political situation has become volatile after its embattled prime minister and other senior officials went into hiding earlier in the day amid the threat of a military coup, MOFA officials said locals should suspend business or sightseeing trips to that country at this time.

Those already there should avoid public demonstrations or assembly venues for the sake of their own safety, the officials said. If necessary, they can contact the country's representative office in Fiji via its round-the-clock emergency hotline: 679-992-6661.

Meanwhile, the officials said locals had better avoid visiting the Yiksan region in South Korea's North Cholla Province at this time because of a recent outbreak of the H5N1 strain of avian influenza there. The South Korean government has taken steps to prevent further spread of the outbreak. Visitors to South Korea should shun the affected region and avoid coming into contact with poultry and wild birds, and avoid eating raw poultry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q4 PRIVATE CONSUMER SPENDING TO RISE 2.21%: DGBAS(repeat)

TEXT.P: Private consumer spending in the fourth quarter will increase 2.21 percent, the highest quarterly growth this year, the Cbinet-level Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) forecast Friday.
The agency also predicted that private consumer spending for the entire year will grow 1.5 percent.

The third quarter saw a mere 0.4 percent increase in private consumer spending due to credit card problems, DGBAS officials said, adding that private consumer spending in the fourth quarter is expected to regain momentum and register a 2.21 percent rise.

Business revenues generated by wholesalers, retailers, and restaurants, which form the bulk of private consumption, totaled NT$952.1 billion in September, representing a 5.8 percent increase compared to the same period last year, the officials said.
