DOC.HEADLINE: OVERDUE LOAN RATIO FOR FARMING, FISHING COOPERATIVES DOWN TO 8.68%

TEXT.P: The average overdue loan ratio of the credit cooperatives run by farmers' and fishermen's associations nationwide stood at 8.68 percent as of the end of October, down 0.15 percentage points from the previous month's level, according to tallies released Saturday by the Council of Agriculture's Bureau of Agricultural Finance.

As of the end of October, the combined assets of the credit cooperatives totalled NT$1.57 trillion (US$48.46 billion) , down NT$5.1 billion compared to the previous month. The net asset value amounted to NT$87.1 billion, up NT$500 million over the previous month.

While deposits at the credit cooperatives amounted to NT$1.36 trillion at the end of October, down NT$4.6 billion from the previous month, loans granted by the credit cooperatives amounted to NT$655.3 billion, up NT$2.6 billion from September.
The overdue loans amounted to NT$56.8 billion at the end of October, down NT$800 million from the month-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMAND FOR FOREIGN CAREGIVERS GROWS SUBSTANTIALLY: CEPD

TEXT.P: Domestic demand for foreign caregivers has spiked significantly since the beginning of this year, with the annual growth rate hitting 9.3 percent for the first 10 months, the country's top economic planning agency said Saturday.

As of the end of October, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan had reached 336,985, up a whopping 16,371 or 5.1 percent from the year-earlier level.
The bulk of foreign laborers worked in the manufacturing sector, accounting for 169,065 of the total and marking an increase of 4,746 over the same period last year, according to CEPD tallies.

CEPD officials attributed the increase mainly to a new market-opening measure adopted in January that allows 19 "dirty, arduous and dangerous" manufacturing industries, better known as "3K' industries, to hire foreign workers.
Caregivers formed the second largest foreign labor group, with the number increasing 12,839 or 9.3 percent year-on-year to 150,326 at the end of October.
The third largest foreign labor group was in the construction sector, but the number shrank 11.1 percent to a mere 12,049, according to the same tallies.

While local society remains divided over the consequences of an influx of foreign caregivers, CEPD officials said the government has sped up a "good housekeeper" project aimed at encouraging local women to receive training and become licensed caregivers.
With an aging local population, the officials said Taiwan needs to train more local caregivers to meet the skyrocketing market demand.

Under the "good housekeeper" project, the officials said the government plans to train a total of 30,000 local home care providers in the coming two years. The Ministry of the Interior has so far offered pre-job or on-the-job training courses for 12,000 local home care providers, social workers at senior citizens' homes and caregivers for people with mental or physical disabilities.

In addition, the officials said, the Ministry of Education, the Department of Health and Council of Labor Affairs have also organized various training programs for would-be local caregiving personnel over the past year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO FOCUS ON 'GETTING OUT THE VOTE' AS ELECTIONS DRAW NEAR

TEXT.P: With only one week remaining before mayor and city councilor races are held Dec. 9 in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the presidential office, Executive Yuan and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are pulling out all the stops in a "get out the vote" campaign, DPP officials said Saturday.

The officials said supporters of the "pan-green camp" led by the DPP are traditionally more enthusiastic in elections than their counterparts of the "pan-blue alliance" led by main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

But a series of alleged corruption scandals implicating the members of President Chen's family and senior aides this year -- with the latest a Nov. 3 indictment of first lady Wu Shu-jen on embezzlement and forgery charges -- have seriously dented the popularity not only of the president but also the ruling party, the officials said.

With support dampened, they estimated the turnout of "pan-green camp" supporters will drop to around 60 percent from 80 percent in the past, although they estimated they would have a greater chance of winning if the turnout rate could surpass 70 percent.

If they cannot tap supporters' passion for the DPP in the final stage before the elections, they estimated the turnout rate might only be 65 percent in Taipei and lower than 70 percent in Kaohsiung, traditionally a stronghold of the DPP.

They said that DPP polls showed support for Chen Chu, the DPP candidate for Kaohsiung mayor, still lagging by three percentage points behind her rival, Huang Jun-ying of the KMT. Pointing out the figure falls within the margin of error, they said stumping efforts and canvassing in the last week will be crucial.

In Taipei, although Frank Hsieh, the DPP's candidate for Taipei mayor, still lags behind KMT candidate Hau Lung-bin, support for him has steadily risen, they said. This, coupled with possible changes within the "pan-blue alliance," could bring about a turnaround at any time, they said.

James Soong, who has taken leave as chairman of the People First Party -- an ally of the KMT -- to run in the Taipei mayoral election, and Lee Ao, an independent legislator, are considered by some to divide the "pan-blue" vote.

Chen Chu will hold a large "hand-in-hand" rally by the side of Love River Sunday, with the participation of four DPP heavyweights -- DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang and Hsieh. President Chen is also expected to attend.

DPP officials said they are hoping that Sunday's rally will recreate a similar effect like the "one million people hand-in-hand" campaign that was launched prior to the 2004 presidential election, considered a major event that catapulted Chen into his second term as president.

Meanwhile, although President Chen has not arranged any stumping activities for Hsieh in Taipei City, Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general of the Presidential Office and a protege of Hsieh, has already taken leave to campaign for Hsieh.
Hsieh will hold a carnival-like rally to drum up support at the Taipei Arena stadium Nov.7.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSES LEARN MANDARIN THROUGH SINGING, READING

TEXT.P: More than 60 foreign spouses of Taiwanese, dressed in the traditional costume of their motherland, took part in singing and oral reading competitions Saturday in central Taichung city at an event organized by the Executive Yuan to help foreign spouses learn Mandarin or local dialects.

Lin Feng-hsi, executive director of the Executive Yuan's Central Taiwan Joint Services Center, said singing and reading are helpful ways to learn a foreign language. In this regard, his center has organized various singing and reading-oriented courses and activities for foreign spouses to help them blend into the local culture.

Besides existing courses and activities, the center will also assist foreign spouses by opening extra courses in Mandarin or a local dialect if a group of at least 15 people can be organized for a private course, Lin noted.

Foreign spouses play an increasingly important role in Taiwan, with one out of every five newlywed couples involving intermarriage and one out of every 6.5 babies born to foreign mothers -- mostly from China and Southeast Asian countries.

Foreign spouses face many difficulties while trying to adapt to the local society, including differences in language, culture, social customs, identity, sense of participation, and education of the younger generation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURN DEMOCRACY INTO DRIVE HELPING TAIWAN'S UNITY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the nation Saturday to turn democracy into a drive that is favorable to the country's solidarity, rather than allowing it to become a barricade.
In his written address to the 6th World Taiwanese Congress held in Taipei, Chen said democracy should be a force that helps Taiwan become a "normal, complete and great" nation.
Chen noted that the power of the people has contributed toward great progress in the country's democratic development in past decades.

In today's Taiwan, Chen said, differences in opinion enjoy full protection by the Constitution, with every individual entitled to the right to express their views without having to worry about being suppressed or persecuted, which is the pride and value of Taiwan's democracy and a sign of great social progress.
While people are allowed to disagree with each other, they must not damage the country's solidarity, Chen said.
While people can be divided on the issue of their national identity, the country must not be allowed to split, nor should the government be allowed to become inoperative, Chen said.

According to Chen, in an ever-changing international situation, Taiwan must stick to the universal values of freedom, democracy, peace and human rights and establish a value-based alliance with the world's democratic community to deepen and consolidate democracy around the globe.

Also addressing the congress, Tan Sun Chen, secretary-general to the Presidential Office, said the issue of whether President Chen should resign over the alleged "state affairs fund" scandal is not a personal affair but a question that concerns the whole nation.
For the sake of the country's 23 million people, the president must hold on and serve out his term until May 20, 2008, Chen said.

The prosecution indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of forgery and corruption Nov. 3 after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
President Chen was named along with his wife but was not charged because of his constitutional immunity from prosecution as head of state.
Chen claimed none of the money went into his own pocket and vowed to resign if the first lady is found guilty in the first trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AID HELPS INDONESIAN SCHOOLCHILDREN REGAIN HOPE
DOC.DATELINE: Nias, Indonesia, Dec.1 (CNA) (By Charles Kang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Nefi, a 10-year-old Indonesian girl, was all smiles Friday when she joined with her teacher and classmates to welcome an aid supervisory delegation from Taiwan that had arrived to inspect her school in Nias, one of the hardest-hit regions in the 2004 earthquake and tsunami catastrophe.

The fourth grader recalled that she was reduced to tears when her earthquake-and-tsunami-destroyed Tetehosi Idanoi Elementary School came into her sight for the first time two months after the tragedy.

"School was my most favored place to study and play. I prayed for God's help, wishing someone would help us rebuild our school... It was so great that my dream has come true, with help from Taiwan. Now we have new classrooms, new schoolbags, uniforms and textbooks. We can go to school again every day," Nefi said.
Nefi said she has studied very hard since her school re-opened under financial aid from Taiwan. She won a championship in a recent Indonesian speech contest at her school.

Nefi joined other students in signing the "Song of Nias" to welcome the visitors from Taiwan, including Hsu Kuo-lang, head of the secretarial department of the Government Information Office (GIO) , Lin Chia-lung, a former GIO minister who is now secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and senior executives of World Vision Taiwan (WVT).

The Tetehosi Idanoi Elementary School reconstruction project is part of a "10,000 Hopes" plan initiated by then-GIO Minister Lin Chia-lung in the wake of the devastating earthquake and tsunami disaster in late 2004, which killed more than 200,000 people in several South and Southeast Asian countries, including Indonesia, Sri Lanka and Thailand.
The "10,000 Hopes" plan was aimed at helping 10,000 children in tsunami-affected areas for three years. Taiwanese citizens and corporations donated more than NT$400 million to the project.
The "10,000 Hopes" supervisory commission has cooperated with World Vision Taiwan, a Christian charity, in carrying out school reconstruction projects on the Indonesian island of Nias.

With a sum of NT$108 million for the Nias rehabilitation project, World Vision Taiwan has not only helped rebuild schools in Nias but also helped parents of schoolchildren rebuild their life and careers. The charity has arranged for parents of schoolchildren to help build classrooms and roads in the vicinity as well as other public facilities.
This is the second consecutive year that Lin has traveled to Indonesia to look into implementation of the "10,000 Hopes" project. Lin said he is very pleased to see it progressing smoothly.

"Last year, many schoolchildren were still barefoot and had no uniform and schoolbags. This time around, we see them come to school joyfully in neat uniforms and shoes with textbooks and stationery in their schoolbags, " Lin said. "From their bright smiles, I feel our altruistic efforts have come to fruition."
It is hoped the three-year aid project can come to a smooth close next year, with 10,000 children in the tsunami-disaster zone receiving good care and true benefits.
Later in the day, Lin and other "10,000 Hopes" project supervisors paid a visit to North Nias District Administrator Binahati B. Baeha.

Baeha expressed his heartfelt thanks to Taiwan's generous humanitarian aid to his district. He said he hopes to visit Taiwan in the future to promote bilateral goodwill exchanges and foster friendship.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP OFFICIAL RETURNS TO 'RESTORE PARTY'S GLORY'

TEXT.P: A former Cabinet member from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday he was returning to Taiwan to "restore the party's glory, " which he considered as having been tainted in the past few years.

Lo Wen-chia, who used to be one of President Chen Shui-bian's trusted proteges and also an ex-DPP lawmaker, made the remarks upon arrival from the United States at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.

Lo is expected to face strong criticism and questions from DPP colleagues after his recent remarks in the United States, in which he commented frankly on the party and Chen's management of the president's discretionary "state affairs fund."

In a speech he gave at Boston University late last month, Lo said he had read the prosecutor's indictment against first lady Wu Shun-jen on charges of embezzling the president's "state affairs fund, " and felt badly the president had provided false testimony in the case.

The prosecutors indicted Wu on charges of forgery and corruption Nov. 3, after determining she had used the receipts or invoices of others to claim funds totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" during the period 2002-2006.
President Chen was named along with his wife in the corruption charges but was not charged because of his constitutional immunity from prosecution as head of state.
Lo said he believes the president had no intention of embezzling public funds, but that he made some "procedural mistakes" in using the "state affairs fund."
On the first lady's being indicted, Lo also suggested that the party should not have double standards in handling the first lady's case by not suspending her party membership rights.
Lo said he knew very well that he would face much criticism against him after his frank remarks toward the party and first family.
However, Lo said, his speech was not aimed at criticizing the president, but that he had just "reminded" the president, as he maintains close relations with Chen.
Noting that some have exaggerated his remarks, Lo said he brought back a video of his speech from the U.S., hoping that it would clarify what he really said in the speech.
Referring to the mayoral elections on Dec. 9, Lo said those DPP candidates are all the party's elite, and that he would stand with DPP supporters to help restore the party's glory and fame.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MRT SYSTEM EVEN BETTER THAN TAIPEI'S: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian lauded the Kaohsiung mass rapid transit (MRT) system as even better than its Taipei counterpart after taking a test ride Saturday.

The president, accompanied by acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan and Kaohsiung Rapid Transit Corp. Chairman Chiang Yao-tsung, rode an 8 km section of the red line between Far Eastern Department Store and Hsiaokang.

Yeh said that 20,000 people had taken the test ride on the same section, with over 95 percent expressing satisfaction with the smooth travel. The MRT's red and orange lines are scheduled to be inaugurated at the end of 2007.

Chiang, who previously served in Taipei rapid transit system, said the Kaohsiung MRT system has been efficient and that the BOT (build-operate-transfer) model of construction has saved the government NT$44.4 billion (US$1.34 billion). The cost of personnel is also cheaper and more job opportunities have been created, Chiang added.

President Chen took the opportunity to praise former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh for his willpower and outstanding sense of responsibility, saying Hsieh had laid a solid foundation for the MRT's construction while serving between 1998 and 2005. Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate in the Taipei mayoral election, stepped down to take the premier post in January 2005.
President Chen, who has been mired in alleged corruption scandals implicating his family members and senior officials, was in high spirits Saturday.
He said he will be attending a "hand-in-hand" rally Sunday by the side of Ai River, also known as Love River, to drum up support for Chen Chu, the DPP candidate for Kaohsiung mayor.
The president, who visited a night market to canvass votes for Chen Chu Friday, said he loved Kaohsiung city very much and twice mentioned he will move to Kaohsiung after leaving office in May 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: POST-SURGERY SURVIVAL RATE OF LUNG CANCER PATIENTS TOPS 50%: STUDY

TEXT.P: More than 50 percent of lung cancer patients survive at least five years after surgery, according to the results of a study released Saturday by the Taiwan Lung Cancer Society.

The study, unveiled during the Asia-Pacific Congress on Lung Cancer and the 10th Annual Meeting of the Taiwan Cooperative Oncology Group held in Taipei, is based on an analysis of 971 lung cancer patients who underwent surgery at Taipei Veterans General Hospital over the past 20 years.

The study found 52.5 percent of lung cancer patients survive at least five years after surgery, and the five-year survival rate could even reach 68.4 percent if the patients did not fall victim to other diseases.
Chen Chih-yi, president of the society, said it is mistaken for patients to think they are doomed to perish after being diagnosed with lung cancer.
Many lose their appetite and a lot of sleep over their disease and would rather follow some unscientific therapies than undergo surgery out of fear, Chen noted.

According to Chen, unlike in the past when some of the patient's ribs had to be removed in lung cancer surgery, today's operations leave only an incision 10 cm to 12 cm in length, thanks to thoracoscopy and progress in anesthetic technology.
While the surgery takes a very short time to complete, patients can eat and get out of bed hours after the surgery and be discharged from the hospital within four to five days, Chen said.
For patients whose lung cancer has proceeded to stage II or stage III, their survival rate will increase by five percent to 10 percent if they receive chemotherapy after surgery, he pointed out.

Chen said smokers, those with a chronic cough, those who are frequently exposed to second-hand smoke or have a family history of lung cancer are at high risk of suffering from the disease and should receive regular health checkups to ensure early diagnosis.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Italy alert on Polonium 210 pollution.
Italy has been on alert for a possible pollution by the radiative polonium 210 since Mario Scaramella, a security consultant, tested positive for the pollutent earlier this week. Scaramella was the person who met former Russian dissident Alexander Litvinenko on the same day when he was poisoned in early November.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH SEEN IN EARLY LUNG CANCER DIAGNOSIS RESEARCH

TEXT.P: Researchers from the National Research Program for Genomic Medicine (NRPGM) have discovered several genes that play a decisive role in the formation and transfer of lung cancer.

Distinguished investigator Wu Cheng-wen of the Institute of Cancer Research at the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) reported the breakthrough in research on lung cancer transfer and deterioration Saturday at an Asia-Pacific lung cancer conference.

Wu warned that in 2006, lung cancer was the top killer in Taiwan and that the rate of growth in lung cancer cases in Taiwan has risen to become the world's highest. Mentioning that smoking can undoubtedly cause lung cancer, Wu said in Taiwan, however, 90 percent of female lung cancer patients were found to have never even smoked.

For this reason, the NHRI began efforts years ago to find out what causes people to suffer from lung cancer, yielding recent rewards when researchers found that besides passive smoking, air pollution and oil smoke, genes also plays a key role in lung cancer's formation.
The NHRI have discovered several genes related to the disease, Wu said, noting that if all the genes mutate, the risk of getting lung cancer will surge to become 20-30 times greater.

Wu explained gene mutation may be congenital or result from other factors, including aging. By pinpointing pathogenic genes, it is possible to discover signs of lung cancer through preventive screen tests. Even further, it is also feasible for physicians to design a personal treatment program for each lung cancer patient.
In the next stage, genetic research will focus on the puzzle of why lung cancer spreads easily to the brain, bones and liver, according to the NHRI.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD REDEFINE ITS ROLE AMID ERA OF GLOBALIZATION: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that Taiwan should redefine its role at a time when globalization is a tendency in the international community.

In a speech given at the World Taiwanese Congress at the Grand Hotel in Taipei, Lu said Taiwan, with advantages in many respects, should closely link itself with the rest of the world amid fierce global competition.

In the speech, titled "Global Taiwan, " Lu stressed that Taiwan's destiny is to be decided by its people, and that the Taiwanese should have the ambition to play a greater and more vital role in the world community.
Noting that Taiwan boasts both geographic and strategic advantages, Lu said it has become a logistics center in the world.

When asked about Taiwan's niche in the world community, Lu said she believes the island's core values and its high-tech performance will be its primary advantages, with which no other countries can compete.
Referring to China's economic rise and its increasing military power, Lu said Taiwan should deliberate ways to squarely face these challenges, as China still harbors hostility toward it.
Lu went on to say that Taiwan's people should have a global view while mapping out a plan for its future, instead of adopting the Chinese point of view.
She stressed that the government aims to make Taiwan the "Taiwanese people's nest, " where people can fly out and always count on a warm home welcoming them when they are tired of flying.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CARES MOST ABOUT PRESIDENT DELIVERING ON HIS WORDS: CAUCUS WHIP

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said Saturday that the party cares more about the president delivering on his word than where the wife of President Chen Shui-bian's son gives birth.
Tsai Chin-lung, a KMT legislative caucus whip, made the remarks one day after Cheng Chih-chung, the president's son, and his wife Huang Jui-ching, returned from the United States.

The first son and his wife flew to the U.S. in late October after visiting the first lady, Wu Shu-jen, who was said to be in poor health due to the investigation into alleged embezzlement of public funds. Huang, who is now seven months pregnant, unexpectedly became an issue during the upcoming election after the opposition speculated whether the first son intended to have his child born in the U.S. to get a U.S. citizenship.
Noting that the president openly stated in September that he would not like to be called a "grandfather of an American, " the KMT demanded that he deliver on his promise.

Also, in a previous presidential election, the president once lambasted his rival as "unpatriotic" after the rival's grandson was born in the United States, so the opposition has asked the president to apply the same criteria.
Tsai said the party took in stride the return of the first son and his wife, saying they are both adults and can choose to give birth here or in the United States.
Their return is "not a big deal, " and only means the president has delivered on his word, and that the KMT will not touch on the subject again, he added.

He also said it should not affect the Dec. 9 Taipei and Kaohsung mayoral elections amid reports that the "pan-green camp" led by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party was greatly boosted by the return of the first son and his wife.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng also said Saturday that the Chen couple's return will not sway voters in the upcoming election, but "if they didn't return, the DPP stands to lose some of its core supporters."
Wang made the remarks while stumping for Huang Jun-ying, the KMT's candidate in the Kaohsiung mayoral election, in the southern Taiwan port city.
Wang, a former KMT vice chairman, said both the DPP and KMT have solidified their core supporters, and that Huang's return will not lure away any of those voters who have made up their minds.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT MONTH FEATURES YEAR-END RETROSPECTIVE, FORECASTS GOOD PROSPECTS

TEXT.P: As thousands pack the exhibition hall for the 2006 Information Technology (IT) Month, Taiwan can look back at the past year and forward to the future with a sense of accomplishment, organizers and officials said Saturday.

"Entering its 27th year, IT Month has become the most compelling and significant year-end event for Taiwan's IT industry and consumers. We estimate more than two million visitors will visit the fair this year, " said Frank Huang, president of the Taipei Computer Association, IT Month's main organizer.

About 350 companies set up more than 1,700 booths at the fair, which is taking place in Taipei from Dec. 2-10, and will head south for shows in Taichung Dec. 15-20, Tainan Dec. 28-Jan. 2 and Kaohsiung Jan. 11-16, 2007.
While consumers care most about cheap computer prices, the fair also provides Taiwan's IT industry a chance to look back retrospectively as well as consider future prospects.

And the results are not disappointing. Despite all the theories of economic "hollowing out" in news reports, Taiwanese companies have been doing well in global markets, manufacturing more than 98 percent of computer motherboards and controlling the manufacture of about 87 percent of laptop computers, said Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long.

Taiwan's brand development and industrial design has received much positive feedback over the past year, winning 146 international industrial design awards and boosting Taiwan's confidence in its value-added efforts. Taiwan has been doing well in foundry, packaging tests, and flat panel sectors as well, Chen added.
However Taiwan will be facing challenges in the upcoming year.

"We'll see a lot of changes in the upcoming year, with the launch of a new Microsoft computer system, Vista, and emerging development of 3G mobile phones, " said Frank Huang, adding that Taiwan needs to devote more energy to digital content development to catch up with South Korea.
"Without a doubt, the IT and digital industries will be Taiwan's lifelines in the future," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CALLS FOR END TO SMEAR CAMPAIGN AFTER RETURN OF PRESIDENT'S SON

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) urged the opposition "pan-blue alliance" Saturday to put a stop to its smear campaign against President Chen Shui-bian's son and daughter-in-law now that the couple have returned home.
DPP Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang made the call after Chen Chih-chung and his pregnant wife Huang Jui-ching returned to Taipei from the United States late last night.

Over the past two weeks, Tsai said some opposition politicians have relentlessly tried to "play up" the rumor that Huang, who is seven months pregnant, will give birth in the United States to facilitate her citizenship application.

The rumor has even been blown up into a bizarre claim that if the DPP loses the Dec. 9 municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Huang and her husband Chen Chih-chung should be held accountable, Tsai regretted, adding that the speculation has caused "unbearable pressure" on the young couple.

"Now that the couple have returned, we are hopeful that all the rumors and smears against the first family can come to a halt. As a matter of fact, Huang has never said she would not return to Taiwan to deliver her first baby," Tsai said.

Stressing that the topic about where the couple will live has nothing to do with the upcoming election, Tsai urged the opposition camp to shift their focus to major policy issues and respect the president's son and daughter-in-law's privacy.
Before his return, the president's son had been interning at a law firm in New York after obtaining master's degrees in law from two noted U.S. universities in the past two years.

Some DPP politicians have claimed that the opposition camp and certain media outlets had been deliberately playing up the story in a bid to divert people's attention from a scandal involving Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's alleged misuse of a discretionary fund for his use.
Just Wednesday, the president's son filed a defamation lawsuit against opposition Kuomintang Legislator Chiu Yi over Chiu's claim that he and his wife have applied for U.S. citizenship.
On Monday, Chen Chih-chung and his elder sister, Chen Hsin-yu, also filed a defamation lawsuit against Chiu over Chiu's claim that they own "huge assets" in the United States.
Because the two cases were unrelated, Chen Chih-chung's lawyer Hsu Ming-shui said they should be handled separately.
If Chiu is indicted over the "citizenship" defamation suit, Hsu said his client will demand NT$100 million in damages.
Chen Chih-chung has rebutted Chiu's "citizenship" claim in a written statement, stressing that he has never applied for nor possessed a passport of any country other than the Republic of China.

Chen Chih-chung further said he has never applied for immigration through investment in the United States nor any other form of U.S. immigration. He also sternly debunked Chiu's claim that he has invested in a supermarket chain in the U.S.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Times: Poison plotters claim their second victim Police fear that the murder of a former Kremlin spy may have been part of a double killing plot after a second man was taken to hospital last night with radiation poisoning.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS RALLY IN PANCHIAO TO OPPOSE PERSECUTION INSIDE CHINA

TEXT.P: Thousands of Taiwanese rallied in a parade in Panchiao, Taipei County Saturday to oppose persecution in China and voice support for a movement urging Chinese to withdraw membership from the Communist Party of China (CPC).

"In two years, almost 16 million Chinese people have submitted statements withdrawing from the CPC or its affiliated organizations. The numbers show the Chinese have spurned the CPC because of its severe persecution inside China and repeated violations of human rights," said Lee Ching-mei, a parade spokeswoman.
During the rally, Falun Gong members carried out an exercise that uses five meditations, and something the Chinese government deems an illegal activity.

The parade was the second time a massive Taiwan rally was organized in support of the secession movement since Epochtimes, a Falun Gong affiliation newspaper, published "Nine Commentaries on the CPC" and launched the movement in 2004, Lee said.

Braving the cold air and light rain, participants held cardboard and banners with anti-CPC slogans, which included "CPC is not China," "Oppose organ harvesting," "Support Chinese human rights activists," and "A democratic China will not exist before the elimination of the CPC."

History shows in Russia, more than 4.2 million members withdrew from the Communist Party before the Soviet Union finally collapsed in 1991. And the CPC may collapse as well, with the secession movement gaining steam, said Li Dayong, who works for the Global Service Center for Quitting CCP.

Li said most people don't realize that behind all the rapid economic growth and development of big cities, the Chinese government has illegally kidnapped and detained dissidents, writers and reporters, suppressed Falun Gong members, and ignored the problems of corruption, discontinued education, unemployment and an ineffective health care system, among many other areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDIDATES FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR ELABORATE ELECTION PLATFORMS ON T.V.

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung's mayoral candidates elaborated their respective policies Saturday in televised campaign speeches organized by the Central Election Commission.

Chen Chu, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , promised to construct the country's first light-rail rapid transit system (MRT) in Kaohsiung during her four-year tenure if elected in the mayoral elections on Dec. 9.

In addition, Chen vowed to complete two MRT lines in Kaohsiung, which are currently under construction; hold a successful World Games in the southern port city in 2009; and complete construction on an international convention and exhibition center in the city.

Huang Chun-ying, the opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate, suggested the government open direct air and marine transport between Kaohsiung and China, which he estimated would create trade opportunities worth NT$10 billion for the city.
Such a move is likely to draw Taiwanese business people back from China, and foreign enterprises will want to set up their operational headquarters in Kaohsiung, Huang claimed.
Lo Chih-ming, who is representing the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) in the races, urged the public not to vote for those who are not deeply involved in Kaohsiung affairs.
Noting that he served as Kaohsiung city councilor for 12 years before being elected legislator, Lo said he was the candidate who best understands Kaohsiung's problems.

Lin Chih-sheng, candidate for the Taiwan Defense Alliance (TDA), noted that Taiwan's current political upheaval lies in its vague national identity, and he promised, if elected, to work toward defining Taiwan's position in the world community.

Expressing his opposition to direct transport links with China, Lin lamented that Taiwan's economy has suffered after some politicians encouraged more investment in China. Lin urged the Taiwanese people to build a truly independent country for their own benefit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOLDS DRILL AGAINST AVIAN FLU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Department of Health (DOH) held an exercise against avian flu Saturday at a community college in Hsinyi district, after a recent outbreak of the deadly H5N1 strain of avian flu in poultry in neighboring South Korea.

The bird flu outbreak in South Korea, whose government has therefore ordered the immediate slaughter of some 300,000 chickens, has caused concern in Taiwan, since the two countries are geographically close and on the same migration route for migratory birds, although Taiwan remains free of bird flu.
The rehearsal, dubbed "White Egret No. 8, " focused on efforts to minimize panic in the event of an avian flu outbreak.

Chiu Chan-hsien, a section chief of the DOH's Center for Disease Control (CDC) , noted that his agency has been cooperating with community colleges around the country and National Cheng Kung University in training volunteers to strengthen the avian flu prevention network. and aims to attract some 100,000 such volunteer workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, VIETNAM SIGN COOPERATION ON HIGH-TECH, VOCATIONAL EDUCATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Vietnam signed a cooperation agreement on collaborating in the fields of technology and vocational education Saturday in central Taichung county.

Taiwan's Representative to Vietnam, Huang Nan-huei, and his Vietnamese counterpart Hoang Nhu Ly signed the pact, which aims to further expand existing exchanges, on the sidelines of a second Taiwan-Vietnam conference on technological and vocational education being held at Chaoyang University of Technology in Wufeng, Taichung County.

The conference was attended by heads of local vocational colleges and Vietnamese university officials, at institutions particularly known for their programs in the fields of Chinese language, information, restaurant and hotel management, as well as agriculture.

According to the Ministry of Education (MOE) , the two countries have stepped up academic exchanges over the past years, with the most significant interactions seen in the field of technological and vocational education.

As a result, in 2004, 26 Taiwanese technology colleges and universities forged sisterhood or cooperation relations with a total of 79 Vietnamese schools, while those numbers increased from 33 to 97 last year.
In the past three years, Taiwan and Vietnam signed 40 cooperation programs concerning technological and vocational education, according to MOE tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVIST URGES TAIWAN TO PLAY ROLE IN DEMOCRATIZATION OF CHINA

TEXT.P: As an emerging democracy, Taiwan should play an active role in China's democratization for the benefit of both people in Taiwan and China, a Chinese human rights activist said Saturday.

"Only by participating in the process of the democratization of China and the deconstruction of the Communist Party of China (CPC) can God truly bless Taiwan," said Li Dayong, who works for the Global Service Center for Quitting CPC, on the sidelines of a parade opposing state-led persecution inside China.
The rally gathered thousands of participants in Panchiao, Taipei County to support a movement calling on CPC members to quit the party, and opposing China's suppression of Falun Gong and dissidents.

Views of Taiwan's future commonly held among Taiwanese people -- unification, independence, and the status quo -- will not work because they are all based on interaction between cross-strait governments, Li said.
"But can you really trust the Chinese government and the CPC, based on its track record?" asked Li, who is one of the founders of Future China Forum, a democracy-advocating Internet forum.

Eastern European countries didn't start their democratization process until the Communist Party of Soviet Union was deconstructed, Li said, adding that it provided a perfect example for both Taiwan and China.
"Most people know that Taiwan is in a stalemate politically, especially in cross-strait relations. The real question we have to ask is how to walk out of it," he said.
"In my opinion, only by helping Chinese people break away from the control and suppression of the CPC can Taiwan secure its future and break away from China's military threat," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYORAL ELECTION LAW DOESN'T BAN PUBLICATION OF POLL NUMBERS: CEC

TEXT.P: The Public Officials Election and Recall Law does not ban release of opinion poll numbers during the official campaign period, Central Election Commission (CEC) spokesman Teng Tien-you said Saturday.

Teng made the explanation after Frank Hsieh, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate in the Dec. 9 Taipei mayoral election, questioned earlier in the day the legality of a local newspaper publishing in its Saturday edition on the results of two opinion polls on voter support rates for candidates in the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral races. In both polls, the ruling party's candidates lag behind nominees of the main opposition Kuomintang.
The timing is against the law as only one week left ahead of the election day, Hsieh claimed.

Nevertheless, Teng said that only the presidential election law clearly bans publication of any opinion poll numbers during the official campaign period, while the law governing election for other public functionaries doesn't include such a clause.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCKU DEVELOPS GPS-BASED MARITIME MONITORING SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) research team has successfully developed an islandwide maritime monitoring system, using global positioning system (GPS) signals, a university spokesman reported Saturday.

Tseng Ching-liang, director-general of NCKU's Satellite GeoInformatics Research Center, said the new system -- dubbed the "maritime remote-sensing system based on GPS reflective signal" -- can provide real-time information of water levels at rivers, estuaries and harbors, as well as coastal areas around the island.
Tseng said that Germany already has such a system in place, but it is the first of its kind in Taiwan.
With funding from the National Science Council, the research team has spent some two years developing the system, completing the project in July this year.
The Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has earmarked funds to set up the system next year, according to Tseng.
The system utilizes reflective signals from the GPS system to measure water or sea levels, and relates that information to the control center for advance warning, Tseng explained.
He added that the system can also be deployed onboard low-altitude airships, which can reach the designated locations during floods to monitor and report the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Taliban Truce in District of Afghanistan Sets Off Debate
After a series of bruising battles between British troops and Taliban fighters, the Afghan government struck a peace deal with tribal elders in Helmand Province, arranging for a cease-fire and the withdrawal of both sides from one southern district. A month later, the ripples are still being felt in the capital and beyond.
Wall Street Journal: Why a Gambler, Snubbed by GM,Folded His Hand
Over the past year, as 89-year-old billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian had high hopes for his GM investment and he hadn't expected it to turn into a long slugfest. This week -- after a difficult year in his personal life, in which two close friends died -- he decided GM wasn't worth a long war. Thursday, Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Corp. liquidated the last of its GM holdings, taking pressure off GM's management for the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING INT'L PRESENCE VIA CULTURAL EXCHANGES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday Taiwan looks forward to expanding its international presence through increased cultural exchanges with other countries.

Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at a happy get-together of foreign students studying at local universities or graduate institutes on scholarships offered by the Republic of China government.
The get-together, organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , is aimed at fostering goodwill and friendship with Taiwan scholarship recipients, Chen said.

The MOFA began to offer scholarships in 2003 to encourage foreign youths to pursue tertiary education in Taiwan as part of its efforts to forge closer links with the international community through cultural exchanges.

The number of recipients of the MOFA-sponsored Taiwan scholarships has reached about 500. This is the first time that the MOFA has hosted a party for all scholarship recipient students to get together for an evening of amusement and entertainment.
Many foreign students performed their country's folm music and dances at the evening party. Resident ambassadors and representatives of various countries were also invited to attend the get-together.
While geographic boundaries and political limitations tend to exist among countries around the world, Chen said cultural exchanges can be freely without any off-limits.

"We believe that arts, music, dances and other cultural activities can be the best vehicle for sharing feelings and aesthetic experiences and forging international partnerships, " Chen said, adding that such exchanges are also the best embodiment of Taiwan's ideal of basing its national development on cultural heritage and creativity.

Noting that the robust development in creative cultural industries in recent years has brought new opportunities for Taiwan to expand its international presence, Chen said Taiwan has taken part in a world-class historic relic restoration project in Guatemala since 2005.

In addition, Chen said, Taiwan has cooperated with the Institute de France in presenting a culture award since 1996 and a UNESCO-affiliated international theater association has relocated its secretariat to Taiwan. To boost cultural exchanges with Russia, Chen said, an exhibition of literary works and relevant archives and artifacts of three great Russian writers is being held at the National Museum of Literature in Tainan.
"All these activities point to our commitment to promoting cultural development and fulfill its duties as an Global Village member in promoting world peace through cultural exchanges, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS YOUNG PEOPLE'S VOTING PREFERENCES

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's candidate for Taipei mayor, Hau Lung-bin, receives the highest level of support from young people in the city, followed by the Democratic Progressive Party's Frank Hsieh, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
While 26.2 percent of respondents favor Hau for Taipei mayor, Hsieh is supported by 14.7 percent.
Independent Lee Ao has a support rating of 11.7 percent, independent James Soong 6.6 percent, independent Ko Tzu-hai 3.4 percent and Taiwan Solidarity Union's Chou Yu-kuo 0.8 percent.
The survey was jointly conducted by 11 local civic groups led by the Taiwan Youth Right Promotion Alliance from Nov. 19-27 on 1,181 youths aged between 16 and 24 in Taipei City.
According to the alliance, the majority of Hau's supporters are in the 16-19 age group, while most of Soong's, Hsieh's and Lee's supporters are in the 20-24 age group.

The survey found that Hau received the highest approval in terms of his ability to resolve the problem of soaring tuition fees in the city's junior and senior high schools, his promise to provide subsidies for student groups, the importance he attaches to leisure space for youth, and his desire and ability to increase the city's budget for youth welfare.

Meanwhile, Hsieh obtained the highest approval in terms of his desire and ability to assist youth in participating in art and cultural activities, while Soong got the highest approval in terms of his promise to improve youth working rights and create more job opportunities for them, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC.3 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Dec. 3:
09:20, Premier Su Tseng-chang will attend a sports meet at Chungcheng Stadium in Kaohsiung City to mark the 40th anniversary of the export processing zone.
09:40, Vice President Annette Lu will attend a global Buddhist meeting to be held at Taipei Arena.
14:00, Taipei mayoral candidates will deliver televised campaign speeches at CTS headquarters.
17:10, President Chen Shui-bian will take part in a "hand-in-hand" rally along Kaohsiung City's landmark Ai River.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SETS HIGH GOAL FOR TAIWANESE IDENTITY PROMOTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday he is hopeful that the percentage of local citizens identifying themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese can reach 80 percent by the end of his term of office on May 20, 2008.
Chen made the remarks while hosting a dinner at the Taipei Guest House in honor of participants to the sixth World Taiwanese Congress which opened in Taipei earlier in the day.

Before he assumed the presidency in May 2000, Chen said only 20 percent to 30 percent of local people identified themselves as Taiwanese rather than Chinese. But the percentage already spiked to 60 percent in an opinion survey conducted by National Chengchi University's Election Study Center last month.

"Let's continue working together to promote Taiwan's self-identity. Hopefully, the percentage of local people identifying themselves as Taiwanese can hit 80 percent before the conclusion of my tenure in 2008," Chen said.

As normalization of Taiwan's statehood is the theme of this year's World Taiwanese Congress, Chen told his guests that Taiwan's recent political turmoil was rooted in difficulties in normalizing Taiwan's statehood.

"As a result, there is a polarized conflict over national identity in our society. And our constitution is unfit and irrelevant to our present national situation, which has in turn caused many unfavorable and even harmful impact on our country's transformation into a mature democracy," Chen said.
Nevertheless, Chen said he has consistently remained confident of Taiwan's democratic future.

"Over the past few months, some people have taken to the streets or even resorted to drastic measures to make known their appeals... However, our country has not paused or faltered over those vociferous protests. The government has continued implemented various policy initiatives, economic activities have remained on normal track and the stock market has become even more robust. Our democratic achievements and our people's democratic mannerism and resilience deserve applause, " Chen said.

The president was referring to a so-called "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign led Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, to force him to resign over a spate of corruption allegations implicating members of the first family and his close aides.

Chen has survived three opposition-initiated recall motions in the legislature. On Nov. 3, prosecutors indicted the first lady, Wu Shu-jen on charges of embezzling NT$14.8 million from a special "state affairs fund" budgeted for the president's discretionary use, and Chen could face the same charges when his immunity from prosecution lapses after he leaves office in May 2008.

The president has denied any wrongdoing, insisting that history will return justice to him and judicial process will clear his name. But he promised to step down if his wife is found guilty in the first trial. The district court will open the first hearing on the case Dec. 15.

In his Saturday speech, Chen told participants to the Taiwanese World Congress that freedom and rule of law are two of a kind and that successful liberal societies tend to protect freedom with consistent and impartial rule of law.
"Now that Taiwan is a liberal democracy, we should abide by the law and follow due process of law, including recalling a president and rewriting the Constitution," Chen said.

Noting that crisis often offers opportunity for reform and development, Chen said that despite the recent political disturbances, he will never back off his promise of carrying out constitutional re-engineering.

"I'll do my utmost during the remainder of my term in office to promote constitutional reform and craw up a constitutional system that is fit and relevant to Taiwan's present status quo, " Chen said, adding that glorifying Taiwan's national identity, defending its sovereignty, dignity and security as well as warding off any change to the peaceful status quo in the Taiwan Strait are his unshirkable missions as the country's head of state.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BAGS BRONZE IN WOMEN'S TRAP ON 1ST DAY OF ASIAN GAMES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's shooting ace Lin Yi-chun captured a bronze medal Saturday in the women's individual trap competition of the 15th Asian Games being held in Doha, the capital of the tiny but wealthy desert country in the Middle East.
It was the first and only medal the Taiwan team, officially dubbed the Chinese Taipei team in the event, has won on the first official day of competition at the Asian Games.
Lin lost to two Chinese athletes -- gold medalist Chen Li and silver medalist Zhu Mei.
The Chinese dominated the shooting range, winning all six gold medals. They won the team and individual events in all three categories -- the men's and women's 10m air rifle and the women's trap.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's baseball team trounced the Thai squad 16-0 Saturday to claim its second win in the round robin. The victory followed a win over South Korea 4-2 Thursday.
In men's basketball, Taiwan lost to Japan 75-85 in Group B competition. Only the top four teams in each group will be eligible to enter quarterfinals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 3, or the 13th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS YOUNG PEOPLE'S VOTING PREFERENCES(repeat)

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's candidate for Taipei mayor, Hau Lung-bin, receives the highest level of support from young people in the city, followed by the Democratic Progressive Party's Frank Hsieh, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.
While 26.2 percent of respondents favor Hau for Taipei mayor, Hsieh is supported by 14.7 percent.
Independent Lee Ao has a support rating of 11.7 percent, independent James Soong 6.6 percent, independent Ko Tzu-hai 3.4 percent and Taiwan Solidarity Union's Chou Yu-kuo 0.8 percent.
The survey was jointly conducted by 11 local civic groups led by the Taiwan Youth Right Promotion Alliance from Nov. 19-27 on 1,181 youths aged between 16 and 24 in Taipei City.
According to the alliance, the majority of Hau's supporters are in the 16-19 age group, while most of Soong's, Hsieh's and Lee's supporters are in the 20-24 age group.

The survey found that Hau received the highest approval in terms of his ability to resolve the problem of soaring tuition fees in the city's junior and senior high schools, his promise to provide subsidies for student groups, the importance he attaches to leisure space for youth, and his desire and ability to increase the city's budget for youth welfare.

Meanwhile, Hsieh obtained the highest approval in terms of his desire and ability to assist youth in participating in art and cultural activities, while Soong got the highest approval in terms of his promise to improve youth working rights and create more job opportunities for them, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING INT'L PRESENCE VIA CULTURAL EXCHANGES: PRESIDENT(repeat)

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday Taiwan looks forward to expanding its international presence through increased cultural exchanges with other countries.

Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at a happy get-together of foreign students studying at local universities or graduate institutes on scholarships offered by the Republic of China government.
The get-together, organized by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , is aimed at fostering goodwill and friendship with Taiwan scholarship recipients, Chen said.

The MOFA began to offer scholarships in 2003 to encourage foreign youths to pursue tertiary education in Taiwan as part of its efforts to forge closer links with the international community through cultural exchanges.

The number of recipients of the MOFA-sponsored Taiwan scholarships has reached about 500. This is the first time that the MOFA has hosted a party for all scholarship recipient students to get together for an evening of amusement and entertainment.
Many foreign students performed their country's folm music and dances at the evening party. Resident ambassadors and representatives of various countries were also invited to attend the get-together.
While geographic boundaries and political limitations tend to exist among countries around the world, Chen said cultural exchanges can be freely without any off-limits.

"We believe that arts, music, dances and other cultural activities can be the best vehicle for sharing feelings and aesthetic experiences and forging international partnerships, " Chen said, adding that such exchanges are also the best embodiment of Taiwan's ideal of basing its national development on cultural heritage and creativity.

Noting that the robust development in creative cultural industries in recent years has brought new opportunities for Taiwan to expand its international presence, Chen said Taiwan has taken part in a world-class historic relic restoration project in Guatemala since 2005.

In addition, Chen said, Taiwan has cooperated with the Institute de France in presenting a culture award since 1996 and a UNESCO-affiliated international theater association has relocated its secretariat to Taiwan. To boost cultural exchanges with Russia, Chen said, an exhibition of literary works and relevant archives and artifacts of three great Russian writers is being held at the National Museum of Literature in Tainan.
"All these activities point to our commitment to promoting cultural development and fulfill its duties as an Global Village member in promoting world peace through cultural exchanges, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Reform panel eyes teacher improvement
A Japanese government panel on education reform will propose measures next month to help improve the quality of teachers in a bid to "rebuild" the education system, panel sources said Saturday.

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Church to Settle with 45 Accusers.
Cardinal Roger M. Mahony said Friday that the Los Angeles Archdiocese had agreed to pay US$60 million to 45 people who said they were abused by Roman Catholic priests-- a payout that would be among the highest per person since the clergy sex abuse scandal exploded four years ago.

Manila Bulletin: Hopes of finding survivors dim
More rescuers rushed yesterday to an eastern Philippine province devastated by mudslides triggered by a powerful typhoon that killed almost 500 people, despite waning hopes of recovering more survivors.

PADANG, Legazpi City -- No one will probably know for sure how many lives were swallowed up in the torrents of volcanic mud and rocks unleashed by Supertyphoon "Reming" (international name: Durian) but the man who should know, Philippine National Red Cross chief Sen. Richard Gordon, said the figure could reach 700.
