Hours of torrential rains and heavy winds were terrifying enough for Benjamin Luga, 70, and his wife Elizabeth, 62 on that fateful Thursday night.
The Manila Times: Death, destruction mount in the aftermath of 'Reming'
LEGAZPI CITY, Albay: Rescuers arrived in this devastated Philippines city on Saturday as officials warned there would be few survivors from giant mudslides which swept away entire villages, killing hundreds.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP DECLINES TO SPECULATE ON MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu declined Sunday to speculate on how the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will fare in next weekend's municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.

Lu said that she usually has a good intuition about which DPP candidates will win but that she really has no idea about this year's mayoral and city council elections to be held in Taipei in northern Taiwan and Kaohsiung in the south Dec. 9.
Lu made the comments while attending a campaign rally to stump for Taipei City Council candidate Huang Hsiang-chun and mayoral candidate Frank Hsieh.

On the lower public interest in the elections compared to previous elections, Lu said that this could be due to the fact that Taiwan's democracy has become more mature, noting that it is natural for voters in a mature democracy not to show as much enthusiasm as voters in newly democratic countries.

Meanwhile, Lu criticized incumbent Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , as "having spent most of his time over the past eight years entertaining the media by constantly changing his outfits instead of performing his role as the mayor of Taiwan's capital."

Noting that 12,500 of Taiwan's 85,000 low-income households are located in Taipei City, Lu said that it is clear that having the KMT run the municipal government has not been a blessing for Taipei residents.
Lu urged Taipei residents to vote for Frank Hsieh, who she said has experience turning Kaohsiung City into a modern and beautiful municipality during his time as mayor of the southern port city.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL NOT CEASE EFFORTS TO CONSOLIDATE 'PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE': WHIP

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) will continue efforts to consolidate the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) to ensure a pan-blue victory in the Dec. 9 mayoral election in Taipei, a KMT lawmaker said Sunday.

Tsai Chin-lung, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, told reporters that both KMT and PFP leaders are aware that most pan-blue supporters want the two opposition parties to present only one candidate in the election.

Although the KMT has fielded the most hopeful candidate in the race -- former Environmental Protection Administration Chief Hau Lung-bin -- PFP Chairman James Soong is running as an independent, raising concerns about a split pan-blue vote.

The Taipei mayoral election is a six-way race that includes three independent candidates. Polls over the past three months have shown Hau leading all other candidates in voter approval ratings at above 40 percent.

Soong's ratings have been between 8 percent and 11 percent, while the ratings of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate, former Premier Frank Hsieh, have been between 15 percent and 20 percent.
Pan-blue supporters have urged KMT and PFP leaders to sort out their differences to ensure a pan-blue victory in the Taipei mayoral election.
KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said the leaders of the KMT and the PFP both know the importance of consolidation within the "pan-blue alliance" and that the question now is how to do it.
Lai said the KMT will not cease its efforts in this regard to the very end.
In related news, media reports Sunday said KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou had a secret meeting with his PFP counterpart for four hours late Friday night in an attempt to thrash out their differences.

While a KMT spokesman declined to comment on the reports, PFP Chairman Soong neither confirmed nor denied that the meeting took place, saying only that news media should verify the report with whatever source that provided them with the information.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HAILS EPZ CONTRIBUTION TO TAIWAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang praised Sunday the great contribution made by Taiwan's nine export processing zones to the country's economic development, encouraging them to keep on moving and create a new economic miracle for the country.

Su made the remarks while attending a sports meet sponsored by the Export Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) at the Chungcheng Stadium in Kaohsiung city to mark the 40th anniversary of the establishment of Taiwan's first export processing zone in this southern port city.

Su was accompanied by Minister of Economic Affairs Steve Ruey-long Chen and EPZA Director- General Tseng Sheng-bao on the occasion. The number of export processing zones has increased to nine across Taiwan, and their contribution to the country's economic prowess has been remarkable, Su said, urging them to continue playing a key role in Taiwan's economic expansion.

According to MOEA statistics, a total of more than 70,000 workers are employed in the nine export processing zones, which together generate over NT$370 billion (US$11.4 billion) in business revenue per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKS ON TAIWAN-MACAU AVIATION PACT RENEWAL POSTPONED AGAIN

TEXT.P: Review and negotiations on an aviation pact between Taiwan and Macau were postponed once again last month, marking the third postponement since 2005, officials said Sunday.

Confirming the postponement, officials from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) and the private Taipei Air Transport Business Association (TATBA) said it is up to the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to determine whether and when a meeting of air carriers' representatives from Taiwan and Macau will be held to have the pact renewed.

Talks on Taiwan's flight rights with foreign countries are usually handled by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, but flight rights talks between Taiwan and Hong Kong as well as Taiwan and Macau have been handled by the MAC as such talks involve cross-Taiwan Strait affairs.

The Taiwan-Macau aviation pact was first signed by the TATBA and Air Macau -- the territory's only airline -- on Nov. 30, 1995, with the pact being in effect for five years and subject to further alterations to adapt to the needs of both sides.
MAC officials took part in the 2000 negotiations in their capacity as TATBA consultants.

The new round of pact renewal talks were originally scheduled to be held in November 2005 but were postponed to May 30 this year. However, as May 30 approached, the negotiators from the two sides decided that the meeting should be postponed again.

CAA Director-General Chang Kuo-cheng confirmed that he was instructed by the MAC authorities recently to inform the Executive Yuan that the Taiwan-Macau aviation pact review had been postponed for a third time.
TATBA Chairman Fan Chih-chiang also traveled to Macau recently and reached a consensus with Air Macau officials on the postponement, according to the TATBA authorities.

Under the existing pact, passenger capacity on the Taipei-Macau route was increased by 8,000 per week. Half of the additional passenger capacity was allotted to Air Macau, and the other half was divided between EVA Airways and TransAsia Airways -- the two Taiwan carriers providing flight services on the route.
Neither Chang nor Fan would confirm whether Taiwan plans to ask in future talks for an increase in cargo volume for Taiwan carriers and an inclusion of a Taichung-Macau route in the pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SOCIAL WELFARE GROUPS FORGE 'LOVE FRONT' TO HELP DROPOUTS

TEXT.P: Five social welfare groups in Taipei City have sought to forge a " Love Front " and will hold a fundraising charity evening party in the city Dec. 14 to help school dropouts, an organizer said Sunday.

The " Love Front" is being formed by the Good Friend Mission Center, the Born Anew Youth Caring Association, the Garden of Hope Foundation, the Cheng Feng Teenager's School and the Yi Lin Teenager's School, said Chu Tai-shen, director-general of the Taipei Christian Church Association.

The five organizations will arrange social workers to offer a variety of services, such as dropout prevention, caring and consulting, special education assistance for dropouts and students planning to quit school around the city, he added.

Chu said that according to the new rules concerning junior high school students in Taipei City enacted by the city's Department of Education, schools are allowed to suspend students " unamenable to guidance " for two weeks. He said the five organizations are worried that the stipulation will empower the schools to drop students without informing the education authorities of their decisions.

The fundraising dinner will take place at Fu Shiang Yuan Restaurant at the Taipei City Council hall, Chu said, inviting the public to join the charity activity. He added that the purchase of just one ticket to the activity can help a dropout get back into school and a couple of dropouts receive relevant assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASTER'S CALLIGRAPHIC WORKS ON DISPLAY IN HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 3 (CNA) (By Chen Semy and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A nine-day exhibition of Buddhist Master Hsing Yun's calligraphic works opened Sunday at Hong Kong Central Library, on the eighth stop of the exhibition's world tour.
Hundreds of people lined up to enter the library Sunday ahead of the opening of the exhibition, according to a source at the library.

The exhibition features 200 calligraphic works selected from a wide array of works by Master Hsing Yun, founder of the Fo Guang Shan Foundation for Buddhist Culture and Education, and grouped into three periods, the source said.

During the exhibition, the 80-year-old master will preside over an event to propagate Dharma in Hong Kong for the last time and will never make a public appearance or receive visitors thereafter, according to the source.
The exhibition's next stop will be Hong Kong University, before moving on to China, Taiwan and Australia early next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU SCIENCE PARK EXPANDING AREA TO ACCOMMODATE MORE COMPANIES

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park has continuously expanded its area in a bid to accommodate more high-technology companies, a ranking official of Taiwan's "Silicon Valley" said Sunday.
As of the end of November, only 0.5 hectares of land under the HSP jurisdiction were available for new operations, said Ho You-chung, secretary-general of the HSIP Administration.

In addition to expanding its territory, Ho said, the science park has also decided to renew or revitalize existing HSP land -- part of which has been left unused as some factories have closed up shop.

A total of 393 companies have made HSP their manufacturing base as of the end of September this year, Ho said, adding that this year alone, 43 new companies have moved in or are preparing to move in after their applications were approved.

An urban development plan and an environmental assessment on an area of 35 hectares near the park was approved last month, paving the way for three major semiconductor manufacturers -- namely Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Vanguard International Semiconductor Corp. and Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. -- to build five new 12-inch wafer foundries, according to Ho.
Meanwhile, Ho said, another area of 100 hectares in Tungluo in the adjacent Miaoli County have also been approved to be developed into HSP factory areas.
This new Tungluo base, according to Ho, will mainly be developed to house manufacturers of high-end testing and packaging techniques as well as IC design companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Berlusconi: I shall return.
Silvio Berlusconi staged a vigorous return to the political foray on a major rally organized by the opposition alliance "House of Liberty" in Rome in protest against the planned government budget bill for the next year. More than two million people participated in the gathering, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CLOSED-DOOR HELD MEETING BETWEEN MA, SOONG: KMT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Communication between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) has been frequent and smooth, and there is no need for the two parties to hold a closed-door meeting, KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen said Sunday.

Huang made the comments in this southern port city, where KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou was stumping for the party's candidate, Huang Chun-ying, in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral election, after a newspaper reported that Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong had met for four hours in a closed-door meeting late Friday.

According to the report, Ma and Soong, who is running as an independent in the Dec. 9 Taipei mayoral election, discussed "put-out mechanisms" and bilateral cooperation after the mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Huang refuted the report and stressed that no such meeting took place between the chairmen of the KMT and the PFP -- which together form the opposition "pan-blue alliance."
"As Soong seems determined to run until the end in the Taipei mayoral race, it is impossible for the KMT to ask him to withdraw from the race now," Huang said.
"The two parties are engaged in a gentlemen's race and they will not make any deal in exchange for Soong's withdrawal from the Taipei mayoral election," he added.
Meanwhile, Soong was reluctant to respond to reporters' questions about the issue, only reiterating that the PFP stands firm in its position of cooperating with the KMT.
According to Soong, he has no idea how news of a meeting came out.
"If elected mayor of Taipei, I promise to do my best to serve Taipei citizens and support the KMT to win back power in the 2008 presidential election," Soong said.
Meanwhile, Hau Lung-bin, the KMT candidate in the coming Saturday's Taipei mayoral election, expressed his strong belief that he will win the contest as Ma is fully supportive of him.

Many pan-blue supporters are concerned that Soong and Hau might split the pan-blue vote, thus paving the way for victory by former Premier Frank Hsieh -- the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI BONE MARROW CENTER LINKS UP WITH U.S., GERMAN COUNTERPARTS

TEXT.P: The Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Research Center, the largest of its kind in Asia, has linked up with its two largest counterparts in the world -- which are located in the United States and Germany, respectively -- to better serve blood disease patients globally, an official of the center said Sunday.

After linking up with the U.S. national bone marrow program, which ranks as the largest in the world with the data of six million donors, and the German bone marrow bank, which is the world's second largest with the data of some three million donors, the Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Research Center now has access to over 10 million donors' data worldwide and is in turn contributing to forming a much larger bone marrow databank to help blood disease patients, the Tzu Chi official said.
Bone marrow transplant is currently the most effective treatment for blood diseases like leukemia and serious anemia.

The Tzu Chi Bone Marrow and Stem Cell Research Center -- a subsidiary of the Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation founded by Master Sheng Yen -- now boasts 290,000 samples, the Tzu Chi official said.

The center currently runs five departments: an immunogenetics laboratory, an umbilical cord blood bank, a clinical medicine research department, a donor activity and outreach department, and a database and administrative department.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALES OF COMPLETED HOMES IN TAIWAN UP IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Sales of completed homes in Taiwan in November increased 29.8 percent in value over the same month last year, according to statistics released Sunday by Sinyi Real Estate Inc., Taiwan's largest housing agent.
Chang Hsin-min, an assistant manager at Sinyi's planning and research division, noted that the November sales of completed homes also rose 14.2 percent in value over October.
Chang explained that in terms of the number of transactions, the November sales were up only 1.4 percent from the same month in 2005 and 4.6 percent from October.
This is due to the fact that the average price of a completed home sold in November went up by 9.1 percent to up about NT$9.43 million, compared with the average price in October, he added.

Chang predicted that sales of completed homes in December will continue to be brisk as a result of seasonal factors. He explained that many young people like to get married before ushering in the new year, creating a new wave of home buyers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL FORECASTS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH AT 4.5% FOR 2007

TEXT.P: A Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) official disclosed Sunday that the council forecasts Taiwan's economic growth for 2007 will exceed 4.5 percent, higher than the forecasts made by several major economic think tanks.
The Cabinet-level council will hold a meeting to discuss the forecast Monday before revealing it as part of the council's views about Taiwan's economic outlook, the official said.

A forecast of 4.5 percent is higher than the International Monetary Fund's forecast of 4.2 percent, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics' figure of 4.14 percent, the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research's forecast of 4.14 percent, the Asian Development Bank's prediction of 4 percent growth, and Global Insight's figure of 3.6 percent.

Global Insight's growth forecast for the global economy for 2007 is 3.3 percent, with the economies of Taiwan's main export markets slowing down. The xxxx forecasts that China's growth will drop from 10.5 percent this year to 9.2 percent in 2007, while the United States' will decline from 3.3 percent to 2.4 percent, and Japan's will slide from 2.5 percent to 2.1 percent.

Asked whether the council's forecast is relatively optimistic in the face of decreasing foreign trade and declining consumption, the official noted the Executive Yuan will put forth a set of five projects to boost the economy, with the first part to be launched next year, which he said should help allay relevant concerns.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2007 A GOOD YEAR FOR SKYWATCHERS IN TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan will be able to see one partial solar eclipse and two total lunar eclipses in 2007, plus a number of meteor showers, according to the Astronomical Observatory of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

Information provided by the observatory shows that people in Taiwan will be able to see the whole process of the partial solar eclipse on March 19, and part of the processes of the two total lunar eclipses on March 4 and Aug. 28.
The observatory also indicated that Taiwan will be an ideal place to watch meteor showers next year, with most of these celestial events concentrated in the second half of the year.
Among these meteor showers, the one radiating from the constellation Perseus on the night of Aug. 13 and those streaming from the constellation Gemini Dec. 14-15 will be the most worth watching.

Other meteor showers visible to people in Taiwan next year include: the Lyrid meteor shower, flowing from the constellation Lyra, on the night of April 23, the Aquarid meteor shower July 28, the Orionid meteor shower Oct. 21, and the Leonid meteor shower on Dec. 18.

A meteor shower occurs when large amounts of small fragments from cosmic debris enter the Earth's atmosphere at extremely high speed within a short period of time, leaving a streak of light that disappears quickly.
Most of the cosmic debris fragments are smaller than a grain of sand, so almost all the fragments burn up in the atmosphere and never reach the Earth's surface.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL RELIGIOUS EXPO OPENS IN YUNLIN

TEXT.P: A national religious exposition, the sixth of its kind, opened Sunday in central county of Yunlin.
According to Magistrate Su Chih-feng, the eight-day religious exposition will feature one religion each day, ranging from Christianity to Taoism.
The main theme of this year's religious exposition will focus on the prevention of suicide in the pursuit of a purified society through religious strength, Su said.
Su expressed her welcome for all families across Taiwan to take part in the activities, including three courses on suicide prevention training, to show their care and concern for every life.
More than 10 troupes kicked off the opening in the streets of Touliu city with acrobatics and martial arts, attracting large crowds despite the low temperatures.
Leaders from the various religions will also light up a lamp in a gesture to pray for peace and love for the Taiwan people.
In an effort to lure a larger number of youth, hip hop and jazz groups, folk arts troupes and a fair of speciality products will also be organized on the sidelines of the religious exposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 PEOPLE KILLED IN BUS ACCIDENT IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: A bus carrying a group of tourists from Kaohsiung to Tainan plunged into a ravine near the Meiling Scenic Area in Nansi, Tainan County, killing 20, and injurring 23 on board according to police in that southern Taiwan county.
The accident took place at 4.40 p.m. The bus plunged into a 20 meters-deep ravine, Ninteen of the 43 people on board died on the spot, while another one died later at the hospital.
Among those killed, four were children. Several of the 23 injured were in deep coma when rushed to nearby hospitals.
The holiday-makers on the bus are commissioners of the Parents' Commission of the Tinghsing Elementary School in Kaohsiung City and their family members.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LOVE FOR KAOHSIUNG AND TAIWAN' RALLY STAGED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A rally organized by a dozen pro-independence groups led by the Taiwan Society to "show love for the island" was staged in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan Sunday evening, bringing together almost all Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) leaders.

The participants, mainly followers of the ruling DPP, began streaming into the venue of the rally along the banks of the Love River between the Kaohsiung Bridge and Chungcheng Bridge in downtown Kaohsiung. By 5: 20 p.m. when the rally formally began, some 100,000 people had already gathered, according to the organizers.

In addition to President Chen Shui-bian, also attending were Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and President Chen's son, Chen Chih-chung, who returned from New York with his pregnant wife Friday night to preempt critics' claims that they were planning to have their first child born in the United States in order to get U.S. citizenship for their child.
Frank Hsieh, DPP's mayoral candidate in Taipei City who had served as the Kaohsiung mayor between 1998 and 2005 also appeard at the site on 7 p.m.

At the request of the master of ceremony, the participants in the rally joined their hands to form a human chain of three to four persons deep along the river "to show their love for the river, the city and the island," according the organizers.

Although the rally was aimed at allowing people to show their love for Taiwan, almost all the speakers at the gathering showered praise on the ruling party, which has controlled the Kaohsiung city hall for the last eight years, for cleaning up the Love Rive and stumped votes for the party's mayoral candidate, Chen Chu.
President Chen and Vice President Lu flashed the figure five, referring to Chen Chu's ballot number, repeatedly during their speeches, to woo support for the ruling party's candidate.
They also railed against the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , whose candidate, Huang Chun-ying, is engaged in a neck-and-neck race with Chen Chu.

Chen Chu was invited to make a speech at the rally, during which she blamed the KMT for turning the Love River into a "dirty ditch" during its five decades in power in the city. She said the DPP, since coming to power in the city eight years ago, has cleaned up the river and expanded the city's sewage system.
She appealed to the people at the rally to keep the DPP in power in Kaohsiung by voting for her in the election.
Meanwhile, four Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidates in the city council elections showed up at the rally despite the TSU's prohibiting any of the party's candidates from attending the gathering.
Chao Tien-lin, one of the four TSU candidates, said they just came to greet the people at the rally, and not to endorse Chen Chu's bid for the mayorship.

The TSU, an ally of the DPP in the Legislative Yuan, prohibited its candidates from attending the rally because the rally's organizers had tried to persuade TSU mayoral candidate Lo Chih-ming to withdraw from the race and to rally behind Chen Chu.

KMT candidate Huang Chun-ying didn't bother to attend the rally, claiming that the rally had been converted into a campaign rally for Chen Chu and that the DPP was trying to claim all the credit for cleaning up the river, even though the project to clean up the river started long before the DPP came to power in Kaohsung.

DOC.HEADLINE: 22 PEOPLE KILLED IN BUS ACCIDENT IN TAINANUPDATES CEP 0025 WITH NEW CASUALTIES, CHANGES DATELINE FOR'TAINAN' TO 'TAIPEI', CORRECTS THE NAME OF THE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL WHOSEPARENTS' COMMISSION MEMBERS INVOLVED IN THE ACCIDENT FROM 'TINGHSING'TO 'TINGCHIN', AND ADDS OTHER DETAILS.

TEXT.P: A bus carrying a group of tourists from Kaohsiung to Tainan plunged into a ravine near the Meiling Scenic Area in Nansi, Tainan County, killing 22, and injuring 24 on board according to a press release issued by the Ministry of Education in Taipei.
The accident took place at 4.40 p.m. The bus plunged into a 20 meters-deep ravine, Nineteen of the 46 people on board died on the spot, while another two died later at the hospital.
Among those killed, one was a child. Several of the 24 injured were in deep coma when rushed to nearby hospitals.

The holiday-makers on the bus are commissioners of the Parents' Commission of the Tingchin Elementary School in Kaohsiung City and their family members. They were on their way leaving the Meiling Scenic Area after a visit to Chimei Museum in Jenteh, Tainan County when their bus plunged into the ravine.
The accident was branded by the Directorate General of Highways under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications as the island's most serious one on highway in the last two decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-TERM JOB SEEKERS WON'T ACCEPT 'POOR SALARIES': POLL

TEXT.P: Poor salaries are the major reason behind the unemployment of most of Taiwan's long-term job seekers, a government survey has found.

According to the results of the latest survey made public by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), long-term job seekers -- those who have searched for work for over 1 year -- ask for an average monthly salary of NT$30,000 -- higher than the average level of NT$27,500 offered to most job applicants.

Some 50 percent of those polled said that they have been offered jobs, with 65 percent of these respondents mentioning "poor salaries" as the reason for turning down the job offers. Higher job requests and age limits were other prime reasons cited by the other half who have never worked, according to the poll.
The survey also showed that as of the end of May, job seekers had remained unemployed for an average 25.4 weeks, marking a drop of 4.2 weeks from the figure one year ago.

At the same time, about 55,000 job seekers, or 13.75 percent of the total, said that they had remained jobless for more than a year, marking a drop of 5.86 percent year on year -- or some 28,000 people.

Of the 55,000 long-term job seekers polled, 63 percent were male, with 54 percent of them aged between 25 and 44. High school and college graduates -- each category with 20,000 people -- formed the largest group among the long-term jobless.
Some 11,000 of the 55,000 long-term unemployed were first-time job seekers, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'LOVE FOR KAOHSIUNG AND TAIWAN' RALLY STAGED IN KAOHSIUNG(REPEAT)

TEXT.P: A rally organized by a dozen pro-independence groups led by the Taiwan Society to "show love for the island" was staged in Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan Sunday evening, bringing together almost all Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) leaders.

The participants, mainly followers of the ruling DPP, began streaming into the venue of the rally along the banks of the Love River between the Kaohsiung Bridge and Chungcheng Bridge in downtown Kaohsiung. By 5: 20 p.m. when the rally formally began, some 100,000 people had already gathered, according to the organizers.

In addition to President Chen Shui-bian, also attending were Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and President Chen's son, Chen Chih-chung, who returned from New York with his pregnant wife Friday night to preempt critics' claims that they were planning to have their first child born in the United States in order to get U.S. citizenship for their child.
Frank Hsieh, DPP's mayoral candidate in Taipei City who had served as the Kaohsiung mayor between 1998 and 2005 also appeard at the site on 7 p.m.

At the request of the master of ceremony, the participants in the rally joined their hands to form a human chain of three to four persons deep along the river "to show their love for the river, the city and the island," according the organizers.

Although the rally was aimed at allowing people to show their love for Taiwan, almost all the speakers at the gathering showered praise on the ruling party, which has controlled the Kaohsiung city hall for the last eight years, for cleaning up the Love Rive and stumped votes for the party's mayoral candidate, Chen Chu.
President Chen and Vice President Lu flashed the figure five, referring to Chen Chu's ballot number, repeatedly during their speeches, to woo support for the ruling party's candidate.
They also railed against the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) , whose candidate, Huang Chun-ying, is engaged in a neck-and-neck race with Chen Chu.

Chen Chu was invited to make a speech at the rally, during which she blamed the KMT for turning the Love River into a "dirty ditch" during its five decades in power in the city. She said the DPP, since coming to power in the city eight years ago, has cleaned up the river and expanded the city's sewage system.
She appealed to the people at the rally to keep the DPP in power in Kaohsiung by voting for her in the election.
Meanwhile, four Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) candidates in the city council elections showed up at the rally despite the TSU's prohibiting any of the party's candidates from attending the gathering.
Chao Tien-lin, one of the four TSU candidates, said they just came to greet the people at the rally, and not to endorse Chen Chu's bid for the mayorship.

The TSU, an ally of the DPP in the Legislative Yuan, prohibited its candidates from attending the rally because the rally's organizers had tried to persuade TSU mayoral candidate Lo Chih-ming to withdraw from the race and to rally behind Chen Chu.

KMT candidate Huang Chun-ying didn't bother to attend the rally, claiming that the rally had been converted into a campaign rally for Chen Chu and that the DPP was trying to claim all the credit for cleaning up the river, even though the project to clean up the river started long before the DPP came to power in Kaohsung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 4, or the 14th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTRIBUTE MORE IF PART OF WHO ACTIVITIES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that Taiwan will make a greater contribution to the world's health efforts if it is allowed to take part in more activities under the World Health Organization (WHO).

Chen said that although Taiwan is not a WHO member or observer, the country has upheld the universal principle of health rights and has made a contribution in line with the WHO's goals of "helping the poor and the weak."

Addressing the opening of the International Forum for Health Leaders held at the International Convention Center of the National Taiwan University Hospital, Chen said despite Taiwan's being expelled from the WHO in 1972 after the United Nations granted the China seat at the U.N. to the People's Republic of China, Taiwan has never relented in its efforts to participate in or push for global health endeavors.

Over the past 10 years in particular, Taiwan health authorities have surmounted various difficulties to implement a national health insurance program to cover virtually everyone in the country, Chen said. At the same time, he added, Taiwan has also actively taken part in international medical aid actions abroad, winning the hearts and minds of people around the world.

Taiwan's medical aid and first-aid personnel have taken part in major natural disaster relief efforts worldwide in recent years, including following the devastating tsunamis that struck South and Southeast Asia in late December 2004, and the major earthquakes that rocked Central Asia in 2005, the president said.

He added that Taiwan has contributed to efforts to arrest the spread of polio in Gambia, control HIV/AIDS in Malawi, expand medical facilities in Swaziland, and control the spread of malaria and cholera in Sao Tome and Principe.

Meanwhile, Chen offered his congratulations to Hong Kong bird flu expert Dr. Margaret Chan, who was officially appointed by the WHO in early November as the new WHO chief. He told Chan that Taiwan is more than willing to contribute efforts to support the new programs in six health areas that Chan is planning to promote worldwide.

Chen also called for the health leaders from around the world attending the meeting to strive harder in dealing with various major health issues, particularly suicide, obesity, chronic disease, drug abuse and seniors' care to help improve the well-being of people around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE KINMEN DELEGATION TO VISIT SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA

TEXT.P: A large Kinmen delegation will depart for Singapore and Malaysia Dec. 11 on a charter flight for a week-long visit with an aim of promoting cohesion among Kinmen compatriots living there.

The 170-odd delegation will be led by Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng and County Council Speaker Hsieh Yi-chang. Members will include county officials and councilors, as well as representatives from Kinmen associations and tourism organizations.
The delegation will first attend a celebration for the completion of the expansion of a Kinmen Association Hall as well as a Kinmen commodity and cultural exhibition in Singapore Dec. 13.

It will then attend a World Kinmen Day activity in the Malaysia capital Kuala Lumpur Dec. 15 and then a celebration marking the 60th anniversary of the founding of a Kinmen association in Klang, Selangor on the west coast of Malaysia Dec. 16 before returning home Dec. 18.
The Kinmen County government noted that number of Kinmen people residing overseas totals 740,000, with most of them living in Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei or the Philippines.

This will be the second time that the Kinmen County government uses charter flights after cooperating with tourism representatives to fly to Macau on a charter flight in September to promote the outlying island's special products and tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER REFUSES TO RELEASE MILITARY INSTRUCTOR

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Jye refused Monday to accede to opposition lawmakers' demands that the high school drillmaster detained on the charge of inciting "active duty servicemen to riot" in late November be released.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan Defense Committee, Lee said the case -- involving Army Maj. Tung Hua-cheng, a drillmaster at the Taibei High School in Shilin, who showed up Sept. 20 at the site of a "Million Voices Against Corruption" rally aimed at pushing for President Chen Shui-bian to step down -- is being handled by the military courts according to the law.

Tung wore his military uniform to the rally but apparently was trying to hide his identity with a face mask and a pair of sunglasses. At the rally, he displayed a letter he wrote to Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, saying that in the event of a war, the rank and file soldiers will "turn their guns inward."

The military instructor could face seven years in prison if convicted of inciting active duty servicemen to riot in violation of Article 16 of the Criminal Law of the Armed Forces, according to Military High Court prosecutors.

Noting that Tung is facing serious charges, Lee said that he cannot agree with the opposition lawmakers' calls for his release. He added that if lawmakers feel that Tung's human rights have been violated, they can file a petition with the commission charged to protect servicemen's rights under the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Opposition People First Party Legislator Chao Liang-yen asked the MND to release Tung immediately, claiming that military prosecutors had "illegally arrested" him. Chao argued that the offense of inciting active duty servicemen to riot only applies to actions that endanger the integrity of the nation's territory, are aimed at toppling the government, or involve the use of violence to threaten or coerce.
Chao argued that Tung did not commit any of these offenses through his actions at the rally.

Meanwhile, Lee said that he has not felt any pressure from "upstairs" since the officer's arrest and that the military has remained calm, with no signs that any "rank and file soldiers have been incited to riot."

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO REVIEW TOURIST BUS SAFETY REGULATIONS: MOTC

TEXT.P: Transportation authorities have begun a comprehensive review of existing measures and regulations concerning tourist bus-related traffic safety after a bus accident claimed 21 lives in southern Taiwan Sunday.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei said Monday at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting that the ministry is working to impose stricter restrictions on the maximum age of passenger buses and considering banning the use of retread tires on tourist buses.
A bus carrying a group of local tourists from Kaohsiung to Tainan plunged into a ravine near the Meiling Scenic Area in Nansi in Tainan County, Sunday, killing 21 and injuring all others on board.
The accident has been called by authorities the country's worst highway accident in 20 years.
A preliminary investigation has revealed that the bus was 18 years old and fitted with retread tires.

Although the use of retreads is not prohibited, most officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) believe it's time to upgrade measures in the management of retreads, with some suggesting banning tourist buses from using the tires, Tsai said.

Faced with lawmakers' concerns, Tsai also said efforts have been launched to screen all "risky roads" for sightseeing buses around the island. The ministry is scheduled to publicize a list of the roads within three months in an attempt to prevent a similar tragedy from occurring in the future.
According to MOTC statistics, there are a total of 11,925 tourist buses in Taiwan, 3,339 of which are over 12 years old.
In early October, a bus carrying 19 Chinese tourists plunged from a mountain road into a valley in the central county of Nantou, killing six people.

In light of the fact that the drivers of the buses in these two accidents had both had their bus licenses for less than three years, Tsai said the MOTC will begin in January of next year to activate a reporting system on the management of bus drivers.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO UNVEIL IMAGE PACKAGING EFFORTS FOR LOCAL FARM PRODUCE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level of Council of Agriculture (COA) is slated to unveil the results of an image packaging effort aimed at helping local farm product exports, a COA spokesman said Monday.

According to the spokesman, experts will give keynote speeches at Wednesday's unveiling, and local agricultural goods distributors have been invited to take part in the activity in which they can exchange views and share experiences with professionals.
Building a good image and creating a distinguished brand name will help a product create more added value and is an indispensable element in increasing sales in the world market, the spokesman said.

Since the COA and the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) began cooperating in 2002 to promete an image packaging and brand building campaign aimed at helping increase sales of Taiwan grown farm produce, 49 companies have seen their business revenues rise markedly through such efforts, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE FLU SHOTS AVAILABLE FOR PEOPLE AGED OVER 50

TEXT.P: From Dec. 1, a government-funded flu vaccination program will be further expanded to cover citizens aged 50 or over, officials from the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health said Monday.

Citizens aged 50 or over are urged to get free flu shots at public hospitals as soon as possible, since the vaccination rate this year has been low and the stock of flu vaccine doses remains high, said Liu Ting-ping, director of the CDC Vaccine Center.

Liu said that since the government started providing 2.24 million free flu vaccinations for the public Sept. 25 in preparation for the winter flu season, only about half of the people eligible for free vaccinations had received shots as of mid-November.

A study conducted by the CDC among 200,000 people vaccinated against the flu between 2003 and 2004 indicates that the ratio of hospitalization for pneumonia or influenza among those who received the shots was 40 percent lower than the ratio for those who were not vaccinated, while the risk of hospitalization for chronic respiratory diseases was 24 percent lower, they noted.

The CDC, after analyzing reported flu cases between 2000 and 2006, said the incidence of flu turning into serious disease among children under 12 years is four or five times the number among people over 65, while the mortality rate is also three of four times that of the elderly, far higher than other age groups.
Liu said Taiwan usually enters flu season around the end of November, with cases reaching a peak around Christmas.
According to Liu, the best way to prevent flu is to get flu shots.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS FAIL TO AGREE ON EASING CAP ON INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties bickered heatedly Monday at a legislative committee meeting over a draft statute revision to ease a 40-percent ceiling on investment in China.

With the views so diverse, Non-Partisan Solidarity Union Legislator Tsai Hao, who chaired the meeting, had tried in vain to smooth out the differences and had to leave the matter for later discussion.

At issue is the statute revision proposed by Legislator Lai Shyh-bao of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and 37 colleagues from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party. The lawmakers said the government's "active management, effective opening" policy regarding cross-Taiwan Strait trade runs counter to the principle of market forces and restricts the investment strategy of Taiwan businessmen.
Lai proposed that Taiwan businessmen only report their investment projects in China to the Ministry of Economic Affairs after six months and that the cap on investment should be eased.
He urged that investment projects in China be seen as general investment or cooperation projects without the requirement of prior approval.

Also, local businesses that have paid-in capital of NT$80 million (US$3.42 million) and a net worth of over NT$10 billion should have their investment cap for investment in China eased from the present 40 percent to 50 percent.

But Legislator Chao Yung-ching of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Legislator David Huang of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) opposed to the change vehemently, claiming that it would "hollow out" Taiwan's economy.
