DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 33.44 points to close at 7,647.01.
The bourse opened at 7,622.09 and fluctuated between 7,659.84 and 7,590.92 during trading. A total of 6.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.13 billion (US$3.93 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by textile stocks at 3.8 percent, construction issues at 3.7 percent, foodstuff issues at 3.5 percent, cement stocks at 3.2 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 1.8 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent.
Only one of the eight major stocks lost ground, with machinery and electronics shares moving down 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 775 to 478, with 153 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRILLMASTERS LEAVING CAMPUSES CAN BE DISCUSSED: DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The notion of pulling military drillmasters off campuses can be discussed and the Ministry of National Defense (MND) will ask the Executive Yuan to sponsor negotiations between the MND and the Ministry of Education (MOE) on the matter, Defense Minister Lee Jye said Monday.

Answering a question from opposition Kuomintang Legislator Kuo Su-chun on whether it is true that all drillmasters on campuses will be phased out by 2020 as noted recently by Education Minister Tu Cheng-sheng, Lee said Tu spelled out his ideas without consulting him in advance and that he had not discussed the issue with Tu.

Lee said the MND has pondered the necessity of posting drillmasters on college campuses but feels it is still necessary to post drillmasters in senior high schools to help "bolster the students' character education, provide counseling for students and maintain campus order and security."

Admitting, however, that the drillmaster system needs to be improved, Lee said the MND thinks that before military instructors are pulled off campuses once and for all, their quality should at least be upgraded. For example, he said, drillmasters should be asked to return to the military rank and file after working on college campuses or in high schools for two years in a bid to provide schools with the "best possible military and character education."

The drillmasters issue became a focus of attention Monday at the Legislative Yuan Defense Committee after Maj. Tung Hua-cheng, a drillmaster at the Taibei High School in Shilin, who attended a Sept. 20 "Million Voices Against Corruption" rally aimed at pushing for President Chen Shui-bian's ouster, was detained on the charge of inciting "active duty servicemen to riot" in late November.

At the rally, Tung allegedly displayed a letter he wrote to Lee, saying that in the event of a war, the army will "turn their guns inward." Tung could face seven years in prison if convicted of inciting active duty servicemen to riot in violation of Article 16 of the Criminal Law of the Armed Forces, according to Military High Court prosecutors.
Tu said recently that vacancies left by retiring drillmasters will be no longer be filled, with the goal of phasing out military officers on campuses by 2020.
Tu said universities should make courageous reforms now that the function of drillmasters "has been completed."
He pointed out that the job of military officers should be to defend the country rather than provide psychological counseling to children and said the job will be taken over by professionals.
According to MOE tallies, there are 1,420 drillmasters in universities and colleges around the country, approximately three-fifths of whom will have retired by 2014, with all of them gone by 2020.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ CLARIFIES FIRST EXECUTION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) clarified Monday that the first approved execution this year is not the one reported by a local newspaper.

Vice Justice Minister Lee Chin-yung was responding to a report carried by the United Daily News that Justice Minister Shih Mao-lin had approved the execution of Tseng Su-jui, who murdered a senior high school teacher after breaking into her residence in 2002.
Reports also said that after Shih approved the execution order, the High Prosecutor's Office should carry out the order within three days.
Lee said the ministry has adopted a very cautious attitude toward execution and has indeed approved an execution, although not Tseng's case.
Lee said lawyers have requested an investigation of the case to see about the possibility of filing an extraordinary appeal.
He pointed out that for all capital cases, the ministry will say clearly whether there is a possibility of an extraordinary appeal or retrial.
"The ministry will only cautiously consider approving an execution after all means are exhausted and there is still no chance of starting a retrial or filing an extraordinary appeal," Lee said.
Asked whether Taiwan will repeal the death sentence, Lee said it is a long-term goal for a nation founded on human rights.
He said the public have polarized views on scrapping the death penalty, adding that the matter will need long-term communications and campaigning to reach a consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUMORED KMT-PFP ALLIANCE ON HOLD

TEXT.P: The proposed formation of a new form of "political alliance" between the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) should wait until after the Dec. 9 elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities have finished, a KMT lawmaker said Monday.

Tsai Chin-lung, the KMT's whip at the Legislative Yuan, made the comments in response to speculation that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong have met to discuss "pullout mechanisms" as the mayoral and city council elections are to be held Saturday in the two special municipalities.

According to a China Times report, Ma and Soong met in a closed-door meeting late Friday to discuss Soong's withdrawal from the Taipei mayoral election in order to secure victory for Hau Lung-bin, the KMT's candidate in the race.

Soong might announce his pullout from the Taipei mayoral election, in which he is running as an independent, at the last minute and urge voters to cast their ballots for Hau, the report said, adding that in turn, the KMT agreed to allow Soong to serve as convener of a proposed KMT-PFP alliance -- a different one to the existing "pan-blue alliance" -- and to continue bi-partisan cooperation at the Legislative Yuan.
Tsai denied the report and argued that it is impossible for the two parties to exchange such terms with only five days left to go before the elections.

Ma did not discuss election issues with Soong and there is absolutely no deal between them on the pullout issue, Tsai claimed, adding that "the KMT won't do anything that could affect the elections now."

As to rampant speculation about the establishment of a new formal KMT-PFP political alliance, Tsai made it clear that "the KMT does not plan to do so at present" and that "it is better to talk about the matter after the Dec. 9 elections" as the KMT and the PFP have always been cooperative partners at the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.028 to close at NT$32.398.
A total of US$855 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.370 and fluctuated between NT$32.250 and NT$32.410.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 46 points to close at 7,658, with 32,018 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January increased 50 points to finish at 7,660, with 1,140 contracts traded, while March futures gained 39 points to end at 7,650, with 17 contract transactions. September futures moved up 57 points to close at 7,456, with 21 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,612 for December, 7,610 for January, 7,611 for March, 7,595 for June and 7,399 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.
December TE futures lost 0.4 points to close at 321.75, with 2,920 contracts traded, while January TE futures decreased 0.35 points to finish at 321.1, with 26 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures gained 7.4 points to close at 1,053, with 2,887 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 6.4 points to close at 1,050, with seven contracts traded. September TF futures decreased 12 points to end at 1,017, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOSPITAL SEEKING VOLUNTEER ASTHMA SUFFERERS FOR NUTRITIONAL THERAPY

TEXT.P: A hospital in the central city of Taichung is seeking volunteers with asthma to test the effectiveness of a nutritional and naturopathic therapy.

Liu Po-jen, director of the Ear, Nose and Throat Department at Cheng Ching Hospital's Chungkang branch, told reporters Monday that the therapy program is a joint effort between the hospital and Hungkuang University's Graduate School of Nutritional Medicine.
The hospital needs 30 asthma patients for the research project and an initial group of 15 volunteers who have accepted the therapy have shown satisfactory results, Liu said.

The hospital will recruit 15 more volunteers with asthma who will receive a free two-month course of treatment with nutrients known to have a beneficial effect on asthma management. The volunteers must be 15 years old or over and have no other complications, Liu added.
Asthma patients interested in joining the program can call the hospital at (04)2463-2000.

Asthma is a complex disease of the respiratory system that is influenced by multiple genetic, developmental and environmental factors. Its symptoms include wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness and coughing.

In the past two decades, scientists have tried to link particular nutrients to asthma. While some studies have examined both the suboptimal status of particular nutrients as causes of asthma, others have tried to use nutritional supplements as therapy for the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL HEALTH LEADERS DISCUSS HEALTH SUSTAINABILITY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Health leaders from more than 40 countries met in a global forum in Taipei Monday to discuss health sustainability and Taiwan's participation and roles in international health affairs.
The forum, with the theme of "Sustainability of Global Health" is taking place at the National Taiwan University Hospital International Convention Center from Dec. 4-6.

President Chen Shui-bian said in an opening address that while Taiwan is not a World Health Organization (WHO) member or observer, it would be able to make a greater contribution to global health if it were allowed to take part in more WHO activities.

Taiwan and the rest of the world did not realize the importance of public health and the impact of a major disease until the SARS outbreak of 2003, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mou claimed.
According to him, it was not until then that the world came to know that a major disease could affect global economic development.

Taiwan and the world are facing "unprecedented challenges" in terms of public health as the issues of AIDS, SARS, avian influenza, other diseases and suicide have either worsened or could return at any time, Hou said, making global collaboration necessary.

The forum discussed topics such as strategic planning for major diseases, regional and global health security, opportunities and challenges facing the health sector, international health law and policy, and Taiwan's participation and roles in global health.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Police to quiz poison suspects in Moscow
Scotland Yard detectives will fly out to Moscow this week to question a number of Russian businessmen who they believe include a leading suspect in the plot to poison Alexander Litvinenko.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
International Herald Tribune : Chavez wins easily in Venezuela.
President Hugo Chavez was re-elected in a landslide on Sunday night, as voting tallies began pouring in from throughout the country. But campaign officials for the opposition candidate contended that the results were tainted by intimidation and other irregularities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEWAY TRAFFIC POLICE TO STEP UP CRACKDOWN ON HARD SHOULDER DRIVING

TEXT.P: Traffic police will step up a crackdown on the practice of using the hard shoulder of freeways to overtake, Taiwan National Freeway Bureau officials said Monday.

Bureau officials said that according to newly revised regulations, the fines for using the hard shoulder in violation of the traffic regulations will be between NT$3,000 and NT$6,000 (US$90.9-US$181.8).

It took a car accident involving Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and his wife Shao Hsiao-ling Nov. 18 to goad the police into making the move. Hu's minivan overturned when a vehicle tried to overtake it on the hard shoulder as he was returning to Taichung after campaign stumping in Kaohsiung. Shao, who had to have her left arm amputated and her spleen removed, was still unconscious at the Chi Mei Medical Center in Liuying, Tainan County.

The officials said past freeway crackdowns have focused on speeding, but tallies by freeway traffic police show that hard shoulder driving in violation of traffic regulations account for between 2,000 and 7,000 cases per month, representing between 3 percent and 7 percent of all violations.

As these violations have a great impact on traffic safety, police will from now on focus on speeding, not keeping a safe distance, driving on the hard shoulder without legitimate reasons and changing lanes recklessly, the officials said.

They noted that the hard shoulders of the freeways are for use only under special circumstances or during the execution of official duties or rescue operations by ambulances, police cars and other official vehicles.

Meanwhile, the director of the intensive care unit at the Chi Mei Medical center, said Shao's Glasgow coma scale has improved to 11 from two when she arrived at the hospital, and added that if her condition remains stable for the next one or two weeks, Hu might be able to consider transferring his wife to a hospital closer to their home in central Taiwan.
Dr. Hou Ching-cheng said that apart from her naso-gastric feeding tube, she no longer relies on her life-support system.

Shao can now make a little sounds and react to pain. Her medical team will continue to give her stimuli to awaken her senses of smell, hearing, vision and touch, in the hope of efficiently upgrading her brain function.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP LU UNVEILS PLANS TO OFFER FREE CLASSES FOR POOR CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Monday plans to open free evening classes for grade school children from underprivileged families in every village across the country.
Lu made the pledge during a speech at an informal meeting at the Presidential Office, attended by representatives of more than 20 village and township chiefs across the country.

Stressing that the move would be an activity whose scope goes beyond political differences, Lu said she will ask Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a member of the main opposition Kuomintang, to jointly promote the cause.
Lu also called on widespread support for the campaign, saying it is an initiative far more important to society as a whole than election campaigns.

According to Lu, the program aims to open more than 1,000 after-school auxiliary classes in 2007, with the first 100 beginning during the coming winter vocation for children from low-income, single parent or poor aboriginal families.

Getting an adequate education is key for impoverished children to overcome the effects of poverty, and the planned extra night classes aim to provide them with a public and therefore free opportunity to study and learn more.
She called on private or public authorities to offer free sites for the classes and urged retired schoolteachers, public servants and college students to serve as hourly-paid instructors.
Each class will comprise no more than 20 children and receive monetary assistance of NT$100,000 per semester, she explained.

Charitable organizations, such as the Rotary International Club, Kiwanis International and local women's rights groups have promised to raise funds for the campaign -- about NT$200 million (US$6.15 million) for the first year, Lu said.

In addition, the vice president said, she is also projecting the construction of residential communities for the silver-haired population. As Taiwan's population is rapidly aging, it is a matter worth very close attention, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DOCTORS FINED FOR PRESCRIBING MEDICINE WITHOUT DIAGNOSIS

TEXT.P: Health authorities in the capital city of Taipei imposed fines Monday in 69 cases where doctors had prescribed medicine for patients without actually diagnosing their ailments first.

Taipei city's Department of Health revealed the identities of the doctors and the hospitals they work for. Twenty-five of these doctors are being fined NT$20,000 for writing prescriptions without first examining their patients -- a violation of the Physicians' Law.

Kao Wei-chun, director of the department's Medical Affairs Division, said most of these unlawful prescriptions were made by dermatologists, ophthalmologists and internists, mainly for the convenience of their patients.
She pointed out that the Physicians Law only allows doctors to prescribe medicine to patients living in remote areas in urgent cases.

Doctors may also renew a previous prescription for patients with chronic ailments who have difficulty moving around, but prescribing medicine to all other patients without diagnosing them first is a violation of the law, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN UNIVERSITY OF ARTS TO HOST ARTS FORUM

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan University of Arts will organize an international arts forum Dec. 7 with art college presidents expected to attend from many parts of the world, an organizer announced Monday.

The university's president, Huang Kuang-nan, said the presidents or deans of several art universities from France, Japan, Australia, South Korea and the United Kingdom will meet in northern Taipei County to discuss cultural creativity and the arts.

The participants will introduce their schools and share their visions and ideas for the arts, Huang said, adding that the forum is aimed at helping local people understand global trends and enhance Taiwan's competitiveness in the field.

The Taiwan University of Arts has set the theme of "Advance, Balance and Creativity" for the event, Huang said, pointing out that art schools are facing the dilemma of developing cultural creative industries while preserving traditional culture.
Huang said it is important for these schools to find their positions and understand their strengths and weaknesses in order to develop their uniqueness.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Report Faults Training of Afghan Police
Five years after the fall of the Taliban, a joint report by the Pentagon and the State Department has found that the American- trained police force in Afghanistan is largely incapable of carrying out routine law enforcement work, and that managers of the $1.1 billion training program cannot say how many officers are actually on duty or where thousands of trucks and other equipment issued to police units have gone.
Wall Street Journal: Affluent Families Have Ways to Sway School Assignments
In Seattle, a group of white parents sued after their children were denied admission to a coveted, majority-white school. They argue school boards go too far to achieve racial integration, but a close look shows that assignment practices often work to the benefit of whites.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN MAYOR TOUTS WATCHING MIGRATORY BIRDS

TEXT.P: Now until March is the best time to watch migratory birds at the Sihcao wetlands in southern Tainan City, as flocks of migratory birds arrive to winter in the area, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair said Monday.
Hsu made the remarks at an event to promote watching migratory birds at the Sihcao Ecological and Cultural Zone, an important stopover site for migratory birds.
He said the Sihcao salt marshes are renowned by birdwatchers because of their rich habitat for a variety of wintering migratory birds, including the famous but endangered black-faced spoonbill.

He said visitors can not only observe the migratory birds but can also enjoy tours of the area's salt fields, an aquarium that has earned a reputation for its whales and dolphins, and oyster farms at the estuary of the Luermenghsi Creek, also known as Taichiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG COUNTY CULTURE CENTER HOLDS STORYTELLING CONTEST

TEXT.P: The Taichung County Culture Center in central Taiwan held a Chinese-language storytelling contest over the weekend to promote reading, a spokesman for the center said Monday.
It marked the first time that the center has organized such an event to promote reading and add fun to daily life, the spokesman said.
The contest attracted scores of groups of competitors composed of adults and children, the spokesman said.
The center invited the county's top storyteller, Cheng Yu-ho, to the event, who told a story titled "The Witch on the Beach."
A book donation event was also sponsored by the Yuen Foong Yu Paper Co., which raised 1,200 books to be donated to schools in remote areas of Taiwan, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAMSUI MUSEUM CELEBRATES ANNIVERSARY WITH CONCERT

TEXT.P: The Tamsui Historical Museum in the northern county of Taipei celebrated its anniversary with a pop concert over the weekend, in which many popular singers and school children performed, according to the event's organizer.
The museum held the concert as part of efforts to promote the area's coastal scenery and sunset views, according to Chang Pao-chuan, the museum's curator.
Popular singer Jeanette Wang performed with a choir of school children and another 14 groups of young singers also performed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CHINATRUST VICE CHAIRMAN PLACED ON WANTED LIST

TEXT.P: The Taipei Public Prosecutors Office placed former Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. Vice Chairman Jeffery Koo Jr. on a wanted list Monday for ignoring summons for questioning about his role in a scandal related to Chinatrust's flawed investment in a rival company.

The prosecution pointed out that Koo, who resigned his vice chairmanship Nov. 24, had ignored three subpoenas without a valid excuse, and that prosecutors also tried twice to detain him but to no avail.
He is the suspected mastermind behind Chinatrust's illegal transactions in an attempt to acquire larger rival Mega Financial Holding Co.
Koo's current whereabouts are unknown. He failed to return to Taiwan in November at the end of a two-month Eisenhower Fellowship program in the United States.
The wanted list will remain valid for more than 25 years and will not expire until March 27, 2031.

Prosecutors are expected to proceed with the prosecution of three of Chinatrust's senior executives -- former chief financial officer Perry Chang, chief legal adviser Deng Yan-dun and vice general manager Lin Hsiang-hsi -- on charges of breach of trust, illegal trading and violation of the Banking Law.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT, COA TO SPONSOR AVIAN FLU SEMINAR

TEXT.P: A symposium on the prevention of avian influenza will be held in Taipei Wednesday under the auspices of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) Taipei Office and Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA), an AIT spokesman said Monday.

The symposium will bring together epidemic control experts from the United States and Taiwan to discuss bird flu prevention measures, tracking of migratory birds, control of poultry slaughtering and disinfection at live poultry markets, as well as avian flu virus genome sequences and other related topics, the spokesman said.

Several other institutions, including the USA Poultry and Egg Export Council, will co-sponsor the seminar, which will be held in a conference hall at National Taiwan University's Department of Veterinary Medicine, the spokesman said.
AIT represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Taiwan remains an avian influenza-free area, but has been on heightened alert since an outbreak of the virulent H5N1 strain of bird flu in South Korea last week.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KAOHSIUNG MAYOR DONATES NT$500,000 TO HELP BUS CARSH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan donated NT$500,000 Monday to help victims in a bus crash a day earlier that claimed 21 lives, all of whom were Kaohsiung residents.
Yeh said she hopes her donation will inspire more people to follow suit to help all those affected by the tragedy.
The tragic traffic accident happened when the double-decker bus tumbled into a steep ravine in the Meiling Scenic Area in southern Tainan County Sunday, killing 21 and seriously injuring 24 others.
The passengers aboard the bus were students from Tingchin Elementary School and their parents.
Both parents from four families were killed in the accident. In another family, the father was killed while the mother and their three children were all seriously injured.
Yeh said the city government will do its utmost to help those families handle the aftermath.
The city government has commissioned the federation of charity groups in Kaohsiung City to raise funds to help all the bus crash victims, Yeh said.

Yeh was originally on a leave of absence to campaign for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's candidate for the Dec. 9 mayoral election, but she has resumed work since the occurrence of the tragic accident, the worst highway traffic accident in recent memory.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS MOTC TO PROBE ROOT CAUSE OF BUS CRASH

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Monday he has ordered the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to form a special task force to identify problems in traffic management in the wake of a tragic bus accident that claimed 21 lives a day earlier.

Su made the remarks to a group of local reporters after delivering a speech at a dinner in honor of public health leaders from more than 40 countries who were in Taipei to attend a forum on disease prevention and health promotion.

Noting that Sunday's bus crash has provided a heart-rending lesson, Su said he wants the MOTC to determine problems in the design and construction of the country's highways, as well as tour bus management.

"We will be able to avert a recurrence of similar tragedies only after we get a clear picture of problems with all those points," Su said, adding that he has demanded the MOTC assume the responsibility of resolving all relevant issues.

Earlier in the day, President Chen Shui-bian visited three hospitals in Tainan County to express concern and sympathy for those injured in the bus crash on the way to the mountainous Meiling Scenic Area in southern Tainan County.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih presented a package of recommendations to Chen on ways to improve traffic management, including tightening supervision of the tour bus industry and working out clear regulations on replacing aged vehicles.

The double-decker tour bus, with parents and students onboard from Tingchin Elementary School in Kaohsiung City, tumbled into a ravine Sunday as it wound its way down the mountain road after stopping in Meiling, Tainan County. Twenty-one people died on spot or on the way to hospitals, with 24 others seriously injured.
The injured, including 16 children, were treated for broken bones and other injuries, a spokesman for the Kaohsiung city government said.

MOTC Minister Tsai Duei said the tour bus was 18 years old but had recently passed a safety inspection. Authorities will consider lawmakers' demands to restrict older buses from driving on mountainous roads, Tsai told lawmakers Monday.
Prosecutor Lin Chih-feng said the cause of the accident was still being investigated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, PREMIER TO VISIT ASE AMID REPORTS OF BUYOUT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Su Tseng-chang will visit Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE) Co.'s factory in Nantzu, Kaohsiung County Tuesday, Cabinet sources said Monday.

As the rare simultaneous visit by Chen and Su to the company comes amid reports that the U.S.-based Carlyle Group will take over the ASE, the sources said, the president and the premier may make important policy announcement.
Nevertheless, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan kept a low profile and would not make any comment on the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DECEMBER 5 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Tuesday, Dec. 5:
11:00, President Chen Shui-bian will meet with U.N. ambassadors of the Marshall Islands and Honduras.
16:00, President Chen and Premier Su Tseng-chang will visit Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Co. in Nantzu, Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 5, or the 15th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary-general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

Noting that Sunday's bus crash has provided a heart-rending lesson, Su said he wants the MOTC to determine problems in the design and construction of the country's highways, as well as tour bus management.

"We will be able to avert a recurrence of similar tragedies only after we get a clear picture of problems with all those points," Su said, adding that he has demanded the MOTC assume the responsibility of resolving all relevant issues.

Earlier in the day, President Chen Shui-bian visited three hospitals in Tainan County to express concern and sympathy for those injured in the bus crash on the way to the mountainous Meiling Scenic Area in southern Tainan County.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih presented a package of recommendations to Chen on ways to improve traffic management, including tightening supervision of the tour bus industry and working out clear regulations on replacing aged vehicles.

The double-decker tour bus, with parents and students onboard from Tingchin Elementary School in Kaohsiung City, tumbled into a ravine Sunday as it wound its way down the mountain road after stopping in Meiling, Tainan County. Twenty-one people died on spot or on the way to hospitals, with 24 others seriously injured.
The injured, including 16 children, were treated for broken bones and other injuries, a spokesman for the Kaohsiung city government said.

MOTC Minister Tsai Duei said the tour bus was 18 years old but had recently passed a safety inspection. Authorities will consider lawmakers' demands to restrict older buses from driving on mountainous roads, Tsai told lawmakers Monday.
Prosecutor Lin Chih-feng said the cause of the accident was still being investigated.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS PIONEER IN TAIWAN PASSES AWAY

TEXT.P: Chuang Che-yen, a pioneer in the control and prevention of AIDS in Taiwan, died of esophageal cancer at National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital Tuesday. He was 76.

Chuang, former deputy superintendent of NTU Hospital who specialized in immunology, began his research on AIDS after the first imported case of AIDS was detected in Taiwan in 1984. He also served for many years as the convener of an AIDS consultative commission under the Department of Health (DOH).

Chuang also served as a goodwill ambassador for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, performing many difficult surgeries in Libya and winning the respect of the Libyan people and government. Libyan strongman Muammar el-Qaddafi is said to have been close friends with him.

At Chuang's urging, NTU hospital set up an AIDS research center after obtaining funds from the DOH. The hospital also set up Taiwan's first ward for AIDS patients, who faced serious discrimination in society at the time.
He also contributed a great deal to the cocktail therapy for AIDs patients project launched by the DOH in 1997.

Chuang began cutting down on research work around five years ago when he was diagnosed with Alzheimer's Disease. Later, he was diagnosed with esophagus cancer. His condition began to deteriorate rapidly about one week before his passing Tuesday morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES CLOSE LOWER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 37.11 points to close at 7,609.9.
The bourse opened at 7,700.15 and fluctuated between 7,703.25 and 7,575.14 during trading. A total of 6.15 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$136.74 billion (US$4.22 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 3.7 percent, followed by construction issues at 3.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 3 percent, textile stocks at 1.8 percent, cement stocks at 1.7 percent, banking and financial shares at 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 944 to 301, with 157 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT'S GAMBIAN VISIT STILL UNCERTAIN: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has made preliminary arrangements for Vice President Annette Lu to visit Gambia as the special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian, but it still remains uncertain whether Lu will go, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Lee Chen-hsiung, director-general of MOFA's Department of African Affairs, said that the ministry is waiting for instructions from the Presidential Office.

Lee made the remarks in response to reports by the China Times, which said that although President Chen Shui-bian announced last month that Lu would visit Africa in mid-December, it is now certain that the vice president will not make a visit to Africa before the end of the year.

President Chen, during a state dinner in southern Kaohsiung City to honor visiting Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore Nov. 22, took the initiative to announce that Lu would visit the west African nation the following month.
The reports said that according to the arrangements, Lu would attend the Dec. 15 inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh and then visit Burkina Faso.

Lee said the ministry is now waiting for word from the Presidential Office on whether there will be a special envoy from Taiwan attending the Gambian president's inauguration. Whether Lu will represent President Chen remains uncertain, he added.
Lee also noted that President Chen has said that the vice president will visit Burkina Faso and that the ministry is making the relevant arrangements.
Lu's office said recently in a statement that she definitely plans to visit Burkina Faso, but the timing of her visit has yet to be finalized.

The office issued the statement after reports said that Lu had declined to make the visit because she plans to attend a conference of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) scheduled for Dec. 8-10 in Taipei. The DPU, inaugurated in August 2005, is the vice president's brainchild.

Lu's office said that after the conference, Lu will receive delegates from various countries and that since the delegates will be leaving Taiwan Dec. 11-12, Lu will be preoccupied and unable to leave Taiwan during that two-day period.

Her office also said that after the DPU conference, the Chinese version of the vice president's biography, penned by a scriptwriter of the popular South Korean TV drama "Dae Jang Geum, " will be launched in Taipei.
As Lu will attend the promotion for the new book, which will come after Dec. 20, her African visit will probably take place after that date, her office added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POOR WATER QUALITY AT GUEST HOUSES: EPA SURVEY

TEXT.P: Guest houses had the poorest water quality among major public or private establishments across Taiwan, according to the results of a probe published Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Environment Protection Administration (EPA).

Among more than 1,200 residential communities, schools, hospitals, department stores, bus or train transfer centers and tourist spots investigated, water quality at guest houses, in particular those on offshore islands, were found to be the country's poorest, the EPA survey found.

Chen Chih-ming, a section chief at the EPA's Environmental Sanitation and Toxic Chemicals Control Bureau, said that most homestays and hotels with low water quality are located in remote areas and that their water supplies mainly depend on underground water or water towers that are rarely cleaned and may contain too much bacteria.

After random checks by EPA officials of cisterns and water towers at 235 guest houses and hotels across the country, nearly 7 percent of them had substandard water quality -- the highest level recorded among all facilities, the survey discovered.
Hospitals and tourist facilities came second and third with 5.7 percent and 5.6 percent, respectively, according to the survey.

In terms of cities and counties, guest houses and hotels on the Matsu Islands group under the jurisdiction of Lienchiang county registered the highest level of substandard water quality -- around 40 percent, followed by those in central Taichung county with 26.3 percent. Around 8 percent of those on the offshore Penghu county and some 6 percent in Kaohsiung city had unclean water.
According to Chen, homestays and hotels with substandard water quality have been required to improve the quality of their water supply and meet conditions set by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q3 CONSUMER CONFIDENCE IN HOUSING PRICES DOWN

TEXT.P: Consumer confidence in housing prices decreased in the third quarter of 2006, indicating Taiwan's housing market is losing steam owing to weak demand, according to a report released Tuesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The composite housing price confidence index stood at 102.48 in the third quarter, down 5.52 points from the previous quarter and up 0.88 points over the same time last year, the report shows.

The confidence index for housing prices in the near term registered 107.56, down 4.43 points from the second quarter, while the confidence index for housing prices in the future dropped 6.6 points to stand at 97.4.
On the financial burden on homebuyers, the report indicates that the average housing prices in Taiwan in the third quarter were equal to 6.5 times the average annual income of local people.

In Taipei City, the average housing prices in the third quarter were equal to eight times the average annual income of its residents, compared with the ratio of 8.7 times in the second quarter and 9.5 times in the first quarter.
In the third quarter, homebuyers in the city spent an average 37.1 percent of their earnings on mortgage loans every month, according to the survey.
Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, said the result indicates that real estate prices in Taipei City remain unreasonably high.

Citing the examples of other countries, Chang noted that housing prices are considered reasonable if they are equal to four to five times the average annual income of the people, with spending on mortgage loans accounting for one-quarter to one-third of their earnings.

Meanwhile, Chang warned the increase in the number of speculators is a major factor for instability in Taiwan's housing market, and urged the financial sector to screen mortgage loan applications with discretion to stop manipulation of housing prices by speculators.
The CEPD report indicates the ratio of first-time housing buyers looking for residences for themselves declined to 49.6 percent in the third quarter, the lowest level recorded so far this year.

While the ratio of homebuyers who were replacing their old residences for new ones increased to 26.3 percent, the ratio of those buying houses for investment purposes rose to 24.2 percent, the highest level registered so far this year.

By region, the highest ratio of investment-oriented housing buyers was recorded in Taipei County, at 31.1 percent, followed by the city and county of Taichung at 30.7 percent, and Taipei City at 28.1 percent.

La Repubblica: Casini: Opposition alliance "House of Liberty" is over.
Replying to former premier Silvio Berlusconi's call for the unity of the the opposition alliance "House of Liberty", former speaker of the House of Deputies Pierferdinando Casini, who is concurrently leader of the opposition Christian Democratic Union, said that the "House of Liberty" is over and that there are now two opposition groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT VOICES OPPOSITION TO PUBLIC UNIVERSITY TUITION HIKE PLAN

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) expressed Tuesday their strong opposition to a proposal to raise public university tuition fees by between 2.4 percent and 10 percent next year.

Members of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan held a press conference to voice their discontent with the plan which was formed Friday during a board meeting of the Association of National Universities of Taiwan (ANUT) on a grounds that a tuition hike will help efforts to maintain educational quality at public universities amid rising costs.

Legislator Hou Tsai-feng argued that as most families' income has been seen shrinking in the country over the past several years, "it will be more and more difficult for poor people to enter the higher education system as they try to rise out of poverty."

Citing governmental tallies, Hou said the income gap between the richest 10 percent of families and the poorest 10 percent of families in Taiwan expanded from 30.7 times in 2000 to 50 times last year. Under the proposed tuition hike plan, a public university student will have to pay NT$3,000-NT$6,000 (US$93-US$185) more in tuition per semester, the KMT caucus member noted.
National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen, who also chairs the ANUT, has revealed that the institution intends to raise tuition fees by between 2 percent and 3 percent in 2007.

The general tuition hike plan will be submitted to the 2007 conference of Taiwan's university presidents for discussion. It is expected the hike will take effect at the start of the 2007 academic year in September, according to Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CYBER POPULATION HITS OVER 12 MILLION IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese using the Internet hit 12.6 million, or 74.5 percent of total households, a rise from 70.6 percent in 2005, according to results of a government survey released Tuesday.

Hsinchu city in northern Taiwan has the largest percentage of households using the Internet at 73.2 percent, ahead of northern Taipei city and central Taichung city both at second with 72.8 percent, the survey by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) showed.
Nearly 90 percent of families in Hsinchu, Taipei and Taichung cities own at least one computer, while fewer than 70 percent in Yunlin, Chiayi and Taitung counties have one, the poll found.
The RDEC conducted the poll on Taiwan's digital divide from April 20-June 20, interviewing 26,702 schoolchildren, teachers and parents.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSES TO BE PROHIBITED FROM USING RETREAD TIRES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) decided Tuesday to prohibit the use of retreaded tires by tour buses and passenger buses plying the nation's freeways.
Relevant regulations will be amended within one month to put the ban in place, MOTC officials said.

The officials also noted that from effective immediately, any tour bus running on a road listed as "risky" will be fined according to highway law, with not only the driver but also the bus owner punished.

The stricter measures to manage passenger buses were made in an ongoing MOTC comprehensive review of existing related laws after a tragic bus accident claimed 21 lives Sunday in southern Taiwan, raising concerns about flaws in regulation.

A tour bus carrying 45 parents and students from Kaohsiung City tumbled into a ravine Sunday in the Meiling Scenic Area in Tainan County. Twenty-one people died on the spot or on the way to hospitals, with 24 others seriously injured.

After the driver was suspected of taking the wheel without having a valid license, the MOTC also decided to put in place a registration system targeting tour bus drivers from the beginning of next year, while stipulating commercial passenger buses must undergo safety tests twice a year if they are older than five years.

Buses 10 years or older must undergo an additional test ever year, according to the MOTC. Meanwhile, authorities are also discussing whether to ban passenger buses older than 10 years from operating on the road.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER WILL ATTEND INAUGURATION OF GAMBIAN PRESIDENT AS ENVOY

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu announced Tuesday that Premier Su Tseng-chang will serve as President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy in attending the Dec. 15 inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh.

Lu made the remarks after a luncheon for legislators in Taipei, during which she expressed hope they would attend the Dec. 10 inauguration of the Pacific Congressional Caucus (PCC) of the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU), which she founded in August 2005. Parliamentarians from more than two dozen countries will attend the inauguration, according to Lu.

Asked whether the PCC's inauguration is too close to Lu's Gambia visit, Lu explained that President Chen Shui-bian had originally asked her to serve as his envoy to attend the inauguration ceremony Nov. 24, but the inauguration was later postponed to Dec. 15.
As she attended the Gambian president's last inauguration, she requested President Chen send another envoy in her stead, and the president consented to the request.
As for another African ally Burkina Faso, Lu said the president had asked her to visit the West African nation when she is available, without detailing a specific time.
Asked when she plans to visit Burkina Faso, she said "we'll wait a while."
Lu said the upcoming PCC meeting will be a key event in Taiwan's diplomatic work, expressing hope for its success.

President Chen, during a Nov. 22 state dinner in the southern city of Kaohsiung for visiting Burkina Faso President Blaise Compaore, took the initiative to announce that Lu would visit the West African nation the following month.
Reports said that according to the arrangement, Lu will attend the Dec. 15 inauguration ceremony of Gambian president before proceeding to visit Burkina Faso.

DOC.HEADLINE: 93% OF GAS STATIONS AT RISK OF EXPLOSION: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION

TEXT.P: Ninety-three percent of gas stations in Taiwan are at risk of explosion due to a neglect for various safety concerns, according to the results of a Consumers' Foundation survey released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted Nov. 14-28 on 189 gas stations in 11 counties and cities around Taiwan. They included 118 gas stations belonging to the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) , 26 Formosa Petrochemical Corp. (FPCC) stations, 19 National Petroleum Corp. (NPC) stations, nine Mech-President Corp. stations, three North-Star Petroleum Co. stations, two Taiwan Sugar Corp. stations and two belonging to the Sunshine chain.

The survey shows workers at 83 percent of the stations do not require consumers to turn off their engines, 58 percent don't ask consumers not to smoke and 89 percent do not require consumers to avoid using mobile phones.
A total of 175 out of the 189 gas stations break at least one of these safety rules.

While 68 percent of NPC gas stations fail to follow all the rules, 67 percent of those from the Mech-President chain, 57 percent from the CPC chain, and 47 percent from the FPCC chain also fail as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CONTINUES TO BLAME KMT FOR LEAKING INFO ABOUT CHAIRMEN MEETING

TEXT.P: James Soong, on leave from his People First Party (PFP) chairmanship to run for Taipei mayor as an independent candidate, blamed the Kuomintang's (KMT) key staff again Tuesday for leaking information about his "secret meeting" with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou last Friday.

The behind-closed-doors meeting held late at night -- and so late in the municipal election campaign -- has sparked intense speculation as to "what secret deals were reached" and "for what purpose." Taipei and Kaohsiung voters elect their mayors and city council members Dec. 9.

According to a newspaper report, Ma signed a written agreement on three "conditions" during the meeting, under which Soong would make a "graceful exit" from the intense mayoral race (to help secure KMT nominee Hau Lung-bin's victory) : Soong would become convener of a "KMT-PFP Alliance"; the KMT would "concede" some legislative seats to PFP members; and the two parties would continue to cooperate in the legislature.

According to Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT member and speaker of the Legislative Yuan, Ma later told him they had not discussed elections; they had "only discussed" how to deal with a government request for a special budget to procure weapons from the United States and how their two parties would cooperate in the future.
As for the report about a "secret deal" made between Ma and Soong, Wang said he was "unaware" of such a deal. Soong himself refused to respond to media queries concerning the reported "secret deal."
But Soong was unhappy his four-hour meeting with Ma was leaked to the media, and strongly suspected it was the KMT side that broke the agreement to keep it from public knowledge.
Soong stressed that it was certainly not his party members who leaked the information, adding "I believe it was not Mr. Ma who released the information."
Soong pointed at KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po, claiming that if it wasn't Chan, could it be possible that Mr. Ma Ying-jeou made the leak?
The PFP leader also blamed the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Taipei mayor candidate, former Premier Frank Hsieh, for releasing a photo of his secret meeting with Ma.
How did Hsieh get that photo? Soong asked: "Was it provided by the national security authorities? If not, by whom? Or was it Hsieh who sent someone to monitor Ma's and my actions?"
To Soong's accusation, Hsieh replied by returning the volley back to "them" -- Soong and Ma -- saying "they know who took the picture."
Hsieh noted that the journalist or amateur photographer met "their people" when taking the picture.

Hsieh said Ma and Soong's secret meeting could be seen as "a victory of the doves inside the KMT and PFP, " whereas its leaking could be attributed to hawks in both parties. He said people have a right to know what the chairmen of the two opposition parties had discussed behind the scenes.
"If they had discussed an exit mechanism [for Soong in this election], they could be suspected of having broken the law."
Premier Su Tseng-chang agreed that Ma and Soong should "honestly tell the people" what they talked about, rather than "trying to hide or cover up anything."

Chen Ching-chun, secretary-general of the DPP's legislative caucus, said the meeting between chairman of the largest opposition party and a mayoral candidate at this stage of the election campaign "gives people ample room for imagination" as to whether they had made a deal on something.
If their "cooperation" was aimed only at boosting their parties' interests, people would not believe they could cooperate honestly with each other, Chen added.

KMT Spokesman Huang Yu-chen claimed that no secret deals had been reached between Ma and Soong and that all of the fuss over the so-called "secret meeting" should "stop here, " as his party would focus all its efforts on winning municipal elections in Taiwan's two largest cities.
"No quid pro quos were made and no deals reached in secret. The KMT thanks Mr. Soong for his enlightenment, and the goal of KMT-PFP cooperation remains unchanged," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLCHILDREN GETTING ONLINE TO PLAY GAMES: RDEC POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 percent of schoolchildren in Taiwan have used computers, and the average age at which they start is 7.9 years, according to the results of a government survey released Tuesday.

Over 70 percent of schoolchildren polled said that they go online to play games, while 65 percent and 62 percent said that they log in to search for information and download music, respectively, the survey by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) showed.

More than 80 percent of sixth graders and junior high school students said that they have chatted and played games on the Internet, while some 83 percent have their own e-mail addresses, the survey found. Some 56 percent of students polled reported having received pornographic "junk mail."
While 88 percent of schoolchildren living in urban areas enjoy Internet access, only around 75 percent from rural regions have an Internet connection.

About one-third of the students responded that they would worry if they were required to do their homework with computers, the survey discovered. The percentage is higher among schoolchildren from low-income families and those living and studying in remote areas.
The RDEC carried out the poll from May 10-June 14, collecting a total of 12,129 valid questionnaires from schoolchildren, teachers and parents, to detect digital divide in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TELLS EXECUTIVE YUAN TO LURE BACK CAPITAL FROM CHINA

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday that he had instructed the Executive Yuan to promote measures to lure back capital from Taiwan businessmen operating in China.
The president made the remarks while visiting Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE) Co.'s factory in Nantzu, Kaohsiung County that day.

ASE -- the world's largest chip packaging and testing company -- became a hot topic recently after reports of its buyout by the U.S-based Carlyle Group, one of the largest private equity investment firms in the world.

Local attention has been focused on whether the buyout will hurt Taiwan's capital market. If Carlyle's buyout bid succeeds, ASE might be delisted from the Taiwan Stock Exchange and the media have also been discussing if ASE's move was prompted by the government's 40-percent ceiling on investment in China.
The president said he understands that Taiwan businesses are adopting a global perspective, but added that he believes ASE will stay in Taiwan and develop locally.
He said the government's trade policy is to pursue sustainable development and social justice, and is against globalization that tilts too much toward China.
Local businesses should keep risk management in mind and should not place all their eggs in one basket, the president said.

Chen advocated his administration's "active management, effective opening" policy regarding cross-Taiwan Strait trade that was adopted earlier this year to replace the "active opening, effective management" policy that had been in place since 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 AUSTRONESIAN FORUM TO TAKE PLACE IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN DEC. 12-13

TEXT.P: The 2006 Austronesian Forum, sponsored by the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples, will take place Dec. 12-13 at National Pingtung University of Education's Minsheng campus in southern Taiwan, with nearly 400 people participating.

Among the foreign delegates will be political leaders from 14 countries, including Australia, Canada, Japan, Fiji, Kiribati, the Marshall Islands, Nauru, New Zealand, the Solomon Islands, Palau, Tuvalu and Venezuela, according to organizers.

Topics to be discussed at the forum include strategies to revive the native languages of the Austronesian peoples, preserving Austronesian ecologies, establishing a platform for cultural exchanges among the Austronesian peoples and promoting the re-emergence of the various traditional tribes in the Austronesian island countries.

Taiwan hosted the first Assembly of Austronesian Leaders in December 2002, bringing the Asia-Pacific island aboriginal cultures together for the first time. The meeting concluded with a declaration providing a vision for the development of Austronesian civilization and outlining goals in promoting cooperation among Austronesian peoples.

In November 2003, aborigines from 12 Asia-Pacific countries, including Taiwan, met again in Taipei and adopted a proposal to set up a permanent forum with its preparatory office in Taipei to promote cooperation and exchange among Austronesian aborigines.

The Austronesian peoples share many common cultural roots, with their territory stretching from Easter Island to Madagascar and from New Zealand to the northern tip of Taiwan, covering nearly one-third of the globe and representing a population of nearly 300 million.

Linguists see Taiwan's indigenous population as pivotal to the reconstruction of prehistoric Austronesian culture. With 10 indigenous tribes left on the island and 420,000 people who speak languages of Austronesian derivation, Taiwan has been recognized as an important center for studies of Austronesian heritage.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN EXPOSITION TO BE HELD IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A "Korean fad" exposition will be held at the World Trade Center in Taichung city from Dec. 7-10 to increase the visibility of South Korean products in central Taiwan, organizers said Tuesday.

The exposition, organized by the World Trade Center Taichung and the Taipei-based Korean Trade Center, will showcase South Korean culture, tourism, hi-high and agricultural products, ranging from home appliances to kimchi.

Thanks to South Korean TV series that have swept Taiwan in recent years, wide ranging exchanges between the two countries are increasing despite the suspension of diplomatic links since 1990, organizers said.
Taiwan is the fifth-largest trade partner of South Korea, while South Korea is Taiwan's sixth-largest trade partner.

The number of South Korean tourists to Taiwan nearly doubled to more than 182,000 in 2005 from 96,000 in 1993, while the number of Taiwan tourists visiting South Korea jumped to over 351,000 from 145,000 during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.094 to close at NT$32.304.
A total of US$1.051 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.398 and hit a low of NT$32.283.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 48 points to close at 7,610, with 42,122 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January decreased 61 points to finish at 7,599, with 1,032 contracts traded, while March futures lost 89 points to end at 7,561, with 27 contract transactions. June futures moved up 25 points to close at 7,666, with seven contract transactions, while September futures decreased 53 points to close at 7,403, with 27 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,658 for December, 7,660 for January, 7,650 for March, 7,641 for June and 7,456 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

December TE futures lost 0.75 point to close at 321, with 4,120 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost 0.65 point to finish at 320.3, with 86 contract transactions. March TE futures increased 0.4 point to close at 319.8, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
December TF futures lost seven points to close at 1,046, with 2,332 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures decreased eight points to close at 1,045, with 44 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FLU CASES EXPECTED TO RISE SHARPLY OVER NEXT MONTH: CDC

TEXT.P: The number of flu cases is expected to increase sharply over the coming month as the country has entered its annual flu season, Center for Disease Control (CDC) officials said Tuesday.
CDC tallies show that the number of flu cases has been rising over the past month.

While 3.08 in every 100 patients making outpatient visits displayed flu-like symptoms in the first week of November, the ratio climbed to 3.31 in every 100 patients in the second week, 3.28 in every 100 patients in the third week and 3.36 in every 100 patients in the fourth week, the tallies indicate.

CDC officials urged the public to pay extra attention to their health during the flu season and advised those who are especially susceptible to flu, such as seniors and children, to get vaccinated against the disease as soon as possible.

According to the CDC, only 48.4 percent of people aged 65 or above have so far received the free flu vaccinations offered by the government, which is lower than the 57.7 percent registered during the same time last year.
Meanwhile, 22.1 percent of children between six months and two years of age have received the shots, compared with 22.9 percent for the same time last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOVEMBER CPI UP 0.21 PERCENT YEAR-ON-YEAR

TEXT.P: The consumer price index (CPI) for November rose 0.21 percent from the level of the same month last year, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS officials attributed the rise to the fact that fuel, gas, electricity and cigarette prices were higher this year compared with of last year, although food prices registered a 2.25 percent drop.
For the 11 months until November, the CPI was 0.59 percent higher than the figure for the same period of last year, the officials said.
The DGBAS predicted the inflation rate for the whole of 2006 will register 0.7 percent, which means the rise in consumer prices still remains moderate, DGBAS officials said.
DGBAS officials said consumer prices has seen a slight increase recently due to the hike in international raw material prices.
For example, oil exported by OPEC countries costs US$55.42 per barrel at present, up 8.1 percent over last year, they noted.
In terms of grain prices, corn prices in November were double that of last November, while prices of wheat and soy beans rose 65.1 percent and 22.9 percent year-on-year, respectively, they said.
In terms of metal prices, nickel prices in November were up 175 percent year-on-year, while the prices of zinc and copper were up 159 percent and 59.9 percent, respectively, they said.
Meanwhile, the wholesale price index (WPI) for November increased 6.06 percent compared with the same month of last year, the officials said.
For the 11 months to November, the WPI was 5.58 percent higher than the level for the same period last year, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH LAUNCHES 'DRUG INFORMATION WEBSITE'

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has launched a new "Drug Information Website" containing names, photos, specifications and usage precautions for more than 10,000 medications common on the Taiwan market, providing the public with a quick and easy reference guide, DOH officials said Tuesday.

Liao Chi-chou, director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said that after an incident involving the distribution of counterfeit Norvasc last month, the public is more concerned about confirming such vital details, so the DOH decided to set up a Web site: drug.doh.gov.tw or drug.unform.com.tw.

In addition to a drug identification search, Liao said the site also offers two databases on drug safety knowledge and "medical express," as well as an online advising service to offer real-time consultation on drug use.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAINAN COUNTY CHIEF THANKS RESCUERS OF BUS CRASH VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih expressed his gratitude Tuesday to police officers, firefighters, emergency workers and volunteers who took part in the rescue operation at the scene of a bus crash in the Meiling scenic area two days ago that killed 21 people and injured 24 others.
Su met with the rescuers at the Tainan Police Department's Yuching station, where he praised their tireless efforts during the rescue operation that lasted from Sunday afternoon until early Monday.

The atmosphere at what was supposed to be a citation ceremony was so charged with emotion that when the magistrate led them to observe a minute of silence for the victims, many of the rescuers could no longer choke back their tears.
Chiang Yang-chueh, leader of the Phoenix Volunteers, said she felt sad that she and her teammates were unable to save more of the bus passengers.
The magistrate promised that the county government will try to work out measures to prevent similar tragedies from happening again.
The accident Sunday occurred when an 18-year-old bus carrying holidaymakers lost control on a steep downhill bend and plunged into a 30 meter-deep ravine.
Most of the 45 people on board were thrown out of the bus. Nineteen of them, including one of the two drivers, died on the spot, while another two died later at the hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREX RESERVES AMOUNT TO US$265.14 BILLION IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves amounted to a record high of US$265.14 billion as of the end of November, up US$3.32 billion from the month-earlier level, according to statistics released Tuesday by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC).
CBC officials said the increase was mainly due to gains generated by appreciation of the euro and the pound against the U.S. dollar, as well returns on investments.
Taiwan remained the country with the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves after China and Japan, the officials said.

According to data for October released by the central banks of various countries, China's foreign exchange reserves reached US$1.96 trillion, Japan's amounted to US$865.6 billion, Singapore's amounted to US$130.6 billion, India's amounted to US$160.2 billion and Russia's amounted to US$187.6 billion.
South Korea's foreign exchange reserves in November were US$233.7 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: POSTAL MEMORABILIA, ANTIQUE STAMP SHOW KICKS OFF IN TAICHUNG CITY

TEXT.P: An exhibition of postal memorabilia and antique stamps, organized by the Postal Museum, began Tuesday at Kuokuang Elementary School in Taichung City -- the show's first stop on a tour of several other primary schools in central and southern Taiwan.

The exhibition displays valuable antique stamps from around the world, as well as replicas of various old and modern postal facilities in China and Taiwan, including a Ching Dynasty mailbox and various types of mail transportation equipment, such as oxcarts and rafts.
The show aims to inform people how the post was delivered in the olden days, as well as show the beauty of philately, said Chen Shu-chen, manager of the Taichung postal office.

Chen also expressed hope the event will revive people's passion for writing letters, saying that in the electronic era, fewer people now communicate with their family members and friends by writing letters, a personalized bridge of communication.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZIL-MADE JETS TO ENTER TAIWAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Brazil-made commercial jets will enter the Taiwan market in the near future, as Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines has leased two commercial jets from the Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. (Embraer), a Mandarin spokesman said Tuesday.

According to the spokesman, the first Embraer-made E-190 and E-195 planes are slated to begin service with Mandarin Airlines from May next year, replacing the company's existing Fokker planes. Mandarin Airlines will take delivery of the Embraer planes in two years, he added.

The official admitted that the company's lease of the Embraer planes is aimed at the fast-growing Chinese air travel market, as the small- and medium-sized planes are suitable for plying routes between Taiwan and as far away as Mongolia.
However, the first of the planes to be introduced next year will be used to ply the Hong Kong and Ho Chih Minh City routes, he noted.

Embraer is one of the world's largest aircraft manufacturers, focusing on specific market segments with high growth potential in commercial, defense and executive aviation. The company was Brazil's largest airplane exporter from 1999 to 2001.
