DOC.HEADLINE: HOMOSEXUAL GROUP ENDORSES CANDIDATES IN CITY COUNCIL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: A homosexual group announced its endorsement of five candidates in the upcoming Taipei city council elections Tuesday and demanded more homosexual-friendly policies from the Taipei and Kaohsiung city governments.

Based on candidates' past records and public statements, the Taiwan Tonzhi Hotline Association (TTHA) said it will endorse Pan Han-shen, Chan Ming-chou, Dai Hsi-chin, Lin Yi-hua and Chou Po-ya in the Dec. 9 election for Taipei city councilors.

Of the candidates, Pan is from the Green Party, which is been known for supporting homosexual rights, while independent candidate Chan Ming-chou claimed he is the first out of the closet homosexual candidate in Taiwan's election history.

"The homosexual population accounts for as much as 10 percent of the population. Votes of homosexuals are going to be critical and that is why candidates should not ignore the importance of these voters, " said Kao Ying-chao, convener of the TTHA's human rights group.

The organization did not endorse any candidates in the elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung city mayors or Kaohsiung city council, which will also be held Dec. 9, as most candidates either failed to answer questionnaires submitted by the group or lack past records for review.

However, Kaohsiung city mayoral candidate Chen Ju did mention common-law partners and families of gay people in her White Paper, while Taipei mayoral candidate Clara Chou is also listed as a homosexual-friendly candidate.
In the survey, most candidates were hesitant to specify their views or policies on homosexuals, said Kao.

Homosexual groups have submitted their recommendations and endorsements in elections from as early as 1995, TTHA Public Relations Director Wu Hsu-liang said, adding that they endorsed candidates such as current legislators Hsiao Bi-khim, Cheng Yun-peng and Joanna Lei in past elections.
"Our surveys and endorsements are non-partisan. All we care about are candidates' track records and whether they are homosexual-friendly, " Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CARLYLE MIGHT SET UP TAIWAN AFFILIATE TO BUY OUT ASE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A senior finance regulator said Tuesday that the Carlyle Group of the United States might set up a Taiwan affiliate to merge with Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE) , a Taiwan blue chip company which President Chen Shui-bian visited earlier that day.

If Carlyle forms a Taiwan-registered company to buy out ASE, there will no longer be an issue of ASE becoming a foreign-invested company that is trying to circumvent the government's restrictions on investing in China, said Susan Chang, vice chairwoman of the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
She noted that setting up a Taiwan affiliate could be "the most beneficial way" for Carlyle to merge with ASE, the world's largest computer chip packaging and testing firm.

Critics have blamed the government for clamping a 40 percent ceiling on Taiwan companies trying to invest a proportion of their total assets in China, a regulation that forces them to find ways to get around the restrictions.
In Kaohsiung, where the president, Premier Su Tseng-chang and Economic Affairs Minister Chen Ruey-long visited ASE, the president urged ASE to "keep its roots in Taiwan."
The president praised ASE Chairman Chang Chien-sheng for claiming the merger plan did not have anything to do with "expanding investment in China."
He also praised Chang for declaring ASE will not alter its policy of keeping its roots in Taiwan and its plan of expanding investment in Taiwan.
"The government welcomes any company, be it Taiwan-invested or foreign-invested, to keep its roots in Taiwan, to operate in Taiwan, and to increase investment in Taiwan," said Chen Shui-bian.

As the country seeks to change, there are things that it wants to keep from changing, such as its economic policy goals of sustainable development and social justice as well as prosperity for all, he added.

"If economic growth results only in increasing wealth concentration in the hands of a few and in widening the gap between rich and poor, how could we unite all people of Taiwan for a common goal?" he asked.

He said it is simply normal for a pluralistic democracy like Taiwan to have different views on economic and trade policy, "and yet, the government must not lose its direction but rather should keep its vision and make its choices."
The president reminded Taiwan's businesses that globalization does not mean "sinification" and that they should not put "all their eggs in a basket called China."
On the other hand, he said, when a Taiwan company like ASE implements its global business plan, it should not be distorted as trying to leave or abandon Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-GRAFT LEADER TO 'IMPRISON' HIMSELF UNTIL PRESIDENT RESIGNS

TEXT.P: The leader of the ongoing "Million Voices Against Corruption" campaign said Tuesday that he will "imprison" himself in the campaign's Taipei office from Tuesday until scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian agrees to step down.

Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who launched the campaign in early September, made clear his determination at a press conference after returning from a trip to Thailand, where he attended an anti-corruption forum.
Shih deplored that the government deployed some 500 police at the airport to prevent followers of the anti-corruption campaign from greeting him and causing a stir.
He urged pro-DPP voters to vote for candidates of the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party in the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
"If you find it difficult to vote for opposition candidates, please cast an invalid vote and don't let the corrupt regime in power have a chance to continue its rule," Shih said.

He admitted that when more than 1 million red-clad protesters joined a parade in Taipei in October, the idea did cross his mind about leading the protesters in breaking a police cordon and occupying the Presidential Office and the president's residence.
Shih added that on second thoughts, however, he gave up the idea and told himself that it was not worthwhile to ruin Taiwan's hard-earned democratic system simply for the sake of one corrupt leader.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIRES NOT CAUSE BEHIND TAIWAN'S WORST BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Worn tires are not the cause of Taiwan's worst bus accident in two decades, said Chen Chin-yuan, chief of the Directorate General of Highways under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications Tuesday.

Citing the results of his office's preliminary investigation, Chen said the tires on the front two wheels of the bus that crashed into a ravine in Tainan County Sunday killing 21 persons were manufactured in July, 2006, while the tires on its four rear wheels were manufactured in January, 2006, all of which are within what Chen described as the "six-year usable period of normal tires."
Furthermore, Chen said, the tread on all six tires was more than 1.6 mm in depth as required by the regulations and ruled out the possibility that the tires played any role in the accident.

Chen said his office had also ruled out the possibility that the road condition might have triggered the accident, saying that the stretch of the road on which the accident took place is about 400 meters long with a slope of 5 degrees which is not very dangerous, despite having many hairpin bends and bridges.

In light of the fact the bus left 43-meter-long skid marks on the road, Chen said the driver must have realized the vehicle was traveling too fast and was trying hard to put the brake on it before the accident, Chen said.
He that suggested that human error and mechanical failure were the possible reasons for the accident.

Although the Directorate General of Highways finding was contrary to media speculation that worn tread on the tires was a factor in the accident, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications had already decided to ban the use of retread tires by tour buses in any case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 6, or the 16th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO BECOME HIGH-INCOME COUNTRY WITHIN 20 YEARS: MASTERCARD

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to advance from a medium-income country to a high-income country within the next 20 years if it continues to transform its manufacturing economy into a service economy, according to a report released Tuesday by MasterCard Worldwide.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, an economic advisor at the company, said that in seeking to become a high-income country, Taiwan should boost its labor productivity, increase its investment in education, strengthen cross-Taiwan Strait communication and links, and increase research and development.

Also, Hedrick-Wong said Taiwan should create a better environment to give Taiwanese businesses a stronger incentive to maintain their roots in Taiwan and to invest more in the country to bolster domestic demand and create more job opportunities.

On Taiwan's economic outlook for next year, the company predicted that Taiwan's economy will post a growth rate of only 1.2 percent due to low consumer confidence as a result of the credit card debt problem and political uncertainties.

According to Hedrick-Wong, while lower confidence will affect consumer spending, a slowdown in the U.S. and Chinese economies is also expected to affect Taiwan's economic performance, which relies heavily on exports.

In addition to declining consumer confidence, private consumption in Taiwan has seen negative growth, and the production value of the manufacturing sector as well as the country's labor productivity have also been declining, he said.
Commenting on the report, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng said MasterCard has underestimated Taiwan's economic growth.
Hu said the negative impact from the credit card debt problem will diminish next year, while the cut in custom duties for imported cars will also stimulate consumer spending.

Mainstream economic research institutions in Taiwan generally believe that the country's private consumption will register a growth rate of 3 percent next year, and the CEPD has predicted that the country's economy will grow by 3.2 percent, Hu noted.
The CEPD's target is to achieve an economic growth rate of 4.6 percent next year, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-VOTE-BUYING DRIVE TO CONTINUE UNTIL ELECTION DAY: MOJ

TEXT.P: Law enforcement authorities will continue relentless with anti-vote-buying efforts up to the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, a ranking Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Wednesday.

Law enforcement officers will closely monitor whether any of the candidates in the municipal elections are engaging in any activities in violation of the Public Officials Election and Recall Law, including vote-buying, violence and other irregularities, Vice Justice Minister Wang Tien-sheng said.

The Prosecutors' Offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung have received 463 vote-buying related complaints since anti-vote-buying and anti-election violence task forces were established in Taiwan's two largest cities and special municipalities under the Cabinet's direct jurisdiction, Wang said.

Among the complaints, 34 were related to the Taipei mayoral election and 19 concerned the Kaohsiung mayoral race. Another 219 complaints were related to the Kaohsiung city council elections and 191 concerned Taipei city council races, Wang said.
Two candidates have been taken into police custody for alleged vote-buying, and one of them -- an incumbent city councilor -- has been prosecuted on vote-buying charges, according to Wang.

Noting that election bribery activities can be expected to increase with campaigns shifting into high gear in the last few days leading up to the elections, Wang urged the candidates to refrain from vote-buying if they want to avoid prosecution and the possibility of seeing their hard-fought election victories declared null and void.

Altogether, 192 candidates are taking part in the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral and city council elections. Of that total, six are running for Taipei mayor and five others are running for Kaohsiung mayor. Another 103 candidates are competing for the 52 seats in the Taipei city council, while 78 others are vying for the 44 seats in the Kaohsiung city council.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS CLARIFIES NEWS REPORT ABOUT LABOR FORCE PARTICIPATION RATE

TEXT.P: The rise in the female labor force participation rate is mainly attributable to the upgrading of women's average educational levels and the continued development of the service industry rather than to a slowdown in the economy, the country's top budget and accounting agency said Wednesday.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) was responding to a recent media report that alleged that the deterioration of the local economy is the main reason behind the substantial increase in the number of double-income families.

DGBAS officials dismissed the report as "misleading," saying that the ongoing rise in the rate of women's labor force participation coincides with an increase in their educational attainment in recent decades.

The officials said the labor force participation rate of married women with children under six years of age reached a 20-year high of 58 percent in 2006. The ratio was also higher than the percentage for all married women, according to DGBAS tallies.

Noting that women with children under 6 years of age tend to be younger and better educated, the officials said this group of women are less likely to quit jobs because of marriage or childbirth. Even if they resign due to marriage or childbirth, they are more likely to return to work.

The officials further said that the enactment of women's welfare promotion legislation, such as the workplace gender equality law, and the implementation of various policy initiatives to increase women's job opportunities have also contributed to the rise in the women's labor force participation rate.
The labor force participation rate refers to the percentage of working-age persons in an economy who are employed or are unemployed but looking for a job.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP STILL BEST PARTY IN TAIWAN: FORMER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Lin I-hsiung, former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said Wednesday that despite his past criticism of the party, he still thinks the DPP is the best party in Taiwan and one that is moving toward a better direction.

Lin made the remarks while accompanying Frank Hsieh, the DPP's candidate in the Taipei mayoral race, to canvass votes in a suburban Shihlin market with only three days remaining before the Dec. 9 election.

Amid the DPP's slipping popularity in the wake of a series of alleged corruption scandals implicating the family members of President Chen Shui-bian and his senior aides, the presence of Lin, who enjoys high esteem within the party, has greatly boosted the morale of Hsieh, who is facing an uphill battle against Hau Lung-bin of the main opposition Kuomintang.
Lin lauded the performance of Hsieh over the years, saying that he admires the former premier's caliber, integrity as well as his warmth towards friends.
Noting that he has been friends with Hsieh as well as Chen Chu, the DPP's candidate in the Kaohsiung mayoral election, for years, Lin said that "he will extend a hand to express solidarity."
Lin, who has stayed out of the limelight since quitting the DPP early this year because of his disappointment with the party, also said that he would stump for Chen prior to Saturday's election.
On questions about suggestions that he take the helm of the party again after Saturday's election, Lin said "the question should be left for discussion after the election."

On whether the mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaoshiung represent a confidence vote on the embattled president, Lin only said that he came to the rally to meet people and not to touch on other subjects.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Panel To Urge Pressure On Iraq Study Group to Present Its Report to Bush Today
The bipartisan Iraq Study Group plans to recommend to President Bush that he threaten to reduce economic and military support for Iraq's government if it fails to meet specific benchmarks intended to improve security in the country, a source familiar with the report said yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PHYSICALLY CHALLENGED PAINTER IN U.S. FOR LECTURE TOUR
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, Dec. 5 (CNA) (By Jih-chun Wu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's physically challenged artist Yang En-dian, whose legendary life story has inspired many in the country, arrived in San Francisco recently for a lecture and fundraising tour.
Yang, 32, who was born without arms and later abandoned by her parents, was raised at a southern Taiwan Catholic orphanage before becoming a mouth and foot painting artist.
She is being accompanied by her husband on the tour, during which she will share her life story with Taiwanese and Chinese expatriates living in the United States.

Yang is also expected to raise funds by selling her own works during the tour for the Liukuei Christian Orphanage, located in the mountainous region of Kaohsiung County, where she was raised under the intensive care of orphanage founder Father Yang and his wife. Thanks to the care she received at the orphanage, Yang grew up to be a courageous artist who now leads a happy and ordinary life as a mother and a wife.
Yang's lecture and fundraising tour on the U.S. West Coast will also take her to Seattle and Los Angeles.

In March 1974, Yang was brought to the orphanage after being abandoned in a marketplace in Kangshan, Kaohsiung County. Believing that the baby was "sent by the Lord, " Father Yang named the infant Yang En-dian, meaning "grace and benevolence from God." Little did he know that the child would grow up and develop a legendary friendship with then-President Chiang Ching-kuo.

President Chiang developed a special attachment to the child and arranged for her to receive surgery in Taipei to help straighten her spine and allow her to stand unaided. He even arranged for her to learn Chinese brush painting and calligraphy.
The child became a celebrity after a picture of her and President Chiang was made into a postage stamp.
Yang did not let the president down and grew up to earn her own living by selling her art works.

Yang gave birth last year to a healthy baby girl, whom she now bottle-feeds using her feet. She initiated a drive early this year to share and distribute breast milk to help mothers who cannot feed their babies with their own breast milk and whose babies are allergic to formulated milk.

DOC.HEADLINE: 66% OF OFFICE WORKERS INTERESTED IN WORKING IN CHINA: POLL

TEXT.P: Sixty-six percent of Taiwan office workers are interested in working in China, with many optimistic about China's development prospects, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by an online employment service provider.
The survey was conducted by Pan Asia Job Bank from Nov. 17-27 on 2,149 office workers via online questionnaires.
While 43 percent of the respondents expressed "a high degree of interest" in working in China, 23 percent expressed "an extremely high degree of interest."

On the reasons why they are considering working in China, 40 percent of the respondents said China's development prospects are promising, 30 percent said they want to increase their work experience, and 17 percent said jobs are hard to find in Taiwan.

The survey shows that most of the workers interested in working in China are in the 26-30 age group, accounting for more than 30 percent of all surveyed workers. The second largest group is those aged 40 or above, accounting for 24.5 percent of all surveyed workers.
Of these workers, 58.8 percent are men, 45.2 percent are university graduates, and more than 50 percent are single.

Among the workers who have no intention to work in China, many said they do not want to leave their home country because of family factors, and others said there are still a lot of development opportunities in Taiwan.
Other reasons cited by the workers for not considering working in China include the bad law and order situation in China and the lack of rule of law there.

On the top concerns in deciding whether they will actually accept any offer to work in China, 32 percent of the respondents mentioned the pay offered by Chinese companies, 26 percent said they will assess the prospect of the industry they plan to enter, 13 percent said they will consider the benefits offered by Chinese companies, and 12 percent said they will see if they are able to display their expertise in the job being offered.
Meanwhile, 93 percent of the respondents think it will pose a threat to local workers if the government is to allow Chinese citizens to work in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF AID EQUIPMENT FOR DISABLED

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang called Wednesday for government-initiated efforts to develop disability equipment and caregiving facilities to benefit the physically challenged.

At a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Su instructed that the establishment of a center for demography, health and social protection studies should be included in the Cabinet's "Mega Warmth" social welfare project to further improve care for the physically challenged.
Under the envisaged center, there should be an agency exclusively responsible for the development of disability equipment and caregiving facilities, Su said.

Noting that disability equipment and mobility aids are the eyes, hands, legs and feet of the handicapped, Su said the government should initiate efforts to enable this special group of people to have better "eyes, hands, legs and feet" so they can enjoy higher quality of life.

He said that in addition to developing and making aid and caregiving equipment, the government should also spare no efforts to improve public facilities accessible to and usable by the physically challenged to make Taiwan "a genuinely barrier free country."

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD OUTLINES PRIORITIES FOR 2007 ECONOMIC AGENDA

TEXT.P: The government will focus on three priorities next year in order to realize its economic growth target, with stimulating domestic demand topping the list, an official with the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.
Also high on the work agenda are stepping up research and development as well as boosting employment and narrowing the wealth gap and urban-rural divide, the official said.

He made the remarks after CEPD commissioners passed the country's 2007 economic development plan a day earlier, which set next year's economic growth target at 4.6 percent, the per capita gross domestic product (GDP) at US$16,886, the unemployment rate at 3.9 percent and the inflation at below 2 percent.

According to the official, the U.S. economy is expected to slow down next year which could affect Taiwan's export growth to some extent. And this is why Taiwan should spur domestic demand to bolster its continued economic expansion, the official said.

To realize this goal, he said, the government will continue expanding public investment, accelerating relaxation of regulations governing the service industry, perfecting the domestic investment environment and further invigorating the financial market.
"Through all these measures, we expect to see a 3 percent growth in private consumption in real terms in 2007," said the official.

With gross fixed capital formation expected to maintain the traditional level of around 20 percent of GDP, the official said, domestic demand will be able to contribute to more than 60 percent of next year's economic growth.

On the R&D promotion, he said, the government's 2007 budget for scientific and technological development will increase 10.8 percent from this year's level, which is higher than the average 7.9 percent growth posted in the past three years.

"We hope our R&D investment will spawn a cluster effect by attracting more high-tech companies to invest in Taiwan as well as enhance our labor productivity and expand value-added output, " the official explained.
While pursuing economic growth, the official said, the government will not overlook the importance of achieving balanced development.

"Equal emphasis will be given on creating jobs so that local citizens can make a living, " the official said, adding that the government's target is to keep the unemployment rate below 4 percent throughout next year.

Moreover, he added, the government will continue working to narrow the gap between the rich and the poor as well as bridge the divide between urban and rural regions. "Our target is to pull the wealth gap between the richest 20 percent and the 20 percent down to below six-fold," the official said.

According to the official, 2007 will be the first year of the first three-year stage of a long-term national development plan valid until 2015, which is aimed at increasing investment in Taiwan, creating jobs, narrowing the wealth gap and balancing development in metropolitan areas and the countryside.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Trial requested for former secret service chief Pollari.
Former military intelligence service chief Nicolo Pollari is among nine Itaians and 26 U.S. CIA agents that prosecutors have targeted on a trial of kidnapping of a Milan-based imam in 2003. The exiled Egyptian religious was suspected of being involved in terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR'S WIFE GRADUALLY REGAINS SPEECH

TEXT.P: The wife of Taichung Mayor Jason Hu is gradually recovering her power of speech after being in coma for the past 18 days since a serious car crash, a doctor at the Chi Mei Medical Center in southern Tainan County said Wednesday.
But Hou Ching-cheng, director of the center's intensive care unit, said Shao Hsiao-ling can only say a few words and cannot utter a complete sentence.

Her eyes can follow specific objects and her Glasgow coma scale had moved up one notch to 12 for the past few days, Hou said. Her medical team is now cautiously assessing when she can be transferred to a hospital nearer Taichung, where Hu and Shao live.
Shao has a swallow reflex but still requires a naso-gastric tube for feeding, Hou added.
Hu believes that a disc of him and their two children speaking has had an effect on bringing Shao out of the coma, according to Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi.

He is now recording another disc with Shao's favorite songs and music, as well as placing some of her favorite paintings and food around her hospital bed, in the hope that this will revive her senses of smell and listening as well as her memory, Hsiao said.

Hsiao said that Hu, who was only slightly injured in the accident, will return to work Monday and that he hopes to have his wife transferred to a hospital near Taichung. If that is not possible, Hu plans to travel to the Tainan hospital every day to see his wife, Hsiao added.

Hu and Shao were returning from a stumping trip to Kaohsiung Dec. 18 when their minivan was hit by another vehicle on the freeway that lost control after trying to overtake Hu's van on the hard shoulder.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY, FREEDOM BACKBONE OF TAIWAN'S SURVIVAL: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday democracy, freedom, peace and human rights is the backbone of Taiwan's survival and the platforms bridging Taiwan with the world's democratic community.

Making the remarks while receiving a delegation from the Washington-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) , a pro-independence lobbying group composed of mainly Taiwanese-Americans, Chen thanked FAPA for its firm support for Taiwan and its contribution in helping the country expand its foreign relations.
Over the past 25 years, FAPA has stood firm by the people of Taiwan and has worked hard to fight for the support of the U.S. Congress for Taiwan's democracy, freedom and human rights, Chen said.
He also expressed gratitude to FAPA for its efforts in promoting a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States.
He pointed out that the United States is engaging in FTA talks with South Korea and Thailand -- the seventh- and ninth-largest trading partners of the United States, respectively.
Taiwan, as the eighth-largest trading partner of the United States, is not inferior to the two Asian countries in terms of economic strength, Chen said.

He further cited statistics showing that the purchasing power of the Taiwan people is higher than the combined purchasing power of the six Central American nations that have signed the Central America Free Trade Agreement with the United States.

Pointing out that these six Central American nations are all Taiwan's diplomatic allies, Chen said the establishment of a Taiwan-U.S. FTA will bring substantial business interests to many American businesses and enhance the economic and trade relations between Taiwan and the United States.

He said that although Taiwan and the United States remain divided on trade issues such as pharmaceuticals, intellectual property rights and telecommunications, this should not hamper FTA talks, because the main purpose of FTA talks is to remove bilateral trade barriers.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SUES DPP TAIPEI MAYORAL RACE RIVAL

TEXT.P: James Soong, head of the opposition People First Party (PFP) who is running as an independent in the Dec. 9 Taipei mayoral election, sued his ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Wednesday for "allegedly trying to make him lose the election."

Chu Ou, convener of Soong's election campaign headquarters, took the legal action at the Taipei Prosecutors Office against Frank Hsieh, who claimed a day earlier that someone sent him an e-mail saying that Soong was slated to announce Dec. 6 that he was pulling out of the Taipei mayoral election.

Soong's election campaign headquarters denied the rumor and said that Soong will take part in the election. They argued that Hsieh's move, apparently aimed at making Soong lose the election, was in violation of the Election and Recall Law.

According to Chu, Soong has demanded that Hsieh clarify the source of the e-mail message. If Hsieh refuses to do so, it would mean that he had intentionally divulged the rumor in an attempt to make Soong fail in the election, Chu said.
With only three days left before Saturday's elections, Soong is determined to counter any defamation or smear through legal action, Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TAIPEI CITY COUNCIL CANDIDATE TO SUE KMT, PFP HEADS

TEXT.P: An opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) member said Wednesday that he will sue Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong on charges of vote buying, claiming that a recent "secret" meeting they had will seriously affect the Dec. 9 special municipality elections.
Chen Chien-ming, a TSU candidate in the Taipei city council election, announced his lawsuit plan against Ma and Soong at a news conference.
According to Chen, the Ma-Soong closed-door meeting last Friday will severely affect the outcome of the elections and was an "obvious violation" of Article 89 of the Election and Recall Law.

Chen claimed that Ma and Soong met in secret in total disregard of public sentiment and political ethics, to secure personal political gains. He further claimed that deals made between them regarding the elections were purely exchanges of political interests.

He urged Soong, who is running as an independent in the Taipei mayoral election, to "stop deceiving voters" and pull out of the race. Ma and Soong should also immediately apologize to the public, he argued.

Ma and Soong are reported to have met last Friday to discuss Soong's pullout from the Taipei mayoral election -- something that is widely perceived by the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the TSU, as a tactic of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the PFP to help the KMT's candidate, Hau Lung-bin, in the race.

It was reported that Ma and Soong reached three agreements to pave the way for their future cooperation in the Legislative Yuan and in the coming elections, but both Ma and Soong have denied such reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN SOFT TENNIS PLAYER PROMISING TO WIN TAIWAN'S 1ST GOLD AT GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Lee Chien-chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Hopes were strong Wednesday that Taiwanese woman soft tennis player, Chiang Wan-chi, would win the country's first gold medal at the 15th Asian Games being held in Doha, Qatar, later that day.

In a laudable performance earlier in the day, Chiang beat her South Korean rival, Kim Ji Eun, in the women's singles semifinal in four straight matches, to challenge China's Jiang Ting, who defeated Japan's Tsuji Miwa in the other semifinal that same day.

Taiwan hopes to win 15 gold medals at the 15th Asian Games that opened in Doha Dec. 1, but officials of the Cabinet-level National Council for Physical Fitness and Sports had not reckoned that anyone from Chinese Taipei's women's soft tennis team would win any golds.
A total of 391 athletes are representing Chinese Taipei in 34 events at the games, which will run through Dec. 15.

Chinese Taipei previously envisaged winning gold in about 10 sports -- taekwondo, archery, shooting, karate, tennis, soft tennis, table tennis, rhythmic gymnastics, bowling and golf. It was also hoping to pick up gold in the equestrian event.
As of Wednesday, day five of the games, Taiwan had won no golds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, TOKYO SIGN LETTER OF INTENT FOR CULTURAL COOPERATION

TEXT.P: Taipei City's Department of Cultural Affairs (DOCA) has signed with its Tokyo counterpart a letter of intent on exchanges of artists-in-residence, DOCA officials said Wednesday.

The document, which marks a planned joint effort to engage in closer and in-depth cultural exchanges between the two cities, was signed Dec. 1 in Taipei by Mitsuru Arakawa, deputy director of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Bureau of Citizen and Cultural Affairs, and Taipei City Director of Cultural Affairs Liao Hsien-hao, according to the DOCA.
Arakawa visited Taipei Nov. 28-Dec. 2 to attend the 2006 fourth Asian Performing Arts Festival held Nov. 29-Dec. 3.
During his stay, he visited the Taipei Artist Village, a DOCA-operated facility where artists-in-residence join hands with local talent to present performances, exhibitions and programs.

Mentioning that a similar facility named the Tokyo Wonder Site was inaugurated Nov. 17, Arakawa confessed that the city has little experience in operating this kind of "artist's colony. " Tokyo would like to borrow Taipei's know-how and experience in the field, he noted.

DOC.TEXT: International Herald Tribune : Defense nominee gains approval of US Senate panel.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Times: Sales of 4x4s slump The gas-guzzling "Chelsea tractor" has suffered a sudden decline in sales after a succession of threatened tax rises, The Times can reveal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, losing NT$0.007 to close at NT$32.297.
A total of US$1.159 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The greenback opened at NT$32.314 and fluctuated between NT$32.193 and NT$32.325.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAKING ALL-OUT EFFORT TO WIN KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Winning the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral election is the most important thing for the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) at present, and all other things are of secondary concern, KMT spokesman Huang Yu-cheng said Wednesday.

Huang told reporters that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou attaches great importance to the final three days in the lead-up to the election and has asked party officials and members to make all-out efforts to help KMT candidate Huang Chun-ying get elected.
The spokesman noted that Ma has already traveled to Kaohsiung 15 times to stump for the KMT nominee and will continue to do so in the next three days.

The KMT was defeated in the previous two mayoral elections in Kaohsiung, but the emergence of one corruption scandal after another involving the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in both the central government and the Kaohsiung city government in recent years has created a favorable climate for the KMT to recapture the Kaohsiung mayorship.
The latest polls show that Huang Chun-ying is ahead of his DPP opponent Chen Chu in voter approval by about 20 percent.

Asked to comment on a secret meeting last Friday between Ma and opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong, the KMT spokesman said the two leaders only talked about future cooperation between the two partners in the "pan-blue alliance" and reached some consensus in principle.

He said there was no quid pro quo about what the two parties should do regarding their candidates in the Taipei mayoral election and that neither had Ma and Soong signed any agreements to that effect.
Soong is running as an independent in Taipei against five other candidates, including KMT nominee Hau Lung-bin and the DPP candidate, former Premier Frank Hsieh.

A TVBS opinion poll released two days ago show Hau leading with a 54 percent voter approval rate, against Hsieh's 20 percent and Soong's 9 percent. These results represent only slight changes compared with previous polls -- an indication that the Ma-Soong meeting had little influence on the voters.

There was speculation after the Ma-Soong meeting that they might have reached a secret deal on Ma helping Soong get elected, with Soong pledging to support Ma to win the 2008 presidential election, but both leaders denied they discussed anything about the mayoral election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI SHARE PRICES CLOSE HIGHER

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 83.43 points to close at 7,693.33.
The bourse opened at 7,634.79 and fluctuated between 7,697.24 and 7,620.98 during trading. A total of 4.67 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.15 billion (US$3.5 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues moving up the most at 2.3 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares at 2.2 percent, construction stocks at 1.9 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals issues at 1.2 percent, banking and financial stocks at 0.4 percent, and cement shares at 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 939 to 311, with 165 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market rose Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 104 points to close at 7,714, with 35,769 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January increased 107 points to finish at 7,706, with 1,074 contracts traded, while March futures moved up 98 points to end at 7,695 with 10 contract transactions. June futures grew 40 points to close at 7,635, with one contract traded, while September futures rose 62 points to close at 7,505, with 22 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,610 for December, 7,599 for January, 7,597 for March, 7,595 for June and 7,443 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly higher.

December TE futures moved up 4.95 points to close at 325.95, with 3,762 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 3.8 points to finish at 324.1, with 82 contract transactions. March TE futures increased 0.9 points to close at 319.5, with six contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June and September.
December TF futures gained 5.2 points to close at 1,051.2, with 2,148 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures rose 4.6 points to close at 1,051, with 30 contracts traded.
September TF futures slid 18.8 points to close at 1,011, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION CALLS FOR STUDENTS TO HEED EYE PROTECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan Orbis International Foundation (Orbis-Taiwan) urged college students to pay more attention to their eyesight Wednesday after the results of a survey were released showing that 20 percent of students suffer from a high degree of myopia.

Tsai Jui-fang, chairman of Orbis-Taiwan, also said the survey, conducted by his foundation among 526 college students on eye checkups, eye pressure and eye structure, also found that 11 percent of students have high eye pressure.
Around 75 percent of the respondents said they had never had their eyes checked and had taken no preventive or therapeutic measures.
Only 2 percent of college students have no myopia, the survey found.

Although a great majority of college students know that a high degree of myopia can result in detached retina and glaucoma, as well as eye neural lesions, only 4 percent have regular checkups every six months.
Orbis and another charity organization embarked on a "make it bright" project in May, in which medical teams were invited to promote eyesight protection campaigns in colleges and universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEE CONDEMNS JUDICIAL YUAN FOR FREEING KEY WITNESS

TEXT.P: The legislature's Judiciary Committee adopted a resolution Wednesday condemning the Judicial Yuan for releasing Tang Shou-yi, who made and sold the gun supposedly used to shoot at the president and the vice president on the eve of the 2004 presidential election.

Tang, who fled the country after serving a jail term for another crime last May, claimed recently that he gave false testimony at the request of investigators probing the March 19, 2004 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.
He reportedly gave the false testimony in exchange for a chance to flee the country, a plan he claimed he executed after getting a phone call from a prosecutor.
Legislators asked why the prosecution did not seek to detain Tang, a key witness in the presidential assassination case, when his jail term expired.
The prosecution should at least have demanded a bond and restricted his residency before releasing him, said the lawmakers.
Deputy Justice Minister Wang Tien-sheng said prosecutors can do nothing if the judges decide to release a witness in a criminal case being handled in the court.
"This is what the criminal code stipulates, " said Wang, who claimed that he was not trying to shift the responsibility for releasing Tang to the Judicial Yuan.

Yeh Yi-jin, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker, said that since the prosecutors are not responsible for failing to request Tang's further detention, a resolution should be adopted to condemn the Judicial Yuan's judges for freeing him.

Her proposed resolution, which was later passed by the committee, said the Judicial Yuan's judges failed to detain Tang or ban him from leaving the country, leading to his claims made from abroad that have damaged the reputation of the country's police investigators and justice system.

In answer to lawmakers' demands for an investigation of the prosecutors to determine if they violated work ethics, Wang claimed that Tang's accusation against the prosecution was groundless and said he had confidence in the prosecutors.
The deputy minister said the government has put Tang on a wanted list and hopes he will return to Taiwan to face justice.

Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Lai Shyh-bao said Tang's accusations, however idle they might sound, have hurt the Ministry of Justice most, because people will have the impression that Taiwan is a police state where politics is in control of everything else.
Wang said he will forward the legislator's opinion to Prosecutor- General Wu Ying-chao, who is responsible for the investigation into the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIP HONORS PEOPLE FOR HELPING QUIT ALCOHOL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) sponsored a citation ceremony Wednesday for individuals and groups in honor of their outstanding efforts in helping aboriginal people quit alcohol, a council spokesman said Wednesday.

The activity was held in a carnival-like atmosphere in which private individuals and representatives from hospitals and charitable organizations from around the country were cited for their remarkable achievements in helping aboriginal people regain their health by staying away from alcohol.
The council also unveiled the results of its "quit alcohol" program in which the people and groups cited have taken part for many years.
CIP Vice Chairman Hsu Ming-yuan said that the council hopes to assist aboriginal people in quitting alcohol and maintaining health through the program.

Hsu ascribed the aboriginal people's shorter average life expectancy -- five years less than other Taiwan residents -- to alcohol addiction and stressed that it is very important to teach them the right way to drink yet stay healthy.

Traffic accidents, liver-related disease, cardiac problems, stroke, diabetes and obesity -- all closely related to alcohol abuse -- are the major illnesses afflicting Taiwan's aboriginal people, Hsu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PEOPLE HAVE HIGHER SAVINGS RATE THAN SHANGHAI, HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Lo Kin-fai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei people have a higher savings rate than their counterparts in Shanghai and Hong Kong, according to the results of a survey unveiled by the Hong Kong-based Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corp. Wednesday.
The bank conducted the survey among 500 residents aged between 18 and 64 in each of six cities in the region -- Hong Kong, Shanghai, Taipei, Kuala Lumpur, Seoul and Tokyo.

The results show that among Taipei, Hong Kong and Shanghai, Taipei people have the highest average savings rate, keeping 33 percent of their incomes, followed by Shanghai at 29 percent and Hong Kong at 25 percent.

The survey also found that if the respondents got a salary rise of 10 percent, 43 percent of Taipei people would save it, but in Shanghai, only 38 percent said they would save the money, compared with 42 percent in Hong Kong who said they would save half and spend half.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRIME VIA MINI LINKS ON DECLINE: KINMEN LAW ENFORCEMENT

TEXT.P: Crime penetrating into the outlying Kinmen Island via the "mini three links" has been on the decline over the past year, law enforcement authorities on the outlying island said Wednesday.

The conclusion was reached during a joint law enforcement meeting that was attended by prosecutors, police officers, immigration officials and coastal and national park patrol agents. Liu Chia-fang, chief prosecutor of the Kinmen Prosecutors' Office, presided over the meeting.

Citing statistics compiled by the office, Liu reported that 124 criminal cases related to the "mini three links" -- direct trade and shipping links between Taiwan's Kinmen and Matsu islands and Xiamen and Mawei ports in China's Fujian province -- were reported to Kinmen law enforcement authorities in the first 10 months of this year, down from the previous year's 174 cases, or nearly 29 percent year-on-year.
Liu called for closer cooperation between the various government agencies to further reinforce law and order on Kinmen Island.

In addition to cracking down on bogus and substandard products or human cargo smuggled in from China, Liu said that Kinmen law enforcement authorities will also focus efforts on detecting "ghost voters" to stamp out vote buying and irregularities prior to elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH TOLL IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN BUS CRASH RISES TO 22

TEXT.P: The death toll from the Dec. 3 bus crash in Tainan County's Meiling scenic area rose to 22 Wednesday after another female passenger died of serious injuries.
Chi Mei Medical Center in Liuying, Tainan County, declined to reveal details about the victim because her family requested that their privacy be respected.

The accident occurred when an 18-year-old bus carrying holidaymakers lost control on a steep downhill bend and plunged into a 30-meter ravine. The passengers aboard the bus were students of Tingchin Elementary School in Kaohsiung and their parents.
Most of the 45 people onboard were thrown out of the bus. Nineteen of them, including one of the two drivers, died on the spot.
The accident is described by Taiwan's highway authorities as the nation's worst road accident in the past 20 years.
Of the 23 injured passengers currently receiving treatment at five different hospitals in Tainan County, seven are still in intensive care units, with one listed in critical condition.
The injured comprise 12 males and 11 females, including 16 children.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN INDIGENOUS LEADERS SHARE EXPERIENCE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A pair of Canadian indigenous leaders shared experiences and expertise with their Taiwanese counterparts in a workshop on Canada's aboriginal self-governance and economic development Wednesday in Taipei.

"In terms of aboriginal relations and development, Canada was far from perfect -- it even made some mistakes in the past. But it can share its experience in aboriginal affairs with Taiwan," said David Hamilton, director of general relations of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) at the workshop, which was co-organized by CTOT and Taiwan's Council of Indigenous Peoples.

From 1870-1950, Canadian aboriginals went through a long period of discrimination just like aboriginals in other countries, said Larry Chartrand, a professor at the University of Winnipeg who also serves as the director of Canada's Aboriginal Governance Program.

It wasn't until 1969 that aboriginals in Canada mobilized and responded through massive protests and pushed for a new relationship between the Canadian government and aboriginal people. After three subsequent constitutional amendments in 1982, the Canadian government began to negotiate one by one with aboriginal tribes on self-governance issues, he said.
However, Canadian aboriginals still face great challenges today such as land claims, the scope of self-governance, and continuing poverty and discrimination, Chartrand noted.

"It's our belief that what you do today will affect seven generations later," said Romeo Crow, a Blackfoot tribe chief of the Siksika Nation, who also serves as president of the Aboriginal Financial Officers Association.

The Blackfoot tribe, a group of nomads that followed buffaloes in the past, has been trying to build its own business, increase the group's educational enrollment rate while at the same time preserving its tradition and culture, Crow said.
Self-governance is one thing, a vision to plan for the future instead of dwelling on the present is another, he said.

Robert M. Gates, President Bush's nominee to be defense secretary, won unanimous approval from a Senate panel on Tuesday after testifying that the United States was not winning in Iraq and that American failure there could ignite "a regional conflagration" in the Middle East.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DUMP VS. SAVE' RUMORS ABOUND IN TAIPEI MAYORAL CAMPAIGNSBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: All major candidates for Taipei mayor were straining to appeal to supporters Wednesday as rumors of "dumping one candidate to save another" abounded in the final stage of the municipal election campaign, with voters in the capital electing a new mayor and city council members Dec. 9.

The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate for mayor, former Environment Minister Hau Lung-bin, had KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and Honorary Chairman Lien Chan making a statement that "Hau is the only one we support" in an attempt to dash the rumor of Ma reaching a secret deal with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong under which Hau would be "dumped" for Soong to get elected.

Indeed, the Dec. 1 secret meeting just days before the vote between Ma and Soong, who is on leave from his party post to run as an independent, has created a bombshell in the election campaign the ruling Democratic Progressive Party was quick to seize as opportunity.

Former Premier Frank Hsieh, the DPP candidate vying with Hau and Soong, has issued a photo of the secret meeting and sent text messages to cellphones alleging that Soong would quit the race Wednesday, in a bid to generate sympathy for Soong among "pan-blue alliance" voters, hoping more Soong votes would reduce Hau's chances of winning. Hau had been leading in public opinion polls.

Observers said judging from Soong's strong reaction to the allegation -- he has sued the Hsieh camp for violating election law -- and his impassioned campaign speech against the KMT, Soong might have won some sympathy, to the DPP campaign's delight.
By increasing Soong's media exposure, KMT Taipei Chapter head Pan Chia-sen said, Hsieh's "real purpose" was more likely to boost the Soong campaign than to damage it.
If Hsieh's strategy works as he has wished, "pan-blue" voters will likely be divided into those voting for Soong and those voting for Hau -- benefiting Hsieh with the alliance's split vote.

Meanswhile, Hsieh himself faced a threat from his "pan-green camp" ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union's (TSU) "dumped" nominee, former media personality Chou Yu-kou, who was almost kicked out of the party and has lost the support of her party in the campaign.

Chou has been campaigning on a theme of anti-corruption, hoping to win the support of some 30 percent of the swing vote that she considered to be the "rational and conscientious" middle class. Her focus on Hsieh's suspected involvement in the Kaohsiung rapid transit scandal might cut a dent into the former Kaohsiung mayor's support base.

Lee Ao is another lone fighter in the six-way mayoral race in Taipei, campaigning on the theme of "opposing military purchases" and "standing up to the central government" in an attempt to solicit support from what he claimed to be "smart and young" Taipei citizens aged between 20 and 50.

"Follow the light, instead of following blue or green, " Lee, an independent lawmaker, urged his electorate, reminding the "blue" half of them not to be fooled a fourth time by the mantra of "pan-blue unity."

In the city council race, where 103 candidates are vying for 52 seats, what they hated most to hear from voters was "you're sure to win" -- a sentence that they feared could easily turn to mean "you're sure to lose, " because results are so uncertain they could go in any direction.

Against such a backdrop, any candidate is likely to cry out for "save me" votes no matter how certain he or she might be about the vote -- an interesting phenomenon at this late stage of the campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS AT TAICHUNG JAPANESE SCHOOL WISH MAYOR'S WIFE EARLY RECOVERY
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan Dec. 6 (CNA) (By Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Students of Taichung County's Japanese School, led by their president, dedicated 1,000 paper cranes to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Wednesday to wish his wife an early recovery from injuries sustained in an accident 18 days ago.

Mikio Tatsui, president of the Taichung Japanese School, presented the paper cranes -- a symbol of longevity -- to Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, asking him to relay the students' good wishes to the mayor and his wife, Shirley Shao.
Tatsui said the pupils began to fold the origami birds -- with the target set at 1,000 -- as soon as they heard the bad news about the accident.
Japanese people believe that by folding 1,000 paper cranes, the gods will grant their wish and make a sick loved one healthy again.
Tatsui also expressed hope that the mayor's wife could visit the Japanese School after she has fully recovered.

Hu has accompanied his wife at Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan County since Nov. 18. He indicated Wednesday that he will return to work at the Taichung city government from Dec. 11 after doctors agreed to move his wife from the intensive care unit to an ordinary ward.

The mayor's wife is now able to open her eyes and repeat simple words after her husband, such as "go home," but doctors said this does not mean her language-related brain functions are back to normal.
She was in a coma for 17 days after a medical team performed two separate surgical operations, amputating her left forearm and a ruptured spleen.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPANISH PARLIAMENT URGED TO FORM TAIWAN-FRIENDSHIP PANEL

TEXT.P: The Spanish parliament should form a special panel to promote friendship and goodwill exchanges with Taiwan, a senior Taiwan official said Wednesday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the call while meeting with a four-member Spanish parliamentary group, led by Elvira Velasco Morillo, a parliamentarian from the Spanish People's Party.

According to Wu, parliamentarians in more than 40 democratic countries around the world have formed Taiwan-friendly groups or Taiwan caucuses to boost substantative relations with Taiwan or help promote Taiwan's cause.

All those groups have indeed played significant roles in their respective countries in fostering closer links with Taiwan over the past decades, the country's top planner of policy toward China added.

"We keenly hope the Spanish parliament can follow suit to help enhance Spaniards' awareness of Taiwan and speak for Taiwan's cause in the international community, " Wu said, adding that the establishment of a Taiwan-friendly group would contribute much toward progress in Taiwan-Spanish relations and attract more Taiwan citizens to study, sightsee or engage in trading activities in Spain.

Noting that China has spared no efforts to suppress Taiwan diplomatically, Wu said China has not only relentlessly obstructed Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization, but has also used every possible means to block Taiwan from participating in non-political international activities, such as a U.N.-sponsored stamp design contest, world beauty pageants and global hairstyling contests. As a result, he lamented that Taiwan has constantly endured unfair and unreasonable treatment in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH COURT DEMANDS NEW DISTRICT COURT RULING ON EX-OFFICIAL'S RELEASE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court overturned a lower court decision to release former Vice Interior Minister Yen Wan-chin on bail Wednesday, demanding a new ruling on the prosecution's request to detain him.

The high court made the ruling in response to the prosecution's appeal against Taipei District Court's Nov. 9 ruling that Yen be freed on bail of NT$1 million. Five others accused in the same case were also released on bail ranging from NT$100,000 to NT$200,000.

The six were detained July 20 on charges of corruption and bribery in connection with the issue of licenses to build a cable car system in Taipei's Beitou District, a BOT project in Yangmingshan National Park.

The high court said in its ruling that Yen and the others accused were "strongly suspected" of having committed offenses as the prosecution has charged, and that their release could give them a chance to collude in evading the legal hooks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD REBUTS AMCHAM COMMENTS AS 'WARPED BY PREJUDICE'

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top economic policy planner rebutted Wednesday as "warped by prejudice" remarks by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) that Taiwan is "backsliding toward becoming a regional backwater" because of rigid regulations and lack of visionary government.

Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , was responding to a commentary published in the latest issue of the monthly AmCham magazine "Topics" that criticizes what it calls the Taiwan government's "plethora of regulations" on China-bound investment and cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges.

The article claimed that Taiwan has continued losing chances of taking full advantage of rapid economic growth in China's coastal regions over the past decade, and has consequently stagnated in its economic development.

Hu said the "Topics" commentary was warped by preconception and exaggeration, insisting the government has consistently pulled out all stops to promote commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait and create a sound investment climate.
Moreover, Hu said, the government has spared no effort over the years to ease restrictions on cross-strait economic and investment activities.

On providing visions for future development, Hu said the government has come up with "mega investment" and "mega warmth" projects that encourage investment in Taiwan and emphasize care for the economic and social well-being of the disadvantaged.

"We have unveiled five packages of measures to reinvigorate our economy from five dimensions -- industrial development, fianncial market reform, manpower cultivation, infrastructure construction and social welfare," Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BAGS TWO GOLD MEDALS AT ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar (CNA) (By Li Chien-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan won two gold medals at the ongoing Doha Asian Games Wednesday, both in the soft tennis categories.
Chiang Wan-chi won Taiwan's first gold medal by clinching the soft tennis women's singles title. The 23-year-old beat Jiang Ting of China in straight sets.
Soft tennis was created in the late 1800s in Japan by a Western missionary, who introduced a lighter racket and a slower, flatter rubber ball.

Meanwhile, Wang Chun-yen also won a gold medal by capturing the soft tennis men's singles title. He defeated his Japanese rival after six tough sets of competition. Taiwan's loss in the soft tennis group competition was avenged by Wang's victory, observers said.
A total of 391 athletes are representing Taiwan in 34 events at the games, which opened Dec. 1 and will run through Dec. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TOURISTS EXPECTED TO BOOST TAIWAN'S GDP: CEPD

TEXT.P: Chinese tourists are expected to contribute 0.1 percentage points per year to Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) after Taiwan opens its doors wider to Chinese tourists, according to a report released Wednesday by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The estimate is based on the presumption that 1,000 Chinese tourists are allowed to visit Taiwan per day, which translates into 365,000 people per year.

With each of the tourists staying in Taiwan for seven to eight days on average and spending an average of NT$5,600 (US$173) per day, they will increase Taiwan's private consumption by NT$16 billion per year, CEPD officials said.

Citing the spending data of Chinese tourists in Hong Kong, the officials pointed out that each Chinese tourist spent a total of HK$4,554 (US$586) on average during their stay in Hong Kong in 2005, with HK$2,979, or 65 percent, being spent on shopping, and HK$610 being spent on dining and drinking.
Compared with American and European tourists who tend to spend most on hotels, Chinese tourists obviously pay more attention to shopping than accommodations, the officials said.
The total of 12.54 million Chinese tourist arrivals in Hong Kong in 2005 contributed 4 percentage points to the GDP of the special administrative region for the year, they noted.
Based on the experience of Hong Kong, the CEPD proposed that Taiwan create a good shopping environment and step up marketing of indigenous products to appeal to Chinese tourists.
In addition, with hotels in Taiwan providing only a total of 21,000 rooms, it is urgent that more hotels be built to cope with the accommodation needs of Chinese tourists, according to the CEPD.
However, in light of the fact that Chinese tourists are less choosy about accommodations, the CEPD suggested that more three-star budget hotels be made available.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUS INVOLVED IN ACCIDENT PASSED SAFETY CHECKS IN OCTOBER: OWNER

TEXT.P: The owner of the tourist bus involved in last Sunday's terrible accident near Meiling scenic area told police Wednesday that the bus had just passed safety checks in October and was fitted with new tires which cost NT$14,000 each, not retreads as some media outlets have reported.

Lee Mao-chang also told police that he had hired Yen Hui-wen as the driver for the bus trip during which the accident happened, and not Wu Chien-hsin, who, according to some reports, was at the driver's seat at the time of the accident. Yen was among the 22 killed in the accident.
The bus plunged into a ravine in Nanhsi Town, Tainan County Sunday afternoon, killing 22 people on board and injuring 23 others -- making it one of the worst traffic accidents in Taiwan's history.
Police referred Lee to Tainan District Court prosecutors Thursday as investigations continued into the cause of the accident and who was actually driving the bus at the time that it occurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 7, or the 17th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOUSING COSTS SOAR OVER 70% OVER LAST 20 YEARS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Housing costs in Taiwan have skyrocketed 77.8 percent over the past 20 years, leading to a significant increase in the loan burden of homeowners, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday.
The survey was conducted by the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency on 20,000 households around Taiwan between Jan. 1 and Feb. 15 this year.
The survey found that a housing unit cost an average of NT$5.06 million (US$156,366) between 2002 and 2006, compared with just NT$2.85 million between 1982 and 1986.
During the 2002-2006 period, 50.06 percent of homeowners bought their homes mainly with mortgage loans, while 46.51 percent mainly used their own savings.
This compares with 42.69 percent of homeowners who relied mainly on mortgage loans during the 1982-1986 period.
Meanwhile, the survey shows that the ratio of homeowners using the preferential housing loans provided by the government reached a high of 14.5 percent during the 2002-2006 period.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG SHOULD QUIT POLITICS IF MAYORAL BID FAILS: DPP LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Calling People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong "the source of chaos in Taiwan, " ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators demanded Thursday that he quit politics if he loses the Dec. 9 Taipei mayoral election.

Soong is on leave from his party post to run as an independent in the Taipei mayoral race, which some observers say could lead to a split of the "pan-blue" vote between himself and the KMT's candidate, Hau Lung-bin, allowing the DPP's candidate, Frank Hsieh, to take the election.

During a press conference, Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, accused Soong of being a "master schemer" who is working with KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to "cover up each other's shady business" and to block the nation's development.

Ker said he is not concerned that the DPP might lose badly in the Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal elections. "What worries me is that the state machine might be torn apart," he said, referring to the PFP legislators' proposal for direct flights across the Taiwan Strait that had twice caused the legislature to "rev an empty engine" recently.
The DPP heavyweight said the "blue-green" standoff has gotten worse since Ma became KMT chairman last year, for which he said Soong should be blamed.
He called on voters to put an end to "extremism" in Taiwan and look at the two municipal elections with calm and reason, so that the country will not "continue to be divided."

Elaborating on Ker's accusations against Soong, DPP lawmaker Wu Ping-jui said Soong's PFP had hijacked the KMT in the legislature, leading to its failure to approve such important decisions as the nomination of the prosecutor general and the government bill on purchasing key weapon systems to upgrade the nation's defense capabilities.

"It's time that Taipei voters had a say on whether to let a minority party keep hijacking the majority view, " Wu said, adding that if Soong's extremism is not accepted by Taipei citizens, "he should leave politics for good, his PFP should disband, so that extremism will come to an end in Taiwan."

Kao Chih-peng, another DPP legislator, called the PFP, created after Soong lost his presidential bid in 2000, "the very source of Taiwan's turmoils" without which, Kao claimed, the arms purchase bill would have passed the legislature long ago and there would not have been three attempts to recall President Chen Shui-bian.
Kao said that the upcoming vote in Taipei is a vote of confidence on Soong and that voters should use their ballots to tell Soong where he should be headed.
"If Soong and his PFP are not accepted in Taipei, that will be a blessing for Taiwan. Otherwise, Taiwan is doomed to disaster, " he claimed.
DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yi said he is concerned that if Soong and Ma keep working together toward "something, " the DPP will be in opposition for 20 full years.

William C.T. Lai, another DPP legislator, also demanded that if Taipei voters veto Soong's mayoral bid this time, Soong should quit politics so that "rationality can prevail again in the legislature."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Tourism booms as arrivals hit nine million.
Bleary-eyed Russian tourist Elena Vladykina was taken aback by the orchid garlands and noisy drumming and dancing that greeted her on her 6am arrival at Changi Airport yesterday.
Then she realised she was being welcomed as Singapore's nine-millionth visitor -- a sweet ground-breaking number that caps a year of new records for Singapore's tourism industry.

Even 2006 still not end, Singapore already welcomed the nine-millionth visitor at Changi Airport yesterday. The number broke the record and exceeded the 8.9 million visitors last year.
