DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S IT INDUSTRY NEEDS TO CREATE NEW VALUE: VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's information technology (IT) industry need to create new value for its products in the face of intense global competition, Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen said Thursday.

According to Tsai, while continuing to improve their manufacturing technology and lower their costs, it is very important for the IT manufacturers to seek to raise the added value of their products through research and development and the establishing of quality and prominent brand names.

Tsai made the remarks while addressing a forum on innovation strategies for the technological and operational models of the IT industry. The event was held by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in cooperation with the Chung Hua Institution for Economic Research.

Noting that Taiwan's status in the world's technological development is becoming increasingly important with the joint efforts of the government and private sector, Tsai said the annual production value of the country's photonics industry topped NT$1 trillion for the first time in 2005, following a similar achievement by the semiconductor industry a year earlier.
Taiwan is also performing well in terms of technological innovation with the expansion of the production value of the IT industry, Tsai said.

For example, Taiwan ranked fourth and fifth in 2006 in terms of technological infrastructure and scientific infrastructure, respectively, among a total of 61 economies surveyed by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management Development, Tsai pointed out.

In 2005, Taiwan obtained the fourth largest number of patents in the United States for the seventh consecutive year, while Taiwan ranked second in the world in terms of the number of patents granted per million people, she said.

For the same year, Taiwan obtained 820 patents in the United States for inventions in the field of semiconductor technology, ranking it third in the world behind only the United States and Japan, Tsai said, adding that Taiwan also obtained the world's third largest number of patents for inventions in the field of liquid crystal display technology.

In terms of inventions in the field of computer hardware and software technology, the number of patents obtained by Taiwan also jumped from 239 in 2004 to 279 in 2005, marking a significant increase of 16.7 percent, with Taiwan's ranking advancing from eighth to fifth, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DYNAMIC KOREA' EXPOSITION OPENS IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: A 2006 "Dynamic Korea" exposition opened Thursday at the World Trade Center in central Taichung city, with more than 100 companies from the two countries taking part.

The 2006 "Dynamic Korea, " co-sponsored by the World Trade Center Taichung, the Korea Trade Investment Promotion Agency (KOTRA) and the Taipei-based Korean Trade Center, aims to increase the profile of South Korean culture, arts, tourism, merchandise and services to people in central Taiwan and to boost two-way exchanges, organizers said.

World Trade Center Taichung Chairman Lin Po-rung and officials of the Korean Mission in Taipei and the Korean Trade Center attended the opening, which featured South Korean traditional dances, music and taekwondo performances.
A kimchi eating competition and an auction of South Korean products were also held to warm up the event.

According to Lin, more than 400,000 Taiwanese tourists visited South Korea last year. In 2005, Taiwan was South Korea's fifth largest trade partner, while South Korea was Taiwan's sixth largest trade partner, with two-way trade amounting to nearly US$20 billion.
Lin expressed the hope that future trade, tourism and investment between the two countries could further flourish, based on the existing boom in exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPORTS 841 BIRD STRIKES IN FOUR YEARS

TEXT.P: A total of 841 bird strikes involving military or civil aircraft were reported in Taiwan from 2002 to 2005, posing a serious hazard to flight safety and leading to an unnecessary increase in the aviation industry's operational costs, according to a report released Thursday by the Bird Strike Committee under the Flight Safety Foundation-Taiwan.

Of these 841 cases, damage was caused to the aircraft in 108 cases, while in another 22 cases, the aircraft were either forced to return soon after takeoff, give up the flight, turn back while in mid-air or take emergency measures, with subsequent flights being canceled or runways being closed, the report said.
It said that over the last 16 years, four expensive aircraft belonging to the ROC Air Force have crashed as a result of bird strikes.

Although no bird strike-related crashes involving civil aircraft have been reported, airlines have suffered huge losses because of damage caused by bird strikes to the engines or other components of their aircraft, the report said.
Meanwhile, the report indicated that 686 of the total of 841 bird strikes occurred during landing, and the other 132 cases occurred during takeoff.
The committee proposed that in addition to installing bird dispersing devices, airports should also conduct bird species surveys and work out bird strike prevention plans to ensure flight safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 6.81 points to close at 7,686.52.
The bourse opened at 7,697.12 and fluctuated between 7,716.85 and 7,669.22 during trading. A total of 5.08 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$120.37 billion (US$3.72 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by construction issues at 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.5 percent, and textile stocks at 0.1 percent.

The four other major stocks lost ground, with paper and pulp issues moving down the most at 1.8 percent, followed by cement stocks and plastics and chemicals both at 0.5 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 717 to 499, with 196 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTARY INT'L PRESIDENT PRAISES CONTRIBUTION OF TAIWAN MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Rotarians in Taiwan have made a great contribution to Taiwan society and communities over the years, Rotary International President William Boyd said in an interview with the CNA Thursday.

Taiwanese Rotarians donated an average of US$138 per person per year to the Rotary Foundation, which is one of the highest figures in the world, Boyd said on the first day of his three-day visit to Taiwan. He added that membership in Taiwan has been growing strong, with a 10-percent increase this past year.

The most satisfying fact, according to Boyd, a New Zealander who is visiting Taiwan for the first time, is knowing that Rotarians in Taiwan have been helping communities and people through collaboration with government agencies and various organizations.
Boyd made the comments on the heels of an anti-drugs and anti-AIDS campaign in Taipei.

Rotary International is an organization of more than 32,000 Rotary clubs located in more than 200 countries. Its members are known as Rotarians. The purpose of the group is to bring together business and professional leaders who provide humanitarian service, encourage high ethical standards in all vocations, and help build goodwill and peace around the world.

Boyd, who was invited to join the Rotary club in 1971, said he has always been interested in helping people. Being a Rotarian has helped him expand his vision and get involved in many international events. As the current president, he has been able to travel with his wife Lorna to different countries and meet different people, he said.

In Uganda, Boyd met a young man who lost his arm in an accident and was later able to make a living as a cab driver after receiving an artificial arm, which was donated by a Rotary club and cost only US$50.
"It's amazing to see what a difference a little effort can make," he said.

Boyd, whose term as president will end in June 2007, has made "water, hunger and health" the three main areas for Rotarians around the world to work on in 2006 and 2007. Stressing his philosophy of "local Rotary clubs know best," Boyd said that he only sets a general direction and then lets local clubs make decisions on specific areas they want to work on.

Boyd said he believes Rotary International's role will increase in the future, adding that it is gratifying to see so many international organizations, such as UNICEF, actively approach Rotary International for collaborate on projects.

What Rotary International can do to help the world is not limited to its 1.2 million members, Boyd said, pointing out that several of the organization's programs involve women and youth as well and that Rotarians usually bring their family members along to participate in community services.
"The future of Rotary International is looking as good as ever, " Boyd said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES SHOULD BE RESOLVED PEACEFULLY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that cross-Taiwan Strait differences, particularly political differences, should be resolved peacefully via dialogue between the official leadership of the two sides, rather than through violence or other non-peaceful means.

During a visit to the Presidential Office by Bastiaan Belder -- a European Parliament member who authored a "China report" calling for fair treatment of Taiwan by all European Union member states -- Chen said he was very grateful that the European Parliament has passed many major resolutions regarding Taiwan's security concerns.

Chen said Taiwan's 23 million people should neither be isolated from the world nor have their human rights neglected. Rather, he said, they should have the right to pluralistic values, like all people do around the world.

He called for the international community to respect Taiwan people's collective human rights, pointing out that it is not only a right for the people in Taiwan to partake in global organizations and activities, it is a responsibility to do so, as part of one global society.

Taiwan should be accepted as part of the international community whether under the principle of universality prescribed by the United Nations charter, or in terms of the supreme "borderless" guideline that has been observed by the world's health and medical sectors, Chen noted.

Citing the "China Report, " which was passed Sept. 7 this year in a majority decision by the European Parliament, Chen said he could not agree more with the main thrust of the report, including opposition to an E.U. resolution to lift the arms embargo on China; firm support for Taiwan's participation in major international organizations, including the World Health Organization; and that controversies and differences across the Taiwan Strait should be solved via peaceful dialogue.

Chen said he salutes the European Parliament, which has vetoed lifting the arms embargo on China in nearly 10 resolutions in the past several years. He said once such an embargo is lifted, it would be tantamount to encouraging Beijing to further infringe upon human rights and facilitating arms sales to totalitarian China, which would in turn use the arms against peace-loving Taiwan.

The president also conveyed his appreciation to the European Parliament for its passage of a resolution calling for China to remove missiles that are deployed along its southeastern coastal provinces, targeting Taiwan.
He said he would like to see China rise as a democratic country, instead of a military hegemony.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTUH DEVELOPS ANTI-OXIDANT WATER EFFECTIVE AGAINST FREE RADICALS

TEXT.P: Taiwanese researchers have developed a device that can transform tap water into an "anti-oxidant water, " which has proven effective against free radical-related symptoms in dialysis patients, sources at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) said Thursday.

Free radicals, such as OH, NO, ROO, H2O2, HOC1, 1O2, and NOOO, have long proven to be health-damaging because they oxidize lipids, destroy cell membranes, and interrupt the functions of protein and DNA, leading to many diseases.
The anti-oxidant water is laced with active hydrogen atoms, which have been proved effective in "catching" radicals and neutralizing the harmful particles into a more neutral substance, they said.

Cheng Chien-ting -- a research fellow of NTUH's Medical Research Department -- said the machine combines a renovated filter, an electrochemical processor and a far infra-red apparatus to enrich ordinary water with hydrogen atoms.
Once the anti-oxidant water is absorbed into the body, the hydrogen atoms seek to combine with radicals to stop the oxidation process, preventing further damage caused by radicals, he said.

Cheng explained that the need for anti-oxidant water became urgent when they discovered that most patients requiring kidney dialysis suffer from a side effect caused by the therapy, in which the process mobilizes white blood cells and produces a large amount of radicals.
If left attended, the radicals would oxidize protein, low- density lipoproteins and red blood cells, causing inflammation, vessel hardening, and anemia respectively, he noted.
Under the auspices of the National Science Council, NTUH's research team collaborated with Wanhwa Hospital in Taipei City and began clinical testing of anti-oxidant water in 2002.

During a one-month observation of 37 patients, they added anti-oxidant water into standard dialysis fluid and found the vessel-hardening index decreased by 35 percent to 69 percent and the inflammatory index went down by 8 percent to 12 percent.
In 2005, NTUH conducted another test among 25 patients requiring kidney dialysis, whose condition also improved after being treated by anti-oxidant water.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOME 60,000 PEOPLE SMOKE MARIJUANA IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that marijuana is an illicit narcotic in Taiwan, over 60,000 people abuse the second-grade "soft drug, " the Department of Health's (DOH) National Bureau of Controlled Drugs reported Thursday.
According to bureau Director-General Chien Chun-sheng, at least 67,000 people smoked marijuana in Taiwan from 2003-2005, making it the third most abused drug among Taiwan's youth.

Although it is the Ministry of Justice's authority to decide whether the drug should be legalized for medical treatment purposes, Chien said that the DOH prefers not to make it a lawful substance for fear there would be no end to the trouble if it is legalized.
Abusing marijuana produces distorted perceptions and causes difficulties in thinking and problem solving in an abuser, making him or her a "lazybone," Chien said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly lower Thursday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 16 points to close at 7,698, with 32,712 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January decreased six points to finish at 7,700, with 915 contracts traded, while March futures increased one point to end at 7,696, with 34 contract transactions. June futures moved down 12 points to close at 7,695, with three contract transactions, while September futures dropped 14 points to finish at 7,491, with 10 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,714 for December, 7,706 for January, 7,695 for March, 7,707 for June and 7,505 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.

December TE futures decreased 1.55 points to close at 324.4, with 3,014 contracts traded, while January TE futures dropped 1.1 points to finish at 323, with 153 contract transactions. March TE futures decreased 0.1 point to end at 323.95, with two contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures gained 8.8 points to close at 1,060, with 3,345 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased nine points to close at 1,060, with 68 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.003 to close at NT$32.300.
A total of US$938 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.397 and hit a low of NT$32.188.

DOC.HEADLINE: UKRAINIAN CHILDREN'S CHOIR ON PERFORMANCE TOUR IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ukrainian children's Choir of Odessa is currently in Taiwan for a round-the-island performance tour.
The choir, which arrived in Taipei Wednesday, will perform in northern Hsinchu City Thursday.

Lu Hung-chih, chief executive officer of the Cardiac Children's Foundation of the Republic of China, said at a welcoming ceremony for the choir that the choir will perform at the National Concert Hall in Taipei City Dec.12 to raise funds for Taiwanese children with heart disease.
The choir will also perform in southern Chiayi city Dec. 8, southern Kaohsiung city Dec. 9 and in central Taichung city Dec. 10.

During the performance tour, the choir will perform "March, " "Dance of the Sugar-Plum Fairy, " and "Waltz of the Snowflakes" from "the Nutcracker" by noted Russian composer Peter Ilyich Tchaikovsky (1840-1893) . The choir will also perform several movie theme songs and seasonal selections, like Christmas carol.
Founded in 1981, the choir made a name for itself not only in Ukraine but throughout the USSR. The turning point emerged in 1991, when it performed at the International Festival of Choral Music.

It has since toured several foreign countries, including France, Lebanon, Austria, the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, England and Belgium. A significant point for the choir emerged in August this year, when they performed for the Pope at his summer residence.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP SHOULD STEP UP CONSOLIDATION: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Y. K. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) should step up consolidation after Saturday's mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said in an interview Thursday with Asia Television Ltd.
The two parties must engage in the field in order to win back power in 2008 by fielding a sole common candidate in the next presidential election, Wang said.

It is the desire of many in Taiwan that the KMT regain power, Wang claimed, expressing his belief that the KMT would do its utmost to better serve the people if it takes control of the central government again.

Wang, however, was reserved about the possibility of his own participation in the 2008 presidential election, saying that it would depend on the situation following Saturday's elections in the two special municipalities.

Commenting on the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, Wang contended that Hau Lung-bin, the KMT candidate, should be able to win the race in Taipei. But, he added, it is hard to predict the outcome in Kaohsiung since results of most public opinion polls show tied support for Huang Chun-ying, the KMT hopeful, and Chen Chu, the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The main opposition KMT and the PFP have already formed a loose "pan-blue alliance, " that also includes the New Party, against the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: POWERCHIP, ELPIDA TIE UP TO BUILD WORLD'S LARGEST 12-INCH CHIP FOUNDRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. (PSC) and the Japanese Elpida Memory Inc. signed an MOU in Taipei Thursday to establish a joint facility in central Taiwan for DRAM production.

When the PSC-Elpida DRAM fabrication facilities -- to be located in the Central Taiwan Science Park -- begin commercial operations -- hopefully in four to five years -- the new joint venture will be the world's largest 12-inch chip wafer foundry, with a total planned capacity of 240,000 wafers per month, said PSC Chairman Frank Huang.

These new DRAM fabrication facilities, carrying a pricetag of NT$450 billion (US$13.85 billion) , would also be the largest joint venture project in Taiwan in recent years involving domestic and foreign companies.

Huang said despite the efforts of Singapore and China to offer attractive packages for such a large-scale investment project, Elpida decided to choose Taiwan as the joint venture's location and to tie up with PSC, reflecting the importance that Elpida has attached to Taiwan's and PSC's competitiveness in terms of semiconductor manufacturing.

Also speaking at the MOU signing ceremony, Yukio Sakamoto, president and CEO of Elpida, said PSC and Elpida -- partners cooperating perfectly over the past several years -- will strive together concertedly, envisaging a challenge to the world's DRAM leader status in three years.

"Now it's time for us to make our move into PC DRAM production and become the number one player in the DRAM industry, " said Sakamoto. "We have decided to do so because we have gained credibility for our advanced DDR2 SDRAM, which was backed up by the high productivity at our E300 fab in Hiroshima. Moreover, we are very confident in our 70nm process technology, soon to be in mass production at our E300 fab. We are very happy to be able to transfer this new technology to ramp up our new joint fab," He added.

He also noted that a combination of Elpida's state-of-the-art technology and PSC's cost competitiveness in DRAM production will definitely translate into outstanding production capabilities in this joint venture, supplying high quality DRAM products at competitive prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS BASEBALL GOLD AT DOHA ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar, Dec. 7 (CNA) (By Lee Chien-chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan won a gold medal in the baseball event of the 15th Asian Games in Doha, Qatar Thursday, defeating Japan 8:7.

Chinese Taipei and Japan were locked in a see-saw struggle from the beginning of the game until the last innings, when Lin Chih-sheng struck a goodbye hit, with two on second and third bases, scoring two more points to give Chinese Taipei a win.
It marked the first Asian Games gold for Taiwan baseball and the country's third in the Doha games that will run through Dec. 15.

A total of 391 athletes are representing Chinese Taipei in 34 events at the games, with hopes of winning gold in about 11 sports -- taekwondo, archery, shooting, karate, tennis, soft tennis, table tennis, rhythmic gymnastics, bowling, golf and equestrian events.

DOC.HEADLINE: FEW USING 'MINI LINKS' TO RETURN FOR ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: No large crowds of passengers have arrived on the outlying island of Kinmen via the "mini three links" in recent days prior to Saturday's elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, a spokesman for the Kinmen port authorities said Thursday.

According to statistics compiled by the bureau, the number of travelers entering and departing the Kinmen port over the past few days has averaged 1,500-1,700 per day -- a normal level for the time of year.

Despite the fact that only Taiwan businessmen operating in Fujian Province and residents of Kinmen and Matsu are permitted to use the "mini three links", the spokesman claimed that the figures indicate that the mayoral and city council elections in the two special municipalities have not had much of an influence on Taiwan's general public.

As most of the 925 travelers who arrived on Kinmen Thursday were Chinese tourists from Fujian Province, not many Taiwan businessmen operating in Fujian are bothering to return home for Saturday's local elections, he explained.

At the same time, 753 Taiwanese businessmen left for China the same day via the direct shipping links maintained between Kinmen and the Fujian ports of Xiamen and Quanzhou -- commonly known as the "mini three links, " he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: IEAT RAISES CASH, GOODS VALUED AT NT$8.36 MILLION

TEXT.P: The Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei (IEAT) has raised cash and goods worth NT$8.36 million in an annual donation drive, an association spokesman said Thursday.
A total of 146 local companies made donations this year, including cash, food, clothes and electronic appliances, the spokesman said.
IEAT has organized the donation drive for 38 years, with a record high increase of 28.6 percent this year, he added
The donations will be distributed to 17 charity organizations and will benefit more than 6,000 people, according to the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTNU TO HOLD SEMINAR ON OPERA, THEATER, CULTURAL POLICY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan Normal University will organize an international seminar on opera, theater and cultural policy Dec. 18 in which it will invite local and foreign professionals in the field to exchange ideas and experiences, a university spokesman said Thursday.
The seminar will feature lectures, symposiums, master classes and videos, the spokesman said.

He pointed out that although the government-funded National Theater and the National Concert Hall were built to enhance the development of the performing arts, in the two decades since its establishment, the theater and the hall have failed to achieve this goal.

According to statistics, more than 75 percent of the world's operas are performed in German-speaking countries, and the seminar will explore the key elements in these countries' success, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE SURPLUS HITS NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade surplus posted in the first 11 months of this year stood at US$18.39 billion, an amount larger than the totals for 2004 and 2005, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Thursday.
The surplus might shore up Taiwan's trade surplus for 2006 to US$20 billion, marking a three-year high, said Lee Li-hsueh, director of the MOF's Department of Statistics.

Lee quoted MOF tallies as indicating that Taiwan exported US$19.54 billion-worth of goods and services in November, up 8.2 percent from the year-earlier level, while importing US$17.12 billion-worth of products and services, up 7.9 percent.
As a result, Lee said, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$2.42 billion in November, an increase of 10.9 percent compared with the same month of 2005.

In the first 11 months of this year, Taiwan's export trade totaled US$204.42 billion, up a whopping 13.3 percent over the year-earlier level, while the import trade amounting to US$186.03 billion, up 10.5 percent.
As a result, Taiwan posted a surplus of US$18.39 billion in the first 11 months of this year, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TO ORGANIZE INVESTMENT SEMINAR ON SOUTHEAST ASIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will organize a seminar on the general investment climate and regulations in Southeast Asia in central Taichung City Dec. 15 to help local companies better understand the region's business environment, officials said Thursday.

The officials said the ministry will invite experts to analyze the business opportunities and risks in the member countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) at the seminar, which will be held at the city's World Trade Center.
The experts will also elaborate on the current situation of foreign companies' operations in Vietnam and Thailand in order to provide references for Taiwan companies, officials noted.
They explained that in recent years, Chinese workers' wages have been growing, slashing Taiwan companies' profits.
As a result, Taiwan companies are moving their operations to Southeast Asia to maintain their competitive edge and to secure their market shares, according to the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI TERM RESULT OF `ONE CHINA' POLICY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian attributed Thursday the term "Chinese Taipei" that Taiwan has to use on many international occasions as a result of the "one China" policy adopted by Taiwan's previous government.

Speaking during a campaign rally in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Chen said he was asked by a visiting European Parliament (E.P.) member earlier in the day why Taiwan athletes are taking part in the 15th Asian Games in Doha, Qatar under the banner of "Chinese Taipei" rather than under the national flag of the Republic of China.

"I told Bastiaan Belder that the ROC has been forced since 1981 to use the 'Chinese Taipei' banner in the Olympic Games and the Asian Games and some other international activities partly because of the 'one China' policy followed by our previous government," said Chen whose Democratic Progressive Party advocates Taiwan's separate national identity.

The president was referring to Taiwan's previous ruling Kuomintang (KMT) which favors Taiwan's eventual unification with a democratic China. The KMT ruled Taiwan for more than five decades until May 2005.

Belder, an E.P. member from the Netherlands who authored a "China report" earlier this year calling for fair treatment of Taiwan by all European Union member states, is visiting Taipei at the head of an E.P. delegation. He met with Chen at the Presidential Office in the morning.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FLAT PANEL DISPLAY OUTPUT TO TOP NT$2 TRILLION BY 2015

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's flat panel display industry in the first 10 months of this year has surpassed NT$1 trillion, which is expected to boost the entire year's value to NT$1.29 trillion, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials announced Thursday.
The officials forecast that Taiwan is likely to replace South Korea as the world's top exporter and producer of large flat panels by the end of this year.
In addition, they estimated that the output value of local flat panel displays in 2015 will top NT$2 trillion.

The Taiwan government initiated a "two-trillion, two-star" project in 2002 with the aim of raising the production value of the semiconductor and display industries to in excess of NT$1 trillion by 2006.
The output value of semiconductors exceeded NT$1 trillion in 2004, according to statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS TO SPUR RELIGIOUS FREEDOM IN CHINA VIA EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan has spared no efforts to promote religious exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, with the aim of spurring religious freedom in China, the country's top China policy planner said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a European Parliament (E.P.) delegation headed by Bastiaan Belder, an E.P. member from the Netherlands.

According to Wu, the director of China's State Bureau of Religious Affairs, Ye Xiaowen, was invited by noted Buddhist Master Hsin Yun to attend the 11th world congress of the Buddha's Light International Association held in Taiwan in October.
"We welcomed Ye's visit and took advantage of it to push China to respect its people's religious freedom," Wu told his guests.

Later this month, Wu said, Ye will visit Taiwan again to attend another religious convention. "We hope Ye can conduct meaningful dialogue with his Taiwanese counterparts on various topics, including urging China to promise to respect its people's religious freedom, " Wu said.

On Belder's concerns about China's lax intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, Wu said Taiwan, like many other advanced countries, faces serious problems as a result of China's IPR infringements.
"We have been pushing China to improve its IPR protection and relevant law enforcement, " Wu said, adding that Taiwan has also been urging China to hold bilateral negotiations on IPR issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: EDITOR'S NOTE

TEXT.P:
Re: CEP Item 22, the 2nd paragraph that reads "...US$138..." should be changed to "... US$193.5..."
A corrected version follows:
ROTARY INT'L PRESIDENT PRAISES CONTRIBUTION OF TAIWAN MEMBERS

Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) Rotarians in Taiwan have made a great contribution to Taiwan society and communities over the years, Rotary International President William Boyd said in an interview with the CNA Thursday.

Taiwanese Rotarians donated an average of US$138 per person per year to the Rotary Foundation, which is one of the highest figures in the world, Boyd said on the first day of his three-day visit to Taiwan. He added that membership in Taiwan has been growing strong, with a 10-percent increase this past year.

The most satisfying fact, according to Boyd, a New Zealander who is visiting Taiwan for the first time, is knowing that Rotarians in Taiwan have been helping communities and people through collaboration with government agencies and various organizations.
Boyd made the comments on the heels of an anti-drugs and anti-AIDS campaign in Taipei.

Rotary International is an organization of more than 32,000 Rotary clubs located in more than 200 countries. Its members are known as Rotarians. The purpose of the group is to bring together business and professional leaders who provide humanitarian service, encourage high ethical standards in all vocations, and help build goodwill and peace around the world.

Boyd, who was invited to join the Rotary club in 1971, said he has always been interested in helping people. Being a Rotarian has helped him expand his vision and get involved in many international events. As the current president, he has been able to travel with his wife Lorna to different countries and meet different people, he said.

In Uganda, Boyd met a young man who lost his arm in an accident and was later able to make a living as a cab driver after receiving an artificial arm, which was donated by a Rotary club and cost only US$50.
"It's amazing to see what a difference a little effort can make," he said.

Boyd, whose term as president will end in June 2007, has made "water, hunger and health" the three main areas for Rotarians around the world to work on in 2006 and 2007. Stressing his philosophy of "local Rotary clubs know best," Boyd said that he only sets a general direction and then lets local clubs make decisions on specific areas they want to work on.

Boyd said he believes Rotary International's role will increase in the future, adding that it is gratifying to see so many international organizations, such as UNICEF, actively approach Rotary International for collaborate on projects.

What Rotary International can do to help the world is not limited to its 1.2 million members, Boyd said, pointing out that several of the organization's programs involve women and youth as well and that Rotarians usually bring their family members along to participate in community services.
"The future of Rotary International is looking as good as ever, " Boyd said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PROMISES TO PUSH FOR YACHT LAW

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang promised during a tour of the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday to push for legislation of a yacht law to boost the local yacht industry.

Su visited a yacht company in the city accompanied by Transportation and Communications Vice Minister Yu Fang-lai, Minister without Portfolio Ho Mei-yueh and Taiwan Yacht Industry Association Director-General Jack Chen.
Taiwan has a reputation as a "Kingdom of Yacht Makers, " but manufacturers are confined by the Law of Ships, Su noted, adding that it is therefore necessary to formulate a specific yacht law.
Chen said Taiwan is the world's fourth-largest yacht producer and that a yacht law will increase the country's international competitiveness in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE SEEKS UPSET WIN IN MAYORAL RACE LIKE BASEBALL TEAM

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate for this weekend's Taipei mayoral election likened Thursday his uphill electoral battle as the Taiwan baseball team's upset win in the Doha Asian Games against Japan.

Frank Hsieh, a former premier and mayor of the southern port city of Kaohsiung, told an evening campaign rally in Taipei Arena that the baseball team's upset win against Japan, an Asian baseball giant, embodies the Taiwan people's tenacity and fighting spirit.
"And the challenge facing me in my pursuit of Taipei mayorship is similar to our baseball team's first-ever gold medal victory in the Asian Games," an emotional Hsieh told jam-packed supporters.

Noting that Taipei is a traditional stronghold of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party, Hsieh said he has been fighting an uphill battle since joining the mayoral race.

"But I has never been daunted by cold-shoulderness or slightness shown by my rivals or some pundits. Taipei is my hometown. I have joined the race with a dream of makign it a better and brighter city. I hope Taipei voters can give me a chance. I would make Taipei a city of trust and love," Hsieh said.

Taiwan trailed 3-0 after two innings, 5-2 after five and 7-6 going into the bottom of the ninth. Then came first Baseman Lin Chih-sheng's one-out, two-run single that gave Taiwan a 8-7 win over Japan and its first Asian Games baseball title.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PREPARING FOR PREMIER'S VISIT TO GAMBIA: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is arranging for Premier Su Tseng-chang to attend the Dec. 15 inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh as President Chen Shui-bian's special envoy, Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsang said Thursday.
"It's an honor for Su to attend Jammeh's inauguration on behalf of the president, " Cheng said, adding that the MOFA is doing preparatory work.
It will be Su's first overseas visit since assuming the premiership in January. His two previous overseas travel plans were canceled at the very last minute because of China's obstruction.

Chen originally designated Vice President Annette Lu to attend Jammeh's inauguration for another presidential term. As the inauguration was postponed from Nov. 24 to Dec. 15, Lu had difficulties attending the occasion due to her busy schedule.

Lu will preside over the inauguration of the Pacific Congressional Caucus of the Democratic Pacific Union, which she founded in August 2005. Parliamentarians from more than two dozen countries will attend the inauguration, according to Lu.

As she attended the Gambian president's last inauguration, Lu requested President Chen send another envoy in her stead, and the president consented to the request. Chen decided on Dec. 4 to appoint Su as his special envoy to the Gambian president's inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FLAT PANEL DISPLAY OUTPUT TO TOP NT$2 TRILLION BY 2015(REPEAT)

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's flat panel display industry in the first 10 months of this year has surpassed NT$1 trillion, which is expected to boost the entire year's value to NT$1.29 trillion, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials announced Thursday.
The officials forecast that Taiwan is likely to replace South Korea as the world's top exporter and producer of large flat panels by the end of this year.
In addition, they estimated that the output value of local flat panel displays in 2015 will top NT$2 trillion.

The Taiwan government initiated a "two-trillion, two-star" project in 2002 with the aim of raising the production value of the semiconductor and display industries to in excess of NT$1 trillion by 2006.
The output value of semiconductors exceeded NT$1 trillion in 2004, according to statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPECTS TO SPUR RELIGIOUS FREEDOM IN CHINA VIA EXCHANGES(REPEAT)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has spared no efforts to promote religious exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, with the aim of spurring religious freedom in China, the country's top China policy planner said Thursday.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks while meeting with a European Parliament (E.P.) delegation headed by Bastiaan Belder, an E.P. member from the Netherlands.

According to Wu, the director of China's State Bureau of Religious Affairs, Ye Xiaowen, was invited by noted Buddhist Master Hsin Yun to attend the 11th world congress of the Buddha's Light International Association held in Taiwan in October.
"We welcomed Ye's visit and took advantage of it to push China to respect its people's religious freedom," Wu told his guests.

Later this month, Wu said, Ye will visit Taiwan again to attend another religious convention. "We hope Ye can conduct meaningful dialogue with his Taiwanese counterparts on various topics, including urging China to promise to respect its people's religious freedom, " Wu said.

On Belder's concerns about China's lax intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, Wu said Taiwan, like many other advanced countries, faces serious problems as a result of China's IPR infringements.
"We have been pushing China to improve its IPR protection and relevant law enforcement, " Wu said, adding that Taiwan has also been urging China to hold bilateral negotiations on IPR issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: NET INFLOW OF FOREIGN REMITTANCES REACHES US$4.24 B. FOR NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: Taiwan registered a net inflow of foreign remittances for the fourth consecutive month in November, with foreign investors remitting a net amount of US$4.24 billion in equity funds into the country during the month, according to tallies released Thursday by the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC).
The amount is the fifth largest recorded for a single month, FSC officials said, adding that it helped push Taiwan's stock index up 546.4 points in November.

From the start of this year until Dec. 1, foreign investors bought listed shares worth NT$4.37 trillion and sold listed shares worth NT$3.88 trillion, with net buying valued at NT$499.2 billion, the officials said.

During the same period, foreign investors purchased over-the-counter shares worth NT$240.5 billion and sold over-the-counter shares worth NT$246.9 billion, with net sales registering at NT$6.4 billion, they said.

Since the government began allowing foreign investment in Taiwan's stock market in December 1990, foreign institutional investors, foreign individuals and overseas Chinese had remitted a net amount of US$127.78 billion into Taiwan as of Nov. 30, they said.
A net inflow of foreign remittances totalling US$572 million was recorded on Dec. 1 alone, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 R&D SPENDING EXPECTED TO FALL SHORT OF 3% GDP TARGET: NSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan's overall R&D spending is not expected to reach 3 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) this year, and the target may not be reached until 2015, a National Science Council (NSC) official said Thursday.

NSC Vice Chairman Yang Hung-tun made the remarks after an NSC commissioners meeting during which the results of a nationwide survey of scientific and technological research and development in 2005 was unveiled.

According to the survey, Yang said, Taiwan's total R&D spending amounted to NT$281 billion (US$8.65 billion) in 2005, marking a year-on-year increase of NT$17.7 billion, or 6.7 percent. The amount was equivalent to 2.52 percent of the country's GDP for 2005, up marginally from 2004's 2.44 percent.
Judging from this trend, Yang said, the country's R&D spending will fall short of the 3 percent GDP target this year as set forth by President Chen Shui-bian.
"It is estimated that we may have to wait until 2015 to see the realization of this goal," Yang said.

In 2005, Yang said, the bulk of the R&D spending came from private enterprises, accounting for 66.9 percent of the total, higher than the figure of 64.8 percent in 2004; with the government sector contributing 31.5 percent, lower than 2004's 33.6 percent. The remaining 1.6 percent of R&D spending was by higher education institutions, non-profit private organizations and foreign institutions.

Noting that none of the government agencies have seen a budget increase in recent years, Yang said the NSC had proposed a 10-percent increase in its R&D budget for 2005, but the proposal was scaled down by the Legislative Yuan.

Another reason behind the slow increase in R&D spending lay in the lackluster results in prodding the private sector to invest more in R&D. "As a result, we have not yet attained the 3 percent GDP target," he added.

According to an NSC-drafted white paper on science and technology development for 2007-2010, the government's R&D spending will still just amount to 0.9 percent of GDP in 2009 and only reach 1 percent in 2015, while the private sector's R&D spending is estimated to amount to 1.7 percent of GDP in 2009 and 2.5 percent of GDP in 2015.
In 2005, Yang said, Taiwan had an R&D work force of 115,954, up 6.5 percent from 108,891 in 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. NOT EXPECTED TO LIFT ARMS EMBARGO AGAINST CHINA ANYTIME SOON: MOFA

TEXT.P: The European Union is not expected to lift its arms sales ban against China anytime soon as Beijing has not yet improved its human rights record and as the European Parliament has yet to enact a code of conduct with regard to arms sales, according to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official.

Speaking at a news conference Thursday, Soong Wen-cheng, deputy director of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, said the topic about whether to lift the China arms ban is expected to be on the agenda of the Dec. 14-15 E.U. summit.

"But we don't think the discussion will lead to a conclusion anytime soon since there has been no marked improvement in China's human rights record and the E.U. has not yet worked out any complementary measures, particularly a code of conduct, to cope with the situation following the removal of the arms embargo," Soong said.

Noting that the E.U. arms sales ban was imposed in 1989 in response to China's brutal crackdown on pro-democracy student demonstrators at Tiananmen Square in Beijing, Soong said it would be "tantamount to encouraging China to commit further human rights violations if the arms ban were to be lifted before Beijing took concrete and significant steps to improve its abysmal human rights record.

Soong further said the European Union will surely formulate a code of conduct and other regulations for its member states to follow in striking arms deals with China once it lifts the arms sales ban. "Since no such rules have been unveiled, we don't expect any decisive conclusion to be reached at the upcoming E.U. summit," he added.

Asked whether the recent formation of a China-friendly panel in the European Parliament -- the E.U.'s legislative arm -- by 16 parliamentarians would bring about any negative impact on Taiwan's substantive relations with the E.U., Soong said that given the close economic and trade ties between China and Europe and China's strenuous efforts to promote cultural exchanges with European countries, including the establishment of Confucius Institutes in several European countries to promote the Chinese language and culture, there is nothing unusual about the emergence of such a subgroup in the European Parliament.

According to Soong, the European Parliament has traditionally had more Taiwan-friendly members than China-friendly ones. Moreover, he said, Europe is a stable place, and its policy toward China has been transparent, namely, that two sides of the Taiwan Strait should engage in dialogue, seek solutions to their disputes by peaceful means and refrain from using military force to resolve their differences.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 8, or the 18th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy-three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH TO ENCOURAGE LABELING OF TRANS FAT CONTENT IN FOOD

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) has no plans to ban the use of trans fats in the country, but it will encourage food manufacturers to label the trans fat content in their products starting next year, a DOH official said Thursday.

The DOH will gauge public reaction toward the measure before further deciding whether to make the labeling compulsory, according to Weng Hsiu-chen, a section chief at the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation.

Weng made the remarks in response to a decision by New York City to prohibit restaurants from using cooking oils containing trans fats -- which are produced during the hydrogenation process of vegetable oils and are believed to be a major cause of heart disease.

Weng pointed out that a series of discussions on the issue of trans fats have been held in Taiwan since 2001 and that in the latest one which took place in August this year, the DOH decided to first require oil suppliers to label the trans fat content in their products before expanding the policy to packaged food manufacturers.
In assessing the influence of fats on human health, the amount of fats consumed must also be taken into consideration, instead of only focusing on what kind of fat is being consumed, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN URGES MEDIA NOT TO 'OVERINTERPRET' HIS ACTIONS

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said Friday that he has been accompanying DPP Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Chen Chu during her last-minute campaigning out of pure friendship and that this should not be "overinterpreted."

Lin, who has led a nearly secluded life since withdrawing from politics five years ago, said that he and Chen have maintained a friendship for 30 years and that he is simply expressing his concern for his friend's election bid by accompanying her during the campaigning.

Lin declined to speculate on how Chen will fare in Saturday's election, saying that it is not appropriate to do so as it may influence voters. "The decision is for the voters to make, and we should respect their decision," he added.

A former DPP member speculated the day before that Lin's campaigning for Chen Chu and the DPP's Taipei mayoral candidate, Frank Hsieh, several days ago may be a sign that he is preparing to return to the DPP as the new party chairman. The speculation was also reported by the media.
Lin responded to the reports by saying the DPP politician and the media have overinterpreted his actions, stressing that the last thing he is interested in doing is getting back into politics.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN TELECONFERENCE ON AIDS TO BE HELD DEC. 12

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) is scheduled to hold a digital video conference Dec. 12 to give U.S. and Taiwan experts and academics an opportunity to exchange views on AIDS and AIDS prevention.

One of the key participants in the teleconference -- to be held to mark the World AIDS Day -- will be Regan Hofmann, an AIDS activist who was recently named the new editor-in-chief of POZ, a magazine for people with HIV/AIDS.
Hofmann, who tested positive for HIV 10 years ago, will talk during the teleconference about the challenges of living with HIV.

Other participants in the teleconference -- dubbed "Compassionate Treatment for People Living With HIV/AIDS in the U.S." -- will include Dr. Anthony Pramualratana, executive director of the Asian Business Coalition on HIV/AIDS and Thailand Business Coalition on AIDS, and Busaba Virochpoka, head of Corporate Affairs, Standard Chartered Bank Thai.

Representing the Taiwan side at the teleconference will be Dr. Twu Shing-jer, a former Department of Health minister who currently serves as chairman of the Taiwan AIDS Foundation; Yang Chieh, founder of the HarmonyHome Taiwan; and Yang Ching-hui, chief medical officer with the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: 56% OF OFFICE WORKERS LIVE FAR FROM HOMETOWN FOR JOB: POLL

TEXT.P: Fifty-six percent of office workers in Taiwan live far from their hometowns for the sake of their jobs, according to the results of a survey released Thursday by an online employment service provider.
The survey was conducted by 104 Job Bank from Nov. 17-27 on 1,078 office workers, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.98 percentage points.

On the motives behind their decision to accept offers to work in places far away from home, 70.9 percent of the respondents mentioned the availability of more job choices in other places, 52.4 percent named the availability of more suitable career arenas, and 40 percent mentioned the availability of better pay.
Taipei City remains the region where the highest number of workers want to work, followed by Taichung City, Hsinchu City, Kaohsiung City and Taipei County, according to the survey.

As to their top concerns in renting a home while working in other places, 35.1 percent of the respondents will consider the distance from their office, 28.4 percent will consider the price, 16.9 percent will consider if the site provides complete facilities, 9.1 percent will consider the safety of the surrounding neighborhood, and another 9.1 percent will consider the convenience of transportation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 65 points to close at 7,633, with 35,681 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 65 points to finish at 7,635, with 1,155 contracts traded, while March futures lost 82 points to close at 7,618, with 11 contract transactions. September futures moved down 57 points to close at 7,443, with 91 contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 7,698 for December, 7,700 for January, 7,700 for March, 7,687 for June and 7,500 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mostly lower.
December TE futures dropped 3.9 points to close at 320.5, with 2,935 contracts traded, while January TE futures lost three points to finish at 320, with 123 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures moved down 5.6 points to close at 1,054.4, with 2,239 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures dropped five points to finish at 1,054.4, with 68 contracts traded. September TF futures lost 14.8 points to close at 1,021, with two contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened low and closed lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 50.22 points to close at 7,636.3.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,658.04 and hit a low of 7,601.3 during trading. A total of 4.39 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.63 billion (US$3.26 billion).
Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.3 percent, followed by textile stocks at 0.9 percent and foodstuff issues at 0.2 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with plastics and chemicals shares moving down the most at 1 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares and banking and financial shares both at 0.8 percent, paper and pulp issues at 0.5 percent, and cement stocks at 0.4 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 655 to 540, with 216 stocks remaining unchanged.
