DOC.HEADLINE: MORE JAPANESE EXPECTED TO VISIT TAIWAN DURING NEW YEAR HOLIDAYS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Yang Ming-chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of Japanese tourists visiting Taiwan during the 2007 New Year holidays beginning Dec. 23 is expected to increase by 5 percent, JTB Corp. estimated Friday.

About 648,000 Japanese people are expected to make leisure trips overseas during the Dec. 23-Jan 3 New Year holidays, marking an increase of 3.2 percent over the year-earlier level, said officials from the JTB -- Japan's major tourist and travel agencies association.
Of that total, 5 percent -- or 42,000 people -- are expected to head to Taiwan for their holidays, according to results of a JTB survey.

Of that total, about half or 355,000 people will holiday in Asia, up 5 percent over the year-earlier level. Of the 355,000 potential tourists, 90,000 will travel to China for the holidays, 84,000 will head to South Korea, 42,000 bound for Taiwan, and 35,000 go to Hong Kong, according to the JTB survey.
Some 29.4 million other Japanese citizens said they will make leisure trips in the country during the New Year holidays.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEALDLINE NEWS

TEXT.P: The Japan Times: Koizumi offers to revisit Pyongyang

Former Japanese Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi has shown a willingness to make a third trip to North Korea, this time as a special envoy, to try to break the deadlock in Japan's relations with the country, a source said Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Iraq Policy 'No Longer Viable', Panel Advises Bush to Wage 'Diplomatic Offensive'. Bush administration policies have set off a " slide toward chaos" in Iraq, a bipartisan national commission declared Wednesday in a major reappraisal that challenges President Bush's view of the war and builds new pressure for disengagement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRAFFIC SAFETY AWARDS TO BE PRESENTED DEC. 15 IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei and Tainan City Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair announced Friday that the 2006 traffic safety awards presentation ceremony will be held Dec. 15 in Tainan City, with singer Evonne Hsu being invited as this year's traffic safety spokeswoman.

At a press conference held at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , the officials said the awards will be presented to those dedicated to the promotion of traffic safety, including volunteer workers, government officials and public organizations.
Hsu, who also attended the press conference, encouraged members of the public to make volunteerism a part of their life.
After the press conference, Hsu proceeded to Taipei's Wenchang Elementary School to work as a volunteer school crossing guard for the day.

According to the officials, this year's traffic safety awards will be given to 26 volunteer school crossing guard, 27 teachers, 26 volunteer traffic police officers, 27 professional drivers, 27 traffic police officers, 12 schools and several government officials dedicated to road safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTH NEW AND OLD ID CARDS CAN BE USED TO VOTE AT MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Both new and old identification cards may be used by voters to obtain ballots in Saturday's mayoral and city councilor elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) announced Friday.

Polling stations in Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two largest cities and special municipalities -- will accept either new or old ID cards presented by voters to obtain election ballots, Hsieh Ai-ling, director of the MOI's Department of Population Administration said.
Hsieh quoted the latest MOI tallies as indicating that as of Oct. 6, there were still 397,975 citizens in Taipei and 192,987 citizens in Kaohsiung who have not yet renewed their old ID cards.
Hsieh called on those who have not renewed their ID to act fast on it, as old ID cards will become null and void by Jan. 1, 2007.

Government and public agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and banks, have said that starting Jan. 1, 2007, old ID cards will not be accepted for new passport applications, or for monetary or financial services.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ENTREPRENEURS WIN TECH MANAGEMENT AWARDS

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu county-based Chinese Society for Management of Technology (CSMOT) awarded two local entrepreneurs Friday with Technological Management Awards (TMA) in recognition of their contributions toward technological development.

The entrepreneurs include Jonney Shih, chairman and chief executive of Asustek Computer Inc., for creating a world-renowned brandname -- Asusteck -- and turning his Taipei-based company into the world's largest maker of motherboards and graphic cards, CSMOT Chairman Wei Cho-ho said.

The other recipient is Delta Electronics Inc.'s Chairman Bruce Cheng, whom Wei praised as a distinguished entrepreneur -- successfully developing a 15-strong company into the world's leading manufacturer of switch power supplies, employing near 50,000 people around the globe.

CSMOT, founded in 1990 to promote professional activities related to technological management, also awarded the Quanta Research Institute, founded by Quanta Computer Inc., and the Kwang Yang Design and Research Center of Kwang Yang Motor Co. Ltd. with awards for best enterprise teams.

The Quanta Research Institute, employing 2,000 experts in design and development, is known globally for its cooperation with several of the world's leading research institutes on an ambitious "US$100 laptop" project called "One Laptop per Child, " aimed at revolutionizing global education for children.

The Kwang Yang center was cited for its outstanding achievements in developing and building an innovative and complete motorcycle production line, covering everything from research and design to marketing, according to CSMOT.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD SEEKS TO REMOVE INVESTMENT BARRIERS FROM SERVICE SECTOR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is planning to begin cooperating with local governments to create a better investment climate for service-oriented businesses starting early next year, a CEPD spokesman said Friday.

To gain an in-depth understanding of the gap between central government policies and practical execution by local authorities and companies, the CEPD has begun a series of seminars with 17 local governments to draft measures promoting the service sector, as service-oriented businesses have become the major force driving up Taiwan's economy, the spokesman said.

Citing statistics compiled by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, the spokesman reported that revenues generated by the service sector already accounted for 73.8 percent of the country's gross domestic product and that some 5.8 million -- out of a total of more than 10 million workers -- were employed in the sector by the end of the third quarter of this year.

The CEPD's ongoing efforts formed part of its action guidelines crafted for the service industry in 2004, which focused on promoting 12 key businesses and 24 flagship projects aimed at creating added value and service quality for the domestic industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, THAI UNIVERSITY FORGING TIES TO BOOST EXCHANGES
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Wu Hsie-chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Medical University (CMU) and Mahidol University of Thailand signed a cooperation agreement Friday aimed at boosting exchanges of students and teachers.
The document was signed by Kuo Chin-tang, a professor at CMU's College of Public Health, and Phitaya Charupoonphol, dean of public health at Mahidol University.
During the ceremony, Phitaya invited CMU to attend an international conference on medical care to be organized by Mahidol University.
Kuo said the two sides will now move toward conducting exchanges focusing on the topic of health, including issues surrounding the environmental impact on public health.
Under the memorandum, the colleges agree to step up personnel and information exchanges, as well jointly hold academic meetings and organize research-oriented activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUTURE OF NEW PARTY TIED TO ELECTION RESULTS

TEXT.P: The New Party (NP) would consider whether to dissolve itself if four of its Taipei city council candidates fail to get elected in Saturday's elections, NP Chairman Yok Mu-ming said Friday.

Yok urged NP supporters to build up a sense of urgency and not overlook the importance of the Taipei City Council election to the party's future, and called for continued support to help the NP continue playing a role in Taiwan's politics.

Although Yok was reluctant to predict the results of the elections, he made it clear that he would propose to discuss the issue within the party if the four candidates -- all party elite members -- fail to win the elections.

Such an outcome would mean the NP is unable to gain public recognition, and it must face up to the issue whether it should continue to exist or not, Yok said, noting the NP, as a democratic party, must deal with its future through due process.

The New Party fielded Lee Ching-yuan in Wenshan and Taan districts, Hou Kuan-chun in Wanhua and Chungcheng districts, Pan Huai-chung in Shihlin and Peitou districts and Wang Hung-wei in Sungshan and Hsinyi districts.

The NP forms a loose "pan-blue alliance" with the main opposition Kuomintang and the People First Party against the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union. It controls only one seat in the "pan-blue" controlled Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD PLEDGES TO STEP DOWN IN CASE OF ELECTION FAILURE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman called widespread support Friday for the party's candidates in Saturday's municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, and vowed to step down if both its mayoral hopefuls lose at the polls.
Yu Shyi-kun issued the call at a news conference held at DPP headquarters, with just one day left before the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in the two special municipalities.
Yu urged DPP supporters to remain optimistic and continue backing all DPP candidates because the party hopefuls still stand a good chance in the two cities' elections.

The Taipei mayoral election will be an interesting and exciting race, while the Kaohsing mayoral race will be a neck-to-neck competition, Yu predicted, and vowed that he would quit the DPP chairmanship should both Frank Hsieh and Chen Chu -- the party's mayoral candidates in Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively -- lose the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CHECKING IF CHINA-MADE GREEN BEAN NOODLES CONTAIN CARCINOGEN

TEXT.P: The Department of Health is checking if a brand of China-made green bean noodles containing a cancer-inducing chemical has been imported into Taiwan, a DOH official said Friday.
According to Chen Shu-kung, head of the DOH's Bureau of Food Sanitation, five to ten Taiwan importers have imported similar products for domestic sale.
Although a preliminary investigation indicates the brand in question has not been imported into Taiwan, the DOH is checking importers' details to ensure the information is accurate, Chen said.
He said the DOH will make the results public as soon as the investigation is completed.

The DOH made the move in the wake of reports that "Longkuo fensi" produced by a company in Yantai in the northeastern Chinese province of Shandong has been discovered to contain sodium hydroxymethylsulfinate, a chemical used as a bleaching agent for textiles, soap and molasses.

Lin Chieh-liang, a toxicologist at Linkuo Chang Hung Memorial Hospital, noted that unscrupulous manufacturers often use the substance to bleach rice noodles, green bean noodles or fruit to give their products a better look.

If consumed by humans, the chemical can cause headaches, vomiting, shortness of breath and relapse of asthma, Lin said, adding that long-time consumption of the chemical can also lead to cancer of the digestive tract.
Lin urged consumers to avoid buying rice noodles and green bean noodles that are excessively white in color.

If consumers are worried that rice noodles or green bean noodles they bought may contain sodium hydroxymethylsulfinate, they can soak the noodles in cool water for one hour before cooking them, Lin said.
While cooking, the pot should be left uncovered to speed up the volatilization of the chemical, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'PHANTOM VOTERS' IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG WARNED NOT TO VOTE IN ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) warned Friday that "phantom voters" should not vote in Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung because they may be prosecuted for violating criminal law.

CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you defined a "phantom voter" as someone who does not actually reside in Taipei or Kaohsiung, but who has registered a household in one of the two cities before Aug. 9, simply for the purpose of voting in the elections.
Teng explained that according to Article 146 of the nation's Criminal Law, a phantom voter could face prosecution for obstructing the correct polling results of an election.

Statistics provided by the CEC earlier this month showed abnormal increases in the number of voters in both cities, with Taipei and Kaohsiung gaining 15,606 and 7,994 voters respectively this year, compared with 2005.

The spokesman also reminded all candidates that all campaigning activity must cease by 10 p.m. Friday on the eve of the election, and that no newspapers will be allowed to publish any campaign advertisements Saturday when the elections take place.
Six candidates, including three independents, are competing in the Taipei mayoral election, while the Kaohsiung mayoral race is a battle among five candidates.

The Taipei mayoral hopefuls include former Environmental Protection Administration chief Hau Lung-bin of the opposition Kuomintang, former Premier Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, and People First Party Chairman James Soong, who is running as an independent.

Conspicuous among the Kaohsiung mayoral candidates are former Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Huang Chun-ying, nominated by the KMT; former Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu of the DPP; and Legislator Lo Chih-ming of the Taiwan Solidarity Union.
In addition, 103 candidates are competing for 52 seats on the Taipei city council, while 78 others are vying for 44 seats on the Kaohsiung city council.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN ACTIVITIES SHOULD COME TO AN END BY 10 P.M. FRIDAY

TEXT.P: All campaigning activities related to Dec. 9 Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections will be prohibited after 10:00 p.m. Friday, the Central Election Commission (CEC) announced earlier that day.
CEC spokesman Teng Tien-you urged candidates and all campaign personnel to heed the rules, reminding voters to carry with them their ID cards, seals and voting guides when heading to the polls.
Polling hours begin Dec. 8 at 8:00 a.m. and last until 4:00 p.m., with ballot counting expected to be completed by 8: 00 p.m. the same day, Teng added.

Noting that voters should carry the newest version of their ID cards to the polling booths, Teng also urged the so-called "ghost voting population" -- those who do not really live in Taipei or Kaohsiung city but have recently registered their households in these two cities -- not to break the law by casting ballots in the elections.
In addition, Teng continued, print media will be prohibited from publishing campaign ads Saturday, and should not publish electoral surveys aimed at stumping for any individual candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.09 to close at NT$32.390.
A total of US$1.003 billion changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.420 and hit a low of NT$32.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAW ENFORCEMENT WATCHING FOR IRREGULARITIES PRIOR TO ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: With less than a day to go before Saturday's polls in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, 81 cases of irregularities involving the two mayoral races and 509 related to the city council elections had been reported to the law enforcement authorities, a Ministry of Justice (MOJ) official said Friday.

Tsai Ching-shiang, director of the ministry's Prosecutorial Affairs Department, said that six people involved in three of the cases related to the city council elections in the two special municipalities had already been indicted by prosecutors -- three people in one case by the Taipei Prosecutor's Office and three people in two cases by the Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office.
According to Tsai, prosecutors and investigation agents had stepped up efforts to prevent irregularities and vote buying in the runup to the elections.

Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission reminded all the candidates that their electioneering must end by 10 p.m. Friday and that print media are not allowed to run any campaign advertisements on polling day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER TO VISIT SWAZILAND FOR BILATERAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long will leave for Swaziland Saturday for the 10th Taiwan-Swaziland meeting on economic cooperation slated for Dec. 11-12.

The meeting, aimed at boosting economic relations between the two countries, will be held in Mbabane -- the capital city of Swaziland -- with Chen heading the Taiwan delegation of officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the government-operated International Cooperation and Development Fund and the Institute for Information Industry.
Swaziland is one of Taiwan's key economic and trade partners in southern Africa, with two-way trade reaching US$23.23 million in 2005, up from US$2.7 million in 2000, marking nearly 9-time growth.
In the January-October period this year, bilateral trade between the two countries amounted to US$24.23 million, posing a year-on-year growth of 22 percent.

Taiwan exports to Swaziland reached US$20.7 million in the 10-month period, recording 8-percent growth, while imports from Swaziland amounted to US$3.53 million, a significant rise of 45O percent, according to MOEA tallies.

In terms of investment, 22 Taiwanese businesses have made investments in the garment, machinery and paper box industries in Swaziland as of November, with total investments amounting to US$65.7 million.

Taiwanese garment manufacturers have created over 16,000 jobs for the Swazi people in recent years, the MOEA said, noting the performance may help Taiwan's garment sector make inroads into the African market.

Topics at the upcoming Taiwan-Swaziland economic meeting will include ways to help improve the investment environment for Taiwanese businesses operating in Swaziland; cooperation in promoting infrastructural construction in Swaziland; cooperation between Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises and their Swazi counterparts; and information and communication technological cooperation, according to the MOEA.
During a stay in Swaziland, the Taiwan delegation will visit Prime Minister Absalom Themba Dlamini, as well as top officials in economic and foreign affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY URGED TO JOIN 'MUTUAL HELP' SOCIAL WELFARE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Taichung county government officials urged more healthy elderly people Friday to join a "mutual help" social welfare program in exchange for any help they might themselves need in the future.

Wang Hsiou-yen, director of the county government's Bureau of Social Affairs, made the appeal after the successful implementation of a pilot social welfare program conducted in a community in the county by the Hondao Welfare Foundation.

The program, which the foundation adopted from models used in Japan and Hong Kong, calls for able-bodied elderly to extend help to other, less fortunate elderly citizens as a form of "insurance" should they require help themselves in later life.
According to Wang, the amount of time people devote to helping others can be accumulated and registered in exchange for the same quantity of service they might need in the future.
The three-month pilot program has received a warm reaction, Wang added.
According to Wang, many elderly people feel they are simply waiting for death as they cannot find any value in their lives, even though they might still be in otherwise good health.
Wang urged more elderly people to join the program to help other old people and create a sense of value in their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUSEUM EXHIBITION DEMONSTRATES FEATS OF ART RESTORATION

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts in the central city of Taichung is holding an art exhibition from Dec. 8 to Jan. 28 to demonstrate how its experts have restored more than 70 damaged paintings by the late Taiwanese artist Shyi Der-jinn.
The artist left 1,500 of his paintings to the Shyi Der-Jinn Foundation before he died in 1981 at the age of 59.
The foundation, set up with an initial endowment of NT$3.5 million, became operational in 1985 but found itself lacking the expertise to maintain the artworks.

In 1988, the foundation decided to donate all the paintings by Shyi in its possession to the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts. The museum began to receive the paintings in 1991 but found that some of them were damaged.
At the time, the museum did not have the funds to hire art restoration experts to repair the paintings.

Through the help of the preparatory office of the National Center for Research and Preservation of Cultural Properties, the museum obtained a NT$2 million donation from Diageo Taiwan Inc. for the repair project.
It took two experts many years to restore the damaged paintings to pristine condition, according to the museum's head curator, Hsueh Pao-hsia.
Hsueh said the exhibition presents proof that Taiwanese experts are equipped with the expertise to restore damaged artworks back to their original condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 TAX REVENUES MAY HIT ALL-TIME HIGH: FINANCE MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The country's tax revenues topped NT$1.512 trillion (US$46.53 billion) in the first 11 months of this year, a figure that would comfortably allow 2006 annual tax revenues to top NT$1.6 trillion, an all-time high, Ministry of Finance (MOF) officials said Friday.

The NT$1.6 trillion tax revenues -- with December's predicted NT$87.2 billion included -- would be an all-time annual high in Taiwan's history, said Lee Li-hsueh, director of the MOF's Department of Statistics.

Lee quoted MOF tallies as indicating that national tax revenues totaled NT$147.9 billion in November, representing an increase of 0.9 percent over the year earlier, while January-November national tax revenues totaled NT$1.5122 trillion, representing a 2.2 percent year-on-year increase.
If December revenues remained at the December 2005 level of NT$87.2 billion, Lee said, the 2006 annual tax revenues are still expected to exceed the government's target by NT$122.2 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Bush Backs Away From 2 Key Ideas of Panel on Iraq
President Bush moved quickly to distance himself on Thursday from the central recommendations of the bipartisan Iraq Study Group, even as the panel's co-chairmen opened an intensive lobbying effort on Capitol Hill to press Mr. Bush to adopt their report wholesale.
Wall Street Journal:As Journalists Die, A Russian Paper Faces Grim Future
Russia is one of the most dangerous places in the world to be a journalist. And the most dangerous place to be a journalist in Russia is Novaya Gazeta. It has lost three reporters in the past six years. One was bludgeoned to death with a hammer. Another died of an allergic reaction relatives suspect was caused by poisoning. A third, Anna Politkovskaya, was shot dead two months ago in the elevator of her apartment block.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Times: Blair tries to bridge the gap between Bush and 'realists' on Iraq strategy President Bush defiantly insisted yesterday that America would still achieve "victory" in the Iraq war as he distanced himself from this week's report of the Baker-Hamilton commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO FOREIGN INSURANCE COMPANIES APPROVED TO SET UP BRANCHES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission has recently approved applications from two foreign insurance companies seeking to establish branches in Taiwan, officials said Friday.
The approval of the applications by Aviva Ltd. and HSBC Life International Limited brings the total number of foreign insurance companies in Taiwan to nine, the officials noted.
They pointed out that Aviva group is the U.K.'s largest insurance group with assets totalling around US$560 billion (NT$18.1 trillion).
Aviva offers products such as life insurance and pensions, with its business covering Europe, Asia, Australia and the United States, officials went on.

Aviva has been rated A+ by Fitch Ratings, an international rating agency, the officials said, adding that the group's application to operate in Taiwan shows its confidence in the country and will have a positive impact on the domestic insurance market.

HSBC Life International Limited is a subsidiary of the HSBC Group, which is Hong Kong's largest financial group, serving 79 countries and territories with total assets of around US$1.74 trillion (NT$52.6 trillion), they said.
The company is also the largest pension fund management institution in Hong Kong, earning the highest premium income and profit in the local market, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATION CRITICAL TO STOP TAIWAN'S HUMAN TRAFFICKING: U.S.

TEXT.P: Anti-trafficking legislation is desperately needed if Taiwan is to prevent its human trafficking problem from worsening, Taiwan and U.S. officials said Friday in a video conference.

Taiwan was listed on the Tier 2 Watch List in the 2006 U.S. Trafficking in People Report published in June, primarily because it failed to show increased efforts in fighting trafficking during the past year, said James Husky, chief of the political section at the American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office.

Human trafficking is seen as the modern-day slavery, which is very different from slavery in the past, said Washington-based John Miller, Director of U.S. State Department's Office of Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons (G/TIP) , in the conference that gathered public prosecutors, officials and law enforcers from Taipei and Kaohsiung.

About 800,000 people are trafficked across national borders each year, which does not count millions trafficked within their own countries, said Miller, whose office coordinates the U.S. efforts in the global fight against modern-day slavery, including forced labor and sex exploitation.

Being listed on the Tier 2 Watch List means Taiwan does not comply with the minimum standards and requires special scrutiny because of a high or significantly increasing number of victims and a failure to provide evidence of increasing efforts to combat human trafficking.
Miller said the "Three Ps" principle -- prevention, protection and prosecution -- should be used when dealing with trafficking issues.
The national action plan to fight trafficking, which was initiated by the Executive Yuan, was a great first step for Taiwan, said Mark Taylor, Senior Coordinator for Reports of G/TIP.
Legislation makes sure the traffickers will be punished, but the implementation of the law is equally important as well, Taylor noted.
Public prosecutors and officials from Taipei and Kaohsiung mentioned the difficulties under the current system to define trafficking cases and identify victims.
"If a person ends up losing his freedom, it's a trafficking case, "Miller said, adding that government agencies should also work with non-government organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: DROP IN 2006 WEDDINGS

TEXT.P: The number of couples that got married in the January-October period amounted to 109,870, a decrease of 945 compared with the same period of last year, according to statistics released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
One in every 5.5 of the new marriages was between Taiwanese and foreigners, down from the record in 2003 that saw one intermarriage in every 3.1 couples, the tallies show.

As of October this year, there were 11,974 Taiwanese citizens married to people from China, including Hong Kong and Macau, posing a 0.7 percent decrease over the level of the previous year, while 8,077 locals were married to people from other countries, down 32.7 percent.

In terms of divorce, 53,563 couples broke up in the period, an increase of 1,742 couples compared with the same period of last year. Among them, 2,956 were intermarriages between Taiwanese and Chinese, including Hong Kong and Macau people, according to the DGBAS.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO END CHINA TOURISM TALKS BY YEAR'S END: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Taiwan still hopes to wrap up tourism talks with China by the end of this year, despite the fact there is only a short time left, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said Friday.

Wu made the remarks during a seminar with a group of election observers from Hong Kong and Macau, with less than one day to go before Saturday's city mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two special municipalities.

According to Wu, China seems to have recently slowed its pace in technical talks with Taiwan due to the approach of the elections, but the MAC chairman expressed the hope nonetheless that the talks will conclude before the end of the year if China accelerates its pace to allow its people to sightsee in Taiwan.

Commenting on Saturday's elections, Wu said that the polls will mark a key turning point in Taiwan's democratization no matter what the results will be. Every peaceful election is a victory for Taiwan's people, he added.
Democracy has turned into a key part of the everyday lives of the Taiwan people and this goes far beyond political divergences and ethnic differences, he said.

But Wu lamented China's cool response to Taiwan's rapid democratization and pointed out that Beijing's reluctance to face the democratic development in Taiwan and its misconception of the situation has become the biggest hurdle to improving bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUNDATION TO HOLD CHARITY CONCERT FOR RARE DISEASE SUFFERERS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Foundation for Rare Disorders will organize a charity concert Dec. 15 with the aim of raising NT$10 million for rare disease sufferers and their families, a foundation spokesman said Friday.
The spokesman said the money will be used to help 227 patients in the next three years.
These patients' medical expenses are very high and the rare diseases are mostly hereditary, the spokesman pointed out.
The diseases can affect several members of a family at the same time, which imposes a heavy financial burden on the family, the spokesman added.
Over the past seven years, the foundation has spent more than NT$20 million providing care for 602 patients and their families, the spokesman said.
More than 20 enterprises and charity groups have sponsored the event, with a number of famous singers expected to perform, the spokesman noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE EXPECTED TO EXCEED US$400 BILLION THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade is expected to exceed US$400 billion this year, with the trade surplus possibly reaching US$20 billion, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials said Friday.

According to BOFT statistics, Taiwan's exports totaled US$36.66 billion in November, an increase of 8.2 percent over the same month of last year, while imports amounted to US$17.12 billion, representing a year-on-year growth of 7.9 percent and resulting in a trade surplus of US$2.42 billion, representing 10.9 percent growth over the same month of last year.
BOFT officials noted that the good performance in foreign trade is significant despite huge hikes in oil and raw material prices during the year.

Overall, Taiwan's foreign trade in the first 11 months totalled US$390.46 billion, with exports and imports registering growth of 13.3 percent and 10.5 percent, respectively, over the same period of 2005, which resulted in a trade surplus of US$18.39 billion.
The officials forecast that Taiwan's foreign trade is expected to reach its target of US$400 billion this year, with exports and imports expected to register year-on-year growth of 10 percent each.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFRICAN BIRDS SIGHTED IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Wild Bird Society urged bird lovers Friday not to buy foreign species because smuggled birds are unquarantined and pose a threat of avian influenza.
The society made the appeal after its members sighted two African bird species -- the golden-breasted starling and the superb starling -- near the Kaohsiung Museum of Fine Arts.
A spokesman for the society said it is believed the birds -- which come from northeastern Africa -- were probably pets that had escaped from their cages or had been released by their owners.
He said such foreign species not only endanger Taiwan's indigenous species because of fighting over habitat and food, but also pose the risk of a bird flu pandemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES AMBULANCES TO INDIAN CHARITIES
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Paul Kuo and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The chairman of a Taiwan charity, on behalf of the Taiwan government and non-governmental organizations, donated five ambulances to three Indian charity organizations Friday.

Chen Che-yan, chairman of an ad hoc Taiwan charitable organization formed to offer assistance to India after several natural disasters hit the nation, presided over the donation ceremony, along with Taiwan's representative to India, Andrew Kao.

The three Indian charities are based in Himachal Pradesh, Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh, respectively, which were struck by severe earthquakes measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale in 2001 and 2005, as well as by the South Asia tsunami of 2004.
The ceremony was held at a hotel in the Indian capital of New Delhi and was attended by representatives from the three charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISRAELI VOCALIST TO PERFORM IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Israeli vocalist David D'or will sing at a charity concert to be held next Monday at the Taipei city government's performance hall, Israel's representative to Taiwan said Friday.
The concert will be sponsored by the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, which represents Israeli interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.

Raphael Gamzou, head of the Israeli representative office said the concert is not only aimed at raising funds for Taiwanese in need but also at recognizing Buddhist Master Cheng Yen, founder of the non-profit Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and its members for longstanding efforts in offering humanitarian aid to needy people around the globe. The proceeds raised from the concert will be donated to the Tzu Chi foundation.
Noted Taiwanese pop singer Yin Chen-yang, who won the 1993 Golden Melody Award for best male singer, will also perform at the concert, according to Gamzou.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC.9 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Saturday, Dec. 9:
09:00, Vice President Annette Lu will cast her ballots for Taipei mayoral and councilor elections at a polling station on Hsinyi Road.
09:30, President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Lu will attend the opening of a Democratic Pacific Union-consored meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 9, or the 19th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti-communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The China Times: "Pan blue," "pan green" heavyweights duel on
eve of mayoral elections
The United Daily News: Polls open today in Taipei, Kaohsiung
The Liberty Times: Campaigns boiling on eve of mayoral elections
The China Post: Voters go to polls in Taipei, Kaohsiung
The Taiwan News: President urges voters not to slip into reverse
The Taipei Times: Parties make last-ditch call for support

DOC.HEADLINE: POLLS OPEN IN TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Polls are open Saturday for the mayoral and city council elections in the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Voters in the two cities began casting their ballots at 8 a.m. Polling stations will remain open until 4 p.m.

Six candidates are vying for Taipei mayor, in the following balloting order: independent Legislator Lee Ao, former Environmental Protection Administration chief Hau Lung-bin of the Kuomintang (KMT), former Premier Frank Hsieh of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chou Yu-kou of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), People First Party Chairman James Soong, who is running as an independent, and independent Ko Tzu-hai.

The five candidates running for the Kaohsiung mayoral post are former Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Huang Chun-ying of the KMT, former Council of Labor Affairs Chairwoman Chen Chu of the DPP, Lin Chih-sheng representing the Taiwan Defense Alliance, Legislator Lo Chih-ming of the TSU and independent Lin Ching-yuan.
A total of 103 candidates are competing for 52 seats on the Taipei City Council, while 77 others are vying for 44 seats on the Kaohsiung City Council.

According to election commissions of the two cities, 2 million residents in Taipei City are eligible to vote in the city's mayoral and city council elections, while the number of eligible voters for the Kaohsiung City elections totals 1.14 million.
The commissions estimated the turnout rate at 70 percent, with the results of the elections expected to be out at 7: 30 p.m. at the earliest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES AMBULANCES TO INDIAN CHARITIES(Repeat)
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 8 (CNA) (By Paul Kuo and T.C. Jiang)

TEXT.P: The chairman of a Taiwan charity, on behalf of the Taiwan government and non-governmental organizations, donated five ambulances to three Indian charity organizations Friday.

Chen Che-yan, chairman of an ad hoc Taiwan charitable organization formed to offer assistance to India after several natural disasters hit the nation, presided over the donation ceremony, along with Taiwan's representative to India, Andrew Kao.

The three Indian charities are based in Himachal Pradesh, Gujarat and Andhra Pradesh, respectively, which were struck by severe earthquakes measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale in 2001 and 2005, as well as by the South Asia tsunami of 2004.
The ceremony was held at a hotel in the Indian capital of New Delhi and was attended by representatives from the three charities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Bush Not Swayed by Findings in Iraq Study. President Bush, responding Thursday to a scathing bipartisan assessment of the Iraq war, vigorously rejected the idea that deteriorating conditions there require the United States to scale back its goals and said that he remains committed to "victory in Iraq."

DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times Ex-governor arrested over bidding scandal
Police on Friday arrested Tadahiro Ando, who resigned as Miyazaki governor earlier in the week after a no-confidence motion, for allegedly collaborating with other officials in rigging bids for public works projects.

DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Genting wins Sentosa IR bid.
Genting International and partner Star Cruises have sailed smoothly to the finishing line, taking home the Sentosa Integrated Resort as its prize.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Genting succeeds to land the Sentosa in IR bid.
Popular Genting International and partner Star Cruises defeated the Eighth Wonder and Kerzner-Capitaland team and won the Sentosa Integrated Resort (IR) yesterday because experts' affirmation and tourists' votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TO REOPEN MECHANISM FOR NOMINATING CONTROL YUAN MEMBERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian will re-activate the mechanism for his nomination of members of the Control Yuan next week, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Saturday.
According to Wang, Vice President Annette Lu will serve as convener of a recommendation and screening team for the nominations.

Wang made the remarks on the sidelines of an international conference on parliamentarian affairs and democratic politics organized by the Democratic Pacific Union, a regional organization initiated by Lu to promote democracy, peace and prosperity for pan-Pacific countries. Chen and Lu attended the conference.
Wang told CNA that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus will propose next week that the president withdraw an old name list of Control Yuan nominees and submit a new one.

Asked about a possible hopeful for the Control Yuan leadership, Wang said it is the president's right to nominate the person he believes is best for the position. However, he said he will give the president his opinion if asked.
Wang reiterated that if Chen submits a new name list of nominees for the Control Yuan to the Legislative Yuan, the legislature will "definitely" act immediately to review the bill.

The opposition-controlled legislature has shelved a nomination list proposed by Chen since last year on claims that some nominees are not up to the post and the Control Yuan -- the country's supreme watchdog body -- has been prevented from performing its functions, including screening petitions from members of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYORAL ELECTIONS DEMONSTRATE TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the peaceful, rational and orderly process of the mayoral elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung attests to the country's democracy.

Noting that a lot of people have taken to the streets over the past few months to express their disapproval or support for his leadership, Chen said he not only has listened to their voices but also is willing to reflect on the government's policy and make improvements accordingly.
Chen said this is a democratic achievement that strikes a sharp contrast to the situation 30 years ago, when Taiwan's leaders used military or police forces to crush the voices of the people.
The president made the remarks during an international conference held in Taipei by the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) on the role of legislature in democratic politics.

According to Chen, Taiwan's legislature has played a critical role in the country's democratic achievements, abrogating a number of outdated laws and establishing a sound foundation for the rule of law.

Chen said the smooth operation of the legislature is the cornerstone that ensures the stability and development of a democratic society, because the legislature is the center of a democratic system, with legislation, budgets and treaties all requiring the approval of the legislature before they can be put into force.

While political parties can monitor the administrative branch through their representatives in the legislature, the legislature must not become a battleground for vicious political competition, Chen said.

Any arguments between political parties in the legislature should be founded on national interests and the people's well-being rather than on partisan interests, he said, adding that the purpose of the mechanism of checks and balances is not intended to contain each other but to prevent either party from abusing its power.

Meanwhile, Chen noted that the DPU has made many achievements since its inauguration Aug. 14, 2005, which include the establishment of the Pacific Disaster Prevention and Control Center and the organization of an election observation delegation for Taiwan's "three-in-one" local elections in 2005.

These achievements have demonstrated what he described as Taiwan's "soft power" and have successfully linked together 28 countries on the Pacific Rim to form a united and strong concentric circle, he said.

He said the forthcoming establishment of the Pacific Congressional Caucus Dec. 10 will mark an important step forward for the DPU, as the caucus will become the largest international congressional organization in the region.

Describing the Pacific region as "the most vital territory on earth, " Chen pointed out that the region occupies one-third of the world's total area, is home to 40 percent of the world's population and accounts for more than 50 percent of the world's economic strength.

Through the Pacific Congressional Caucus and the cooperation of parliamentarians of various countries, the DPU will secure democracy, peace and prosperity in the Pacific region and further promote these achievements to non-DPU members and the rest of the world, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS WOMEN'S TEAM GOLD IN TENNIS AT ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Qatar, Dec. 9 (CNA) (By Li Chien-chung and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan won the women's team gold in tennis at the 15th Asian Games in Doha, Qatar, Saturday, defeating India 2:1.
The victory marked the first Asian Games gold for Taiwan's women's tennis team and was the 6th gold medal for Taiwan at the games.
Hsieh Su-wei, Chan Yung-jan, Chuang Chia-jung and Chan Chin-wei will share a national sport award of Taiwan worth NT$16.5 million (US$509,260) upon their return to Taiwan.

As of Saturday, Taiwan athletes had accumulated six gold medals, three silvers and 11 bronzes at the games, putting the country in 6th place among the 45 countries and territories participating in the games.
A total of 391 athletes are representing Taiwan in 34 events at the games, which opened Dec. 1 and will run through Dec. 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO MEN NABBED FOR SMUGGLING PIGEONS

TEXT.P: Two men were arrested Saturday on a freighter in Putai Port in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan, with 179 stud pigeons smuggled from China via the "mini three links, " according to coast guard officials.

The two men, surnamed Lu and Chuang, were caught while transporting the pigeons to Taiwan proper for sale. The "mini three links" refer to the postal, transport and trade links between Taiwan's outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu and the ports of Xiamen and Mawei in China's Fujian Province.
The men confessed that the pigeons, which came from Belgium, are worth nearly NT$20 million (US$617,280).
The police are still checking the sources and the possible selling channels of the smuggling ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMAN PRAISES TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: A member of the U.S. House of Representatives issued a statement Friday in the U.S. Congress honoring and acknowledging Taiwan's democratic practices and respect for human rights.

Republican House Representative Thaddeus G. McCotter, who chairs the House Republican Policy Committee, praised Taiwan for its efforts over the past two decades in the promotion of "liberty, the rule of law, freedom of the press, an independent judiciary and associated rights."
The promotion has contributed to the creation and continuation of a mature democracy" in Taiwan, McCotter said.
The statement came one day before the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral and city council elections.
McCotter said Taiwan's system has helped institutionalize democracy, fostered the nation's emancipation from authoritarian rule and ensured the nation's allegiance to liberty and justice.

He also described Taiwan as "a staunch ally of the United States and a responsible member of the community of nations." He asked his colleagues to join him in commending Taiwanese people "for establishing a flourishing, multiparty democracy and for their dedication to democratic ideals and human rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN REPORTS YEAR'S FIRST FLU DEATH

TEXT.P: An 18-year old student has died of serious complications triggered by type B influenza, becoming the first case of flu-related death recorded this year, the Center for Disease Control (CDC) reported Saturday.
The victim was a Changhua County resident who studied in Kaohsiung County and started to display symptoms of flu and fever Nov. 26, according to CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Chih-hao.
Despite medical visits and medication, the patient's symptoms did not improve and he fell unconscious and was rushed to the hospital Nov. 29, Chou said.
The hospital reported the patient as a suspected case of SARS Dec. 1 after he was diagnosed with pneumonia, along with shortness of breath and multiple organ failure, he said.
Chou said the patient died Dec. 3 and test results indicated that he was infected with the type B influenza virus.

With Taiwan having entered its annual flu season, 3.83 percent of patients making outpatient visits over the past week displayed flu-like symptoms, up 6.1 percent from the previous week, with the type B influenza being most prevalent, Chou said.
He said the CDC has so far received reports of two confirmed severe influenza cases.

Meanwhile, data collected from an inter-school infectious disease monitoring system shows that 0.58 percent of students were infected with flu this week, up from 0.52 percent recorded in the previous week, Chou said.
