Manila Bulletin: 12th ASEAN Summit postponed
MANDAUE CITY, Cebu -- The 12th Summit of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) leaders, scheduled to open tomorrow, has been postponed to January next year because of a storm which is expected to hit Cebu, ASEAN National Organizing Committee (NOC) Chairman Ambassador Marciano Paynor Jr. announced yesterday.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo may drop constituent assembly
THE FIERCELY LOYAL Union of Local Authorities of the Philippines (Ulap) has asked President Macapagal-Arroyo to drop her support for the constituent assembly as it might be the trigger for "people power," a key member of Ulap told the Inquirer.
The Philippine Star: Asean summit reset
Undaunted by terror warnings but fearful of a coming typhoon, the government decided yesterday to postpone to January next year the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and East Asia summits, which were originally scheduled on Monday in Cebu. No new date was announced.
The Manila Times: Asean summit scuttled
The Philippine government has postponed the leaders' summit next week of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and a wider East Asia grouping, blaming a brewing storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Equal rights for de facto couples spark row.
The government commitment to a law on equal rights for all de facto couples, including Gay couples, sparked a bitter row between the ruling and opposition camps. Minister for Equal Rights Barbara Pollastrini affirmed that her ministry is to present a draft bill on the issue, while Christian Democratic Union Party leader Pierferdinando Casini pledged to fight against it in the parliament.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT IGNITES DPP-KMT ACCUSATIONS REGARDING ALLEGED VOTE BUYING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the prosecution authorities Saturday to investigate the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate's alleged vote-buying, triggering vehement accusations from KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou that Chen has violated the election law by making allegations aimed at spoiling a candidate's chances of getting elected.

After casting his ballot in Taipei, Chen told reporters that media reports about suspected vote-buying in Kaohsiung City are "the greatest insult to the voters and the severest damage to Taiwan's democracy" and he urged the prosecution to immediately investigate.

In Kaohsiung, district court prosecutors summoned two drivers of tour buses allegedly involved in the dispensing of "attendance fees" of NT$500 (US$15.50) to participants in an election-eve rally organized by the Huang Chun-ying campaign. Huang is the KMT nominee for mayor.

Chen Chi-mai, campaign manager of Huang's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) rival Chen Chu, said he had evidence that a campaign worker for Huang gave NT$1,000 to two rally participants, while another person "hinted at them to elect No. 1 candidate" -- Huang.

The Chen Chu campaign immediately filed a lawsuit with the Kaohsiung District Court accusing the Huang campaign of vote buying. The Ministry of Justice said the district court prosecutor's office has started looking into the allegation.
The Huang campaign followed with a counter-suit charging the DPP candidate with false accusation.

Huang himself filed another suit against President Chen Shui-bian, claiming that the president's accusation was aimed at scuttling his chances of winning the election -- an offense under the election law.
Ma said it was "extremely inappropriate" for a head of government to make a "groundless" accusation against a candidate on the election day.
He also accused Chen of abusing his constitutional immunity from prosecution in an attempt to "win elections by all means."
KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen said that by "fabricating facts," the president was "insulting voters' intelligence" and "causing the biggest hindrance to democracy."

DPP legislative caucus convener Ker Chien-ming said Huang's campaign workers were video-recorded distributing "attendance fees" to rally participants -- an act that he claimed could be interpreted as vote buying and bringing "shame to Taiwan's democracy."
He claimed that it was "concrete evidence" of the KMT and Ma "racing to the bottom" and said the DPP must sue them and demand that the Ministry of Justice report the incident to the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 800 INDIVIDUALS ALLEGEDLY INVOLVED IN VOTE-BUYING CASE: MOJ

TEXT.P: More than 800 people are allegedly involved in election bribery cases related to the mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Saturday.
Six of them have been indicted on charges of vote-buying in three separate cases, MOJ officials said, adding that efforts to crack down on vote buying will continue.
Of the accused, 106 were involved in mayoral election-related bribery cases, while the rest were allegedly involved in cases related to the city council elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION KMT TAKES TAIPEI, NARROWLY LOSES KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Hau Lung-bin trounced his ruling Democratic Progressive Party rival Frank Hsieh in Saturday's Taipei mayoral election.
The KMT nominee for Kaohsiung, Huang Chun-ying, lost by a narrow margin to his DPP rival Chen Chu, who, according to the city's election committee, won the race by a mere 1,120 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU CITY PUBLISHES FLAG MANUALS IN GLOBALIZATION EFFORTS

TEXT.P: Hsinchu City in northern Taiwan published Saturday 300 flag manuals containing images of the flags of 197 countries and territories around the world in an attempt to "underline its efforts in globalization."

Hsinchu Magistrate Lin Cheng-tse claimed that Hsinchu City, which boasts Taiwan's first science park, is becoming an international metropolis and a melting pot with different ethnic groups from around the world.

With a growing foreign population and diverse ethnic groups in Taiwan, the Hsinchu city government decided to publish the flag manuals to "allow people coming from all over the world to feel comfortable while living here," according to Lin.
According to Lin, the publication of the flag manuals was also to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the city's upgrading to the status of a city under the jurisdiction of the provincial government.
Lin noted that the city government will have the flag manuals, which will be written in Chinese and English, formally published July 1 next year, after correcting errors in the first print run.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Iraqis Near Deal on Distribution of Oil Revenues
Iraqi officials are near agreement on a national oil law that would give the central government the power to distribute current and future oil revenues to the provinces or regions, based on their population, Iraqi and American officials say.
Wall Street Journal:As Rivals Catch Up, Toyota CEO Spurs Big Efficiency Drive
Toyota's chief executive officer Katsuaki Watanabe is a worried man. He thinks Toyota is losing its competitive edge as it expands around the world. He frets that quality, the foundation of its U.S. success, is slipping. He grouses that Toyota's factories and engineering practices aren't efficient enough. Within the company, he has even questioned a core tenet of Toyota's corporate culture --kaizen, the relentless focus on incremental improvement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR-ELECT DECLARES 'CITIZENS' VICTORY'

TEXT.P: Bowing to cheering supporters at his campaign headquarters, Taipei Mayor-elect Hau Lung-bin of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) declared Saturday that what he described as the "clean KMT" has triumphed over "the corrupt Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) " in a grueling battle in which "all of the city's citizens" could claim victory.
Hau trounced his ruling DPP rival, former Premier Frank Hsieh, by 160,000 votes after a lengthy campaign that saw candidates slinging mud at one another as rumors of schemes and plots swirled around.

"Throughout this campaign, I've been constantly smeared, " Hau said, adding that "I always have confidence that real gold will not be blackened and that charcoal can never become white because I firmly believe Taipei's citizens will not accept smear strategies in an election."

Now that the election campaign is over, Hau said he will work with people from all political camps in building a great city, focusing on cleaning up the Danshui river, zero tolerance on crime, and adopting uniform textbooks in schools.
At Hsieh's campaign headquarters, where thousands of supporters gathered, some shed tears while others called on Hsieh to prepare to run for president in 2008.
Lee Ying-yuan, Hsieh's campaign manager, said Hsieh was at least able to "groom" quite a number of DPP politicians for the city council.

Moreover, Lee added, Hsieh's performance as Kaohsiung mayor -- a post he held before becoming premier -- helped DPP candidate Chen Chu win the mayoral race in the southern Taiwan city so that the DPP can continue to keep Hsieh's promise to "protect the city's Love River."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Royal Mail plans to axe over 7,000 post offices
Half of the country's 14,400 post offices should be shut to stem mounting losses, Royal Mail has told the Government.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Iraq Strategy Review Focusing on Three Main Options
As pressure mounts for a change of course in Iraq, the Bush administration is groping for a viable new strategy for the president to unveil by Christmas, with eliberations now focused on three main options to redefine the U.S. military and political engagement, according to officials familiar with the debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD ANNOUNCES DEPARTURE FROM POLITICS

TEXT.P: James Soong, who took a leave of absence as chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) to run in Saturday's Taipei mayoral election as an independent, announced that he would bow out of politics after yet another election trouncing.

Soong made the announcement at 6 p.m. before the completion of the vote count, which showed that Hau Lung-bin of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) had been steadily in the lead, with Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) trailing behind and Soong not even in the running.
"I respect the choice of the Taipei citizens and I gladly accept my defeat," he said.
"I'll pursue my future with my wife by my side," he added.
Soong said that during the campaign, he had examined the city's problems in the hope of getting the chance to serve the residents, a hope that was dashed by his dismal showing in Saturday's polls.

The former Taiwan provincial governor said that during the past three decades in politics, he has taken every post as a responsibility and challenge and has always prided himself on being a "can-do man."
Soong left his campaign office shortly after delivering his remarks, with his supporters urging him to stay in politics and run in the 2008 presidential election.
Vice Legislative Yuan Speaker David Chung of the PFP claimed that voters "were positive about Soong's performance, " but put him behind Hau because they were worried that Hsieh would win.
He described Soong as an "asset of the nation" and claimed that the public "will not be able to accept" his departure from the political scene.
But Soong's coterie said that before Soong threw his hat into the ring, he had said the mayoral election would be his "last battle."

Soong ran unsuccessfully in the 2000 presidential election as an independent, when he split the KMT vote, assuring President Chen Shui -bian victory. He ran again in the 2004 presidential election, this time teamed up as Lien's deputy in a 'pan-blue" coalition. He was beaten by Chen again, by a small margin.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CANDIDATE WINS KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Chen Chu, the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party candidate in the Kaohsiung mayoral election, won 379,417 votes Saturday, leading Huang Chun-yin of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) by only 1,120 votes, according to statistics announced by the Central Election Commission (CEC).
Chen gained 49.41 percent of the votes, while Huang obtained 49.27 percent, garnering 378,297 votes, the narrowest margin between the two camps in special municipality elections in Taiwan's history.
Chen at one point led Huang by only 251 votes during the hard-fought race.
Lo Chih-ming, who was representing the Taiwan Solidarity Union, gained 6,599 votes, just 0.86 percent of the total votes.
Lin Chin-yuan, an independent, obtained 1,808 votes, or 0.23 percent, while Lin Chih-sheng, candidate for the Taiwan Defense Alliance, garnered 1,746 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN LOCAL GOVERNMENT SETS UP PAINTBALL PROMOTION COMMISSION

TEXT.P: The county sports committee of the outlying island of Kinmen set up a commission Saturday to promote the sport of paintball.

County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng celebrated the inauguration of the new facility at the county council and presented a certificate of the commission chairmanship to Hsu Yu-chao, who was elected to head Kinmen's 28th sport-related commission.
Hsu is the deputy speaker of the county council.
Paintball has not been seen before on Kinmen, Taiwan's key frontline outpost in its military confrontation against China until 1992, when the island was opened for tourism.

In recent years, with the military's move to release abandoned military bases and barracks for public use, allowing the sport to expand, according to Lee, who said he expects the new commission will turn the game into the island's most popular sport and help to boost tourism.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOSING CANDIDATE TO FILE ELECTION SUIT: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A spokesman for opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying said Huang will demand a recount of the vote and file a lawsuit to dispute his rival's narrow win in Saturday's election.
Huang lost to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Chen Chu by a mere 1,120 votes, according to the Kaohsiung election committee.
Chen Hsueh-sheng, spokesman for the Huang campaign, said Huang will demand the vote be recounted and will file a suit asking the court to rule Chen's victory invalid.
Huang himself was ambivalent, responding to supporters' demands for a recount with the philosophical statement that "there are losers and winners in every election."
However, he said he strongly protests a DPP accusation that his campaign workers gave "attendance fees" to participants in his final campaign rally the previous evening.
"It's beneath my dignity to win an election through shady means," Huang said.
Analysts said the DPP strategy seems to have worked well for Chen Chu, whose support ratings had lagged behind those of Huang, albeit narrowly in the final stage of the campaign.

Tsai Chin-lung, secretary-general of the KMT legislative caucus, said the DPP had used "unseemly" strategies against Huang, with the previous evening's bribery allegation being the worst and having the greatest impact.
"Our caucus can only respect the choice made by Kaohsiung's citizens, though we also regret it," Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT RETAINS BIGGEST SHARE IN TAIPEI CITY COUNCIL

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) snatched 24 seats in the city council elections Saturday, outnumbering the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) 18 to retain its leading position in the council that will monitor the city government led by KMT Mayor-elect Hau Lung-bin.

The KMT caucus is now four seats stronger than it was in the previous council, while the DPP added one seat, which the party's Taipei chapter head Lee Cheng-yi said should be credited to unsuccessful mayoral candidate Frank Hsieh.

The opposition People First Party (PFP) was the big loser in the municipal elections, losing six seats to retain only two seats in the council, with its chairman, James Soong, trailing a distant third behind Hsieh in the mayoral race.
The tiny New Party lost one seat but won four others, proving it is still a force to be reckoned with, at least in Taipei -- it nominated only four candidates, all of whom were elected.
New Party Chairman Yu Mu-ming said his party will work toward "integrating the pan-blue alliance" with the KMT and PFP.
The Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and independents scored two seats each in the 52-member council.

DOC.HEADLINE: EASING OF POLITICAL UNCERTAINTY EXPECTED TO BOOST STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Several economic analysts claimed Saturday that the results of the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections represent "an easing of political uncertainty in Taiwan," which could be conducive to the stock market.

An analyst from President Investment Trust Corp. predicted that the results of that day's elections will give a boost to the stock market as Taiwan's political panorama has not changed much compared to before the elections, with both the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang occupying the mayorships of Kaohsiung and Taipei, respectively.

However, Hu Man-ling, a senior analyst from Polaris International Securities Investment Trust Co., forecast that the election results will have little influence on the stock market, pointing out that it is the situation between the two sides of Taiwan Strait that is the crucial factor in deciding Taiwan's economic development.

In addition, Hu noted that the soon-to-be inaugurated Taiwan High Speed Railway, the continued appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar, as well as several urban renewal projects, are expected to stimulate related industries, while the banking sector is expected to enjoy benefits at the end of the year with the easing of the credit card debt crisis.
Taiwan's stock index increased 7.78 percent in November, the largest growth rate among the Asian stock markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHU BECOMES FIRST FEMALE MUNICIPALITY HEAD

TEXT.P: Chen Chu, the candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Kaohsiung mayoral election, was brimming with joy and pride Saturday after winning the election to become the first female municipality head in Taiwan's history.

"The hard-won victory is a confidence vote for former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh as well as me, " Chen said after she won by a razor-thin margin of 1,114 votes against her rival Huang Chun-ying of the main opposition Kuomintang.
She credited Hsieh for laying a solid foundation for Kaohsiung, saying that the public owes Hsieh and that it is time to "return him justice and extend him warmth."
She said that Hsieh, who unsuccessfully represented the DPP in the Taipei mayoral election, fought a brilliant battle that also helped her own campaign.
Although basking in the triumphant atmosphere, she said however that the joy should not be longer than one minute as she knows the tremendous responsibility and public expectations that lie ahead.

At a time when the DPP's popularity has slipped to its lowest ebb due to a series of corruption scandals implicating the family of President Chen Shui-bian and his close aides, Chen Chu had to fight an uphill battle with a big pre-poll margin between her and her rival.
Observers attributed her success to an excellent campaign team, which smoothed out feuds in the primary and bridged the differences between various factions.
She also solicited former acting Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chi-mai to serve as the campaign manager and received support from Hsieh's team.

Apart from turning foes into friends, she also used her personal charisma, stressing her devotion to Taiwan's democratic development since the Formosa Incident of 1979 -- a peaceful rally to mark World Human Rights Day that turned violent and for which she was imprisoned.

At the beginning of the election campaign, supporters of the "pan-green camp" of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) worried that Lo Chih-ming of the TSU would split the vote and tried to persuade Lo to bow out, but when Lo insisted on running, Chen's team adopted an undermining strategy to put him out of the race.

Chen's staff said the final week in the runnup to Saturday's election had been crucial, with President Chen, Premier Su Tseng-chang, revered former DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung and various other DPP heavyweights all converging on Kaohsiung to stump for her.

A Dec. 3 "hand-in-hand" rally around the Love River also played a part in boosting her momentum, resulting in a nearly 70 percent turnout rate. A higher turnout rate was helpful to the DPP in the election, as Kaohsiung has traditionally been the party's stronghold.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT GRATIFIED WITH ELECTION OUTCOME: PREMIER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian is pleased with the outcome of the just-concluded mayoral elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung -- the country's two largest cities, Premier Su Tseng-chang said Saturday.

Su made the remarks after the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) candidate, Chen Chu, narrowly won the crucial mayoral election in southern port city of Kaohsiung, while the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate, Hau Lung-pin, won comfortably in the capital of Taipei.

"I have informed the president of the electoral results via telephone. The president is pleased with the outcome and grateful for all DPP comrades' campaign efforts and support from members of the public toward the DPP candidates, " Su said, adding that the president looks forward to a quick return to "business as usual" in the wake of the hotly contested elections.
Su will soon leave for Gambia to attend the Dec. 15 inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh as President Chen's special envoy.
He said he takes it as great honor to attend Jammeh's inauguration on behalf of the president.
Chen Chu bested KMT candidate Huang Chung-ying by 1,114 votes out of almost 800,000 cast, in a result expected to help boost the position of embattled President Chen.
The two mayoral elections had been seen by some pundits as a referendum on Chen's presidency.
However, DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun dismissed that view, saying that the elections should not be regarded in such a perspective.
In Taipei Hau beat the DPP's Frank Hsieh by about 13 percentage points with all the votes counted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURNOUT RATES FOR TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG ELECTIONS LESS THAN 70%

TEXT.P: The turnout rates for the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections were 64.52 percent and 67.93 percent, respectively, the Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Saturday.

The CEC also announced that Hau Lung-bin of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) won Taipei mayoral election with 692,085 votes, or 53.81 percent of the votes, while Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was second with 525,869 votes, or 40.89 percent.
In southern Kaohsiung City, Chen Chu of the DPP won with 379,417 votes, or 49.41 percent of the vote, beating Huang Chun-ying of the KMT, who garnered 378.303 votes, or 49.27 percent.

In the Taipei council election, the KMT maintained its hold as the largest party with 24 seats, four more than it had in the previous council, followed by the DPP with 18 seats (one more) . The People First Party managed only two seats, six seats less than the previous election. The New party had four seats (one less) , the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and independent candidates grabbed two seats each. No other political parties obtained seats.

In the Kaohsiung council election, the KMT remained the largest party with 17 seats (five seats more), followed by the DPP with 15 seats (one more), the PFP with four seats (three less) and the TSU with one seat. The independents and candidates who had not been nominated by political parties had seven seats between them.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT SEE UP AND DOWN IN MAYORAL ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang garnered 10.3 percentage points less of the votes than in the previous Taipei mayoral election in 2002, compared with an increase of 5 percentage points for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Saturday.
In the Kaohsiung mayoral election, the KMT grabbed 2.45 percentage points more than it did in the previous election, while the DPP's votes decreased by 0.63 percentage points.
In the Kaohsiung mayoral election, the KMT's Huang Chun-ying lost by 0.14 percent, or 1,114 votes, to the DPP's Chen Chu.

In the 2002 Taipei mayoral election, KMT"s Ma Ying-jeou won 64.11 percent of the votes, compared with the DPP's Lee Ying-yuan, who got 35.89 percent. In the Kaohsiung mayoral election of that year, Frank Hsieh won 50.04 percent of the votes, beating Huang Chun-ying's 46.82 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG WIN GIVES DPP CHANCE TO REGROUPBy S.C. ChangCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) managed to retain its power base in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, while its candidate for Taipei mayor, although he lost the race, was able to snatch over 40 percent of the vote Saturday, giving the party a chance to regroup in the midst of a political crisis triggered by a string of corruption scandals involving members of the first family.

After badly losing the local government elections of 2005, in which the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) snatched even Chiayi City, the DPP has aimed to retain its power base in southern Taiwan and Kaohsiung was a bridgehead it could not afford to lose.

As President Chen Shui-bian has claimed, Saturday's polling was a vote of confidence in former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh's administrative performance -- the city's citizens gave the DPP's nominee Chen Chu a narrow win over the KMT's Huang Chun-ying.

Hsieh, who was recruited as premier by Chen Shui-bian before running for Taipei mayor, also managed to get 40 percent of the capital city's vote, more than the 36 percent won by Lee Ying-yuan, the DPP's previous candidate to challenge Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, an indication that a moderate and forward-looking DPP aspirant can still win the swing vote in Taipei.

DPP insiders said Saturday's vote results in Taipei and Kaohsiung signify that the DPP is gradually emerging from the dark clouds caused by one after another corruption scandals involving the president's senior aides and family members as well as Cabinet- level officials.

Senior DPP officials noted that 2006 was "a year of crisis" for the party because the first family's suspected involvement in the "state affairs fund" scandal and former DPP Chairman Shih Ming-teh's anti-corruption campaign shook the confidence of many of the party's staunch supporters.
"Keeping Kaohsiung gives us a breather, " they claimed, adding that their insistence on "party unity" has won endorsement from a substantive section of the voters.

But other party members pointed out that the DPP's support rates had been dropping from 29 percent in mid-2005 to 18 percent prior to the local elections that year, further dipping to 15 percent in the aftermath of corruption scandals this year, indicating that a large number of middle-class supporters have turned their backs on the party.

Political pundits noted that the DPP's popularity has never exceeded 35 percent, and Chen Shui-bian was able to win the 2000 and 2004 presidential elections because middle-class voters who were disgruntled with the KMT had voted for him, and so losing their support would be quite devastating for the party.
From that perspective, the DPP leadership may no longer ignore calls for "serious reform" which will be a critical indicator of whether the party will be able to make a new start, they said.
For the KMT, the latest vote serves as a reminder that southern Taiwan was still out of its reach even though its rival has been bogged down by corruption charges.
And KMT leaders could not hide their shock that the DPP's Hsieh has managed to break through the 40 percent benchmark in Taipei, the "pan-blue alliance's" stronghold.
The KMT was quite demoralized that its chances of winning Kaohsiung was dashed and its sure win of Taipei was not as big as had been anticipated.
"Boosting the KMT's morale will be Chairman Ma's major work" after he steps down as Taipei mayor Dec. 25, if he wants to stage a good campaign for 2008, said party insiders.

With PFP Chairman James Soong announcing he will leave politics for good after losing his mayoral bid, Ma is the sure top leader of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT, PFP and New Party -- a position from which he will have to prove himself a serious contender for the nation's top job.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESPITE CHALLENGES, DEMOCRATIC VALUES WILL PREVAIL: VP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday that although many emerging democracies face challenges from remnants of their previous authoritarian regimes, democratic values and ideals will prevail so long as assiduous efforts are devoted to consolidation of democratic systems.

Lu made the remarks in a speech delivered at the opening of an international seminar on the role of the legislature in democratic politics sponsored by the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , which was founded in Taipei in August 2005.

Noting that globalization has spurred freer flow of not only population, money and merchandise but also ideas and notions, Lu said democracy has emerged as a basic universal value in the 21st century.

As an inefficient or corrupt government tends to impede democratic reform, Lu said emerging democracies, including Taiwan, should continue pulling out all the stops to consolidate their democratic systems.
While mass rallies and street protests may ignite waves of democratic movement, Lu said the consolidation of democracy requires visions and wisdom.
"We need a visionary legislature in the pursuit of democratic consolidation and overhaul of political system, " said Lu who once as a legislator for three years.

During her stint as a lawmaker, Lu said she came to a full understanding that the legislature must play the role of "public conscience." Under the principles of division of power, Lu said the legislature should strictly oversee government operations and the allocation of government budget.

To promote cooperation among parliaments in Pacific rim countries, Lu said a Pacific Congressional Caucus will be formed under the DPU this Sunday. The establishment of the caucus will mark an important step forward for the DPU, as the caucus will become the largest international congressional organization in the region.
"We hope the caucus will function well to contribute to the consolidation of democracy in the Pacific region which would in turn help ensure regional peace, stability and prosperity," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC.10 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Sunday, Dec.10:
09:30, President Chen Shui-bian will attend a seminar on declassification of secret files and pursuit of historical truth.
11:30, Vice President annette Lu will attend the inaugural ceremony for the Pacific Congressional Caucus.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG CHUNG-YING CAMPAIGN DEMANDS VOTE RECOUNT

TEXT.P: Representatives of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying asked the city's district court Saturday to rule Huang's rival's narrow victory invalid.
Huang lost to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Chen Chu by a mere 1,114 votes, according to the Kaohsiung Election Commission.

KMT Legislators Hou Tsai-feng and Lo Shih-hsiung, accompanied by Huang's lawyer Ho Hsu-ling, also demanded the Kaohsiung District Court impound all ballots cast in the mayoral election in preparation for an across-the-board vote recount.

Meanwhile, the Huang Chung-ying campaign filed a forgery charge with the Kaohsiung Prosecutors' Office against the Kaohsiung Election Commission, claiming that the commission has issued voting notices to certain city dwellers, including those who are serving time in prisons.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS GIVE DPP BREATHER AFTER CRISIS

TEXT.P: The just-concluded municipal elections in the country's two largest cities gave the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) a breather after being dogged by corruption scandals swirling around the first family for several months, a political pundit said Saturday.

Professor Emile Sheng from Soochow University in suburban Taipei made the remarks after the DPP managed to retain its grip in its traditional stronghold -- the country's second largest city of Kaohsiung -- in Saturday's mayoral election.

Although the DPP resoundingly lost, as expected, to the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) in the mayoral race in the capital city of Taipei -- the KMT's main support base -- the number of votes captured by its candidate Frank Hsieh surpassed the benchmark 40 percent.

Sheng said the electoral outcome would allow embattled President Chen Shui-bian to recoup its popularity after the "special state affairs" debacle and the DPP to stop its downward streak triggered by voter discontent over corruption scandals involving members of the first family and some administration officials.

In the wake of the municipal elections, in which the DPP-led "pan-green" camp saw a slight expansion of its presence in the city councils of the two special municipalities, Sheng predicted that Premier Su Tseng-chang will remain in the post in the foreseeable future and may emerge as the front runner in the race for the "pan-green" camp candidacy for the 2008 presidential election.

Turning to the post-election situation of the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People Fist Party (PFP), Sheng said the KMT's narrow loss in Kaohsiung would deal a blow to KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's reputation.

"It's really disappointing that the 'pan-blues' failed to win the mayorship in the DPP's traditional heartland in a political milieu so unfavorable to the DPP," Sheng said, adding that the failure has hurt Ma's reputation.

Meanwhile, Sheng said the PFP Chairman James Soong's decision to quit politics after receiving a mere 4.1 percent of the total in the Taipei mayoral election will help limit the impact of the latest election defeat to the party, which also performed poorly in councilor elections in both cities.
In contrast, professor Wang Yeh-li of Tunghai University said he believes that the election setback could enhance the possibility of the PFP's disintegration or accelerate its merger with the KMT.

For his part, Hsu Yung-ming, an associate researcher with Academia Sinica, questioned the propriety of the KMT's plan to file a suit to invalidate the DPP candidate Chen Chu's narrow victory in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

"Our memory of the 'pan-blue alliance' filing two lawsuits against the results of the 2004 presidential election remains vivid. A vote recount didn't find irregularities in the vote nor change the result of the election. The 'pan-blue' ticket of then-KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong owe all of us an apology," Hsu said.

Lien and Soong teamed up to challenge President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu's re-election bid in 2004, but lost by a razor-thin margin. They also lost both suits challenging the validity of the Chen-Lu ticket's electoral victory and even the validity of the election. Neither of them has ever apologized for the money and energy spent on the vote recount and relevant judicial procedures.
Hsu said he keenly hopes that the KMT can refrain from taking any controversial moves to continue nightmarish partisan bickering that has long gripped local political scenes.
Voter turnout in the just-concluded elections was about 67 percent in Kaohsiung with a population of about 1.6 million, and 64 percent in Taipei which boasts a population of 2.6 million.

Six candidates vied for Taipei mayor, and five contenders sought the job in Kaohsiung. Taipei victor Haul Lung-bin enjoyed a comfortable lead when he declared himself victor at 7 p.m. before voting results were final. Hau eventually won 692,085 ballots, outnumbering his closest rival, the DPP's Hsieh, by more than 160,000 votes.
Kaohsiung winner Chen Chu, also a former Council of Labor Affairs chairwoman and once a prisoner of conscience, said experience would set her apart.
"I have participated in every step of Taiwan's democratic development history," Chen said shortly before the vote. "Only if you have a sense of history can you understand this land from your heart."
Chen Chu garnered 379,417 ballots, compared to KMT hopeful Huang Chun-ying's 378,303 votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOSING CANDIDATE'S APPLICATION FOR IMPOUNDING BALLOT BOXES APPROVED

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung District Court approved early Sunday the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Kaohsiung mayoral candidate's application for impounding all ballot boxes to facilitate probes into his election lawsuit aimed at invalidating the electoral outcome announced a day earlier.

A court judge is scheduled to visit the Kaohsiung Election Commission at 10: 30 a.m. in the company of the losing KMT candidate Huang Chun-ying's representatives to seal up all ballot boxes, the name list of eligible voters and vote counting reports furnished by all polling stations.

Huang's campaign applied for impounding all ballot boxes late Saturday after some of its volunteers overseeing vote count procedures at various polling stations claimed that the figures announced by the election commission diverged from those presented by polling stations and many of Huang's votes were counted as "invalid" simply because they were slightly tainted by ink.
The court originally ruled that Huang's campaign should present more evidence in five days to back up its "irregularity" claims.
After KMT Legislator Chiu Yi led two volunteers responsible for vote count supervision to testify at the court, the presiding judge approved the "impounding" application.
Huang lost to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) Chen Chu by a mere 1,114 votes, according to the Kaohsiung Election Commission.
Huang's representatives asked the city's district court Saturday to rule his rival's narrow victory invalid.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 10, or the 20th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng-hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Six-party talks to resume in China dec. 16
Six-nation talks on ending North Korea's nuclear program will begin Dec. 16 in Beijing, two months after Pyongyang defied international pressure and conducted its first nuclear test. The talks have been stalled for more than a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Congress Oks Nuclear Agreement with India.
Reversing three decades of U.S. policies intended to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, Congress early today approved a long-stalled agreement giving India access to American nuclear technology with limited safeguards to discourage possible proliferation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The China Times:
Opposition KMT's Hau Lung-bin wins Taipei mayoral race while ruling DPP's Chen Chu declares victory in Kaohsiung after narrow win.
The United Daily News:
Ruling DPP retains Kaohsiung with razor-thin margin.
The Liberty Times:
Hau Lung-bin wins Taipei mayoral race, Chen Chu elected Kaohsiung mayor.
The China Post:
Blue sky over north; green field in south.
The Taiwan News:
DPP, KMT aplit mayoral elections.
The Taipei Times:
Voters stay faithful to big parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: House now pushes Con-con
In an unexpected turnaround, the House majority coalition yesterday proposed the holding of a Constitutional Convention (Con-con) to amend the 1987 Constitution with delegates elected during the May, 2007, elections for local and national officials.lbay today to assess the extent of damage brought by supertyphoon "Reming.''
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Arroyo: Stop Con-ass now
THIS comes direct from the Palace. President Macapagal-Arroyo had instructed her political affairs adviser Gabriel Claudio on Friday to "order" the lawmakers allied with her to drop the constituent assembly (Con-ass) as a means of changing the Constitution, Executive Secretary Eduardo Ermita said yesterday.
The Philippine Star: House holds off con-ass
Charter change advocates led by Speaker Jose De Venecia Jr. decided to defer plans to convene the House of Representatives into a constituent assembly (con-ass) to give way to a constitutional convention to amend the 1987 Constitution next year.
The Manila Times: House backs down on Con-Ass
Faced with threats of massive protests against the planned constituent assembly (Con-Ass), President Arroyo's allies in the House of Representatives said on Saturday that they would settle for a constitutional convention (Con-con).

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The GOP Era In Congress: A 'Mixed Bag' Of Results
Demoralized Republicans adjourned the 109th Congress at 5 a.m. yesterday with a near-empty Capitol, closing the door on a dozen years of nearly unbroken GOP control by spending more time in the final days lamenting their failures -- to rein in government, tame the deficit and temper their own lust for power -- than reliving their successes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BACK TO WORK, NOW ELECTIONS ARE OVER: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian exhorted the country Sunday to resume work now that Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal elections are over.

Chen was asked by a reporter whether he is planning to "move to Kaohsiung" as he had promised Kaohsiung voters while stumping for ruling democratic Progressive Party mayoral candidate Chen Chu several days ago. Chen said that if Chen Chu wins the Kaohsiung mayoral race, he and his wife would move to the southern port city to live. Chen Chu won the race Saturday, with a razor-thin margin over her opposition Kuomintang rival Huang Chun-ying.
The president just smiled and declined to answer the reporter's question.

Chen attended the opening of a seminar on archive decipherment and historic truths sponsored by Academia Historica -- a national institute under direct administrative supervision of the president, where archives on the Republic of China's history are kept, as well as records of the nation's major, important historic incidents.

Addressing the event, Chen said over the past six years, the government has striven to decode and study historical documents on major political cases or incidents in an effort to recover historical evidence and reestablish historical truths.

Chen said the actions may have temporarily disturbed the country's harmony, but he has insisted that such work must continue so the country's social justice can be restored, historic wounds healed and long-term national development secured.

He added that if historical truths cannot be brought into broad daylight, past wrongdoings will never serve as reminders and historic wounds and rifts will not pass away as time goes by. Instead, these historical mysteries will remain a source of hatred, continuing to divide the country if not properly tackled.

Academia Historica was founded in 1914 and was reestablished in Taiwan 43 years later. It is responsible for preserving documents and conducting research on modern Chinese history, particularly the republican period.

The academy has a collection of 7.5 million publications and national records, mainly from the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan, provincial and local governments, plus some personal and other archives. Most records are open to Academia Historica staff and researchers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN NABBED FOR SMUGGLING HEROIN COULD FACE 10 YEARS IN PRISON

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese and his girlfriend returning from a trip to Thailand Saturday night may face at least 10 years in prison for smuggling illicit drugs after customs officials at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport found 2.89 kg of heroin in a hidden layer of their baggage.

According to the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice, the 39-year-old man, surnamed Chen, admitted he had agreed to work as a "mule" for a drug-trafficking syndicate because he badly needed money to repay debt.
Chen also reportedly tried to disguise his trip to Thailand as a leisure trip by inviting his 21-year-old girlfriend, surnamed Wang, to accompany him as his cover.
They departed for Thailand Dec. 4 and returned aboard a Royal Dutch Airlines flight Saturday night.

A spokesman for the bureau said that customs officials, who noted that Chen appeared nervous, checked his baggage thoroughly and found four bags of first-grade heroin -- weighing 2,898 grams -- in a secret compartment of his baggage, with an estimated street value of tens of millions of NT dollars.
Chen and his girlfriend have been referred to the Taoyuan Public Prosecutors' Office for prosecution under the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT 'GREEN PROCUREMENT' PROGRESSING COMMENDABLY: EPA

TEXT.P: Efforts made by publicly run agencies to use and procure environmentally friendly products have been commendable, Environmental Protection Adminsitration (EPA) officials said Sunday.

EPA officials said 11 Cabinet-level agencies -- including the Council of Indigenous Peoples -- have performed commendably in the first half of this year, in terms of using and procuring environmentally friendly products or "green products," which cut down on waste and pollution, use less raw materials, conserve resources and are recyclable, EPA officials said.
To take the lead in environmental protection efforts, the Cabinet set a 2006 goal whereby 80 percent of procurement made by governmental agencies will be green products, EPA officials said.
"Green" procurement by governmental agencies as a whole totaled NT$3.464 billion in the January-June period, an increase of NT$26 million over the year-earlier level, the officials said.
Only three Cabinet-level agencies, including the Ministry of Education, have not performed so successfully in this area and thus have room for improvement, they added.

For the next year -- when the government's "green procurement" will target 83 percent -- more public agencies, including the Presidential Office, Legislative Yuan, Judicial Yuan, Examination Yuan and Control Yuan, will also be included in the "green procurement" and "green consumption" initiative, starting Jan. 1, 2007, the EPA officials said.
Privately run companies and private organizations will also be required to jump on the bandwagon Jan. 1, 2007, they noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEBSITE LAUNCHED, OFFERING TO DISPATCH STORYTELLERS

TEXT.P: An Internet site offering to dispatch storytelling teachers was launched in Sanchung City, Taipei County Saturday, with a number of teachers demonstrating enchanting storytelling skills at the inauguration ceremony.

The Smart Story Website, organized by Smart Orange Consulting Inc., will save parents significant time and cost involved in looking for suitable storytelling teachers, the event organizer, Chang Ping-chung, said at the ceremony.

The Website was established after the organization succeeded in training nearly 100 storytelling teachers through a series of certification programs, Chang said, adding that he believes the storytelling talent pool will provide the Website's most valuable resource.
The Website is the first of its kind offering to dispatch storytelling teachers, and will offer a channel of communication between parents and teachers free of charge.
A party at the ceremony featured creative performances staged by storytellers to celebrate the Website's creation.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Holy See criticizes on legislation of equal rights for de facto couples.
The Holy See strongly criticized the Italian government's commitment to a law on equal rights for all de facto couples, including Gay couples, with its newspaper "l'Osservatore Romano" warning that it would destroy the value of family, if approved.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD SUPPORTS LOSING CANDIDATE'S LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that he supported the decision of KMT mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying to request a court ruling to invalidate the election results.

Huang lost Saturday to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Chen Chu by 1,140 votes -- or 0.14 percent of the vote -- the narrowest margin ever in the history of Taiwan's municipal elections.
When Ma arrived at Huang's campaign headquarters, supporters chanted calls for a vote recount.
Huang filed a request for the court to impound all ballot boxes to facilitate further checks, a request that was approved earlier in the day.
Ma said he will stand by Huang throughout the legal process and render any assistance as needed.
Ma and Huang boarded a vehicle for a tour of the city to thank voters for their support of KMT candidates in the municipal elections.
Ma said he was in Kaohsiung both to express his gratitude to supporters and to seek opinions on how to improve its election campaigns in the future.
The KMT's legislative caucus, meanwhile, said it "respects" Huang's decision but will not intervene in the legal dispute.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP LAWMAKERS WANT PARTY CHIEF TO STAY

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the opposition People First Party (PFP) called a news conference Sunday to voice firm support for party Chairman James Soong, urging him to continue leading the party despite his announcement to withdraw from politics after losing in Saturday's Taipei mayoral election.

Cheng Chin-ling, the PFP's legislative caucus whip, issued the call at the Legislative Yuan while accompanied by PFP lawmakers -- including Liu Wen-hsiung, Lin Hui-kuan, Daniel Hwang, Lin Chung-te and Fu Kun-chi. Also present were Legislative Yuan Deputy Speaker David C. Chung, a PFP member, and PFP Secretary-General Chin Ching-sheng.

Cheng deplored Soong's failure in the Taipei mayoral elections and ascribed Soong's loss to voters' "dump and save" tactic to avoid a split in the "pan-blue alliance" and secure the victory of Hau Lung-bin, the candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), in the face of competition from Frank Hsieh, a former premier and rival from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Although Soong announced following the elections that he would pull out of the political sector, Cheng said that all PFP lawmakers hope Soong will change his mind and continue leading the party. They also urged PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung to now serve as acting chairman to maintain the party's normal operations.
Chung and Chin also praised Soong as an outstanding politician and voiced regrets over his decision to pull out of politics, saying that it will be a great loss to Taiwan and its people.

However, PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun admitted that it will be very hard for Soong to change his mind. He called on Chang to hold off his decision to follow Soong's lead and instead stay in the party to help overcome its current obstacles. The PFP should continue its cooperation with the KMT in the legislature, he said.
Soong garnered 53,281 votes, or 4.14 percent of the total, in Saturday's Taipei mayoral election, ranking behind Hau's 692,085 votes (53.81 percent) and Hsieh's 525,869 votes (40.89 percent.)

The PFP and the KMT form a loose "pan-blue alliance" that also includes the small New Party, versus the "pan-green camp" of the ruling DPP and Taiwan Solidarity Union. The PFP controls 22 seats at the pan-blue-controlled Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON INVESTMENT, TECHNOLOGY COOPERATION WITH ISRAEL TO OPEN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs will hold a symposium Dec. 12 on investment and technological cooperation with Israel, after bilateral trade between the two countries exceeded US$1 billion last year for the first time, a ministry spokesman said Sunday.

The symposium will be held at National Taiwan University's international conference center, and aims to help Taiwanese enterprises gain a better understanding of Israel and seek collaboration and commercial opportunities in the Mideast country, the spokesman said.

In this symposium, Israeli officials as well as Taiwanese entrepreneurs and business experts who have conducted business with Israel will be invited to participate in discussion on Israel's investment climate, the development of its high-tech industry and key characteristics of its culture and trade, according to the spokesman.

He added that Israel has earned the reputation of a second "Silicon Valley," with 100 companies listed on the NASDAQ, and that it has become an international hub for technological cooperation and multinational investment, the spokesman said, adding that the main international corporations, such as Intel, IBM and Microsoft have all established factories there.

According to 2005 statistics, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Israel hit a new high of US$1.0318 billion that year, representing 5.1% growth over the previous year. Taiwan's total exports to Israel accounted for US$37.96 million, with total imports from Israel accounting reaching US$65.23 million, and marking a trade surplus in Taiwan's favor at US$27.27 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CAUCUS TAKES HANDS-OFF STANCE ON INVALIDATING POLL RESULTS

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang's (KMT) legislative caucus said Sunday it would take a hands-off approach toward the decision of KMT Kaohsiung mayoral candidate Huang Chun-ying to file a lawsuit aimed at invalidating Saturday's election results, in which Huang lost to his rival by a razor-thin margin.

Tsai Chin-lung, party whip of the KMT's legislative caucus, said the caucus respects Huang's call on Saturday for all ballot boxes in Kaohsiung city to be impounded -- as a means to facilitate his lawsuit, which aims to invalidate the election results -- but that it will not exert any further pressure on the prosecution on the matter.
Early Sunday, the Kaohsiung District Court approved Huang's request to impound all ballot boxes to facilitate probes into his election lawsuit.
Tsai said the case has now entered the judicial process and the KMT legislative caucus will do nothing further in this regard.

Huang lost to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Chen Chu by a mere 1,114 votes. Chen got 49.41 percent of the vote, or 379,417 votes, while Huang obtained 49.27 percent, garnering 378,297 votes -- the narrowest margin in Taiwan's history between the two camps in special municipality elections.

Huang's campaign applied for the impounding of all ballot boxes late Saturday after some of its volunteers who were overseeing vote-counting procedures at various polling stations claimed figures announced by the election commission diverged from those presented by polling stations, claiming many of Huang's votes were counted as "invalid" simply because they were slightly tainted by ink.
The court originally ruled that Huang's campaign should present additional evidence within five days to back up its claims of irregularity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NARROWLY DEFEATED CANDIDATE REFUSES TO CONCEDE ELECTION

TEXT.P: Huang Chun-ying, the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for Kaohsiung mayor who lost by a mere 1,114 votes to ruling party rival Chen Chu Saturday, said Sunday he had "not yet lost" the election and still has a good chance of winning.
Accompanied by lawyer Ho Hsu-ling at the Kaohsiung Election Commission, Huang told reporters he will file a lawsuit to dispute the election results, claiming "chances are I will win the election."
The lawyer was scheduled to file suit Monday, when the court will likely set a time to recount ballots that were cast and counted at 839 polling stations across the city.
All valid and invalid ballots, voter registrations and vote-counting records were sent to the election commission in the morning, under police escort.
Representatives of Huang's and Chen Chu's campaigns were present as six judges and several election officials sealed the ballots and other relevant papers.
Initial witness reports indicated that a certain candidate's vote gain had been inflated, and that some votes were proclaimed invalid due to "excessively stringent" confirmation standards.
KMT Legislator Chiu Yi, who was also present at the election commission, said that preserving the evidence is the most difficult part of an election dispute.
Chiu praised the on-duty judges for making a "wise" decision soon after the Huang campaign had filed a request to seal ballot boxes late Saturday.

He said more than 6,000 invalid votes were counted for Huang -- an unreasonably large number. Inferring from the 2004 presidential elections in which about one-tenth of the invalid votes could be "validated," Huang's vote gain could be 600 or more.
In addition, irregularities were allegedly found at more than 10 polling stations, so that more than 1,000 votes may go toward Huang and reverse the election results, Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER LAMENTS SOONG'S PULLOUT FROM POLITICS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng lamented Sunday opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's announcement to withdraw from politics, calling it "a great loss" to the country and its people.

Wang made the comments one day after Soong announced he would be leaving Taiwan's political scene after having lost Saturday's mayoral election in Taipei. Soong had 53,281 votes, or only 4.14 percent of the total, ranking third among five candidates.

Hau Lung-bin, candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), won the lion's share with 53.81 percent, or 692,085 votes, in the Taipei mayoral race. Frank Hsieh, a former premier and candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), came second with 40.89 percent, or 525,869 votes.

Wang, a KMT heavyweight, expressed his belief that KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou would seek to mend bilateral relations with the PFP in the near term, and that the PFP will try to adjust its pace following its defeat in the Taipei mayoral and city council elections.

As there are still nearly two dozen PFP lawmakers serving in the Legislative Yuan and some of the party's members have still managed to get elected in Taipei and Kaohsiung city council elections, the KMT needs to show respect for the PFP in terms of future cooperation, Wang said.
The PFP controls 22 seats in the 220-member Legislative Yuan, but only two PFP candidates were elected in the 52-member Taipei city council elections, down from eight who were elected four years ago.
The PFP, KMT and New Party form a loose "pan-blue alliance" to counter the "pan-green camp" of the ruling DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

KMT legislative caucus whip Tsai Chin-lung said that he did not believe Soong would go back on his word, but predicted that the PFP will not be dissolved. Cooperation between the two parties will remain strong as it has been in the past, he said.
The PFP should consider consolidating its leadership to stabilize its operations, Tsai suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR EASTERN TAIWAN DEVELOPMENT PLAN IN THE WORKS

TEXT.P: The government will soon launch a "mega-development project" aimed at transforming eastern Taiwan's agricultural and tourism industry while ensuring the quality of life there, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Sunday.
The project, formally known as the "Eastern Taiwan Sustainable Development Plan," is expected to be in the pipeline beginning Monday when the CEPD convenes its first meeting on the project.

Under the plan, the government will invest some NT$50 billion over nine years to transform the eastern corridor -- from Yilan County's Nanao and Tatung rural townships to Hualien and Taitung counties -- into an international-standard tourism area, conserving eastern Taiwan's natural beauty while building an environment with a leading quality of life, CEPD officials said.

Specifically, the project will feature developing the tourism industry in the corridor's rural townships; developing an industrial processing zone for deep-sea products; promoting an "immigration" program to build new tribal villages in the area; developing a cottage industry-based economy; bolstering railway and multiple transportation systems; and reviewing the existing policy of transporting sand and gravel from east to west Taiwan, according to CEPD officials.

The project -- initiated by former Premier Frank Hsieh in August 2005 and put on the drawing board in February this year with Su Tseng-chang as the new premier -- is expected to be carried out via 18 sub-plans and 45 tasks, planned and implemented concertedly by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Ministry of the Interior, Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Council of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Administration.

An ad hoc committee to promote the "Eastern Taiwan Sustainable Development Plan" is expected to be established shortly, probably with Premier Su Tseng-chang or Vice Premier Tsai Ing-wen as convener, CEPD officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYOR-ELECT SAYS SHE RESPECTS RIVAL CANDIDATE'S DECISION ON LAWSUIT

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor-elect Chen Chu said Sunday that she respected the decision of Huang Chun-ying, who lost by a razor-thin margin, to request a court ruling seeking to invalidate the election results.

"Winning and losing are part of the election process, " said the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) successful candidate, who beat her opposition Kuomintang rival by a mere 1,114 votes in Saturday's mayoral election.
"For me, I have been psychologically prepared to lose this election -- for example, just during the vote-counting process, I twice felt I might lose," said Chen.

The Huang campaign has decided to dispute the election results on grounds there were too many invalidated votes, while claiming DPP allegations that his campaign workers tried to buy votes for him negatively impacted voting behavior.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP VICE CHAIRMAN SHOWS NO WILLINGNESS TO RETAIN POST

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung remained unmoved Sunday despite PFP lawmakers' calls for him to reverse his decision to resign from his post, in the wake of PFP Chairman James Soong's announcement a day earlier that he would quit politics.
According to Cheng Chin-ling, the PFP's legislative caucus whip, Chang remained firm in his intention to resign from the post, despite party lawmakers' efforts to retain him.

Soong announced Saturday following his defeat in the Taipei mayoral election that he accepted the voters' judgment, and that he would pull out of Taiwan's politics altogether. Soong, once a powerful politician, gained more than 50,000 votes in the race, only 4.14 percent of the total.
Cheng made the comments following a meeting over the issue between Chang, a group of PFP lawmakers and David J. C. Chung, a PFP member and Legislative Yuan vice speaker.

Although PFP lawmakers tried hard to persuade Chang to stay and help maintain the party's normal operations, Cheng said that the party vice chairman's decision about quitting the post remained unchanged.

According to Cheng, Chung and PFP lawmakers asked Chang to continue leading the party and also promised to demand Soong continue to serve as party chief. They contended that the PFP should continue collaborating with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) at the Legislative Yuan in future, as the PFP still controls 22 seats in the 220-member legislature.
Asked whether the two parties would still form a formal political alliance as it has been reported, Cheng said that they are working toward that direction, but added that the KMT "holds the key."

It was reported that Soong and the KMT Chairman had met for four hours prior to Saturday's elections in a closed-door, late-night meeting to discuss the two parties' future collaboration in the legislature and to form a formal political alliance -- an alignment different from the loose "pan-blue alliance" that comprises the two parties and the New Party.
Meanwhile, Soong has no public activities scheduled and has rejected all visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP ON BRINK OF CRUMBLING AFTER LOSING ITS CHAIRMANBy Han Nai-kuoCNA Staff Writer

TEXT.P: Taiwan's second largest opposition party, the People First Party (PFP), is on the brink of crumbling after its chairman, James Soong, bowed out of politics Dec. 9 following a defeat in the Taipei mayoral election.

Soong, who founded the PFP almost single-handedly in 2000 after losing the presidential election by a narrow margin, received some 50,000 votes, or a little more than 4 percent, in the election -- lower than the 5 percent threshold necessary to get his NT$2 million deposit back. He was defeated by Hau Lung-bin, candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), who captured 53.8 percent of the vote.

Soong's failure was a sharp contrast to late 2000, when he ran as an independent in the presidential election while a member of the opposition Kuomintang at the time. Although he failed that year, he won 4.6 million votes nationwide -- about 37 percent of the popular vote.

That stunning performance prompted him to form the PFP, which captured 46 legislative seats in 2001 elections with 19 percent of the ballots cast, followed by winning eight seats in the Taipei City Council election in 2002.
Even when the PFP's legislative seats dropped to 34 in the 2004 legislative elections, the party still managed to secure 17 percent of the vote in the capital city of Taipei.

Soong's humiliating defeat in the Taipei mayoral election Dec. 9 was coupled with the party's defeat in city council elections in Taiwan's two largest cities. Only two PFP members won Taipei city councilor races, while four others won elections for Kaohsiung city councilor.
Soong's sudden departure leaves the PFP headless, with no clear direction in the party's future. There is no one in the party who could take over the chairmanship and fill Soong's large shoes.

Political analysts have blamed Soong himself for turning a blind eye to PFP supporters' fervent hope that the PFP be merged with its "pan-blue alliance" partner, the KMT, after Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou became KMT chairman in July 2005.

Like the KMT, the PFP is against Taiwan independence and champions eventual reunification with China. The party has maintained a close working relationship with the KMT in the legislature, but the relationship has been tense sometimes, especially in election years, because the two parties must compete for support from the same voters.
It has been the common wish of pan-blue alliance supporters that the KMT and PFP become one stronger, united party that challenges the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.
When their hope could not be realized, and when compelled to choose between the PFP and the KMT, most of the PFP's past supporters switched allegiance to the KMT in the Dec. 9 elections.

The PFP will become increasingly immaterial in Taiwan's politics and appears destined to fade into history. Some of the 22 PFP legislators have acknowledged they are seriously thinking of leaving the PFP and joining the KMT, because failing to do so, they will have very little chance of getting re-elected in legislative races next year.

The 2007 election will use a "single-member constituency, two-vote system," with the number of legislators slashed from 225 to 113 and their term extended from three years to four. The new system will be extremely unfavorable to small political parties, including the PFP.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN PRIEST, JOURNALIST CITED WITH HUMAN RIGHT AWARDS

TEXT.P: The Formosan Association for Human Rights cited a Taiwan-born priest, Hsu Tien-hsien, as well as a senior journalist Chen Ming-cheng Saturday, awarding them US$4,000 each at the association's 30 anniversary celebrations in Bedford, Texas.

The Cheng Nan-jung Memorial Award and the Dr. Wang Kang-lu Human Rights Award honor the two recipients' longstanding efforts in fighting for Taiwan's human rights and democracy, said Helen Wang, the association's president.
The award ceremony was held at an evening party co-organized by the Taiwanese Association of America's Dallas-Fort Worth Chapter, as part of a series of events marking the association's founding.
The celebrations gathered some 100 members from its branches throughout the U.S. and from Taiwan, as well as founder Tina Chang, who established the association in New York in 1976.

The association also discussed Taiwan media in a meeting earlier in the day, with the aim of urging the industry to be impartial and objective in news-gathering and avoid fabrication so as to protect people's basic human rights.
Wang said the association was founded to help political prisoners and their family members, and now works toward safeguarding basic human rights.

Based on this consideration, Wang noted in future the association's memorial award and human rights award will focus on citing prisoners of conscience as well as those who challenge media's disregard for human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNCIL FACING UNCERTAINTIES AFTER ELECTION

TEXT.P: The opening of an extra session of the Kaohsiung Council was shrouded in uncertainty Sunday after its Speaker Tsai Chien-hsing and Deputy Speaker Tsai Shung-hsiung suffered upsets in re-election bids Saturday.

Hsiu Lung-sheng, the council's secretary-general, said both the speaker and deputy speaker were not in a mood to decide when to convene a meeting among the various parties to reach a consensus on when to hold the extra session, which is necessary after the council went into recess early November without approving the city's general budget for 2007.
According to law, the council is supposed to finish the debate before the councilors' term expires at the end of this month.
The speaker and vice speaker are two of ten incumbent councilors who failed to win another term in Saturday's election, in which 77 candidates vied for 44 council seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CAUCUS SUGGESTS PARTY HEAVYWEIGHTS WORK TOWARD PARTY UNITY

TEXT.P: Members of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) legislative caucus called on the party's "four heavyweights" Sunday to sit down and discuss how to achieve party unity now that the party has weathered another election crisis.

Chen Ching-chun, caucus secretary-general, made the call after DPP candidate Chen Chu won the Kaohsiung mayoral race by a razor-thin margin Saturday, retaining a power base for the party that has been dogged by a string of corruption scandals over the past months.

If the party's key figures -- Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh -- try to jockey for an advantageous position with only a view toward becoming the party's presidential candidate in 2008, people would feel disillusioned, he said.

Hsieh, who ran on the party ticket for Taipei mayor, lost the election but managed to snatch over 40 percent of the vote -- a prowess some analysts said shows he is a potential contender for the next presidency.

Lin Cho-shui, who recently quit his legislative seat in protest over the party's inaction on the corruption scandals, suggested the four heavyweights sit down to discuss whether to launch the presidential nomination process early so the party would have enough time to prepare for the next big fight.

Kao Chih-peng, a DPP lawmaker in the "[pro-]Chen Shui-bian faction, " said primaries for next year's legislative elections and 2008 presidential elections could be held simultaneously, but whether the timetable should be moved forward needs further discussion.

Chen Ching-chun said just-concluded municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung are not a prelude to the 2008 race, which will be decided more by what the ruling party can achieve in the coming 18 months than by the emergence of the party's candidate.
"If President Chen has a poor administrative record for the remainder of his term, whoever will be running on the DPP ticket in 2008 will face an uphill battle," he said.

William C.T. Lai, another DPP legislator, said it matters little whether a party candidate is chosen early or late; what really matters is that the candidate is chosen by consensus and in the interest of harmony, something that can only be achieved if party heavyweights demonstrate their wisdom.

DOC.HEADLINE: 82 PEOPLE FALL ILL IN POSSIBLE MASS FOOD POISONING IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: Eighty two people sought medical treatment in hospitals Sunday morning after taking part in a wedding party the previous day in a possible mass food poisoning case in this southern port city, health officials said Sunday.
Most of the patients complained of nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and had developed slight fever which are the hallmarks of food poisoning caused by bacteria, health officials said.

Although the patients sought medical treatment in eight different hospitals in the city, all of them were among some 460 guests who attend a wedding party at the Marine Prince Restaurant which provides sea foods in Chienchin District.
All of the patients were released from hospitals except 11 who were kept in hospitals for observation Sunday.

Twenty six specimens of leftover food from the previous day's party as well as the patients' vomit and stool had been collected for tests to verify the cause behind their disease, health officials said.
The restaurant had been ordered to close pending the results of the tests, according to health officials.

The release of the report by the bipartisan Iraq Study Group this week exposed deep fissures among Republicans over how to manage a war that many fear will haunt their party -- and the nation -- for years to come.
A document that many in Washington had hoped would pave the way for a bipartisan compromise on Iraq instead drew sharp condemnation from the right, with hawks saying it was a wasted effort that advocated a shameful American retreat.
