DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 11, or the 21st day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan-chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR-ELECT TO CHOOSE 'RIGHT PERSONS FOR RIGHT JOBS'

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor-elect Chen Chu said Monday that ability will be the top consideration in choosing "the right persons for the right jobs" when she forms her new municipal government team.

Chen, who defeated her opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rival, Huang Chun-ying, by a razor-thin margin of just over 1,000 votes in Saturday's mayoral race, said that talent, and not party affiliation, will be her guiding principle in forming her "small Cabinet."
Chen said she will not start working on filling the top posts in the new city government for the next three days until she finishes her "thank-you tour" around the southern port city.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor-elect Hau Lung-bin of the KMT said Monday that no personnel decisions on his new city government team will be made until next week.

Hau, who garnered 692,085 votes, or 53.81 percent of all the ballots cast in Saturday's election, to defeat his main rival, Frank Hsieh of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, also stressed that choosing the right persons for the right posts will be a top priority.
Both Chen and Hau are expected to be sworn into office on Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO TALK OF CABINET RESHUFFLE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and the Presidential Office have not discussed a possible Cabinet reshuffle following Saturday's municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Cho Jung-tai, deputy secretary-general to the president, said Monday.

Cho was responding to questions raised by Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Legislative Yuan about whether Premier Su Tseng-chang will remain in his post after the elections and whether Su has talked about his future plans.
Cho said that President Chen will carry out a comprehensive review in the wake of the elections, with "political stability" being his main concern.
"In addition to the continuation of the administration's policy and its implementation, the president is also concerned about personnel stability," Cho said.

The DPP's popular support ratings slipped to new low in the wake of a series of alleged corruption scandals involving members of the first family, but the party's morale was greatly boosted after its candidate won the mayoral election in the southern port city of Kaohsiung and its candidate in the Taipei mayoral election garnered more votes than its candidate in the previous election.

DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles Times: Iran Looks Like the Winner of the Iraq War. The report issued last week by the blue-ribbon Iraq Study Group provides fresh proof of Iran's strengthened hand in the Middle east since the U.S.-led invasion:It mentions the Islamic Republic more than 50 times and makes clear that the U.S. will have to seek Iran's help for any resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S PRIMARY FOR PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION TENTATIVELY SET FOR NEXT MAY

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential primary has been tentatively set for next May, DPP Secretary-General Lin Chia-lung said Monday.
However, final decisions on the primary's timetable and details will be made by the DPP Central Executive Committee after consultations with opinion leaders from all sectors of society, Lin said.

Lin added that the question of whether the DPP primaries for next year's legislative elections and the 2008 presidential elections should be held simultaneously as some DPP lawmakers have suggested is still up in the air.

Lin said that he doesn't completely agree with the idea put forward by some DPP members that the party launch the presidential nomination process early to offset the negative impact of the rivalry among the party's four "heavyweights, " namely Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Su Tseng-chang, Chairman Yu Shyi-kun and former Premier Frank Hsieh.

He reasoned that producing a DPP presidential candidate early would not necessarily prevent these "heavyweights" from competing. Besides, he said, if a DPP presidential candidate were to be named too early, the candidate would unavoidably become the target of smear campaigns and mudslinging by the opposition camp, adding that such a development would also be detrimental to the DPP administration's operations at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange closed lower Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 24.18 points to close at 7,612.12.
The bourse opened at 7,636.3 and fluctuated between 7,635.72 and and 7,582.62 during trading. A total of 4.11 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$102.98 billion (US$3.17 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up 1.4 percent and plastics and chemicals shares increasing 0.14 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by construction issues and banking and financial shares both at 1.1 percent, cement stocks and textile stocks both at 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 668 to 547, with 191 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES SHOULD THINK GLOBALLY: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: In a time of globalization, Taiwan businesses should not confine their investments to "just a certain part of the world, " the head of a local think tank said Monday, referring to China.
Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, made the remarks at a seminar sponsored by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

He noted that some media is exploring why Taiwan's economic performance lags behind that of South Korea and attributes some of the reasons to the government's China investment restrictions on certain sectors, but said he disagrees with that view.
Chen claimed that the key to the gap between Taiwan and South Korea lies in the fact that Seoul is seeking to be No. 1 in the world, while Taiwan businesses are content to be No. 1 only in China.
Chen said there are a lot of opportunities to make money in China and that Taiwan businessmen should seize those opportunities.

But he also said that not every Taiwan business makes money, citing the example of manufacturers of notebook computers. Since they have been allowed to invest in China, their profits have not seen a dramatic increase, showing that "going west" is no guarantee of profits, he added.
Taiwan businesses should not blame the government's cross-Taiwan Strait trade policy for their failure to make money, he added.

With the ratio of Taiwan's exports to China higher than that of South Korea's to China, Chen said the reason Taiwan's industry and profits lag behind South Korea is because Taiwan businesses look only at how to make money from the gap between Taiwan and China.
"They fail to focus on building a fortress of knowledge, so that they are easily surpassed by their rivals," he said.
He added that some businesses, such as Taiwan's DRAM and flat panel businesses, which have not gone to China, have developed better than their South Korean counterparts.
He also pointed out the fallacy of some Taiwan businesses that think they are incapable of competing globally, but at the same time believe that they can win if they invest in China.
Moreover, in the midst of the free flow of goods and capital, businesses should realize that if they cannot widen the knowledge gap between them and their rivals, they could fall quickly, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS PROPOSE RELOCATING CAPITAL CITY TO CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Trong R. Chai has decided to propose a bill at the end of the month to promote his idea of relocating the capital city from Taipei in northern Taiwan to the central area of the island.

DPP legislative caucus whip Yeh Yi-jin praised Monday the plan as a positive move for national development, explaining that judging from the perspective of geography, it is "even-handed" for the central government to place its headquarters in the central area of the country.

Tsai announced the proposal a day earlier in a press release along with several of his colleagues. He revealed that the proposal has won the support of over 70 lawmakers and that he has therefore decided to present the bill to the legislature in late December. If the bill fails to clear the Legislative Yuan, Tsai said, he will push for a referendum on the issue.

In the press release, Tsai argued that Taipei's economic development has greatly outpaced that of other Taiwan cities in the central and southern regions, adding that relocating the capital would help in efforts to balance development in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: 'Seniang' kills 2 in Leyte
TACLOBAN CITY -- Two children were killed when they were pinned by fallen trees that were knocked down by typhoon "Seniang" that hit the islands of Leyte and Samar Saturday afternoon.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: INC warned GMA of public outrage
The influential Iglesia Ni Cristo had told President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of its concern over the country's political stability in the face of moves by her house allies to revise the Constitution even without Senate participation, The Inquirer leanred yesterday.
The Philippine Star: GMA hit for summit failure
President Arroyo is facing growing criticism over the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) summit, whose last-minute cancellation has raised questions about her handling of the event.
The Manila Times: 'ERAP NOT GUILTY'
Detained President Joseph Estrada is not guilty of plunder and perjury as charged, according to the defense's formal offer of evidence. The 65-page document was presented by defense lawyers to impeach and rebut the testimonies of the prosecution's 76 witnesses and voluminous evidence against Estrada.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Foreigners' medical subsidies to be cut.
From October next year, foreign workers here will have to pay the full cost of all medical treatment they receive at public hospitals.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Foreigner workers' subsidies to be cancel and PRs' subsidies to be cut from next October.
From October next year, foreign workers in Singapore will not have the medical subsidies from Singapore government.
Government will cut ten percent of Permanent residents (PRs)' medical subsidies in next two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Monday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 19 points to close at 7,614, with 30,621 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January dropped 23 points to finish at 7,612, with 1,700 contracts traded, while March futures lost 20 points to close at 7,620, with 57 contract transactions. June futures moved down 32 points to close at 7,590, with three contract transactions, while September futures dropped 14 points to finish at 7,429, with 28 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 7,633 for December, 7,635 for January, 7,640 for March, 7,622 for June and 7,443 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures moved up 0.6 points to close at 321.1, with 2,943 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained 0.3 points to finish at 320, with 132 contract transactions. June TE futures increased 1.7 points to close at 320.4, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

December TF futures lost 12.6 points to close at 1,041.8, with 2,394 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures dropped 12.2 points to close at 1,042.2, with 151 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE REVIEWS BILL ON ESTABLISHMENT OF IPR JUDGES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan Judicial Committee approved Monday after a preliminary review a draft bill calling for the establishment of associate judges in courts to help facilitate the process of lawsuits involving intellectual property disputes.

Associate intellectual property rights (IPR) judges, if installed in courts, could provide professional consultations to judges, ask questions or offer explanations on behalf of the judges and assist in investigations to help judges handle IPR lawsuits, which otherwise would be daunting tasks for the judges due to their lack of specific knowledge in the IPR field and related industry and commerce, said ruling Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Wu Ping-jui.

Noting that the installation of IPR associate judges would substantially increase judges' credibility in settling lawsuits, Wu said it is hoped the bill can be passed by the legislature before March 2007.
Meanwhile, the committee also reviewed and approved a proposal that civil suits involving IPR disputes should be referred to intellectual property courts for settlement.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.1 to close at NT$32.490.
A total of US$913 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.540 and hit a low of NT$32.450.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'THREE LINKS' SHOULD BE OPENED CONDITIONALLY: PUNDIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan should consider opening direct trade, postal and transportation links -- better known as "three direct links" with China conditionally, the head of a think-tank said Monday.

Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Taiwan Thinktank, said that from the perspective that "the world is flat, " Taiwan should consider opening direct links -- particularly direct air links -- with China if three prerequisites can be secured.

Chen said Taiwan should launch direct air links with China if the nation's dignity can be upheld, if Beijing promises not to interfere in Taiwan's efforts to forge free trade agreements with other countries and if China agrees to remove trade barriers it has imposed on imports from Taiwan.
He made the remarks during a speech he delivered at a seminar co-sponsored by the Industrial Development Bureau and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.

He said Taiwan's lack of direct links with China is basically against the "world is flat" trend, in which multinational companies have increased their presence globally while funds move around the globe quickly.
He also said that if Taiwan were to begin "three direct links" talks with China, it should be a "package" of talks with all relevant issues included rather than talks on just one or two aspects.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA `FOLLOWS NORM' IN NATIONALITY APPLICATION FROM PAKISTANI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has followed international norms in dealing with an application for Republic of China nationality from a Pakistani man married to a Taiwanese woman, a MOFA official said Monday.

The official made the remarks after Legislator Lu Shiu-yen, the Taiwanese woman Tsou Shih-yung and her Pakistani husband called for attention to the difficulties of the Pakistani man in obtaining ROC nationality.

Tsou said that after they married in Taiwan, the MOFA told them to go to Pakistan to register their marriage and get it authenticated by the Pakistan Embassy in Saudi Arabia because Taiwan does not maintain diplomatic relations with Pakistan. They have spent NT$200,000 (US$6.060) in getting the marriage certificate and getting it authenticated, but have received no response from MOFA since submitting the relevant documents in mid-June.

Lu said that apart from Chinese spouses, ROC law stipulates that foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals have the right to apply for ROC nationality. However, the ministry said that since Pakistan is "a terrorist country," screening of Pakistanis should be more rigorous.
Chen Shan-you, an official of MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, said Pakistan is not friendly toward Taiwan while friendly to terrorists.

The international community generally adopts a strict manner in verifying the identity of Pakistani people, Chen said, claiming that the delay was caused by the "slow authentification" by the Pakistan Embassy in Saudi Arabia.

But he also said that Chien Kang-tan, director-general of MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, has instructed him to continue the rigorous screening but to also take the individual case into humanitarian consideration.
The Bureau of Consular Affairs has asked its representative office in Saudi Arabia to help with the authentication and verification and should get the results in three days, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Pinochet, the general who terrorized Chile, dies.
Former Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet died at 91 Sunday. Pinochet and his junta were accused of killing former President Salvator Allende and some 3,000 political prisoners. Demonstrations celebrating his death turned violent in Santiago.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12-YEAR CAP ON MAXIMUM AGE OF TOUR BUSES

TEXT.P: Tour buses will have to be taken out of service once they reach 12 years of age, according to new regulations being considered by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.

However, Minister of Transportation and Communications Tsai Duei told the Legislative Yuan Monday that the 12-year ceiling might be extended by one to four years if the buses are assessed as being in good shape.
Tour buses should undergo compulsory examinations after 10 years in use and should have roadworthiness certificates issued by accredited garages.
Tour buses that are more than 12 years old before the regulations take force Jan. 1 will be limited to operating only within their home county and neighboring counties.

From Jan. 1, all tour buses must be installed with tachographs and have their manufacture date printed near their doors. New tour buses, as well buses operating on the freeways, should have safety belts on all seats and should not use retread tires, according to the new regulations.

There are 11,918 tour buses in operation in the country, 3,339 of which are more than 12 years old. All information on them will also be published on the Web site of the Directorate General of Highways, said Tsai.
The new regulations are a reaction to a bus accident in Meiling, Tainan County Dec. 3 that killed 22 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY'S COURT APPEARANCE TO DEPEND ON HER HEALTH: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Whether the first lady will appear in court over the use of state affairs funds this week will depend on her physical condition and her lawyers' advice, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said Monday.
Cho made the remarks in response to questions raised by reporters after attending a meeting of a legislative committee.

Prosecutors indicted Wu on charges of forgery and corruption Nov. 3 after determining that she had used the receipts or invoices of others to claim funds totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's discretionary "state affairs fund" during the period 2002-2006.
President Chen Shui-bian was named along with his wife in the corruption charges but was not charged because of his constitutional immunity from prosecution as head of state.
Cho said the first lady's lawyers will make a thorough evaluation of whether she can appear in court after receiving the suggestions of her medical doctors.
Asked about Wu's current health condition, Cho said he didn't have the details and only knows that her physical condition has been not stable for quite some time.

Cho said that he was happy to see that the first lady came to cast her vote in last Saturday's municipal elections, adding that he hopes she is healthy enough to face all the problems she has encountered. Wu has been wheelchair-bound since being run over by a truck in 1985.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO VISIT GAMBIA DEC. 13-17

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) James Huang said Monday that Premier Su Tseng-chang is scheduled to visit Gambia Dec. 13-17 to attend the Dec. 15 inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh.
Huang made the remarks at a legislative committee when Legislator Lee Jih-chu of the opposition Kuomintang asked if it is in keeping with diplomatic protocol to send an envoy at such short notice.

President Chen Shui-bian announced last month that Vice President Annette Lu would represent him at Jammeh's inauguration, but later decided to designate Su as his special envoy because of Lu's busy schedule.

Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the ruling Democratic Progressive asked if the itinerary could have unexpected twists and turns, given the fact that the premier's plans to visit other countries have twice been called off at the last minute this year.
The minister said that the ministry keeps abreast of relations between the two countries, and is cautious in dealing with bilateral ties.

Noting that Taiwan has only used 33 percent of its international compassionate and humanitarian fund this year, the legislator also asked if Gambia, which is in dire economic straits, could be entitled to financial assistance.
Huang said that Gambia had made no request for money and that Su will meet with Jammeh and other Gambian officials.
Su canceled a plan to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's inauguration Aug. 8 after learning that Chad was ready to switch its diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
His plan to visit Haiti in mid-May was also scuttled because of China's obstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FIRM ON COOPERATION WITH PFP: KMT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) stands firm on its stance of continuing to collaborate with the People First Party (PFP) and will not back out of a cooperation agreement it reached with the PFP, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Monday.

Ma made the comments after attending a public charity activity while answering questions from reporters about the reported accord that the two parties signed prior to the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung -- Taiwan's two special municipalities.

According to a China Times report, Ma and PFP Chairman James Soong inked an accord Nov. 28 to form a political alliance and step up bilateral cooperation after the municipal elections. But Ma regretted clinching the pact and asked to meet Soong again Dec. 1 in a meeting that was leaked the following day, the report said.
Saying that the KMT does not regret having cooperated with the PFP, Ma added that his meetings with Soong were aimed at reaching a consensus on continued collaboration between the two parties.
But he argued that it is wrong to view their meetings as "secret" or "closed-door" and claimed that he and Soong did not sign any formal documents, although they agreed to keep on cooperating.

"The KMT is very sincere about the promise that it made to the PFP and it will not change its position in this regard," Ma repeated, stressing that his party will make pubic any formal accords that it inks through due process with the PFP.

The KMT and the PFP already form a loose "pan-blue alliance" that also includes the New Party against its rival "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun urged the two "pan-blue" partners later that day to rebuild mutual trust and establish a formal alliance as soon as possible after the Saturday's elections to meet the high expectations of supporters for "pan-blue" unity.

Although Soong has announced his intention to quit the political scene following his hammering in the weekend Taipei mayoral race, Lee said that 22 PFP lawmakers still serve in the Legislative Yuan and that they are the PFP's most valuable asset as they form a key minority in the 220-member legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SCREENS GENETIC HEALTH LAW AMENDMENT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan began Monday to screen an amendment bill concerning the Genetic Health Law, which, if passed, will exempt women from obtaining prior consent of their spouses in case they want to seek abortion.
According to the draft amendment, a married woman only need "inform" her spouse of a planned abortion by telephone, mail or cellphone message.
Under the current law, a married woman must acquire her spouse's consent and signature before seeking an abortion.

The draft revision, proposed by the Department of Health (DOH) , demands the cancellation of the rule after government authorities found that many victims of domestic violence have been forced to give birth to an "unwanted" child or seek an illegal abortion after failing to obtain their spouse's agreement.
The existing law deprives a woman of her right to have an abortion if she chooses, DOH Bureau of Health Promotion Director Hsiao Mei-lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFERS AID TO PHILIPPINE TYPHOON VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate US$300,000 in cash to the Philippine government to aid victims of typhoon Durian, which devastated southern Luzon -- the largest island of the Philippines -- in late November, Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang announced Monday.
More than 1,000 people died or went missing during the typhoon, which also left over 800,000 people homeless.
Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo announced a state of disaster Dec. 4 and asked for humanitarian aid from around the world, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP CALLS FOR TALKS ON NEW ALIGNMENT WITH KMT

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) and the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should start talks soon on forming a new alliance to meet supporters' high expectations for unity in the "pan-blue alliance," PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun said Monday.

The two parties must rebuild mutual trust and set up a platform upon which to boost two-way communications as the first step in moving toward that goal -- a consensus that Lee said was reached in meetings between KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and PFP Chairman James Soong prior to the Dec. 9 municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung.
Now that the elections are over, both parties should stop bickering through the media, Lee said, adding that the PFP is looking forward to quickly beginning talks over the issue with the KMT.

Although the PFP is now at a disadvantage due to Soong's announcement last Saturday that he is to quit politics, Lee pointed out that the PFP is still an independent political party. It still has some 20 lawmakers serving at the 219-member Legislative Yuan and they are the key to guaranteeing a "pan-blue" legislative majority, he noted.
The PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan will continue to operate normally and the party has no plans to elect a new party chairman, Lee said.

Soong said that he would retire from politics last Saturday after conceding defeat in the Taipei mayoral election. He earned just over 58,000 votes, or 4.14 percent of the total, ranking a distant third among the six candidates.
The once powerful Soong set up the PFP in 2000 after losing the presidential election to President Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER HOPES TO VISIT CHINA IN SPRING

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Monday that he hopes to visit China next spring in an attempt to help mend bilateral ties.

In a meeting with reporters, Wang said he has been seeking the opportunity to make such a trip for the past five or six years and that it is now more probable that he will be able to realize the trip early next year.
He declined to provide any further details, saying that the time is not yet ripe.

Asked whether he will vie for the presidency in the 2008 election, Wang said he was "unable" to assess the possibility at present, but he said he was planning to meet main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong in the coming days.

According to Wang, a KMT heavyweight, he will discuss issues related to a quicker screening of a presidential nomination list of Control Yuan members at the Legislative Yuan, while also trying to persuade Soong to remain in the political arena.

Commenting on a long-stalled law amendment that will allow direct transport links between Taiwan and China, Wang contended that it is no good to ram the controversial bill through the legislature despite the fact that the KMT and the PFP together command a majority at the 219-member Legislative Yuan.
Soong announced last Saturday that he would retire from politics after conceding defeat in the Taipei mayoral race earlier the same day.
Soong gained only around 58,000 votes, or 4.14 percent of the valid ballots, placing him a distant third among the six candidates.
The KMT, the PFP and the New Party are partners in the "pan-blue alliance" -- rivals of the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNITY MENTAL HYGIENE CENTER INAUGURATED IN TAIPEI COUNTY

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government inaugurated a community mental hygiene center Monday to offer help to those on the brink of suicide or who are suffering from other mental disorders.

The center was opened after five members of a family of six in Taipei committed suicide one after another in less than four months, suspectedly due to economic factors. The tragedy shocked society and made the front pages of several newspapers.
At the opening ceremony, Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei said suicide has become the sixth-most-common cause of death in Taipei County.
Chou said the county government has already set up a telephone hotline to offer counseling to those in need.
Tai Chuan-wei, deputy director of the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) suicide prevention center, noted that family members are the best people to find out if someone is suicidal.

Citing the example of the six-member family, in which the father and his adult daughter jumped into a river in August, Tai claimed that if more people show concern to other members of their families, "tragedies would not occur again."
The mother of the family killed herself and her two sons Sunday, jumping into the same river where her husband and daughter died.
Tai said he had high expectations for the mental hygiene center.
According to Tai, the people most likely to attempt suicide are in the 16-24 age group, with most suicide deaths occurring among the elderly.

Chiang Hung-chi, deputy executive officer of the DOH's suicide prevention center, noted that some 45 percent of suicides had revealed their intention in advance. However, 70 percent of family members believed they were not serious, Chiang added.
Chiang urged families and friends not to ignore threats of suicide.

According to government statistics, the World Health Organization (WHO) has listed depression as one of the three biggest diseases of the 21st Century, with suicide the ninth-most-common cause of death in Taiwan last year.

Hsu Ming-neng, director of the Taipei county government's Health Department, said the mental higiene center will held seminars and related activities to allow the public to better understand various mental diseases and teach them techniques to relieve stress.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S LARGEST COFFEE MUSEUM TO BREAK GROUND FRIDAY

TEXT.P: The world's largest coffee museum is scheduled to break ground Friday at an agricultural park belonging to the Council of Agriculture in southern Pingtung County, Taiping Coffee Biotech Co. executives said Monday.
The officials said the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park will be inaugurated Friday, with a ground-breaking ceremony for the museum also held that day.
Ambassadors to Taiwan from such coffee-producing countries as Panama, Costa Rica and Malawi will be invited to attend the ceremony, they said.
They said the company's premises will cover an area of 6,600 pings (one ping equals 3.3 square meters) with 2,900 pings given over to the coffee museum, which will feature five theme parks.
They said the museum will combine a coffee biotech factory, tourism and leisure facilities, showcasing coffee culture as well as coffee-making equipment.

In addition to a detailed introduction to the history of drinking coffee, several world-renowned coffee brands in cooperation with the company will also provide coffee-producing equipment and coffee sets, they said, adding that some of the equipment is dated to four or five hundred years ago.
The museum will take about a year to complete and is scheduled to open to the public in 2008, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW IMMIGRANTS IN TAIPEI COUNTY COMPETE IN TALENT CONTEST

TEXT.P: The Taipei county government organized a talent contest for the northern county's new immigrants over the weekend as part of efforts to help them adapt to Taiwan society, county officials said Monday.
A total of 508 new immigrants from 10 countries competed in the contest featuring speeches, storytelling and talent performances, the officials said.
Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei also attended the event.
Chou said the county government has worked with many schools since 2004 with the aim of helping the new immigrants integrate into the local community through educational activities.

Among the contestants, 368 were from Vietnam, 58 were from Indonesia, 21 were from Thailand, 17 were from Cambodia, 15 were from the Philippines, 13 were from Myanmar and 13 were from China. The remaining three were from South Korea, Japan and India, respectively.

DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, Dec.12 [CNA] The Moscow Times: 45 Perish in Fire at Treatment Center
Forty-five women died when a fire broke out in a drug and alcohol treatment center in southern Moscow early Saturday morning. [By Chang Hung-kuang]

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Police find third body in serial killer hunt
Police began a hunt for a serial killer last night after it was confirmed that a third woman found dead in woodland in Suffolk was a prostitute.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Metro Considers Increasing Rail Fares; Service Cuts Are Also Among Ideas to Plug $116 Million Shortfall
Metro faces a $116 million budget shortfall the next fiscal year, raising the possibility of fare increases, reduced bus and rail service and higher contributions from area taxpayers, according to budget documents and interviews with board members.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL FORUM ON ANIMAL WELFARE HELD IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: People's attitude toward animals has changed over time, especially in the last 10 years, but Taiwan still faces barriers that impede the practice of animal protection, scholars said in an international forum Monday.

"Animal protection is a policy that cannot be delayed," said Chen Shei-saint, chairman of the Animal Protection Association (APA) of the Republic of China at the opening ceremony of the 2006 International Companion Animal Welfare Forum.

The two-day forum, co-organized by the APA, Life Conservationist Association and the Department of Veterinary Medicine at National Taiwan University, is taking place in Taipei with scholars from 11 countries meeting in a "dialogue between Taiwan and the World."

David Fraser, a Canadian professor at the University of British Columbia who also works for the Office International des Epizooties (OIE, World Organization for Animal Health), offered a global perspective on animal welfare in a keynote speech.
It is amazing how quickly people's opinion could change in 30 years toward animals, Fraser noted, adding that the animal protection movement is looking for a more global reach in the 21st century.

However, there are new challenges ahead, including the rising production of meat -- especially in developing countries; the human impact on wildlife species, and increasing cases of domestic animals living in human communities, Fraser said.
Briefing the audience on the animal protection movement in Taiwan, Shih Chao-hwei, a Buddhist nun, followed up Fraser's viewpoints with her concerns.
Taiwan's animal protection movement has a long way to go, said Shih Chao-hwei, a professor at Hsuan Chuang University.

"The [animal protection] law in Taiwan has been in place. All we need now is the improvement of law enforcement. Too many times we have allowed unlimited generalizations of cultural diversity, tourism and sacred sacrifice to impede the practice [of animal protection] in Taiwan," she said.
Twelve theses will be presented at the forum.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:Taliban and Allies Tighten Grip in North of Pakistan
Islamic militants are using a recent peace deal with the government to consolidate their hold in northern Pakistan, vastly expanding their training of suicide bombers and other recruits and fortifying alliances with Al Qaeda and foreign fighters, diplomats and intelligence officials from several nations say. The result, they say, is virtually a Taliban mini-state.
Wall Street Journal:How a Highflier in Marketing Fell at Wal-Mart
Wal-Mart hired the 36-year-old executive away from car maker DaimlerChrysler AG in January to shake up its marketing department, widely seen as a sleepy province turning out ads with smiley faces and drab reminders about low prices. The nation's largest retailer, besieged by political opponents and upscale competitors, felt it needed to bring its brand into the 21st century.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 2,000 STUDENTS PROMOTE FUNDRAISER TO HELP POOR FOREIGN CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Students in central Taiwan took part in a fundraiser Sunday to raise funds for disadvantaged children in foreign countries, Hu Wuan-wen, director of the central Taiwan office of the World Vision Taiwan (WVT), said Monday.

The campaign was launched by WVT, a Christian charity, to raise funds for poor children in 19 countries in Africa, Latin America, the Middle East, Eastern Europe and the Asia-Pacific region, with more than 2,000 students taking part, Hu said.

The students introduced the WVT-designed fundraising plans to passers-by in Taichung City and Changhua County, while auctioning off merchandise made by WVT supporters to raise funds for the program, according to Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP MEETS HER HONDURAN COUNTERPART

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu met her Honduran counterpart Ernesto Santos Ordonez Monday, calling for greater efforts in strengthening friendship between the two countries.

Meeting at the Presidential Office, Lu hailed Santos for providing great assistance to Honduran President Manuel Zelaya, adding she believes Santos will get high marks for his role in Honduras' modernization.

After the meeting, the two met congressmen from Spanish-speaking countries who came to Taiwan to attend several activities and the Dec. 10 inauguration of the Pacific Congressional Caucus (PCC) under the Democratic Pacific Union (DPU) , which was founded in Taipei in August 2005 under Lu's push.
Lu and the visitors exchanged opinions on the PCC, which Lu formed to bring together Congress members from nearly 30 countries around the Pacific rim.
Lu expressed hope that the PCC's establishment would further strengthen democracy among Pacific countries, regardless of race, religion or sex.
Santos noted the PCC will help develop democracy and peace among Pacific countries.

He also extended gratitude to the Republic of China government for offering him the opportunity to witness the country's achievements in several sectors, especially in economic aspects, adding that he will bring these valuable experiences back to his country for Honduras' reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENG WAN-JU FOUNDATION CITES PROFESSIONAL HOUSEKEEPERS

TEXT.P: The Peng Wan-ju Foundation, a noted women's group in Taiwan, held a citation ceremony at the Chien Tan Overseas Youth Activity Center in Taipei Sunday for outstanding and senior housekeepers who have attended its training programs and received professional certification.

Several professional household workers were cited in two categories -- those with a distinguished performance and those who have worked as housekeepers more than five years, the foundation's director Liu Yu-hsiu said.

This year's winners have an average monthly income NT$40,000, and are an average age of 46, Liu noted. All winners are required to undergo at least 16 hours of training and volunteer services, as well as gain recognition through opinion surveys that are filled out by their employers.

The Peng Wan-Ru Foundation has succeeded in training a total of 5,000 professional housekeepers since it began offering training programs in 2001, and 13,000 families are being served by these professional household workers, according to Liu.
Some 2,000 women have completed training programs this year and are currently providing housekeeping services for 5,000 families, Liu added.

According to the foundation's statistics, the employment rate reached 99 percent for those who have already completed certification training programs in the past two years. Some 98 percent of them have worked for three months and 91 percent have worked for over one year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG MAYOR RETURNS TO WORK 22 DAYS AFTER CAR ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu returned to work at the Taichung city government Monday after spending 22 days at Chi Mei Medical Center in Tainan County receiving treatment and accompanying his wife, Shirley Shao, who was seriously injured in a Nov. 18 car accident.
Hu thanked city council speaker Chang Hung-nien and other council members for their support in helping him and his wife tide through their ordeal.
He termed progress in his wife's recovery as "a miracle" and expressed gratitude to all who have prayed for her and sent their best wishes.
Shao, who has not fully recovered from her injuries, is still at Chi Mei Medical Center.

She lapsed into a coma after the accident and remained in an intensive care unit for 18 days. A medical team performed two surgical operations, amputating her left forearm and a ruptured spleen. Five days ago, she was able to open her eyes and utter a few syllables. Doctors determined she was no longer in critical condition and allowed her to stay in an ordinary ward.
The mayor compared his wife's condition to "a lightbulb that turns on and off because there isn't enough electricity."
He added that his wife is "off" more often than she is "on."
Queried by reporters about the possibility of a photo opportunity with his wife, Hu said news media should not expect to see her for at least six months.
Hu disclosed that starting Dec. 13, China Medical University Hospital in Taichung will take over the job of providing patient care and undertaking rehabilitation work for his wife.
Asked how he felt about the driver of the car who had tried to overtake them on a freeway shoulder and caused his chauffeured minivan to overturn, Hu said he bore no grudge against that young man.
"I hope his life has returned to normal and that he would obey traffic rules and drive carefully in future," he said.

Later Monday, the Taichung City Council invited the mayor to a ceremony to light up a Christmas tree in the plaza in front of the council -- not only to greet the festive holiday, but also to celebrate the mayor's return to work and to pray for his wife's early recovery. (Han Nai-kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTRICTIONS ON RESIDENCE PERMITS FOR FOREIGN SPOUSES TO BE RELAXED

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a draft revision to the law governing entry, exit and immigration Monday which would relax restrictions on foreign spouses seeking to retain their residence permit.

Under the terms of the draft amendment, foreign spouses would be eligible to keep their residence permits under one of the following circumstances: the death of the spouse, being placed under governmental protection after proven mental or physical spousal abuse, having the guardianship of a child or children aged under 20 after divorce, and repatriation resulting from a withdrawn residence permit that causes "irretrievable" harm to the foreign spouse's children born in Taiwan.
The draft amendment is now pending a second reading by a legislative plenary session later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATES ENCOURAGE TAIWAN'S STUDENTS TO 'STAY CURIOUS'

TEXT.P: Nobel prize-winning scientists encouraged Taiwan students Monday to remain curious about the world around them, while also cultivating a concern for political and social affairs.

During a rare question-and-answer session at an international seminar in Yilan, northeastern Taiwan, Taiwan high school and college students were excited to have the opportunity to ask questions of six Nobel laureates gathered in part to celebrate the 70th birthday of Dr. Lee Yuan-tseh, the former president of Academia Sinica.

Wei Yu-shu, a sophomore at Taichung First High School, asked the top scientists if a laser that captures atoms could control the atoms' movement. Other students asked the scientists when they had made the resolution to become a scientist, or if they had ever thought of changing their job after winning the Nobel prize.

Dodley Herschbach, who had served as Lee's lab research advisor, said he came from a farming background and was the first member of his family to attend college, and that he hadn't become interested in science until entering university.

German-born John Polanyi was born to a family of scientists. He said he naturally joined their ranks, even though his father had not asked him to become one, asking him instead to care about politics and society.
Polanyi added that he enjoyed sharing his findings with other people, and also hoped to hear constructive suggestions from others.

John Fenn of Virginia University, an octagenarian, and Caltech Professor Rudolph Marcus, the 1992 Nobel prize winner of chemistry, encouraged young students to remain curious about everything in the world.

Steven Chu, who won a Nobel prize in 1997, said he practices what Fenn and Marcus had advised and has always remained curious about all things. Chu said the Nobel prize gives him a chance in public service.
Lee advised students not to be dejected by criticism that their findings "look stupid."
"Marcus' finding was called 'stupid, ' too, but 20 years later it was proven right," he said.

Some of the students were nervous when meeting in person with these international figures, asking questions in a quivering voice. But as for Taichung's Wei, he said he could understand 70 percent of what was said in their lectures.
"These masters expanded my scope. I admire their truth-seeking spirit, " he said, determined that he will follow in their footsteps on the path of scientific research.
The seminar was sponsored by the Academia Sinica's Institute of Atomic and Molecular Sciences with some enterprises co-sponsoring.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT'S NOT TIME YET TO NAME PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: DPP

TEXT.P: Senior government officials said Monday it is not yet time for the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to consider when to hold its presidential primary election and whom to nominate as the party's presidential and vice presidential candidates.

In response to media queries about DPP legislative caucus whip Ker Chien-ming's call for an early decision to nominate the DPP's presidential and vice presidential hopefuls, Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Cho Jung-tai said a rush or hurry is "unnecessary."

Noting that Taiwan held mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung only two days go, Cho said, "The DPP should not give the impression that the purpose of its existence is solely elections."

Cabinet spokesman Cheng Wen-tsan echoed Cho's remarks when asked to comment on media reports that Premier Su Tseng-chang and former Premier Frank Hsieh form the best ticket for the DPP in the 2008 presidential election.
Cheng said that now is the time for Taiwan's society to recuperate from the Dec. 9 elections.
"The people expect the DPP to do a good job, and there is no need to hurry on fielding candidates for the next elections," he said.

In the Dec. 9 elections, DPP candidate Chen Chu was elected Kaohsiung mayor. Although the party's candidate for Taipei mayor, Frank Hsieh, was defeated by opposition Kuomintang candidate Hau Lung-bin, he garnered more than 40 percent of ballots cast against Hau's 53 percent, making him one of the presidential hopefuls for the 2008 race.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUVALU PRIME MINISTER PLEDGES UNSWERVING SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Visiting Tuvalu Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia said Monday his country has been and will continue to be Taiwan's staunchest ally and will seize every possible opportunity to speak for Taiwan's cause in the international community.
Ielemia made the pledge during a dinner given by Premier Su Tseng-chang at the Taipei Guest House in honor of him and his entourage.

This is Ielemia and his wife's second visit to Taiwan this year. During the dinner, Su expressed his gratitude for Ielemia's firm support for Taiwan over the years. Ielemia has voiced support for Taiwan's bid to join major international organizations, including the United Nations and the World Health Organization, on numerous international occasions.

Earlier in the day, Su accompanied Ielemia on a visit to a tropical fruit orchard in the southernmost county of Pingtung where more than 300 new or rare tropical fruit species have been developed and cultivated. Ielemia said he was impressed by beautiful scenery and people's hospitality in Pingtung -- Su's hometown.
Meanwhile, Tuvalu Parliament Speaker Kamuta Latasi is also in Taipei. He met with President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office Monday.

Chen, who made a half-day state visit to Tuvalu May 30, 2005, extended a warm welcome to Latasi who attended the inauguration of the Pacific Congressional Caucus under the Pacific Democratic Union Sunday.

Chen said Taiwan is grateful for Tuvalu's long-term support for Taiwan's cause in the world arenas, adding that he hopes relations between the two countries will further expand and thrive. Chen is the first Republic of China head of state to visit the South Pacific island country.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY HONORS SOUTHERN TAIWAN VOLUNTEERS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung city government held a sports meet to honor volunteer workers from southern Taiwan Sunday in celebration of International Volunteer Day, an official said Monday.
The event was held at National Kaohsiung Normal University, with 1,231 volunteer workers among more than 5,000 participants receiving medals in recognition of their contributions, the organizer said.
Acting Kaohsiung Mayor Yeh Chu-lan presided over the event, now in its fourth year, the organizer noted, adding that the city now has more than 40,000 volunteer workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 12, or the 22nd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans-Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION COMMISSION REBUTS VOTE-RIGGING ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung Election Commission (KEC) rebutted Tuesday opposition accusations that the just-concluded mayoral election was rigged.
Chen Pao-teh, a KEC section chief, said the voting and vote count procedures in Saturday's mayoral election were transparent and closely supervised.
"It is simply not likely that any major mistake occurred in the vote count process, nor is it likely that any election staff deliberately rigged the process," Chen Pao-teh said.

He was responding to opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiu Yi's allegation that the number of ballots garnered by ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate Chen Chu at No. 160 polling station was "474" rather than "747" as tallied in the final count.
"The accusation was ill-motivated and completely unfounded," Chen Pao-teh said, adding that the figure reported to the KEC and the Central Election Commission was exactly "474."

As to the opposition's claim that a family with five eligible voters received seven voting notices, including two for the borough chief elections to be held later this month, Chen Pao-teh said it was purely a case of negligence and didn't have any effect on the mayoral election result.

"A voting notice could hardly be used to rig an election. A voter can never receive a ballot at a polling station simply with a voting notice. Voters must produce their ID cards to get blank ballots. So long as you have your ID card, you can receive a ballot, even if you don't have a voting notice," Chen Pao-teh explained.

In Saturday's hotly contested mayoral election, Chen Chu narrowly defeated the KMT candidate, Huang Chun-ying, by a mere 1,114 votes. Huang has filed a lawsuit demanding that the courts invalidate the outcome on the basis that legal infractions occurred.
The Kaohsiung District Court has impounded all the ballot boxes for a possible vote recount.

Chen Pao-teh said that all the ballot boxes have been sealed up and subject to strict round-the-clock monitoring. "They won't be unsealed until after the court decides on whether to hold a vote recount," he added.
