DOC.HEADLINE: DEFEATED KMT CANDIDATE LAMBASTES DPP 'IMMORALITY'

TEXT.P: Defeated Kuomintang (KMT) candidate for Kaohsiung mayor Huang Chun-ying lambasted the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday for "setting up" a vote-buying scheme to sabotage his campaign, vowing he will persist to the end in his lawsuit against the perpetrators.
Huang lost by a paper-thin margin of 0.14 percent of the valid votes to his DPP rival, former Labor Affairs Minister Chen Chu, in Saturday's municipal election.
Huang said the rival camp "designed a delicate hoax" to allege that his campaign workers tried to bribe participants attending the election eve rally.

Chen Chu campaign held a late night press conference to spread the rumor Friday, followed by President Chen Shui-bian's voting day allegation that under such suspicions, even if Huang won the vote, his election would be invalid, Huang said.
"The president was evidently trying to influence voter behavior, a move that was extremely immoral," Huang claimed.
As his campaign has sued the DPP manipulators over the vote-buying allegation, he urged the judicial authorities to speed up investigation and find the fact quickly.
"Only truth will clear my name and return justice to Kaohsiung's one million voters, " he said, adding that Taiwan deserves a "clean" election environment.
Partly because of this incident, he has filed another election lawsuit to request a recount of the vote aimed at invalidating Chen's narrow win.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUIT SMOKING HOTLINE CENTER TO WORK WITH JUNIOR, SENIOR HIGH SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The quit smoking hotline service center established by the Bureau of Health Promotion will cooperate with junior and senior high schools to help students kick the habit in light of the increasing number of teenage smokers, an official said Tuesday.

Lin Lien-chang, deputy director of the service center, pointed out that Taiwan schools have traditionally punished students for smoking by giving them demerits, a method which he said is ineffective in getting students to quit the habit.

Under the program promoted by the service center, schools will transfer students who smoke to the center for five quit smoking counseling sessions via telephone, with each session lasting 30 minutes to 50 minutes, Lin said.
Statistics from the bureau indicate that although the number of smokers in Taiwan declined from 4.89 million in 2002 to 4 million in June this year, the number of teenage smokers has been increasing.
A survey conducted by the bureau earlier this year shows that 17.13 percent of Taiwan teenagers aged 16-18 are smokers, compared with a figure of 15 percent in past surveys.
By gender, 22.67 percent of boys and 10.68 percent of girls in the age group are smokers, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINDOW OF OPPORTUNITY FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS HAS OPENED: MAC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 11 (CNA) (By H.C. Ku and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A "window of opportunity" for cross-strait talks has opened between now and July 2007, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said here Monday.

MAC Vice Chairman Tung Cheng-yuan made the remarks during a seminar held at Columbia University in New York, where a delegation of Taiwan journalists exchanged views with scholars from the Weatherhead East Asian Institute of the prestigious university on U.S.-China-Taiwan relations.

Tung noted that China slowed down its pace in terms of engaging in talks with Taiwan prior to the Dec. 9 municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung, but now that the elections are over, which saw the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) retain its hold on the southern port city of Kaohsiung, he believes that a "window of opportunity" has opened for such talks between now and July 2007.

Noting that legislative elections will be held in Taiwan at the end of next year and the presidential election will be held in March 2008, Tung said that if there is no substantial progress in cross-strait talks before July 2007, then China could again slow down its pace on cross-strait engagement because of considerations of election-related factors.

Columbia University professor Lu Xiaobo said that China has enhanced its understanding of Taiwan. After the Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal elections, many in China have adopted a more pessimistic view regarding Ma Ying-jeou, Taipei mayor and chairman of the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

China is not sure whether Ma, the most likely bet to be the candidate of the KMT in the 2008 presidential election, will win the race, Lu said, adding that China has lowered its expectations for the "pan-blue alliance" led by the KMT.

Lu also said that China has not completely ruled out the possibility of the pro-independence DPP retaining power in the 2008 presidential election despite the fact that a series of recent alleged corruption scandals involving family members of President Chen Shui-bian and his senior aides have dented the DPP's popularity.
However, China has no idea who will succeed President Chen within the DPP camp, nor is it sure of the future cross-strait policy of the DPP, Lu said.
For this reason, Lu said he believes that China will not take any rash actions prior to 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange plunged Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 153.56 points to close at 7,458.56.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,604.75 and hit a low of 7,441.01 during trading. A total of 5.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$126.41 billion (US$3.89 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4.32 percent, followed by banking and financial shares at 2.56 percent, paper and pulp issues at 2.34 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 2.21 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.88 percent, textile stocks at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.91 percent, and cement stocks at 0.79 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,035 to 236, with 127 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AIR ACCIDENT RATE HIGHER THAN WORLD AVERAGE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's airline industry recorded 28 accidents involving fixed-wing aircraft between 1996 and 2005, with a total of 467 people killed in seven of these accidents, according to tallies released Tuesday by the Cabinet's Aviation Safety Council (ASC).

The number translates into an accident rate of 2.1 per million departures, which is lower than the accident rate of 2.17 per million departures recorded for the 1995-2004 period and 2.82 per million departures recorded for the 1994-2003 period, ASC officials said.

However, the world's total air accident rate for the 1996-2005 period was 0.89 per million departures, which means that there is much room for improvement for Taiwan's flight safety, the officials said.
Of the 28 air accidents, 13, or 46.4 percent, occurred during landing, they said.
While the aircraft swerved off the runway in seven cases, six accidents occurred during rainy days and another five happened during typhoons, they said.

The officials said that in addition to poor weather conditions, the air crew's failure to follow standard operational procedures or their lack of understanding of the aircraft system were responsible for most of the accidents.

According to the ASC, 88 percent of the air accidents recorded by Taiwan's airline industry over the past 10 years were due to human error, 42 percent were related to environmental factors, and 19 percent were related to problems with the aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY HELICOPTER MAKES FORCED LANDING IN CHANGHUA

TEXT.P: An MD-500 submarine-hunting helicopter belonging to the ROC Navy made a forced landing in a paddy field in central Changhua County Tuesday, with no casualties reported, military officials said.

The pilots are suspected of taking the emergency measure because the aircraft was running out of fuel while in the middle of a training flight from Tsoying naval base in Kaohsiung County to the Chingchuankang air base in Taichung County, the officials said.
They said the military is investigating the real cause behind the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ASKS KMT HEAD TO APOLOGIZE IF VOTE-BUYING ALLEGATIONS TRUE

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) demanded Tuesday that main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou apologize if President Chen Shui-bian's vote-buying allegations against the KMT candidate in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral race were true.

DPP Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Huang-liang and Public Relations Department Director Mong I-chao issued the call at a news conference at DPP headquarters after the KMT ran an advertisement in newspapers charging Chen of seeking to influence the Saturday mayoral election by making such remarks earlier that same day.

Tsai and Mong asked Ma to resume political responsibility and offer a public apology to Kaohsiung residents should the vote-buying allegations filed by the DPP camp against Huang Chun-ying, the KMT's defeated hopeful, be proven true.
Now that relevant evidence has been given to prosecutors, the KMT should stop provoking social confrontation and wait for the final judgment of the judiciary, Tsai said.

Tsai also claimed the Huang camp's lawsuits against Chen Chu, his DPP rival and now Kaohsiung mayoral-elect, was only part of its efforts to smear the DPP in a bid to cover its vote-buying for Huang by passing the buck to Chen Chu.
Huang said earlier the same day that he will hold on to the last minute until his name has been cleared by court. He lashed out at the DPP for orchestrating the scheme to make him lose the election.
Huang challenged Chen Chu Monday to hold a new election if her vote-buying accusation against himself is proved to be a plot staged by Chen Chu's camp.

Huang's campaign has lodged a suit against Chen Chu after her campaign made public a videotape on the eve of Saturday's elections showing that a man suspected to be Huang's campaign was giving money to rally attendants while soliciting votes for Huang aboard a bus.
Huang lost the race to Chen Chu by a slim margin of 0.14 percent, or just 1,114 votes.

Meanwhile, KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as mayor of Taipei, vowed to examine the party's worse-than-expected results from the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung in Wednesday's weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee.
Ma said that he will also review his own responsibility as KMT chief and adjust future party policies.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER URGES PUBLIC NOT TO SMUGGLE DRUGS INTO COUNTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin urged the public Tuesday not to violate the law by smuggling in drugs or narcotics.
Shih made the remarks during a news conference held at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport to promote a "no-drug home" campaign.
He noted that many people bring home drugs without their knowledge or are lured into smuggling them.

Shish offered some tips to avoid violating the law, saying that the public should refrain from complying with requests to carry luggage for others, that they will not let others carry their luggage or touch others' luggage. If they encounter any troubles, they should immediately seek the assistance of Taiwan's representative offices overseas.
An anti-drug short film was aired and customs' sniffer dogs were also on hand to display their expertise.

According to tallies of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the number of Taiwanese who are incarcerated in Southeast Asian countries is around 140, with nearly 90 percent of them imprisoned on drug-related charges.

In a breakdown of that figure, 120 Taiwanese are serving terms in Thailand, with 110 of them serving terms related to drugs. Twenty-three Taiwanese are serving terms in the Philippines, with 90 percent related to drugs. Nine Taiwanese are serving terms in Burma for drugs, and two others are serving terms in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN APOLOGIZES TO HONDURAN VP OVER DELAYED MEETING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian apologized to Honduran Vice President Ernesto Santos Ordonez Tuesday for postponing a planned meeting between the two a day earlier.
Chen explained to Santos that he caught a cold over the weekend and that he felt very uncomfortable Monday due to the effects of the medication.
As a result, Vice President Annette Lu was assigned to receive Santos on that day instead, Chen said.
Cancelling a tour to Kaohsiung County scheduled for Tuesday morning so as to rearrange a meeting with Santos, Chen said he was very happy that they finally met each other.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO IMPROVEMENT IN CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD REPORT

TEXT.P: China's human rights record not only saw little improvement in the past year, it even worsened, contrary to its excellent performance in pushing for economic development, according to a human rights report released Tuesday by the Taipei-based Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD).

In the TFD 2006 China Human Rights Report, six scholars released results of their observations on China's human rights performance in the fields of society, politics, judicature, economic environment as well as education and culture, in the one-year period between July 1, 2005 and June 30.

TFD Vice President Tung Li-wen stated that in 2006 Beijing authorities and some enterprises in China were seen as notorious for their pressure on workers' "right-defending" movement, saying based on news reports from overseas media outlets over the past year, there were more than 20 incidents in China where police arrested or assaulted laborers protesting to defend their working welfare and level of wages.
China needs to allow workers to organize their own independent unions that can work to safeguard the working rights of their members, Tung suggested.

In politics, Chen Chu-ju, an assistant researcher of the Institute of International Relations at National Chengchi University, said she found that with increasing social conflicts triggered by increasing economic development, the communist authorities have enacted stricter measures to press down on the human rights of the people.

While taking severe steps to crack down on human rights defenders and advocates, Beijing further strengthened its control over freedom of press and speech, as well as the Internet, Chen noted, adding that although the regime has been declaring an intention to develop democratic politics in China, in fact it has been acting to reduce the political rights of the people.

In the field of judicature, Academia Sinica Assistant Researcher Liao Fu-te said China performed badly in work to safeguard freedom and human dignity, establish a fair judicial system and properly enforce the law. Citing Amnesty International statistics, he said that in 2005 a total of 2,148 people were sentenced to death around the world, with 1,770 of them in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT REPS SIGN MOU TO ENHANCE PRODUCTIVITY, COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Chief executives of productivity centers across the Taiwan Strait signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Monday in Taipei on building a productivity-managing platform to promote mutual cooperation and enhance business competitiveness in the Greater China Area.

The MOU was inked by representatives of Taiwan, China and Hong Kong productivity institutions, including Shi Dinghuan, director-general of the China Association of Productivity promotion centers (CAPPC) and Hsu Sheng-hsiung, chairman of the China Productivity Center in Taiwan, as well as Weiman Chu, branch director of the Hong Kong Productivity Council, according to Hsu.

A forum dubbed the " 2006 Universal Productivity-Managing Business in Asia" was held Tuesday in Taipei as well, with a wide variety of topics discussed, such as how to raise the levels of productivity and operation management through multilateral collaboration, as well as how to create an economic alliance comparable with the European Union and North American Free Trade Area, Hsu said.

During the signing ceremony, the cross-strait managers have promised to take turns hosting the forum thereafter in order to help establish a platform for promoting productivity-managing exchanges within the Greater China Area, Hsu noted, adding that Macau is expected to join the coalition next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD PASSES 173 SUBSIDY PROJECTS FOR OUTLYING ISLANDS

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has passed 173 subsidy projects aimed at boosting the development of outlying islands for next year, with the subsidy fund totalling NT$750 million, CEPD officials said Tuesday.

While the subsidy projects for Penghu County are mainly targeted at tourism development in the Penghu archipelago, those for Kinmen County are mainly focused on the promotion of industries unique to the region, the officials said.

Most of the subsidy projects for Lienchiang are related to transportation development, and most for Taitung County are related to ecological conservation and sustainable development of Green Island and Orchid Island, they said.
For Pingtung County, most subsidy projects focus on the improvement of the infrastructure and environmental education on the outlying island of Hsiao Liuchiu, they said.

The officials noted that the government has provided financing for businesses interested in investing in development projects on outlying islands and that two businesses have officially submitted their applications for the financing.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA DEMANDS SUNKEN INDONESIAN FREIGHTER BE REMOVED BY NEXT APRIL

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) gave an ultimatum to the owner of an Indonesian freighter Tuesday to remove a sunken ship off Taipei County in northern Taiwan by the end of next April.
Hsu Jen-tseh, a section chief of the EPA's Department of Water Quality Protection, was referring to "Dewi Bunyu" of Indonesia, which overturned off Taipei Harbor July 15.
The sunken ship, carrying 1,000 tons of highly volatile chemical ethyl acetate, or commonly known as "Banana Oil," and 33 tons of petroleum products, has triggered worries that it could explode.

Hsu said the latest inspection report showed that only 87 tons of ethyl acetate and four tons of fuel oil were left on the Indonesian vessel, now lying 50 meters under the sea and two nautical miles off Linshanpi.
"The vessel will no longer threaten the ecology and environment of surrounding water areas," Hsu said.

He said that the chemical is soluble in water and easily breaks down, adding that the chemical originally stored in 10 tanks has almost dissolved in the water. Investigation has shown that the ecology and fisheries in the surrounding areas have not suffered losses.
But to ensure navigational safety, Hsu said that the EPA has asked the owner to remove the vessel and residual oil.

The EPA also demanded that the owner pay for the mishap, including more than NT$3 million (US$92,000) incurred in administrative fees and NT$300,000 in pollution fines, by the end of this month before he is allowed to leave the country.
Meanwhile, the issue of a South Korean freighter, San-Ho Brother, is more thorny.
The freighter was carrying more than 3,100 tons of highly toxic benzene when it overturned off Hsinchu.
The air force mobilized F-16 fighters and the Army also used combat helicopters to attack the ship so as to trigger an explosion.
Hsu noted that as the owner of the ship has yet to offer any feasible plan to remove the benzene, the EPA has since Nov. 4 served tickets and the fines have so far accumulated to NT$58.5 million.
The South Korean owner will start exploration under the sea to prepare for the final removal work, according to Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY HALL FACILITIES NAMED AFTER HISTORIC FIGURES

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou hosted a ceremony Tuesday in renaming a briefing room, a meeting room and the lobby of the Taipei City Hall building after influential figures in Taiwan's history.
Ma said he expected the new names will breathe historic and cultural life into the modern building.
At the ceremony, the briefing room on the 12th floor was re-named as "Liu Ming-chuan Hall, " the meeting room on the 11th floor was named "Wu San-lien Hall" and the lobby "Shen Pau-chen Hall."

Ma described Liu Ming-chuan (1836-1896) as the father of Taiwan's modernization, saying Liu was the person who defeated French military troops in northern Taiwan, stopping the invasion of foreign forces.
According to Ma, Liu was also the first Taiwan governor during the Ching Dynasty, who constructed the island's first railway using the building-operation-transfer model, called BOT.
Wu San-lien (1899-1988) was appointed by the Republic of China government to serve as Taipei mayor in 1949. One year later, he won the city's first popular mayoral election.
Wu, founder of the Independence Evening Post and Tainan Spinning Co., was also regarded as an influential figure in Taiwan's democratic movement and publishing development, Ma said.

As to Shen Pau-chen (1982-1987), Ma commended the heavyweight in the Ching Dynasty imperial regime for relocating Taiwan's political center from Tainan in the south to Taipei in the north, and building the city's now-defunct wall.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAITUNG ELEMENTARY SCHOOL USES ICE TO FORCE PLUM BLOSSOMS

TEXT.P: An elementary school in eastern Taitung County is using ice to try to force plum trees on campus to blossom in the hope that the flowers will be out before the school holds an annual concert, a school spokesman said Tuesday.
Lijia Elementary School will stage a concert Dec. 17 featuring old trees, plum blossoms and music, the spokesman said.
However, due to unseasonably warm weather this winter so far, the plum trees have yet to blossom, the spokesman pointed out.
Renowned violinists and other performers have been invited to perform at the concert, the spokesman noted.

Worry about a lack of blossoms is deepening with the approach of the concert. Three days ago, the school began to place large blocks of ice under the trees and to spray iced water on the trees every day in an attempt to force the flowers, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHIEF DEMANDS DPP APOLOGY OVER VOTE-BUYING CHARGES

TEXT.P: Main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou demanded a public apology Tuesday from the ruling party over vote-buying allegations and said he strongly suspects the allegations were part of a scheme against the KMT hopeful prior to the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung municipal elections.

Ma made the comments while answering questions from reporters on the issue after the KMT ran an advertisement in local newspapers accusing the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of indulging in foul play to win the elections.

The DPP must make a public apology for the allegations it made against Huang Chun-ying, the KMT Kaohsiung mayoral candidate, because fairness and abiding by the law are key elements of a democratic society, Ma said.

Ma also blasted President Chen Shui-bian for airing unconfirmed vote-buying accusations to attack Huang early on polling day, which came after a questionable videotape made public on the election eve by Chen Chu, the DPP candidate in the race, showing one of Huang's campaign workers allegedly bribing voters aboard a bus.
Such attempts to abort rival election bids, Ma said, are not only just unlawful but also extremely immoral.

Huang lost the Kaohsiung mayoral election to Chen Chu by a slim margin of 0.14 percent, or 1,114 votes, in sharp contrast to the results of most pre-election public opinion surveys that showed Huang enjoyed a lead over Chen Chu, in particular in the initial stages of the campaign.

According to Ma, the DPP's vote-buying charges against Huang are far from the truth because Huang's camp would not have tried to buy votes in a bus that it did not lease. In addition, he pointed out, the street intersection where the bus was parked at the time was not a district where the KMT enjoys widespread support.
Meanwhile, KMT Secretary-General Chan Chun-po said that he will take full responsibility for the KMT's loss in the Kaohsiung mayoral election and added that he has offered Ma his resignation.

Commenting on the advertisement that the KMT ran in local newspapers questioning the DPP's win in the Kaohsiung mayoral race, KMT spokesman Huang Yu-chen said that his party hopes to bring the truth to light and leave the issue to be judged by the public.
The KMT is by no means a bad loser, but the Kaohsiung people must realize that no one can be allowed to win an election by nefarious means, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU RANKS TOP IN GLOBAL WAFER PRODUCTION: SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 12 (CNA) (by Charles Kang and Zep Hu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's northern city of Hsinchu has been ranked the first around the world in terms of wafer production, according to a survey released Tuesday by U.S.-based Strategic Marketing Associates, a marketing research company focusing on the semiconductor industry.

After comparing wafer production capacity among cities worldwide, the survey indicated that Hsinchu currently has the greatest capacity, while Singapore trailed as the second largest base for wafer production.
In terms of nation-wide capacity, the first is Japan, while the United States, Taiwan, South Korea, and China ranked second to fifth, respectively.
As for capacity expansion between 2007-2010 within a single city, Taichung, Taiwan is the city with the largest expansion scale, while Hwaseong, South Korea comes second and Singapore third.
Furthermore, in terms of future nationwide expansion scale in the period of 2007-2010, Taiwan places first, trailed by Japan, South Korea, China, the U.S and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP'S NO. 2 MAN WANTS QUID PRO QUO FOR STAYING IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: The vice chairman of the opposition People First Party (PFP) indicated Tuesday that he will lead the party temporarily after Chairman James Soong's departure only if the PFP's legislative caucus agrees to support legislation requiring political parties to return ill-gotten party assets.

Chang Chao-hsiung attended a meeting of the PFP legislative caucus and expressed his intention to quit his post as vice chairman, but PFP lawmakers urged him to take over the helm in the absence of Soong, who announced his decision Dec. 9 to bow out of politics following a humiliating defeat in the Taipei mayoral election.

Chang told the PFP legislators that he would stay in office temporarily only if the PFP lawmakers agree to support the Cabinet and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's version of proposed legislation requiring political parties, especially the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT), to return ill-gotten party assets to the national coffers.
The quid pro quo drew mixed reactions from the 22 PFP legislators, half of whom accepted his offer, while the other half were opposed to it.

While acknowledging that the PFP caucus needs to form a consensus on the issue, Legislator Cheng Chin-ling, convener of the PFP legislative caucus, said she believes the rift between the DPP and its "pan-blue alliance" partner, the KMT, is unlikely to deepen, because the proposed legislation in question would uphold social justice.
Legislator Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the PFP, said the tough condition shows that Chang is really not very interested in remaining in his post.
He added that the PFP caucus does not have an answer to the question now because it needs time to consider such a vital issue.

In reaction, the KMT legislative caucus deplored Chang's quid pro quo, claiming that the Cabinet and DPP's version of the draft legislation on ill-gotten party assets is "unfair and unjustified" because it is targeted specifically at the KMT.
The KMT has made clear previously that it will propose its own version of a political party law to deal with the party asset issue.
Legislator Tsai Chin-lung, a whip of the KMT legislative caucus, expressed confidence that most PFP legislators will not work with the DPP against the KMT.
He added that KMT legislators expect continued close cooperation with their PFP counterparts in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR-ELECT DENIES CHARGES OF FABRICATING EVIDENCE

TEXT.P: Vote-buying allegations made by Kaohsiung mayor-elect Chen Chu against his opposition Kuomintang (KMT) rival were not fabricated by the Chen camp and the KMT should immediately stop smearing Chen by making such claims, a spokesman for Chen's election campaign said Tuesday.

According to Hsiao Yu-cheng, Chen Chu's campaign workers filmed what they claimed was vote-buying by campaign workers for Huang Chun-ying, the KMT's candidate in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral race, aboard a bus Dec. 8 after receiving a tipoff the previous day.

The Chen Chu camp released the videotape on the eve of the election and President Chen Shui-bian made vote-buying allegations against Huang early on polling day -- developments that the KMT claimed led to his defeat.

In response to the KMT's charges that the videotape was a plot orchestrated by the Chen Chu camp to ruin Huang's election bid, Hsiao called it KMT mud-slinging and argued that it is aimed at blurring the focus of the matter.

Hsiao expressed his belief that the matter will soon be clarified as relevant evidence has been referred to prosecutors. Secret witnesses and several people filmed on the bus have also displayed willingness to testify before prosecutors, he added.
He urged the KMT not to comment further on the incident, as the prosecution is investigating the matter.
Huang, who lost the Kaohsiung mayoral election to Chen Chu by a slender margin of 0.14 percent, has filed a lawsuit against her to clear his name and has demanded a recount of the votes.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER URGES EARLY ADJUSTMENT TO FACE MAJOR ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) should adjust and improve for the legislative elections of late 2007 and the presidential election of early 2008.
Wang also said that "the important thing is to think about winning the 2008 presidential election" and that "all other things are insignificant."

Wang made the remarks amid reports that Lien Chan, honorary chairman of the KMT, urged KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou at a meeting that day to cooperate with Wang. Lien wants Ma to invite Wang -- a seasoned and savvy politician from Kaohsiung, a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- to serve as his first deputy chairman.
Asked about reports of teaming up with Ma for the 2008 presidential election, Wang declined to comment.

Reports also said that some "native" legislators have strongly urged a party conference to discuss the party's "native" direction, which is considered to be the party's Achilles heel and one of the main reasons it lost the Kaohsiung mayoral election by a razor-thin margin. The DPP, although it lost in the Taipei mayoral election, garnered more votes than in the previous election.

With the DPP pulling free of the quagmire it was in for months in the wake of a spate of alleged corruption scandals implicating the family members of President Chen Shui-bian and his senior aides and registering a better-than-expected performance, Wang said a party review should not target only Kaohsiung.

Wang said that all 23 cities and counties in the country, including seven cities and counties now served by DPP heads, are important and that the KMT "should think seriously about how to win back the trust of the people."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, losing NT$0.001 to close at NT$32.489.
A total of US$633 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.490 and fluctuated between NT$32.410 and NT$32.550.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 147 points to close at 7,467, with 51,804 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January decreased 143 points to finish at 7,469, with 2,631 contracts traded, while March futures decreased 135 points to end at 7,485, with 62 contract transactions. June futures moved down 138 points to close at 7,472, with seven contract transactions, while September futures dropped 119 points to finish at 7,310, with 41 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 7,614 for December, 7,612 for January, 7,620 for March, 7,610 for June and 7,429 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were lower.

December TE futures decreased 7.1 points to close at 314, with 5,661 contracts traded, while January TE futures dropped 7.05 points to finish at 313.25, with 432 contract transactions. March TE futures decreased four points to end at 316, with one contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for June and September.

December TF futures lost 29.2 points to close at 1,012.6, with 4,223 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures decreased 29.2 points to close at 1,013, with 332 contracts traded. September TF futures decreased 15.4 points to end at 993, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March and June.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCILORS FAIL TO SCREEN 2007 BUDGET BILLS

TEXT.P: Screening of the Kaohsiung city government's budget bills for 2007 will be postponed until after the inauguration of the newly elected city councilors, caucus whips of the ruling and opposition parties in the city council said Tuesday.

The budget screening was stopped in early November by disputes on the City Bureau of Transportation's public bus procurement project and issues concerning the mass rapid rail system construction project.

At that time, City Council Speaker Tsai Chien-hsing ruled that the budget screening should be postponed until after the Dec. 9 mayoral and city councilor elections. However, Tsai and his deputy, Tsai Sung-hsiung, both lost their election bids and said they did not want to be involved with the screening any more.

The caucus whips of the Democratic Progressive Party, the Kuomintang and the Taiwan Solidarity Union therefore decided to postpone the screening again, leaving the screening to be carried out by the new councilors who will be sworn in Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS BIG IN SCIENCE OLYMPIAD

TEXT.P: The Taiwan team captured five gold medals and one silver at the 2006 International Junior Science Olympiad held in Brazil, officials from the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Monday.
Among the five gold medalists, Hsu Nai-luen from Jiansing Junior High School in southern Tainan city gave the most remarkable performance -- he took home two other awards in addition to a gold medal.
The other gold medalists include Yu Chih-yeh, Tsai Wei-che, and Chien Cheng-chi from Jianguo High School in Taipei, as well as Lai Yen-lin from Chiayi Senior High School in southern Chiayi city.
The silver medalist is Wu Yi-chan, a student at Feng-Xi Junior High School in southern Kaohsiung county.
The officials said that last year in the same contest, the Taiwan participants snatched the same number of medals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP VOWS TO CONTINUE OPPOSING ARMS PROCUREMENT BILL

TEXT.P: The opposition People First Party (PFP) vowed Tuesday that it will continue to oppose any plans by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government to buy arms from the United States at what the party described as "exotic prices."

Legislator Lee Hung-chun, spokesman for the PFP, reiterated his party's determination after PFP legislators and their allies in the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) joined forces at a meeting of the legislature's Procedure Committee to block a bill requesting a NT$6.3 billion supplementary budget for a submarine feasibility assessment, P-3C anti-submarine aircraft in the first year, and the upgrading of Patriot II missiles.

The KMT again collaborated with the PFP against the arms procurement legislation despite its previous assurance that the supplementary budget would be included in the legislative agenda of the current legislative session.
It was the 66th time in five years that the arms procurement budget legislation submitted by the DPP government had been blocked in the Legislative Yuan.

Lee noted that Randy Schriver, former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, had said that the PFP's dwindling influence after the Dec. 9 mayoral and city council elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung would allow its ally, the KMT, to have a free hand in supporting the arms procurement plans.

"The PFP's position on arms procurement is not something that Mr. Schriver or the United States can manipulate," he said, vowing that the PFP will continue to oppose any plans to buy arms from the United States at unreasonable prices.
The DPP government has planned to purchase eight diesel-electric submarines, a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and six Patriot PAC III anti-missile batteries from the United States.

An initial budget bill requesting NT$610.8 billion (US$16 billion) was slashed to NT$480 billion last year to placate the opposition lawmakers. It was further reduced to NT$340 billion to purchase only the submarines and the sub-hunting aircraft, but opposition lawmakers have repeatedly refused to include the draft bill on the legislative agenda.

A separate bill requesting a NT$6.3 billion supplementary budget would earmark NT$200 million for a submarine feasibility assessment, NT$1.7 billion for the P-3Cs in the first year, NT$3.7 billion for he upgrading of the Patriot II missiles, and NT$700 million for building an airstrip on Taiping Island in the Spratly archipelago located in the southern part of South China Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PASSES LAW BANNING CORPORAL PUNISHMENT IN SCHOOLS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Education Basic Law Tuesday, banning any form of corporal punishment in schools and making Taiwan the 109th country in the world to protect students with formal legislation.
The Humanistic Education Foundation -- the prime mover behind the legislation -- welcomed the good news for students after lawmakers passed the amendment following a third reading.
According to a spokesman for the foundation, the amended law will benefit 5.3 million students in different levels of schools throughout Taiwan.

He said that all students are entitled to the right not to be subjected to physical punishment, be they in public or private kindergartens, elementary schools, high schools, colleges or any other educational institutions.

The spokesman pointed out that the U.N. Secretary-General's Study on Violence Against Children, presented Oct. 11 to the third Committee of the General Assembly by independent expert Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, urges more than 130 countries that have signed the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child to pass legislation on zero physical punishment of children by 2009.
He noted that Taiwan became the 109th country in the world to adopt such a law after Mongolia passed similar legislation Dec. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS AGREE TO LIMIT RETIRED GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES' PRIVILEGES

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of different political parties agreed Tuesday to limit the amount of pensions retired government employees can deposit in banks at a preferential interest rate of 18 percent.

According to a consensus reached among the lawmakers, the maximum deposit should be 1.45 times the retirees' monthly pension multiplied by the number of years of government service, rather than 1.2 times as suggested by the government. Previously, there had been no such limit imposed.
The consensus will be enacted Dec. 15 and put into practice Feb. 16 next year.
Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu of the opposition Kuomintang, which had resisted cutting this privilege for retired government employees, said afterward that her party agreed to the deal "reluctantly".
Under this consensus, a Feb. 26 decree issued by the Ministry of Civil Service to limit the privilege will be invalidated and those retired government employees damaged by it will be compensated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 13, or the 23rd day of the 110h month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PASSES LAW BANNING CORPORAL PUNISHMENT IN SCHOOLS(repeat)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Education Basic Law Tuesday, banning any form of corporal punishment in schools and making Taiwan the 109th country in the world to protect students with formal legislation.
The Humanistic Education Foundation -- the prime mover behind the legislation -- welcomed the good news for students after lawmakers passed the amendment following a third reading.
According to a spokesman for the foundation, the amended law will benefit 5.3 million students in different levels of schools throughout Taiwan.

He said that all students are entitled to the right not to be subjected to physical punishment, be they in public or private kindergartens, elementary schools, high schools, colleges or any other educational institutions.

The spokesman pointed out that the U.N. Secretary-General's Study on Violence Against Children, presented Oct. 11 to the third Committee of the General Assembly by independent expert Paulo Sergio Pinheiro, urges more than 130 countries that have signed the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child to pass legislation on zero physical punishment of children by 2009.
He noted that Taiwan became the 109th country in the world to adopt such a law after Mongolia passed similar legislation Dec. 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS AGREE TO LIMIT RETIRED GOVERNMENT EMPLOYEES' PRIVILEGES(repeat)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of different political parties agreed Tuesday to limit the amount of pensions retired government employees can deposit in banks at a preferential interest rate of 18 percent.

According to a consensus reached among the lawmakers, the maximum deposit should be 1.45 times the retirees' monthly pension multiplied by the number of years of government service, rather than 1.2 times as suggested by the government. Previously, there had been no such limit imposed.
The consensus will be enacted Dec. 15 and put into practice Feb. 16 next year.
Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu of the opposition Kuomintang, which had resisted cutting this privilege for retired government employees, said afterward that her party agreed to the deal "reluctantly".
Under this consensus, a Feb. 26 decree issued by the Ministry of Civil Service to limit the privilege will be invalidated and those retired government employees damaged by it will be compensated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S EMPLOYMENT OUTLOOK REMAINS WEAK FOR Q1 2007: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Taiwan employers remain cautious in their hiring intentions for the first quarter of 2007, with the country reporting the worse employment outlook for the second consecutive quarter among major economies in the Asia-Pacific region, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday.

The survey was conducted by Manpower Inc., a leading international employment service provider, on more than 49,000 human resources directors and senior hiring managers from 27 countries and territories worldwide, 1,372 of whom are from Taiwan.
In addition to Taiwan, the seven other Asia-Pacific economies surveyed were Australia, China, Hong Kong, India, Japan, New Zealand and Singapore.

The survey shows that Taiwan's net employment outlook for the first quarter of 2007 stands at 15 percent, up 1 percentage point from the current quarter but down 7 percentage points over the same period in 2006.

While 24 percent of the Taiwan respondents said they plan to increase their staff numbers in the next quarter, 9 percent expect to cut staff and 55 percent said they have no plans to hire new workers.

Owing to the reviving housing market and the government's efforts to expand public development projects, respondents from the construction and mining industry demonstrated the strongest intention to hire new workers, with the sector's net employment outlook soaring 18 percentage points from the current quarter to 23 percent for the next quarter.
The net employment outlook for the financial, insurance and real estate sector stands at 14 percent for the first quarter of 2007, down 4 percentage points quarter-on-quarter.
Meanwhile, the net employment outlook for the manufacturing sector stands at 10 percent, up 1 percentage point quarter-on-quarter, according to the survey.

The net employment outlook for the service sector stands at 18 percent, up 3 percentage points quarter-on-quarter, while the net employment outlook for the wholesale and retail sector stands at 10 percent, down 13 percentage points quarter-on-quarter, the survey shows.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE PERSON DIAGNOSED WITH CANCER EVERY 8.4 MINUTES IN TAIWAN: DOH

TEXT.P: One person was diagnosed with cancer every 8.4 minutes on average in Taiwan in 2003, compared with 8.5 minutes in 2001 and 9 minutes in 2000, according to a report released Wednesday by the Department of Health (DOH).
The figures were calculated based on the number of cancer cases at 212 hospitals around the island with at least 50 beds in 2003.

There were 250.77 cancer patients out of every 100,000 people in Taiwan in 2003, with liver cancer and breast cancer being the most common types of cancer among men and women, respectively, the report showed.

It was found that the 10 most common types of cancer among men were liver cancer, lung cancer, colon cancer, oral cancer, stomach cancer, prostate cancer, bladder cancer, esophagus cancer, pharyngeal cancer and skin cancer, in that order.

Among women, the 10 most common kinds of cancer were breast cancer, colon cancer, liver cancer, lung cancer, cervical cancer, stomach cancer, thyroid cancer, ovarian cancer, uterine cancer, and skin cancer, in that order.
Chao Kun-yu, deputy director-general of the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion, said a total of 62,542 new cancer cases were reported in 2003, up 3,543 cases compared with 2002.
While there were 288.98 male cancer patients out of every 100,000 men, there were 212.02 female cancer patients for every 100,000 women, Chao said.
With the promotion of smear tests by public health offices around the country, the occurrence rate of cervical cancer in women has dropped by roughly 37 percent over the past five years, Chao said.
However, the occurrence rates of oral cancer and esophagus cancer in men have increased by 20 percent, mainly as a result of smoking, alcohol consumption and betel nut chewing, Chao added.

Since cancer tops Taiwan's list of 10 major causes of death, Chao called for the public to form the habit of undergoing regular cancer screening tests, pointing out that "an ounce of prevention is better than a pound of treatment."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO WORK TO ENHANCE TAIWAN'S PROFILE ABROAD

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang said Wednesday that he will work to enhance Taiwan's profile given the nation's difficult diplomatic plight due to China's relentless obstruction.
The premier made the remarks at a Cabinet meeting prior to his departure for Gambia later the same day to attend the inauguration of Gambian President Yahya Jammeh slated for Friday.
The premier said that he will head a delegation on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian to attend Jammeh's inauguration.
"I will exchange views with President Jammeh on boosting bilateral friendly and cooperative relations. I will also invite him to visit Taiwan on behalf of President Chen," Su said.

The premier said that he will take the opportunity of his visit to meet with the leaders of Taiwan's diplomatic allies and promote substantial relations with countries with which Taiwan does not maintain diplomatic relations.

The premier stressed that Taiwan has to actively work to raise its international profile, adding that he is not discouraged even though his two previous planned overseas visits were canceled at the last minute due to Beijing's obstruction.
Su canceled his planned visit to Chad to attend President Idriss Deby's inauguration Aug. 8 after learning that Chad was ready to switch diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

His plan to visit Haiti in mid-May was also scuttled because China had pressured Haiti through the United Nations and other international channels not to invite Su to attend Haitian President-elect Rene Garcia Preval's inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 40% OF OFFICE WORKERS 'ENSLAVED' BY CREDIT CARD DEBT: POLL

TEXT.P: Approximately 40 percent of office workers in Taiwan are so-called "credit card slaves, " with each of these workers shouldering an average of NT$462,000 (US$14,237) in credit card debt, according to the results of a survey released Wednesday by an online employment service provider.
The survey found that 57.31 percent of the respondents mostly make purchases with cash, 28.06 percent with both cash and credit cards, and 14.33 percent mostly with credit cards.
According to the survey, the period of time needed for an indebted worker to pay off their credit card debt is 36 months on average.
The survey was conducted by 1111 Job Bank on 1,340 office workers via online questionnaires between Nov. 27 and Dec. 11. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.7 percentage points.
As to what office workers use their money for, the top three answers were living expenses, payments to parents, and savings, according to the survey.

While men spend most of their earnings on buying household products and travel and leisure activities, the three items that women spend most on are cosmetic and skin care products, household products, and travel and leisure activities, the survey shows.
Approximately 60 percent of the respondents admitted that they have bought items on impulse, with 40 percent saying they were unhappy about their behavior when they came to their senses.

By gender, 63.33 percent of women and 47.1 percent of men have had such experience, and the most common reasons mentioned for making impulse purchases were to reward themselves while in a good mood, getting discounted prices during department store sales, and making preparations for some special purpose.
Meanwhile, nearly 20 percent of the respondents said they spend all of their earnings every month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL SERVANTS LEAST CORRUPT: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Civil servants are the least corrupt group among the 21 public employee categories in the country, according to a report released Wednesday by the Taiwan chapter of Transparency International (TI).

Medical professionals at public-run hospitals are the second least corrupt group, followed by environmental workers, firefighters and taxation inspectors and investigators, in that order, said Chen Chun-ming, an executive of the TI Taiwan Chapter and manager of the government integrity evaluation project for 2006.

The survey conducted in July found that officials in charge of gravel production and business are the most corrupt group among public employees, followed by legislators, and officials in charge of procurement and public engineering, according to Chen.

The integrity ranking of senior officials and division heads in the central government has slid noticeably this year, indicating that the image of central government officials has been adversely affected by a string of corruption scandal allegations against high-ranking officials since the beginning of the year, Chen noted.

The TI Taiwan conducted the survey on randomly selected adults around the island for the report in July via telephone. A total of 1,604 valid samples were collected in the survey, which was followed by three seminars held in August and September, with 20 civilians and civil servants taking part.
Transparency International is a non-governmental group based in Berlin with branches in more than 90 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO LAUNCH CONSTITUTIONAL FIGHT ON PRESIDENT'S IMMUNITY

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will file a petition with the Council of Grand Justices Thursday for an interpretation on Article 52 of the Constitution regarding the president's immunity from prosecution, a caucus leader said Wednesday.

The caucus will also request that the trial on the alleged misuse of the president's "state affairs fund" be suspended until the constitutional dispute is clarified, according to Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP caucus.

Claiming that it is in violation of the president's immunity for a prosecutor to question President Chen Shui-bian during an investigation into the case, Ker said the DPP's move is aimed at protecting the constitutional system and ensuring the normal operation of the government.

If the president is to agree to being questioned, investigated and even searched just because someone has made an "arbitrary accusation" against him, the country will have problems functioning, according to Ker.

The prosecution indicted first lady Wu Shu-jen on charges of forgery and corruption Nov. 3 after determining she had used receipts provided by others to claim reimbursements totaling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) from the president's "state affairs fund" between July 2002 and March 2006.
Chen was named in the charges along with his wife but was not charged because of his constitutional immunity from prosecution as head of state.
Chen claims that none of the money went into his own pocket and vowed to resign if the first lady is found guilty at the first trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTUT PRESENTS BOOKS, COMPUTERS TO GAMBIA

TEXT.P: The National Taipei University of Technology (NTUT) presented around 30 cartons of books and five computers to the Gambia Wednesday to be distributed to children there.
Mawdo C. Juwara, Gambian ambassador to the Republic of China, received the donations presented by NTUT President Lee Tsu-tian.

The donation coincided with an official visit to Gambia by Premier Su Tseng-chang, who was scheduled to leave for the West African country later that day to attend the inauguration of re-elected President Yahya Jammeh slated for Dec. 15.
The idea for the donation came up this summer when Lee led a 29-member NTUT delegation comprised of faculty and students to Gambia for a three-week cultural exchange visit.

Lee said during that visit that he saw poverty has resulted in denial of access to cultural assets in most African countries, including Gambia, prompting him to launch a book and computer-raising drive when he returned to Taiwan.
Noting that "knowledge is power, " Lee said the poor will become rich through books while the rich will become wiser through reading.

NTUT and Gambia maintain an academic cooperation program that includes classes offered by NTUT to Gambian students and government officials in the fields of oil exploration and information technology.

With financial support from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , NTUT will be sponsoring the program starting next August, offering four-year university education scholarships to 25 Gambian citizens.

Lee said during his visit in Gambia that he met with Jammeh, who had told him that he hopes the Gambian people can establish a "Silicon Valley" by 2020, a goal that makes the nurturing of high-tech talent imperative.
According to Lee, Jammeh said he is grateful that the MOFA and NTUT are sponsoring information technology classes for Gambian students to help Gambia realize its dream.

In addition to attending the English IT class, the students will also be able to take other NTUT classes such as electronic engineering, electrical engineering and optoelectronics, as elective courses, Lee said.

NTUT has since 2004 helped Gambia nurture specialists in oil exploration and other areas of the petroleum industry by offering four-year university courses to 25 Gambian citizens, also under the auspices of the MOFA.
The Gambia, a former British colony, possesses huge deposits of crude oil in its offshore areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES POLITICIANS TO MOVE TOWARD DEMOCRATIC MATURITY

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang urged all political figures and parties Wednesday to reflect upon themselves and move toward democratic maturity.
Su said that if political figures and parties become arrogant after winning elections and create disturbances when losing them, then they will "not live up to the expectations of the voters."

The premier made the remarks at a Cabinet meeting in which he said that the smooth conclusion of the mayoral and city councilor elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung has underscored the maturity of Taiwan's democracy.
"There will be winners and losers in every election," the premier said, and all should accept the election outcome.

He noted that there will be bitter rivalry during each election campaign, which he termed a norm of democratic politics and also a chance for political parties to reflect upon themselves and to make headway.

Now that elections are over, he expressed the hope that all will put aside their rivalries and return to the urgent tasks of improving the nation's economy and law and order, as well as social justice.
He said that vote-rigging was rampant in Taiwan's elections "in early years," but added that nowadays, from presidential elections down to borough chief elections, they are held in a transparent way.

The premier's words came as Huang Chun-ying, the candidate of the main opposition Kuomintang in the Kaohsiung mayoral election who lost by a razor-thin margin of 1,114 votes to his rival Chen Chu of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, filed a lawsuit demanding that the result be invalidated on the basis that legal infractions occurred, including irregularities by election staff.
The Kaohsiung District Court has impounded all the ballot boxes pending a possible vote recount.
Huang also protested vehemently a DPP accusation that Huang's campaign workers paid participants for showing up at his final campaign rally on the eve of Saturday's election.
Huang and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou claimed that the accusation was a scheme orchestrated by the DPP to smear Huang in the last stretch of the campaign.

President Chen Shui-bian urged the prosecution authorities on polling day to investigate Huang's alleged vote-buying, triggering further accusations by the KMT that this was aimed at swaying the voters.
The Kaohsiung Prosecutor's Office has already begun investigations and a man who admitted paying NT$500 each to a coach-load of participants at a Huang rally has been taken into custody.
