DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DROP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange slid Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 8.26 points to close at 7,450.3.
The bourse opened at 7,480.04 and fluctuated between 7,494.49 and 7369.09 during trading. A total of 4.59 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$110.56 billion (US$3.4 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 4 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks at 2.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.5 percent, textile issues at 1 percent, and cement shares and plastics and chemicals stocks at 0.9 percent.
Banking and financial shares rose 0.7 percent, while machinery and electronics shares gained 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 883 o 323, with 186 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS SPREADING AMONG TAIWAN FEMALE DRUG ADDICTS: HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: While the number of female AIDS patients is rapidly growing around the world, the number in Taiwan has also been rising, in particular among female drug abusers, an official at National Cheng Kung University Hospital (NCKUH) in southern Tainan City said Wednesday.

Lin Shing-chun, an NCKUH doctor, ascribed the spread of AIDS among local female drug addicts to rampant needle-sharing, adding that the practice has since 2005 outpaced sexual activity as the No. 1 cause of infection.

Some 20 years ago, there was one woman in every 10 AIDS patients in Taiwan, with the ratio increasing to one in eight today, Lin reported, expressing concern that the actual number might be triple that reported to the official authorities.

As most Taiwan women infected with AIDS are usually diagnosed through pre-natal examinations at hospitals or clinics, it is very hard to trace the disease among those who have had abortions or who don't plan to give birth, she said.
Most of Taiwan's female AIDS patients are aged between 16 and 45, with half of them married housewives. Only a small number of them are sex workers, relavent statistic showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PINGTUNG AGRICULTURAL BIOTECHNOLOGY PARK TO BE LAUNCHED DEC. 21

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Wednesday that after two years of preparation, the Pingtung Agricultural Biotechnology Park will be formally inaugurated Dec. 21.
COA Chairman Su Jia-chyuan and manufacturers stationed in the park said the COA set up the park to promote agricultural biotechnology and upgrade Taiwan's international competitiveness.
COA officials said 42 manufacturers have already set up in the park with a combined investment of NT$1.86 billion (US$56.36 million).
They estimated that 20 manufacturers will start operation by mid-2007, creating 1,000 jobs by the end of next year.
Although the investment in the park is not very high, COA officials said all the manufacturers have their own specialities and will help bring modern technology to agriculture.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS KARATE GOLD IN DOHA ASIAN GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Doha, Dec. 12 (CNA) (By Li Chien-chung and Han Nai-kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Hsieh Cheng-kang won the gold medal in the men's 55 kg class kumite event Tuesday at the 2006 Doha Asian Games, defeating Malaysian Puvaneswaran Ramasamy 3:2 in the final match.
This is the first karate gold medal won by a Taiwan athlete in the Asian Games and also the Taiwan team's ninth gold medal in the 15th Asian Games.

Earlier the same day, Hsieh defeated Syria's V.C. Gunarathna 3:0, beat Kazakhstan's T. Al Malki 5: 1 in the quarter-final and overpowered Uzebekistan's I. Sharapov in the semi-final with a score of 5:1.
In the last few seconds of the final event, Ramasamy scored two points against Hsieh with a head shot but was still unable to snatch the gold medal from him.
Hsieh will be entitled to a National Glory Order and a NT$3 million scholarship award from the Ministry of Education.

In other karate events, Taiwan's Huang Hsiang-chen and Shen Chia-hau won bronze medals in the men's kumite in the 60 kg category and in the men's individual kata competition, while Chen Yen-hui captured bronze in the women's kumite in the 48 kg class.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HEAD MIGHT STAY IN POLITICS: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong might change his mind and not retire from politics until 2008, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Wednesday.
According to Wang, Soong voiced willingness during a meeting they had Tuesday to "rethink" his decision to retire from politics.

If Soong really changes his mind, he will stay on at least until after the 2008 presidential election, Wang pointed out, adding that Soong is a seasoned and capable political figure and that he tried to persuade Soong to continue contributing to the country, as ongoing political development is critical to Taiwan's future.

Wang said that he also urged Soong to stay on as head of the PFP and to push for its consolidation with the main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) . However, he added that it remains unclear whether Soong will remain in that position.

Soong announced his retirement from politics last Saturday evening after conceding defeat in the Taipei mayoral election. He garnered only 53,000 votes, or 4.1 percent of the total, ranking a distant third among the six candidates.

PFP spokesman Lee Hung-chun said later Wednesday that the PFP has not any set position about establishing a formal alliance with the KMT -- consensus on which was reached between Soong and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou prior to the Dec. 9 Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal elections.
The PFP has neither worked out any specific model nor has it drafted any plan aimed at consolidating with the KMT, Lee said.

He also denied a local newspaper report that the PFP has agreed in principle to merge with the KMT based on the New Party model -- meaning that the two parties would first engage in talent exchanges and establish a cooperation platform before moving toward an eventual consolidation, probably by the end of next year after the legislative elections.
The KMT, the PFP and the New Party already comprise a loose "pan-blue alliance."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES LOWER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Wednesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved down 17 points to close at 7,450, with 49,738 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January decreased 11 points to finish at 7,458, with 2,939 contracts traded, while March futures dropped 25 points to end at 7,460, with 37 contract transactions. June futures moved down 78 points to close at 7,388, with one contract transaction, while September futures slid 36 points to finish at 7,256, with 36 contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 7,467 for December, 7,469 for January, 7,484 for March, 7,466 for June and 7,292 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.

December TE futures slid 0.1 point to close at 313.9, with 4,881 contracts traded, while January TE futures rose 0.15 point to finish at 313.4, with 606 contract transactions. September TE futures moved down 3.15 points to close at 303 with one contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for March and June.

December TF futures gained nine points to close at 1,021.6, with 2,925 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased eight points to close at 1,021, with 291 contracts traded. March TF futures moved up 10.2 points to end at 1020, with two contracts traded, while September TF futures decreased 1.6 points to end at 1001, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for June.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL WORKING TO RETAIN INDIGENOUS MOTHER TONGUES VIA TESTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) is preparing national level language tests exclusively for indigenous youths, aimed at helping retain indigenous mother tongues, CIP Chairman Walis Pelin said Wednesday.

The first of the tests is scheduled to be held in March 2007 and applications to take the test can be made this month until Dec. 29, said Walis Pelin. The examinees will sit two examinations -- one on hearing and one on spoken language -- during the test, he added.
Those who pass the test will be entitled to extra points for their entrance examinations to high schools and colleges, he said.
He added that the policy is designed to push indigenous youths to pay greater attention to their mother tongues, most of which are dying due to lack of usage.

Touting the tests at the Legislative Yuan, Walis Pelin said potential indigenous examinees can familiarize themselves with the languages -- including 12 languages from 12 indigenous tribes and 43 sub-dialects -- by studying textbooks published by the Ministry of Education (MOE).
Only textbooks at levels 1-3 will be used when the test questions are prepared, although the MOE textbooks on indigenous languages have nine levels, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTAVIRUS TOP CAUSE OF ACUTE GASTROENTERITIS IN CHILDREN: REPORT

TEXT.P: Rotavirus infection is the most common cause of acute gastroenteritis among children in Taiwan, with up to 10,000 children hospitalized every year as a result of the infection, according to a report released Wednesday by National Taiwan University Hospital.

The report said that 160,000 to 540,000 people seek medical treatment for rotavirus infection every year in Taiwan, 3,000 to 10,000 of whom require hospitalization because of gastroenteritis triggered by the virus.
The medical costs resulting from rotavirus-related hospitalization amount to NT$300 million to NT$1 billion per year, the report said.

Huang Li-min, a pediatrician at the hospital, pointed out that most children will be infected with rotavirus at least once before they reach five years old, with 20 percent displaying severe symptoms.
Huang said rotavirus is the most prevalent between November and March each year and that common symptoms of the infection include diarrhea, vomiting, fever and abdominal pain.
In some cases, the infection can lead to severe complications such as dehydration, shock and even death, he said.
He suggested that parents should have their children vaccinated against rotavirus to prevent infection.

Also Wednesday, GlaxoSmithKline Inc., a leading pharmaceutical company, announced that it will donate oral rotavirus vaccine to the city and county of Taipei for vaccination of infants up to six months from low-income families.
The vaccines will be provided free of charge to the targeted children starting Dec. 18 at the Jenai, Chunghsing, Yangming, Chunghsiao, Hoping, Women and Children section of Taipei City Hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Trail of a serial killer
A serial killer murdering women at a rate unprecedented in modern British criminal history was still evading police last night.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
La Repubblica: Tunisian cohabitant exonerated from Erba family massacre.
Tunisian cohabitant of one of the three women who were killed together with a three-year-old boy in a family massacre Monday in Erba, northern province of Como, has been exonerated from the horrible quatriple murder. His absence from the scene was proved.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HOPES FRANCE WILL SUPPORT TAIWAN'S WHO BID

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Wednesday that France will support Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Organization (WHO) as an observer, saying that Taiwan has worked toward the WHO goal for 10 years.

The president made the remarks at the Presidential Office when he received Christian Bataille, chairman of a pro-Taiwan group in France's National Assembly, who is heading a visiting delegation of French lawmakers.

The president said Taiwan hopes to play an active role in international organizations, especially as medical care should be without borders and the voice of the 23 million people of Taiwan should be heard.
"Taiwan has worked toward joining the WHO as an observer for the past decade," Chen said, expressing the hope that Taiwan's cause will get support from the French government and National Assembly.
The president likened the friendship between Taiwan and France as "red wine that will get even more aromatic as time goes by."

He also noted that bilateral trade between the two countries totaled US$4 billion last year, with France enjoying a trade surplus of US$1.06 billion. Taiwan is France's sixth-largest importer in Asia and its fifth-largest export destination.
"There is still ample room for the development of bilateral relations," he added.
He also said that Lafayette frigates and Mirage-2000 fighters purchased from France now form the backbone of Taiwan's naval and air forces.
On the European Union's intention to lift an arms embargo on China in place since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre, Chen also expressed concern.
He said that since the massacre, China's human rights record has yet to improve, with many dissidents, religious figures and journalists still persecuted.
China is notorious for its lack of respect for freedom of speech, the press and religion, Chen said.

He said the lifting of the arms embargo would be tantamount to letting a unfree and undemocratic China deal with a free and democratic Taiwan, which would also endanger the peace and stability of the Asia and Pacific region.

He said China's defense budget has been increasing in double digits over the past 17 years, while it also passed its Anti-Secession Law in March 2005 giving itself the "legal basis" to launch a military attack against Taiwan should it tilt toward independence.

China has also deployed more than 800 missiles in its coastal areas opposite Taiwan, a number that is increasing at a speed of more than 100 missiles per year, leaving Taiwan people under the constant threat from the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPUTY MAYOR DENIES HE WILL HEAD MA'S PRESIDENTIAL CAMPAIGN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou's deputy denied Wednesday that he will form a campaign office to help Ma's bid to win the 2008 presidential election.
Ma, who doubles as chairman of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT), is widely expected to be the KMT's presidential candidate in 2008 although he has not announced his candidacy yet.

Media reports Wednesday said that Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung will form a campaign office for Ma outside the KMT after Dec. 25, when they will hand over their offices to the newly elected mayor, Hau Lung-bin, and his deputy.
Queried by reporters, King denied the reports, saying, "How is that possible? This is going too far."
King said he plans to take a vacation and enjoy life with his family after retiring as Taipei's deputy mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH LEVEL OF ENVIRONMENTAL HORMONES FOUND NEAR TAMSUI RIVER ESTUARY

TEXT.P: Residuals of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and insecticides have been found near the estuary of the Tamsui river, posing a possible threat to human health, officials of National Taiwan Ocean University (NTOU) said Wednesday.

A research team, led by Gong Gwo-ching, a professor at NTOU's Department of Oceanography, has surveyed coastal areas near the Tamsui river estuary for several months and has found the levels of environmental hormones, especially PCBs and insecticides, have been higher than normal in the mud on the perimeters of the discharge pipelines of the Bali sewage treatment plant.
Gong suggested that although Taiwan has prohibited the use of PCBs for years, old residuals have not decomposed and still exist in the environment.

PCB residuals travel with rain or ground water into the river and are then deposited at the estuary and coast, Gong said, adding that they could enter the food chain and damage human health if they are digested by fish or shrimp.

"The worry is not unfounded," he noted, "since we found disrupted gene expressions by environmental hormones in the livers in four species of fish, including mullet -- a common fish in local markets."
He said that the levels of PCB are still far below the standard that would pose an immediate threat to health. "However, consumers are recommended not to eat fish skin, guts and heads," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA SETS UP BRANCH IN TAITUNG TO STUDY MARINE LIFE

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has decided to set up a branch of the National Marine Biological Germplasm Bank in eastern Taitung County's Chihpen, a project that has won the support of the local government and council.

The announcement came after Taitung council officials convened a meeting Monday with representatives from the Fisheries Research Institute's Eastern Marine Biology Research Center and officials from the Taitung county government.
Chiang Wei-chuan, a research assistant at the center, said the new branch will be constructed in a coastal area of Chihpen covering more than 64,000 square meters.
The project is expected to be completed in 2009, Chiang said, adding that it now urgently requires an access road.
County Magistrate Kuang Li-chen also proposed a plan at the meeting to establish a deep ocean water science park in the county.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAVYWEIGHTS THANK VOTERS FOR SUPPORT

TEXT.P: A group of ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweights thanked voters Wednesday for their support in the Dec. 9 municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung cities.

DPP Chairman Yu Shyi-kun, Premier Su Tseng-chang, former Premier Frank Hsieh and Kaohsiung Mayor-elect Chen Chu expressed their appreciation for voters' backing at a news conference prior to the weekly meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee -- the first since last Saturday's elections.

According to Yu, voter support for the DPP is a reflection of the public's desire to safeguard the country and a clean government. The DPP will take concrete action to respond to voters' high expectations, he promised.

Chen defeated his opposition Kuomintang rival Huang Chun-ying in the close-run Kaohsiung mayoral race by a slim margin, while Hsieh, despite his defeat, performed better than expected and gained some 41 percent of the votes in the hard-fought Taipei mayoral election.

While Vice President Annette Lu was absent from the news conference, interaction between Hsieh and Su -- the DPP's most likely contenders at present to vie for the 2008 presidential election -- became the central focus of media.

As Hsieh seemed to have markedly cemented his power base due to his relatively good performance in the Taipei mayoral race, Su is also a DPP figure who enjoys widespread support at a time when the party's image has been tarnished by a series of corruption allegations related to the first family.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Americans Say U.S. Is Losing War; Public, Politicians Split on Iraq Panel's Ideas
Most Americans think the United States is losing the war in Iraq and support a bipartisan commission's key proposals to change course, according to a poll released yesterday. But the Iraq Study Group's report has become a political orphan in Washington with little backing from either party.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2006 AUSTRONESIAN FORUM OPENS IN PINGTUNG

TEXT.P: The 2006 Austronesian Forum, aimed at promoting cooperation and exchanges among Austronesian aborigines, is being held at the National Pingtung University of Education in southern Taiwan.
The forum, which opened Tuesday, was organized by the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples on its 10th anniversary as part of efforts to raise public awareness of Austronesian culture.

Ministers from 10 countries -- New Zealand, Canada, Japan, Fiji, Nauru, Palau, the Marshall Islands, the Solomon Islands, Kiribati, Belize -- and representatives from Nordic Sami Conference attended the fifth forum.
Following the forum, the foreign delegates were scheduled to visit indigenous tribes in the southern county.

Council Chairman Walis Pelin said in his opening remarks that Austronesia is considered by experts as the most widespread language family in the world, reaching Madagascar in the west, Easter Island in the east, New Zealand in the south and Taiwan in the north.

He claimed that the peoples in this vast region speak the same Austronesian language, have the same marine culture, and face the same difficulties and challenges brought by modern regimes of colonization.
As a result, all the Austronesian peoples can forge partnerships to work on these issues, he said.
He added that since 2002, the council has organized international conferences on various issues. At a conference held in 2003, representatives agreed to establish a forum for Austronesians.
Pelin noted that the council is also planning to set up a secretariat that will be used as an exchange platform for Austronesian peoples.

Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung said some European and American academics have said that Taiwan is the birthplace of the Austronesian people and it is therefore particularly meaningful to hold such discussions in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF SPONSORS SEMINAR TO HELP TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: The semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will sponsor a seminar Thursday aimed at helping China-based Taiwan businessmen avoid investment risks and step up globalization, an SEF spokesman said Wednesday.

SEF Chairman Chang Chun-hsiung will address the opening, while Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will give a keynote speech on trade and investment prospects across the Taiwan Strait to help protect Taiwan business interests in China and assist businessmen seeking listing for their companies on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, the spokesman said.

The SEF hopes to lure more Taiwan businessmen from overseas to invest at home in line with a "mega investment project" being promoted by the government to further invigorate Taiwan's economy, the spokesman said.
More than 230 experts and representatives from the business and industry community are expected to attend the seminar, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times:White House to Delay Shift on Iraq Until '07
The White House said Tuesday that President Bush would delay presenting any new strategy for Iraq until early next year, as officials suggested that Mr. Bush's advisers were locked in internal debates on several fronts about how to proceed.
Wall Street Journal:How Immigration Upended Dreams Of an Entrepreneur
Amid the debate over illegal immigration, one of the most contentious questions is whether unauthorized workers from Mexico and other Latin American countries displace U.S. workers, especially low-wage workers in agriculture, cleaning and construction. The Hairstons' saga shows that the issue is not just about low-paid workers, but also entrepreneurs who set out to make their own fortune.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS, MALAYSIANS OF KINMEN DESCENT ON ROOTS-SEEKING TOUR

TEXT.P: A total of 187 people of Kinmen origin residing in Singapore and Malaysia took an international charter flight Tuesday to the Taiwan-held outlying island to find their roots, Kinmen county officials said Wednesday.
The charter flight was the first of its kind between Kinmen and Singapore under a cooperation agreement between TransAsia Airways and the Kinmen county government, the officials said.

It was the return flight of a TransAsia plane that carried 189 passengers, including Fujian Provincial Governor Yen Chung-cheng and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Chu-feng, to Singapore Monday evening for a pleasure trip, the officials noted.

The county government invited overseas Taiwanese and their children in Singapore and Malaysia to take the return flight as part of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications' plan to double the number of tourists visiting Taiwan, the officials added.

The passengers will visit tourist attractions on Kinmen and Taiwan proper during their six-day stay, according to the officials, who added that 136 of the passengers have obtained permits to travel to China's Xiamen and Guanzhou via the "three mini-links."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S AVERAGE HOUSE PRICE 3.3 TIMES THAT OF KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: This year's average housing price in the capital city of Taipei is 3.3 times that of southern Kaohsiung city, according to the results of a survey released by Yungching Real Estate Group.
The study also showed the price gap has continued to widen since 2003.

The group's president, Liao Ben-sheng, explained that Taipei city offers more job opportunities, which serves as an incentive for the working population in other parts of Taiwan to flow into the city.

As a result, although Taipei and Kaohsiung are special municipalities under the Cabinet's direct jurisdiction, their residents have a different willingness and purchasing power to buy a house or an apartment, Liao said.

The study indicated that after the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003, the overall housing market began to boom, with an average housing price increase of 10 percent every year -- while Kaohsiung saw less than 5 percent of annual increase.

According to another survey the group had conducted with 104 Job Bank, an online job site for Taiwan, 66 percent of Taipei office workers wanted to remain in the city, compared to merely 33 percent of Kaohsiung office workers who had the same view.
Liao pointed out the increasing number of office workers will provide a boost in the housing market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA REBUTS REPORT ABOUT RAMPANT ABUSE OF VIETNAMESE WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) rebutted Wednesday as "unfactual and erroneous" a U.S. media report that claimed an average 2,500 cases involving abuse of Vietnamese laborers are reported annually in Taiwan.

Tsai Meng-liang, a CLA section chief in charge of vocational training affairs for migrant workers, said the CLA has cooperated with non-governmental organizations to offer temporary shelter for disgruntled foreign laborers.
"Most of those staying at temporary shelter centers were mainly involved in salary disputes with their employers, and only a few cases were related to abuse or maltreatment," Tsai said.

Over the past year, Tsai went on, the government has made many improvements in foreign labor administration and management with a view to better protecting their rights and interests. For instance, since November employers have been required to report the arrival of their foreign employees to local government authorities within three days.

Starting this year, Tsai said, local employers can no longer arbitrarily take the initiative to have a foreign worker repatriated before their working contract expires. In such a case, local labor administrators must explore the foreign laborer's views before determining whether repatriation should be carried out.
Moreover, Tsai said, local employers are now required to offer better meals and lodging conditions for their foreign employees in addition to modernizing relevant management rules.
The CLA has consistently offered subsidies for local governments to inspect foreign laborers' living and working conditions and to provide them with counseling services, Tsai said.

According to CLA tallies, more than 336,000 foreign nationals are now working in Taiwan legally, with Thailand and the Philippines tying as the top source of foreign labor, followed by Vietnam, Malaysia and Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER DEPARTS FOR GAMBIA VISIT

TEXT.P: Premier Su Tseng-chang headed for the Gambia Wednesday to attend the Dec. 15 inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.

Members of Su's entourage include Minister of Foreign Affairs James Huang, Department of Health Minister Hou Sheng-mau, Council of Agriculture Minister Su Jia-chyuan and Government Information Office Minister Cheng Wen-tsan.
It is Su's first overseas trip since he assumed the premiership in January. He kept a low profile to avoid any unexpected obstruction by China.
Su canceled a plan to attend Chadian President Idriss Deby's inauguration Aug. 8 after learning that Chad was ready to switch its diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
His plan to visit Haiti in mid-May was also scuttled because of China's obstruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENTIAL AIDE GETS 12-YEAR SENTENCE OVER CORRUPTION

TEXT.P: Former Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General Chen Che-nan received a 12-year sentence Wednesday for taking bribes from a businessman, but he was acquitted of an insider trading charge.

The Taipei District Court also ruled that Chen should return NT$6 million in bribes to Liang Po-hsun, head of a bankrupt construction company. Liang gave the money to Chen in 2002 in hopes that Chen would assist in persuading a judge not to convict him of fraud. Liang was later convicted of fraud, but Chen declined to return the money.

The court ruling said Chen set a bad example for public servants by abusing his position to get personal gains at the expense of a troubled businessman. The court also ruled that Chen be deprived of his civil rights for 10 years.
In response, Chen said while he respects the judiciary, he couldn't accept the court ruling and will definitely appeal his case to the high court.
Chen was also indicted of profiting from insider trading of Chekan stocks, but the court acquitted him of the charge on the grounds that there was no sufficient evidence to prove the accusation.
Chen was detained for several months before he was released on a NT$6 million bail in early November.
Investigations on Chen's alleged involvement in other insider trading cases are still on going, judicial authorities said.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR DEC. 14 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are important events scheduled to take place Thursday, Dec. 14:
09:50, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu will attend a seminar on changes in China's investment climate.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a news briefing.
15:00, President Chen Shui-bian will receive winners of an award honoring outstanding overseas Taiwanese entrepreneurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTISAN COMPETITION SHOULD NOT IMPEDE PROGRESS: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday differences in political stances should not impede national development nor blot out hard-won achievements in reform and advancement in various aspects.
Chen made the remarks while attending an annual award-presentation ceremony in honor of outstanding civil servants.

Praising the prize winners for their dedication to public service, Chen said they have become catalyst for changes and standard bearer for reform and innovation. "I salute your efforts to upgrade public service quality and operational efficiency," he added.

Noting that the fruit of reform and development belongs to all fellow citizens, Chen said partisan competition should never smudge progress in infrastructure construction and nor should political differences hinder sustainable economic growth.
Chen said it is hoped that the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan can pass a number of critical bills and budget proposals to facilitate reform and development.

During his six-year presidency, Chen said he has pulled out all the stops to complete a number of tough infrastructure construction projects, including the Hsuehshan Tunnel -- the centerpiece of the Peiyi Expressway that shortens the travel time from Taipei to Yilan to just half an hour from original two hours -- and the Yuanshantzu flood-prevention sluice along the Keelung River that has spared residents in the greater Taipei area from flood damages during typhoon season.

Chen also took the opportunity to tout the achievements of the Central Taiwan Science Park which he said has quickly grown into one of the world's most promising high-tech heartland, with its 2006 turnover expected to nearly double the year-earlier level.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAXPAYERS COULD GET HIGHER DEDUCTION FOR EDUCATIONAL EXPENSES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has completed a preliminary review of a proposed amendment to the Income Tax Law that would allow taxpayers to claim a higher deduction for educational expenses.

According to the bill passed by the Finance Committee Wednesday, taxpayers would be able to claim a deduction of up to NT$25,000 (US$769) for educational expenses for each child who is receiving higher education, compared with up to NT$25,000 per household at present.
In addition, taxpayers would also be able to claim a deduction of up to NT$25,000 for each child who is within three years before entering elementary school.

The amount of the allowed deduction would be adjusted accordingly whenever there is an average hike of more than 3 percent in the tuition fees of local colleges and universities, according to the committee.

Chang Sheng-ho, director-general of the Ministry of Finance's Taxation Agency, estimated that approximately 2 million people will benefit from the new measure after the amendment is passed by the legislature, including 1.2 million college, university and post-graduate students and more than 800,000 children within three years before entering elementary school.
However, the government is expected to see its revenues decrease by NT$4 billion per year as a result, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VOTE-BUYING SCANDAL SUSPECT ADMITS TO HANDING OUT HIS OWN MONEY

TEXT.P: A key suspect in the vote-buying scandal surrounding last weekend's Kaohsiung municipal elections said Thursday that he did give money to participants in opposition Kuomintang (KMT) candidate Huang Chun-ying's campaign rally but was not told by any one to do so.

Ku Hsin-ming, who surrendered to prosecution investigators accompanied by his lawyer, told the media that although he handed out money to passengers on a bus, he is innocent because he was not doing it for anyone and because the money was his own.
He explained that he gave passengers NT$500 each "just to call on more people to attend the campaign rally of a certain candidate."
Police earlier detained Tsai Neng-hsiang, nicknamed "Hei Sung, " or "Black Pine, " after viewing videotape of him handing out NT$500 to passengers on a bus last Friday.

Investigators have since interviewed 22 of the people who were aboard the buses on which the alleged vote-buying occurred. All of them told the investigators that they had received NT$500 as they were urged to "vote for a certain mayoral candidate and a certain city council candidate."
The investigators have found that both Ku and Tsai had been passing out money to passengers on board two buses, which were rented by Ku.

Tsai received tens of thousands of NT dollars from Ku, and they talked to each other by cell phone immediately before they began to distribute the money, according to the initial results of the investigation.

Ku disappeared for several days after the incident became a major news story as Huang, who lost the election by a razor-thin margin, blamed his defeat in part on the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) underhanded tactic of accusing the KMT of vote-buying on the eve of the election.

As the prosecution continued its probe into the matter, Huang called on the investigators to subject all those involved to a polygraph, or lie-detector test, in order to uncover the facts as quickly as possible.

Huang noted the license plate numbers of the suspected buses did not match with any of those rented to carry people to his campaign rally, which he said proves that his campaign had nothing to do with the alleged vote-buying.
He has filed a lawsuit with the court to declare his DPP rival's election victory invalid and to request a vote recount.

DOC.HEADLINE: 65% DISAPPOINTED WITH GOVERNMENT'S ANIT-VOTE-BUYING CAMPAIGN: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of respondents to a recent opinion poll expressed disappointment with the government-led campaign against election bribery, pollsters said Thursday.

The telephone poll of 1,604 randomly chosen adult residents, conducted by the Taiwan chapter of Transparency International (TI) in July, found that 65 percent of those interviewed felt the government's anti-vote buying campaign was insufficiently effective.

Comparing the results with similar surveys conducted in the previous two years, Chen Chun-ming, a TI Taiwan researcher in charge of the survey, said the latest poll shows that more people have become disillusioned with the government's anti-vote-buying campaign.

Generally speaking, Chen said, the respondents were positive about the government's efforts to promote political integrity and accountability but were dissatisfied with the results of the efforts, including efforts to eliminate shady links between politics and organized crime and crack down on official corruption and election bribery.

More than 70 percent of the respondents expressed disappointment with the campaign against official corruption and involvement of criminal rings in politics, Chen said, adding that the figure is higher than those recorded in the previous polls.

Although the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) has adopted many new measures in investigating suspected vote-buying cases, Chen said the poll results show that those efforts have so far failed to boost local people's confidence in the campaign's effectiveness. "This is a phenomenon worthy of our attention," he stressed.
The latest poll also shows that over 60 percent are unsatisfied with the government's recent efforts to revamp unused public facilities.
Asked about their level of confidence in the process of improving the government's integrity, 39 percent expressed optimism regarding the issue, while 47 percent said they are pessimistic.

As to what constitutes the most serious violation of political integrity or ethics, election bribery was mentioned most often by the respondents, followed by lobbying public officials for illicit favors or personal gain.

Meanwhile, 60 percent of those polled said they think the requirement for public office holders to declare their family assets can be effective in promoting clean politics; more than 60 percent said they believe that demanding political appointees to place their assets into trust will contribute to political integrity; and 80 percent expressed support for the proposal to make it a crime for senior officials not to clearly account for significant increases in personal assets.

While 65 percent said they believe that the establishment of an independent anti-corruption agency will contribute to political integrity and clean politics, the percentage of those who think otherwise has risen steadily in the past three years, Chen said, adding this phenomenon deserves further study in order to figure out the root cause.

The Berlin-based organization Transparency International is dedicated to wiping out government corruption and enhancing political accountability. It has branches in more than 90 countries. The organization's Taiwan chapter has been commissioned by the Ministry of Justice to conduct an annual political integrity index survey over the past few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST BELIEVE CHINA'S ENGAGEMENTS WITH TAIWAN ILL-MOTIVATED: POLL

TEXT.P: A majority of the Taiwan people are suspicious of China's intentions regarding conducting exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, with more than 60 percent of respondents to a recent opinion poll believing that China's engagements with Taiwan are mostly ill-motivated, pollsters said Thursday.

The poll conducted by the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) also found that the number of Taiwan people inclined to support the pursuit of Taiwan independence is higher than the number of Taiwan people who want to maintain the present status quo.

A total of 1,073 valid samples were collected in the telephone survey conducted Nov. 26-27 on adults randomly chosen from around the country. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 2.99 percentage points.

In the poll, 60.1 percent of the respondents said they believe that China's military, diplomatic, economic, social and cultural actions toward Taiwan are mostly ill-motivated rather than based on good will.

Nearly 55 percent of those polled said they are worried about the overconcentration of Taiwan's outbound investments in China, compared to 29.6 percent who said they are not concerned about the matter.

While 21.7 percent said they are satisfied with the fact that annual two-way trade across the Taiwan Strait will soon surpass the US$80 billion mark, 30.6 percent said they are unhappy with this development.

Meanwhile, 68.9 percent said they support the government's policy of opening Taiwan's doors to Chinese tourists, but the respondents were divided over the government's current regulations governing Chinese people's visit to Taiwan. While 30.8 percent said the current rules are too strict, 30 percent said the restrictions are too loose, and 14 percent said the existing control measures are "just right."

Nearly 60 percent gave the thumbs-down to China's insistence on engaging only with Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" parties -- the Kuomintang, the People First Party and the New Party -- and refusing to have any dialogue with Taiwan's democratically-elected leaders and government.

On the sensitive issue regarding Taiwan's future, 33.5 percent said they look forward to seeing formal Taiwan independence; 22.7 percent said they want to see cross-strait unification; and 23.8 percent said maintaining the status quo is the best option for Taiwan.
If the present status quo couldn't be maintained, 41.9 percent said they would opt for independence, compared to 31.4 percent who said they would choose unification with China.

Analyzing the poll results, professor Chen Ming-tong of National Taiwan University said that young people in Taiwan have become increasingly hostile toward China and that they are becoming more vocal in expressing their views on Taiwan's future regarding the issue of independence versus unification.
"The poll results attest to Beijing's intensified campaign to woo Taiwan's youth. I'm convinced that Beijing authorities would be interested in the findings of this survey," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 14, or the 24th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Dog according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti-corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso-kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: COA ASSURES PUBLIC OF SAFETY OF TAIWAN-PRODUCED MUSHROOMS

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) assured the public Thursday of the safety of locally produced Agaricus blazei Murill mushrooms, after some products sold on the Taiwan market were discovered to contain a toxic chemical.

Addressing the issue during a committee meeting in the Legislative Yuan, COA Vice Chairman Lin Kuo-hua claimed that the products discovered to contain a toxic chemical were imported and that there is no such problem with locally produced Agaricus blazei Murill mushrooms.

Lin was responding to the results of tests on 35 mushroom products released Wednesday by the Consumers' Foundation, which indicated cadmium content in all eight Agaricus blazei Murill products sampled by the foundation.

With the exception of one in which the cadmium content was within the maximum acceptable level of 2 ppm, all the other seven Agaricus blazei Murill products contained an excessive amount of cadmium, according to the test results.
In one of these products, the cadmium content was found to be more than eight times the maximum acceptable level.
However, contrary to what the COA claims, data from the foundation shows that one of the sampled products was produced by an organic farm located near Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER, FORMER PREMIER PROMOTE NEW YEAR'S DAY HIKE EVENT

TEXT.P: The Hope Foundation, headed by world-renowned woman sprinter Chi Cheng, will hold a 2007 New Year's Day Hike to bring in the new year as well as an online charity auction to raise funds for several social welfare groups, Chi said at a news conference Wednesday.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and former Premier Frank Hsieh, both of whom are hiking enthusiasts, also attended the news conference held at Zhongshan Soccer Stadium in Taipei City, inviting the public to join the hiking event.

Hsieh, who is the "number one" volunteer of a "walking 10,000 steps per day campaign, " also displayed a Taiwan-shaped pottery flute that he donated for the online charity auction organized by the foundation.

Included among the 12 other hot items up for auction are loungewear products donated by top Taiwan model Lin Chi-ling, baseballs autographed by Taiwan-born Yankees pitcher Wang Chien-ming, as well as copies of the book "Baseball in Taiwan"....

The items will be up for auction at Yahoo's Web site through Dec. 22, with the proceeds to be donated to the Taiwan Heart Foundation and the Chinese Taipei Sports Association of the Deaf, according to Chi.
Also at the news conference, Wang Jin-pyng, an avid hiker, shared some of his hiking experiences and described some of the many health benefits of hiking.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LOOKING FORWARD TO BETTER RELATIONS WITH SAINT LUCIA

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday that it hopes to improve relations with Saint Lucia following the victory of former Saint Lucian Prime Minister John Compton's party in the eastern Caribbean country's general elections Dec. 11.

Simon Ko, director-general of the MOFA's Department of Central & South American Affairs, said that after pro-Taiwan Compton assumes the post of prime minister, he may work to improve relations with Taiwan, adding that "we're looking forward to such a development."

Taiwan established diplomatic relations with Saint Lucia in 1984 when Compton was prime minister, but when current Prime Minister Kenny Anthony assumed the post in 1997, he switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in late August of that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST HALF OF 2007 OPPORTUNE TIME FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: The first half of 2007 may be an opportune time to restart cross-strait talks on issues that are important to the interests of people in both Taiwan and China, Taiwan's top official in charge of China policy planning said Thursday.

Since cross-strait negotiation has been an issue that has often been manipulated by candidates during elections, the first half of next year, during which there will not be any elections, seems to be an ideal period for cross-strait talks, said Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

It is hoped that the two sides can restart negotiations in the following months on issues including the opening of Taiwan to Chinese tourists, the expansion of cross-strait charter flight services, the building of monetary supervisory systems across the strait, and joint efforts in crime-fighting, Wu said.

Stressing that charter flights can never be better than the opening of direct cross-strait air links, Wu called for the Beijing leadership to remove political barriers so that cross-strait negotiations on direct air links can be started before long.
Wu made the remarks after he attended a seminar sponsored by the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation on China's investment climate and Taiwan investors' strategies.

He said Taiwan companies and businesspeople have channeled some US$150 billion into China in various investment projects, making it imperative that their investments there are protected under an investment guarantee mechanism.

Taiwan keenly hopes that cross-strait negotiations will be resumed soon to also discuss other issues, including the exemption of double taxation, protection of intellectual property rights, cross-strait judicial support, and the repatriation of illegal immigrants, Wu said.
Meanwhile, Wu noted that the 2007 Chinese New Year cross-strait charter flights will be implemented from Feb. 5 for 28 days under the principles established June 14.

A total of 96 charter flights will be available to facilitate China-based Taiwan businesspeople returning home for the holiday. Six China-based carriers and six Taiwan-based carriers will offer flight services on routes connecting Taoyuan, Kaohsiung, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Xiamen, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP, KMT SPAT OVER CONSTITUTIONAL PROVISION ON PRESIDENTIAL IMMUNITY

TEXT.P: The ruling party's lawmakers claimed Thursday they were asking for grand justices' interpretation of Article 52 of the Constitution not for the sake of President Chen Shui-bian but for the sake of ensuring that the government can run under a good system, an argument that the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) said is simply off the point.

Article 52 gives the president immunity from criminal prosecution while in office, a privilege that the DPP's legislative caucus said must not be given up in order to ensure the smooth operation of the government.

"In the future, whoever is the president, if he or she abandons the constitutional immunity, unimaginable consequences will ensue and similar political strife will never end, " warned Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP caucus.
He stressed that his caucus' petition requesting suspension of a court trial of first lady Wu Shu-jen was aimed at protecting the judicial system, and not the president.

But the DPP caucus petition, filed on the eve of the court's scheduled trial concerning Wu's suspected involvement in the alleged misuse of the president's special "state affairs fund, " left the KMT caucus unconvinced.

The KMT caucus claimed that the court is going to try the president's wife, not him, on Friday and so the DPP caucus' petition was totally off base, and it could even be suspected of attempting to interfere with the judicial authorities.
Wu and several of the president's senior aides were indicted on charges of embezzlement, forgery and perjury in connection with the investigations into the "state affairs fund" scandal.

The prosecution found that Wu had used receipts offered by other people to claim reimbursement totalling NT$14.8 million (US$450,000) between July 2002 and March 2006 from the "state affairs fund" budgeted for the president's discretionary use.
Calling the PDP caucus "a busybody, " KMT Legislator Wu Yang-chih said the Presidential Office's legal hook is none of the business of the PDP legislative caucus.

Wu said the president himself has pledged to step down if his wife is found guilty of embezzlement or forgery in the first trial. "If he really has any respect for the law, why is he trying to stop the court from trying his wife?" Wu asked.

Moreover, Wu asked in what capacity the DPP caucus was filing the petition for constitutional interpretation, noting that the law stipulates that a lawmaker cannot request a constitutional interpretation unless it involves a dispute over the exercise of his/her legislator's duties.

Ker argued that his caucus was within its rights to file such a petition as the legislature, which is dominated by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and People First Party, was involved in legislating an unconstitutional law that authorizes prosecution of the president and the vice president for suspected violation of the election law.

Another KMT lawmaker, Kao Sze-po, retorted that the legislation on a special prosecutor's investigations into alleged corruption and dereliction of duty by senior officials including the president and vice president was passed under a consensus of the ruling and opposition parties.
"Now the DPP is slapping its own face by filing a petition to challenge the law's constitutionality," Kao claimed.

Yeh Yi-jin, secretary-general of the DPP caucus, pointed out that by filing such a petition, her caucus actually was telling the president that he had made mistakes by agreeing to being questioned by the prosecutor in 2004 over a local election dispute and in 2006 over his role in the "state affairs fund" case.

"We decided to request a grand justices' interpretation to preserve the dignity and the spirit of constitutional democracy" she said, adding that it does not have anything to do with the first lady's scheduled court trial.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR QUALITY CONTROL 'EXCELLENT' IN TAIPEI: U.N. REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Timothy Huang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei is one of the Asian cities with "excellent" capability to manage air quality, according to a report released recently by the United Nations.
The other six cities with "excellent" air quality management capability are Bangkok, Hong Kong, Seoul, Shanghai, Singapore and Tokyo, the report said.

The study, focusing on the air pollution of 22 Asian cities, was backed by the U.N. Environment Programme and was published ahead of the first governmental meeting on urban air quality opening Wednesday in Yogyakarta, Indonesia.

The study rated Beijing, Busan and New Delhi as having "good" air quality management capability and rated Colombo, Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Manila and Mumbai as having "moderate" management capability.
Meanwhile, Dhaka, Hanoi, Surabaya and Kathmandu have "limited" capability to manage air quality, the report said.

The report said that although most of these Asian cities have been able to reduce the emissions of key pollutants, pollution caused by fine particulate matter remains a problem owing to the rapid rise in the number of motor vehicles.

In particular, the concentrations of particulate matter up to 10 micrometers in size (PM10) are "serious" in Beijing, Dhaka, Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City, Jakarta, Kathmandu, Kolkata, New Delhi and Shanghai, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES HIGHER ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange opened high and closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 30.11 points to close at 7,480.41.
The bourse opened at 7,456.31 and fluctuated between 7,492.3 and 7,428.38 during trading. A total of 3.8 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.99 billion (US$2.95 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.2 percent, textile stocks at 0.8 percent, machinery and electronics shares at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemicals shares at 0.3 percent, and banking and financial shares at 0.2 percent.
The other two major stock categories lost ground, with cement stocks moving down 1.9 percent and foodstuff issues decreasing 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 844 to 328, with 205 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER CALLS FOR MORE MEDICAL RESOURCES FOR PRISONS

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Shih Mao-lin said Thursday that he hopes more medical resources will be devoted to prisons or penitentiaries to help combat drug crimes.

Shih made the remarks while attending a seminar on drug rehabilitation, during which he also said that cooperation between judicial and medical systems will mean a big step forward in combating the drug problem in Taiwan.
Shih cited statistics to show around 80 percent of larcenies and burglaries in Taiwan are drug-related, and drug users also account for more than 60 percent of AIDS patients.
For drug offenders, the question is not where to detain them, but how to do something to help adjust their character and even behavior, which he said would require more medical resources.

He noted that Taiwan has defined drug criminals as both criminals and patients since 1998, but has been unable to put the concept into practice because there has not been enough medical resources to back it up.

He said that the inmates are most in need of health education, citing 300 juvenile delinquents in a Taoyuan prison as an example, saying that a lot of them have learning difficulties or mental diseases, and if medical resources could help them back on track, then the risk they pose to society would be greatly reduced.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST LADY TO APPEAR IN COURT UNLESS DOCTORS SAY OTHERWISE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's wife, Wu Shu-jen, will appear in court in principle Friday for her trial on embezzlement and forgery charges, a Presidential Office spokesman said Thursday.

Noting that appearing in court when requested is the duty of every citizen, Lee Nan-yang said the first lady will show up at court Friday as scheduled unless her doctors prohibit her from doing so out of health considerations.
As of Thursday afternoon, Wu's doctors have not made any suggestions that Wu should not appear in court because of health reasons, Lee said.
Wu was indicted Nov. 3 on charges of embezzlement and forgery in a scandal involving the misuse of a special "state affairs fund" budgeted for the president's discretionary use.

Prosecutors decided to indict Wu after discovering that she had used invoices collected from family members and others to claim NT$14.8 million in reimbursements from the state affairs fund between July 2002 and March 2006.

Chen was named along with Wu as a "joint perpetrator" but was not charged because of his constitutional immunity while in office as the head of state. He has denied any wrongdoing, claiming that the use of invoices belonging to other people was to cover expenses incurred in "secret diplomatic programs."

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 4,000 VETERANS RECEIVING SUBSIDIES LIVE IN CHINA: DGBAS

TEXT.P: More than 4,000 veterans who receive government subsidies live in China on a long-term basis, the Directorate General of the Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Thursday.

Based on the Veterans Affairs Commission's (VAC's) tallies, DGBAS officials said, as of the end of September, the total number of veterans stood at 504,988, down 12,000 from the same time last year. Among these veterans, 309,663, or 61.3 percent, are over 65 years old.
The officials said that a total of 92,861 veterans live in nursing homes, with 4,314 of these living in China on a long-term basis, down 7.9 percent from the same period last year.

Meanwhile, 44,964 of the veterans have landed jobs, with 11,864 working at VAC-affiliated institutes. The VAC has also helped 33,090 veterans find work at other institutes or organizations, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT SAYS HE IS SERIOUS ABOUT MOVING TO KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday the idea of moving to the southern city of Kaohsiung was not raised on the spur of the moment but was instead a "very serious" one.

Chen made the remarks in the latest issue of his online newsletter. He was referring to a promise made by his wife, Wu Shu-jen, during the run-up to last week's Kaohsiung mayoral election that the first family would buy housing in the port city if Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Chu won the election.
Chen Chu was elected to the mayoral post Dec. 9 by capturing 49.41 percent of the vote, leading her main opponent, Huang Chun-ying of the Kuomintang, by only 1,114 votes.
Likening the passion of Kaohsiung people to the warm sunshine, President Chen said he and his wife have long been looking forward to moving there.
Also, Chen said he and his wife very much admire the pride displayed by Kaohsiung people for their hometown, which he said has made major progress in various ways in recent years.

"It would be a kind of happiness to be able to move to Kaohsiung and become neighbors with all of you. We are very thankful to the people of Kaohsiung for giving us the chance to fulfill our dream, " Chen said.
According to Chen, the support offered by Kaohsiung voters to Chen Chu proves that a person with excellent ability will definitely succeed.
The election outcome also demonstrates Kaohsiung residents' approval for former Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh of the DPP and his achievements in promoting the city's development, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOTULINUM TOXIN EFFECTIVE IN MIGRAINE TREATMENT: STUDY

TEXT.P: The results of a local study have indicated that botulinum toxin is effective in treating migraine headaches, in addition to removing wrinkles, researchers said Thursday.

The study, jointly conducted by six major medical centers in 2002 on 60 patients suffering from severe migraine, showed that patients saw a significant decrease in the frequency and intensity of their migraine after they were injected with 0.5 c.c. to 1 c.c. of botulinum toxin at the exact spots of pain.

Researchers noted that approximately 1.5 million people over 15 of age in Taiwan suffer from migraines, and that these patients usually display symptoms of nausea, vomiting and fear of light and noise, besides severe headache.

Chen Jou-hsien, a neurologist at Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, said migraine patients who have at least four relapses per week can consider receiving botulinum toxin therapy if they do not want to receive long-term preventive medication.
According to Chen, the effect of one botulinum toxin therapy can last up to three months, with each therapy costing NT$8,000 to NT$15,000.
