DOC.HEADLINE: SIX-YEAR-OLD TAIWAN BOY GETS WISH OF MEETING ASTRONAUT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 13 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A six-year-old leukemia patient from Taiwan has met and hugged a U.S. astronaut as he had wished, the Make-A-Wish Foundation said Wednesday.

Six-year-old Kao-yuan Chen wished he could watch the launch of a spaceship and hug an astronaut and had expressed this to the Make-A-Wish Foundation, which vows to grant the wishes of children around the world with life-threatening medical conditions, to enrich the human experience with hope, strength and joy.

Before Chen met and hugged U.S. astronaut Gordon Fullerton at a special event in Los Angeles Tuesday, under arrangements by the foundation the six-year-old also visited the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral in Florida several days ago.
At the space center, Chen was wearing an astronaut suit, an astronaut helmet and a look of great excitement, according to a video shown by the foundation at the event.
Fullerton also gave the boy a high-power telescope, which will allow him to gaze at the stars from his home in Taiwan.
Among some 10 children from around the world that the foundation helped realize their heartfelt wishes this year, Chen was the only child from Taiwan.

Since 1980, the Make-A-Wish Foundation has enriched the lives of children with life-threatening medical conditions through its wish-granting work. The Foundation's mission reflects the life-changing impact that a Make-A-Wish experience has on children, families, referral sources, donors, sponsors and entire communities.

The Make-A-Wish Foundation was founded in 1980 after a young boy named Chris Greicius realized his heartfelt wish to become a police officer. Since its humble beginnings, the organization has blossomed into a worldwide phenomenon, reaching more than 144,000 children around the world.

A network of more than 25,000 volunteers enable the Make-A-Wish Foundation to serve children with life-threatening medical conditions. Volunteers serve as wish granters, fundraisers, special events assistants and in numerous other capacities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MOSTLY HIGHER ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were mostly higher Thursday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for December moved up 28 points to close at 7,478, with 30,195 contracts changing hands.

TAIEX Index futures for January increased 12 points to finish at 7,470, with 2,453 contracts traded, while March futures decreased three points to end at 7,457, with three contract transactions. September futures gained 37 points to finish at 7,307, with four contracts traded.
No transactions were recorded for June.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 7,450 for December, 7,458 for January, 7,460 for March, 7,448 for June and 7,270 for September.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were higher.

December TE futures increased 1.3 points to close at 315.2, with 2,504 contracts traded, while January TE futures gained one point to finish at 314.4, with 339 contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

December TF futures increased 0.6 point to close at 1,022.2, with 1,368 contracts changing hands, while January TF futures increased 1.8 points to close at 1,022.8, with 258 contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for March, June and September.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.035 to close at NT$32.557.
A total of US$682 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.622 and hit a low of NT$32.530.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA WELCOMES JAPAN'S RECOGNITION OF TAIWAN-ISSUED INT'L DRIVING PERMIT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Thursday welcomed reports that Japan plans to recognize the international driver's licence issued by Taiwan.
The ministry said in a press release that it has promoted the matter for quite some time, and was gratified to receive a positive response from Japan.
The MOFA attributed the reason to the high calibre of Taiwanese tourists as well as their high spending capabilities.

The ministry's press release came after reports that Japan's National Police Agency decided Tuesday to submit for approval a revised traffic bill to the Japanese Diet next spring, which will allow Taiwanese tourists to drive in Japan if they possess a Taiwan-issued international driver's license.
The new measure will promote bilateral economic benefits, given the fact that Taiwanese and Japanese pay nearly 2.5 million visits to each other's country every year.
The MOFA also said this is another piece of good news after Japan waived its visa requirement for Taiwan tourists in September 2005, and that the move should enhance bilateral exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPULSORY MILITARY SERVICE TO BE CONDITIONALLY CUT TO 1 YEAR: MND

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Ko Chen-heng said Thursday that the Ministry of National Defense is still planning to curtail the compulsory military service period to one year by the end of 2008, but added that this will be based on the premise that the volunteer recruitment goal can be achieved smoothly.

Ko made the remarks while reporting to a Legislative Yuan committee on the situation surrounding recruiting volunteer military servicemen as well as the plan to adjust the term of compulsory military service.

He noted that President Chen Shui-bian and the MND have said previously that the compulsory military service period will be shortened to one year by the end of 2008, but he also said that judging from the present situation, there does not seem to be room for further shortening compulsory military service in 2007.
He also said that the ministry will make a final assessment by the end of 2007 on the exact timing of the adjustment.
The MND had planned to recruit 6,561 servicemen in 2005, but actually accepted 6,644. It had planned to recruit 13,500 this year and had so far accepted 8,164.

Ko was responding to Legislator Lin Yu-fang of the opposition Kuomintang, who asked about media reports that compulsory military service will be shortened to 14 months from the present 16 months next year and will be further cut to one year by 2008.
Lin said the MND should keep the public abreast of the situation so that future draftees can make their career plans accordingly.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: The Times: Killer leaves crucial clues All five victims of one of Britain's most prolific serial killers were suffocated or strangled and left naked but for their jewellery, senior detectives have told The Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL AIMED AT KMT'S ASSETS MIRED IN LEGISLATIVE COMMITTEES

TEXT.P: Two draft bills designed to force the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) to return its "ill-gotten" assets to the national coffers got nowhere in the Legislative Yuan Thursday after a joint meeting of three committees adjourned in chaos.

The two bills -- one submitted by the Executive Yuan and the other by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- were supposed to be discussed by the joint meeting of the Home and Nations Committee, the Judiciary Committee, the Finance Committee and the Organic Laws and Statutes Committee.

At the beginning of the sitting, Legislator Yeh Yi-jin, secretary of the DPP legislative caucus, appealed to her KMT colleagues to debate unemotionally the bills that were crafted to settle the assets problem, which is deeply rooted in the country's unique history.

However, her appeal fell on deaf ears of the KMT committee members, who claimed that the bills are part of what they described as "the DPP's political scheme to monopolize political power," citing its "shady governance, " and its attempts to seek permanent immunity from criminal charges for scandal-ridden President Chen Shui-bian.

The claims drew fierce rebuttals from DPP lawmakers and ended in bickering, with DPP lawmakers unfolding posters denouncing the KMT in the chamber and KMT lawmakers responding by motioning for an adjournment.

The motion triggered chaos on the floor, with DPP lawmakers occupying the podium in attempts to stop the chairman of the session, DPP Legislator Kao Chien-chih, from acting on the adjournment motion and KMT lawmakers trying to reclaim the podium to push the chairman to put their motion to a vote.
After realizing that the individuals involved were incapable of holding a debate, Kao put the sitting into recess.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUANG CAMP CALLS FOR NEW ELECTION FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYOR

TEXT.P: The camp of the main opposition Kuomintang's (KMT's) candidate in the Dec. 9 Kaohsiung mayoral race called Thursday for a new election if vote-buying allegations made by a rival camp are proven untrue.

Lee Liang-chien, spokesman for the campaign headquarters of Huang Chun-ying, issued the call at a news conference after a case in which a videotape showing alleged vote-buying aboard a bus by Huang's workers took new turns in recent days.

A man shot in the film giving money to passengers aboard the bus, which was waiting to leave for a campaign rally, told prosecutors that he gave away NT$500 in cash to each passenger to buy their votes for a "certain" candidate

The camp of Chen Chu, candidate of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and Kaohsiung mayor-elect, made public the videotape late on the eve of the election and accused Hung of vote-buying -- which the Huang camp claimed was slander that led to his loss in the election.
Huang lost the election by a margin of only 0.14 percent -- or just 1,114 votes -- to Chen.

Lee said that they strongly suspected that the videotape was set up by Chen's camp with the aim of ruining Huang's election bid and that he demanded that Chen promise to hold a new election if the content of the film is proven untrue.

Lawyers from the Huang camp have filed a suit to clear his name and have demanded that the court invalidate Chen's election victory and recount the votes. They also demanded the Central Election Commission put a temporary hold on Chen's election as Kaohsiung mayor, slated for Dec. 15.
Hung Chih-kun, director of Chen's election campaign office, urged Huang's camp to respect the investigation authorities and denied the charges of having staged the film.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNG-CHENG U. THESIS WINS PRIZE IN INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A thesis from National Chung-cheng University (NCCU) presented at the First International Workshop on Functional Materials (IWOFM) and the Third International Workshop on Nanophysics and Nanotechnology (IWONN) has won first prize in the poster section of the workshop, university officials said Thursday.

The thesis was submitted by a research team led by Hsu Chia- chen, a professor at NCCU's Department of Physics, and titled "Isotropic Photonic Band-gaps and Defect-free Localized Modes in the Air-rod Circular Photonic Crystals."

The IWOFM-IWONN is an annual conference organized by the Vietnamese Academy of Science and Technology. This year's event took place Dec. 3-5 in Hanoi and was attended by scientists from the United States, France, Germany, the European Union, Japan, Taiwan and Singapore.

The award-winning thesis is comprised of two parts -- theoretical analysis and experimental study, Hsu said, adding that in the theoretical part, they studies the structural specifications of air-rod circular photonic crystals, while in the experimental part, they applied the hypothesis to a real production process.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AGAINST RAISING CHINA INVESTMENT CEILING

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that people are "putting the cart before the horse" when they argue that the government should lift the 40-percent ceiling on Taiwan investment in China.

Instead, Chen said, they should look at the issue from the opposite perspective by pondering how to increase investment in Taiwan instead of China, and they should seek to overcome barriers to investment in Taiwan instead of "blindly" challenging the government's restrictions on investment in China.

Chen made the remarks during a meeting at the Presidential Office with a group of businessmen from home and overseas Chinese and Taiwanese communities who have performed exceptionally during business start-ups.

He said that benefiting from the recovery of the world economies, Taiwan's domestic economy has regained momentum, with growth of 5.02 percent posted in the third quarter and growth for the entire year expected to be between 4.3 percent and 4.6 percent, plus an unemployment rate that is likely to be controlled under 4 percent for this year.

He noted that Taiwan's Powerchip Semiconductor Corp. (PSC) and the Japanese Elpida Memory Inc. signed an MOU in Taipei Dec. 7 to establish a joint venture in central Taiwan for DRAM production. When the PSC-Elpida DRAM fabrication facilities -- to be located in the Central Taiwan Science Park -- begin commercial operations in four to five years -- the new joint venture will be the world's largest 12-inch chip wafer foundry, with a total planned capacity of 240,000 wafers per month.
The president said this joint venture also represents three major points.

First, he said, despite the efforts of Singapore and China to offer attractive packages for such a large-scale investment project, Elpida decided to choose Taiwan as the joint venture's location and to tie up with PSC, reflecting the importance that Elpida attaches to Taiwan's and PSC's competitiveness in terms of semiconductor manufacturing.

Second, these new DRAM fabrication facilities, carrying a pricetag of NT$450 billion (US$13.85 billion), represent the largest investment project in Taiwan since the government put forth a "mega investment, mega warmth" plan early this year, and also the largest single investment project in Taiwan's history, he said.

Third, he went on, in order to facilitate the joint venture, relevant government agencies have been striving in a short period of just nine months to complete all the paperwork required, including land requisition and environmental impact assessments, a record in this regard in the history of the development of Taiwan's science-based industrial parks.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ALIGNMENT WITH PFP STIRS DEBATE WITHIN KMT

TEXT.P: As the biggest party in the opposition "pan-blue alliance, " it is normal that Kuomintang (KMT) members differ on the issue of whether to form a formal alignment with the People First Party (PFP), KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday.
Ma made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after a meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee (CSC) the previous day failed to reach a consensus on the issue.

Pointing out that the issue must be eventually settled within the decision-making CSC, Ma said it is important that KMT members are able to freely air their viewpoints and that it is no surprise that party members hold different stances on the issue.

Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, a KMT heavyweight, contended that PFP Chairman James Soong should not retire from politics, despite his recent announcement to do so shortly after he conceded defeat in the Dec. 9 Taipei mayoral race.
Soong must stay on to help the PFP consolidate with the KMT, Wang said, adding that if he fails to do so, the PFP-KMT merger might get into trouble and further hobble Taiwan's political development.
Wang also denied rampant speculation that he will form a KMT ticket with Chairman Ma Ying-jeou to run in the 2008 presidential election.

But according to PFP officials, Soong remains firm on his decision to withdraw from the political scene and the only thing that concerns him now is the future of some PFP lawmakers. It is hard for Soong to "leave them like this, " the officials said, although they added that it is true that some PFP lawmakers might not be willing to join or return to the KMT.
Once the PFP and the KMT have wrapped up their negotiations on forming a new political alliance, Soong will really be free from his "moral duty" as head of the PFP by that time, they said.

While Soong has no preference for any specific model to conduct consolidation talks with the KMT, the KMT effectively holds the key on putting negotiation results into practice, the officials explained.

Despite the fact that Soong decided to retire from politics "out of respect for the public mandate, " he can still help bridge differences between PFP lawmakers and the KMT before he really bids farewell to the party, they said.
Soong garnered only a little over 50,000 votes in the recent Taipei mayoral race, ranking a distant third among the six candidates.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION TO LOOK INTO CHAO'S REINSTATEMENT APPEAL

TEXT.P: The Civil Service Protection and Training Commission (CSPTC) will look into an appeal filed by Chao Chien-ming, the indicted son-in-law of President Chen Shui-bian, for a re-examination of his request to return to his job as a doctor at the National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH).

Lee Chun-sheng, chief of the CSPTC Division of Protection, said the commission will take about three months to examine, screen and discuss Chao's re-examination appeal, which he filed last week after an earlier request to return to his job as an orthopedic surgeon at the NTUH was rejected by the medical center.
The screening period could be extended for two more months if necessary, in accordance with regulations, Lee said.
The NTUH voted down in mid-October Chao's request on the grounds he had "seriously violated medical ethics."

Chao was suspended when he was indicted on insider-trading charges in July, charges that are still being handled in court. On Oct. 9, he filed an application with the NTU Hospital requesting reinstatement.

The request was rejected after three polls were held by the hospital's Clinical Ethics Committee, Department of Orthopedic Surgery and finally by hospital management, all of which voted overwhelmingly against allowing Chao to return. The last vote was 57 versus one, with one abstention.

The hospital said participants in the three meetings "unanimously agreed" that Chao's behavior was in severe violation of medical ethics and damaging to the hospital's reputation, therefore rendering him "unfit to be an NTU Hospital doctor." Honesty and integrity are part of the hospital's core values, said a hospital spokesman.

Prosecutors have demanded an eight-year sentence for Chao. His father, Chao Yu-chu, also charged in the same Taiwan Development Corp. stock-trading scandal, deserves a 10-year jail term, according to the indictment.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTEST HELD AGAINST NCC CLAMPDOWN ON ILLEGAL RADIO STATIONS

TEXT.P: Hundreds of independence supporters staged a protest Thursday in front of the National Communications Commission (NCC) against its clampdown on unlicensed radio stations.

Protesters mobilized by various pro-independence groups, including the Taiwan Independence Party, argued that the NCC's ongoing campaign against pirate radio stations is part of a plot mounted by pro-China media organizations to seize all broadcasting resources.

The crowds charged the NCC's establishment as "unconstitutional" on the grounds that it should be an independent agency free from political interference. The NCC's current lineup was formed in proportion to the number of seats that each of the major political parties controls in the Legislative Yuan.

They also blasted the NCC's decision to refer a case regarding President Chen Shui-bian's televised remarks about vote-buying on the Dec. 9 polling day of the municipal elections in Taipei and Kaohsiung to the Central Election Commission, saying that doing so is in violation of the Constitution.

Because the NCC is an unconstitutional organization, it is not entitled to handle any dispute related to media, the protesters claimed. They also demanded that all NCC members step down to allow for the establishment of a fair environment for Taiwan's media.
Wang Hsing-nan and Yen Wen-chang, lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , were also present during the hour-long demonstration.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has accused Chen of making the televised comments in an attempt to influence the elections, in particular the mayoral election in Kaohsiung, which the DPP viewed as a critical battle to secure a chance of victory in the 2008 presidential election.

NCC Chairman Su Yeong-chin said earlier the same day at a legislative committee that his commission plans to eradicate some 50 unlicensed radio stations in the coming year. More than 100 such pirate stations have already been wiped out since early this year, he noted.

Unlicensed radio stations, more rampant in southern Taiwan, create many social problems, as most of them sell fake medicine or spread false information, especially in the runups to elections, Su claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Circumcision Halves H.I.V. Risk, U.S. Agency Finds
Circumcision appears to reduce a man's risk of contracting AIDS from heterosexual sex by half, United States government health officials said yesterday, and the directors of the two largest funds for fighting the disease said they would consider paying for circumcisions in high-risk countries.
Wall Street Journal:On Death Row, Fate of Mentally Ill Is Thorny Problem
Mr. Thompson is on death row at the Riverbend Maximum Security Institution, and like many prison inmates, he is mentally ill. Today, his case is at the center of a complex debate about the death penalty in the U.S. Recently, the Supreme Court ruled that mentally retarded defendants and juveniles cannot be sentenced to death. Mr. Thompson is asking the courts to decide whether mentally ill prisoners can be executed if rendered competent only by medication. His twice-delayed execution and similar cases are working through the judicial system; one will likely end up in front of the high court.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNICATION INDUSTRY OUTPUT TO EXCEED NT$700 BILLION: ITRI

TEXT.P: The output of Taiwan's communications industry is expected to surpass NT$706.5 billion this year, representing a 43 growth year-on-year, according to a forecast released Thursday by the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

The forecast was made at a two-day symposium that opened the previous day in Taipei on the review and outlook of Taiwan's electronics industry under the sponsorship of the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK) and the MOEA's Industrial Technology Information Service (ITIS).
The IEK-ITIS project predicted that this year's top five products will be mobile phones, GPS products, WLAN products, DSL CPE products and SOHO routers.

Chang Huai-chi, the project's research manager, said the development of cell phones is still the focus while forecasting that the total number of mobile phones to be manufactured in 2007 will reach 140 million.
Chang added that 3G cell phones will become focus products.
According to Chang, the next wave of the global communication industry will center on the integration of various functions.
For instance, cell phones can already be used as digital cameras and music players he said, adding that in the future, they can function as GPS navigators and TVs.
The number of 3G cell phone users in 2006 reached 390 million with an annual rise of 100 million subscribers, Chang said.
The number of 3G cell phone users next year is likely to be 520 million, accounting for 18 percent of all mobile phone subscribers, Chang predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COAST GUARD DISPERSES INTRUDING CHINESE FISHING BOATS

TEXT.P: Five Chinese fishing boats have been seized in the past few days while poaching elvers in waters surrounding the Taiwan-held outlying island of Kinmen, local coast guard authorities said Thursday.

The onset of winter brings the start of the elver season to Kinmen waters and Chinese fishing boats often intruded into Kinmen waters to poach, enraging the Kinmen fishermen and threatening navigation safety of ferry boats plying the direct "mini three links" route between Kinmen and Xiamen in China's coastal Fujian Province.

The Kinmen coast guard corps has joined forces with the Kinmen county government in mounting several rounds of a crackdown on Chinese poachers in recent days to protect the country's fishery resources and maintain coastal safety, coast guard officers said.

In addition to expelling Chinese fishing boats from Kinmen waters, coast guard patrol boats also seized five Chinese boats for serious legal infractions. Four Chinese fishermen from two of the ships may be indicted in accordance with the statute governing exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Kinmen officials said.
Meanwhile, nine Chinese fishermen aboard three fhsing boats from Fujian which were caught poaching in Kinmen waters earlier this week were repatriated earlier in the day.
Coast guard officials said they have traditionally stepped up maritime patrol and coastal investigations from Nov. 1 through the end of February to prevent elver poaching and maintain coastal safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS TO GIVE CHRISTMAS BLESSINGS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng will lead lawmakers across party lines at the legislature to give their Christmas blessings to Taiwan Friday.

This year marks the second time the event has been held and is expected to be a rare phenomenon -- a brief respite in the fighting between the ruling and opposition legislators, particularly after the fierce Dec. 9 Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral and council elections.

The activity was initiated by opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Joanna Lei and ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Wang Shih-hsun, among other Christian legislators. Christmas is not celebrated as a holiday in Taiwan.
Wang will dress up as an "archangel" when he presides over the activity, which will feature a number of choirs.
